Speaker: NA
Text: National Capital and External Territories

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Order! The following

Speaker: NA
Text: message from the Senate has been received:

Speaker: NA
Text: The Senate acquaints the House of Representa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tives that it concurs in the resolution transmitted

Speaker: NA
Text: the Senate by message no. 29 of the House of

Speaker: NA
Text: Represeritatives relating to the appointment of a

Speaker: NA
Text: Joint Standing Committee on the National Capital

Speaker: NA
Text: and External Territories, subject to the following

Speaker: NA
Text: modification:

Speaker: NA
Text: Paragraph (2), omit the paragraph, substitute the

Speaker: NA
Text: following paragraph:

Speaker: NA
Text: //(2) That the committee consist of 11 members:

Speaker: NA
Text: the Deputy Speaker and Chairman of Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittees, 2 members of the House of Repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sentatives to be nominated by the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment Whip or Whips, 2 members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives to be nominated

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Opposition Whip or Whips or by any

Speaker: NA
Text: independent Member, the Deputy President

Speaker: NA
Text: and Chairman of Committees, 2 Senators to

Speaker: NA
Text: be nominated by the Leader of the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in the Senate, 2 Senators to be nomi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nated by the Leader of the Opposition in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate and 1 Senator to be nominated by

Speaker: NA
Text: any minority groups or independent Sena-

Speaker: NA
Text: tors.//.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Senate requests the concurrence of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives in the Senate's modifica-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of the resolution transmitted to the Senate by

Speaker: NA
Text: the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: In relation to this matter, joint committees of

Speaker: NA
Text: this kind are not formed until both Houses

Speaker: NA
Text: have agreed to resolutions of appointment in

Speaker: NA
Text: identical terms. As the next scheduled item of

Speaker: NA
Text: business indicates, the resolution of appoint-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of this proposed committee has been

Speaker: NA
Text: modified by the Senate, and I understand that

Speaker: NA
Text: in considering this modification the House

Speaker: NA
Text: will be requested to make an alternative

Speaker: NA
Text: modification.

Speaker: NA
Text: The appointment of the committee is not

Speaker: NA
Text: yet resolved. Indeed, it is the very question of

Speaker: NA
Text: the composition of its membership which is

Speaker: NA
Text: the subject of negotiation between the Houses.

Speaker: NA
Text: I feel that no action should occur which could

Speaker: NA
Text: be taken to anticipate the final decision of

Speaker: NA
Text: either House in this matter. Therefore, it is

Speaker: NA
Text: not appropriate that I report to the House at

Speaker: NA
Text: this stage details of the messages concerning

Speaker: NA
Text: membership of that proposed committee.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, one of the messages also informed

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee the House of Senate appointments to the Joint

Speaker: NA
Text: Appointment

Speaker: NA
Text: Standing Committee on Electoral Matters and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Joint Standing Committee on Migration

Speaker: NA
Text: Regulations. Resolutions relating to these

Speaker: NA
Text: committees have been agreed to by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Houses in identical form and the details

Speaker: NA
Text: to relating to these committees will be incorpo-

Speaker: NA
Text: rated in the Votes and Proceedings.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ordered that the message be taken into

Speaker: NA
Text: consideration forthwith.

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Text: Swan-Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House) (10.08 a.m.)-I move: I

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) That the modification of the Senate be dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: agreed to and the following modification be made

Speaker: NA
Text: in place thereof:

Speaker: NA
Text: Paragraph (2), omit the paragraph, substitute the

Speaker: NA
Text: following paragraph:

Speaker: NA
Text: "(2) That the committee consist of 12 members:

Speaker: NA
Text: the Deputy Speaker and the Chairman of

Speaker: NA
Text: Committees, 3 Members of the House of

Speaker: NA
Text: Representatives to be nominated by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government Whip or Whips, 2 Members of

Speaker: NA
Text: the House of Representatives' to be nomi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nated by the Opposition Whip or Whips or

Speaker: NA
Text: by any independent Member, the Deputy

Speaker: NA
Text: President and Chairman of Committees, 2

Speaker: NA
Text: Senators to be nominated by the Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government in the Senate, 2 Senators to

Speaker: NA
Text: be nominated by the Leader of the Opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion in the Senate and 1 Senator to be

Speaker: NA
Text: nominated by any minority group or groups

Speaker: NA
Text: or independent Senator or independent

Speaker: NA
Text: Senators."; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) That a message be sent to the Senate request-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the reconsideration by the Senate of the

Speaker: NA
Text: resolution in respect of the modification

Speaker: NA
Text: by the House in place of the Senate modifica-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion.

Speaker: NA
Text: Basically what this does is increase the

Speaker: NA
Text: number of members from 11 to 12. The initial

Speaker: NA
Text: modification which occurred in the Senate

Speaker: NA
Text: was effectively to add an opposition senator.

Speaker: NA
Text: We were of a mind to accept that, and we did

Speaker: NA
Text: so in the Senate. However, an anticipated

Speaker: NA
Text: change was not assented to by the Senate:

Speaker: NA
Text: that there be an extra government member

Speaker: NA
Text: from the House. So there is a view on this

Speaker: NA
Text: side of the chamber that the basis on which

Speaker: NA
Text: those arrangements were entered into was not

Speaker: NA
Text: fully conformed with by the Senate. Hence

Speaker: NA
Text: the amendment that we put forward here.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is a general practice on joint committees

Speaker: NA
Text: that a relative balance is maintained that

Speaker: NA
Text: reflects the numbers in the House of Repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sentatives, in particular, in these arrange-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments. Therefore, I have moved to effectively

Speaker: NA
Text: add a government House of Representatives

Speaker: NA
Text: member to the committee. I have no particular

Speaker: NA
Text: reason to believe that if we were to pass this

Speaker: NA
Text: motion the Senate would reject it.

Speaker: Mr TIM FISCHER
Text: Farrer-Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: National Party of Australia) (10.09 a.m.)-Let

Speaker: NA
Text: me say that part of my role as shadow

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Trade impinges indirectly on part

Speaker: NA
Text: of the work of the Joint Standing Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: on the National Capital and External Territor-

Speaker: NA
Text: ies. Let me further say that following discus-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion with the Manager of Opposition Business

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Howard) the coalition accepts the general

Speaker: NA
Text: convention associated with committee number

Speaker: NA
Text: structure. I gather that the real reason this has

Speaker: NA
Text: all come about is that the Government did not

Speaker: NA
Text: realise that after 1 July the new Deputy

Speaker: NA
Text: President of the Senate and Chairman of

Speaker: NA
Text: Committees will be a member of the coali-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, and that is what has caused the altered

Speaker: NA
Text: circumstances.

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Text: Is that because we did better

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Senate election?

Speaker: Mr TIM FISCHER
Text: Let me trail that

Speaker: NA
Text: before the House for a brief moment. The

Speaker: NA
Text: coalition did very well in the Senate election.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor lost Senate positions. The National

Speaker: NA
Text: party did very well in HinkIer and Kennedy

Speaker: NA
Text: and, I might add, it is a great pleasure not to

Speaker: NA
Text: have the previous member for HinkIer sitting

Speaker: NA
Text: made in this House, for which the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for HinkIer ( Mr Neville), a member

Speaker: NA
Text: of the National Party, can take a lot of credit.

Speaker: NA
Text: But let me come back to the motion. I simply

Speaker: NA
Text: say to the House, and I also say this to the

Speaker: NA
Text: press gallery and to a lot of political pundits

Speaker: NA
Text: around here-

Speaker: NA
Text: Government members-There's no-one

Speaker: NA
Text: there.

Speaker: Mr TIM FISCHER
Text: AAP can always be

Speaker: NA
Text: relied on to be there and doing a good job-

Speaker: NA
Text: that it is about time that people around Can-

Speaker: NA
Text: berra and around this nation realised that it

Speaker: NA
Text: will be a different Senate from 1 July. After

Speaker: NA
Text: all, Senator Peter Walsh will have departed.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is about time people realised that it will be

Speaker: NA
Text: a whole new ball game, and that whilst the

Speaker: NA
Text: election took place on 13 March and changes

Speaker: NA
Text: took place immediately as from the next

Speaker: NA
Text: sitting of the lower house, the changes in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate-most members of the public do not

Speaker: NA
Text: realise this because they do not focus enough

Speaker: NA
Text: on the importance of the Senate-in fact will

Speaker: NA
Text: not take place until 1 July.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is at that time that the composition of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate will change, when we come back for

Speaker: NA
Text: the Budget session. A very interesting legisla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive circumstance will arise as legislation is

Speaker: NA
Text: dealt with in both Houses of Parliament. We

Speaker: NA
Text: recognise with joy the gains we have made in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Senate, and we will use those responsibly.

Speaker: NA
Text: Equally, we are responsible in our approach

Speaker: NA
Text: to this Parliament and will not oppose the

Speaker: NA
Text: motion before the chair.

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Text: Swan-Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Employment, Education and Training) (10.12

Speaker: NA
Text: a.m.)-in reply-While I am deeply grateful

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Opposition has chosen to preserve the

Speaker: NA
Text: normal practice in regard to this, and I do not

Speaker: NA
Text: in any way, shape or form detract from that

Speaker: NA
Text: gratitude, I think some history needs correc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. The fact of the matter is that we find

Speaker: NA
Text: ourselves-

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Text: That is passing strange

Speaker: NA
Text: coming from your side.

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Text: We are very good at

Speaker: NA
Text: history on our side of the House, as the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Bennelong has had

Speaker: NA
Text: occasion to acknowledge from time to time.

Speaker: NA
Text: He has said quite friendly and kindly things

Speaker: NA
Text: about the Australian Labor Party's devotion

Speaker: NA
Text: to a sense of history, and how he feels that

Speaker: NA
Text: that is needed in the Liberal Party as well. I

Speaker: NA
Text: think honourable members opposite should

Speaker: NA
Text: press Australia Post very hard for a fiftieth

Speaker: NA
Text: anniversary celebration stamp for the Liberal

Speaker: NA
Text: Party, and that they should get about doing

Speaker: NA
Text: that as soon as possible. But I digress.

Speaker: NA
Text: Basically, the problem alluded to was a

Speaker: NA
Text: suggestion that by virtue of a change of

Speaker: NA
Text: numbers in the Senate there will no longer be

Speaker: NA
Text: two government officers presiding. As I

Speaker: NA
Text: understand the arrangements which occurred

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Senate previously, the minority parties

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Senate-which still have the numbers

Speaker: NA
Text: in terms of cross-bench control, irrespective

Speaker: NA
Text: of the outcome of the last Senate election-

Speaker: NA
Text: previously decided that they did not like the

Speaker: NA
Text: Liberal Party nominee for Deputy President,

Speaker: NA
Text: Senator Noel Crichton-Browne. I understand

Speaker: NA
Text: that either the decision has been made not to

Speaker: NA
Text: put him forward again on this occasion or, if

Speaker: NA
Text: he is to be put forward again, it is now

Speaker: NA
Text: considered by the minority parties that he is

Speaker: NA
Text: potable and therefore they will be prepared to

Speaker: NA
Text: vote for him.

Speaker: NA
Text: Whatever the situation is in that regard,

Speaker: NA
Text: is a matter for those parties but the Opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion ought not kid itself that in some way or

Speaker: NA
Text: another it has obtained a Senate majority. It

Speaker: NA
Text: emphatically has not done that. It has agreed

Speaker: NA
Text: to put forward an acceptable candidate for one

Speaker: NA
Text: of those positions. Be that as it may, there

Speaker: NA
Text: still upon us a requirement to ensure that

Speaker: NA
Text: there is an appropriate balance of opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: and government members on this joint com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee, and I am glad that the Opposition, as

Speaker: NA
Text: I said at the outset, is standing by past prac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tice in this regard.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question resolved in the afftnnative.

Speaker: NA
Text: SOCIAL SECURITY AMENDMENT

Speaker: NA
Text: (LISTED SECURITIES) BILL 1993 [S]

Speaker: NA
Text: First Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill received from the Senate, and read a

Speaker: NA
Text: first time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Tim Fischer-On a point of order, Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker: the House is placed in a unique

Speaker: NA
Text: situation this morning on two counts. We are

Speaker: NA
Text: about to consider the Social Security Amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment (Listed Securities) Bill, on which you

Speaker: NA
Text: may be about to make a statement, Mr Speak-

Speaker: NA
Text: er. The honourable member for Berowra will

Speaker: NA
Text: it then lead for the coalition on the following

Speaker: NA
Text: separately listed Social Security Amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment Bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: The first of those three Bills is a private

Speaker: NA
Text: member's Bill which was introduced by the

Speaker: NA
Text: is honourable member for Berowra here and by

Speaker: NA
Text: his opposite number in the Senate, where it

Speaker: NA
Text: was carried. But subsequently, as I understand

Speaker: NA
Text: the position, the Senate inserted additional

Speaker: NA
Text: clauses in the second and third Bills to be

Speaker: NA
Text: dealt with here this morning. Certainly, the

Speaker: NA
Text: coalition supports absolutely the first Bill and

Speaker: NA
Text: its contents as they flow through to the other

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation, as will be detailed by the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Berowra.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Speaker, facing the House are two

Speaker: NA
Text: problems on which I seek your clarification.

Speaker: NA
Text: Firstly, how can we debate this Bill in the

Speaker: NA
Text: knowledge of how matters will be treated in

Speaker: NA
Text: the other two Bills? Secondly, and more

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly, what happens if you take a view

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Senate's amendments do not fall

Speaker: NA
Text: within the Standing Orders on the proceedings

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Parliament relating to the drafting of

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments, leave to introduce a Bill and

Speaker: NA
Text: like matters? Therefore, I simply seek your

Speaker: NA
Text: guidance and clarification for the House on

Speaker: NA
Text: this unique circumstance, whilst reiterating

Speaker: NA
Text: our very strong support for the contents of the

Speaker: NA
Text: listed securitieS Bill to end notional capital

Speaker: NA
Text: gains tax.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: In respect of the point of

Speaker: NA
Text: order raised by the Leader of the National

Speaker: NA
Text: Party of Australia, debate on the Bill which

Speaker: NA
Text: the Clerk has just read a first time is to be

Speaker: NA
Text: made an order of the day for the next sitting.

Speaker: NA
Text: A motion to that effect will be moved by the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Berowra. So the Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: will be considered at a time subsequent to the

Speaker: NA
Text: consideration of the·following two Bills. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the National Party is absolutely

Speaker: NA
Text: correct: I will make a statement in connection

Speaker: NA
Text: with the Social Security Amendment Bill, so

Speaker: NA
Text: further consideration of the matter can rest

Speaker: NA
Text: until after that time.

Speaker: Mr RUDDOCK
Text: Berowra) (10.17 a.m.)-I

Speaker: NA
Text: move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the second reading be made an order

Speaker: NA
Text: day for the next sitting.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to emphasise the importance of this

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation being debated at an early oppor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunity. I note that we have only one more

Speaker: NA
Text: sitting day. This motion is to the effect that

Speaker: NA
Text: the legislation be debated at the next sitting.

Speaker: NA
Text: I assume that arrangements can be made for

Speaker: NA
Text: it to be debated tomorrow.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a pressing matter. The Department

Speaker: NA
Text: of Social Security is gearing up to administer

Speaker: NA
Text: this new test, which commences in Septem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber. If we are to put an early end to that

Speaker: NA
Text: expensive process, it needs to be done at a

Speaker: NA
Text: time which enables the department to gear

Speaker: NA
Text: up-to gear down might be more appropri-

Speaker: NA
Text: ate-and to stop the process. Otherwise we

Speaker: NA
Text: are only putting the Australian taxpayers to a

Speaker: NA
Text: good deal of expense in computer equipment

Speaker: NA
Text: and subjecting pensioners to intrusive ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions about their securities.

Speaker: NA
Text: If we are to dela): the debate of this matter,

Speaker: NA
Text: the opportunity to put this matter right in a

Speaker: NA
Text: timely fashion is lost to us. As I have moved

Speaker: NA
Text: that the second reading be an order of the day

Speaker: NA
Text: for the next sitting, honourable members

Speaker: NA
Text: should clearly understand that the next sitting

Speaker: NA
Text: ought to be tomorrow and that tomorrow is a

Speaker: NA
Text: convenient opportunity to bring this legisla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion forward and to carry it through all stages

Speaker: NA
Text: to ensure that, well before September, this

Speaker: NA
Text: process that is now afoot is aborted.

Speaker: Mr SINCLAIR
Text: New England) (10.19

Speaker: NA
Text: a.m.)-I suggest to the House that on many

Speaker: NA
Text: occasions when we have legislation of a

Speaker: NA
Text: similar character we have cognate debates.

Speaker: NA
Text: While I understand the motion is that this

Speaker: NA
Text: matter be made an order of the day for the

Speaker: NA
Text: next sitting, in this instance there is a time

Speaker: NA
Text: constraint. The payments to which this legis-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation relates commence from September. The

Speaker: NA
Text: two Bills about to be put before the House are

Speaker: NA
Text: similar in context, if not in substance. I put to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Leader of the House ( Mr Beazley) that for

Speaker: NA
Text: all that the Government might have views on

Speaker: NA
Text: the matter, would it not be more convenient

Speaker: NA
Text: for the three matters to be dealt with by way

Speaker: NA
Text: of a cognate debate? Each of the issues would

Speaker: NA
Text: then be put separately to the Parliament, as is

Speaker: NA
Text: of the the normal practice of this place.

Speaker: NA
Text: That would mean that instead of taking up

Speaker: NA
Text: time tomorrow, or on some other occasion,

Speaker: NA
Text: we would be able to deal with these matters

Speaker: NA
Text: now. It would seem to be the most expedi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tious way for the convenience of the House,

Speaker: NA
Text: as well as for dealing with a matter that is of

Speaker: NA
Text: some significance, and of considerable con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cern to members on both sides of the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question resolved in the afftrmative.

Speaker: NA
Text: SOCIAL SECURITY AMENDMENT

Speaker: NA
Text: BILL 1993

Speaker: NA
Text: Consideration of Senate Message

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill returned from the Senate with an

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: I wish to advise the

Speaker: NA
Text: House that the Senate amendment to this Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: raises an issue to do with the interpretation of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Constitution. Paragraph 3 of section 53 of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Constitution provides that the Senate may

Speaker: NA
Text: not amend any proposed law so as to increase

Speaker: NA
Text: any proposed charge or burden on the people.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Senate amendment to this Bill would

Speaker: NA
Text: overturn changes already made in the princi-

Speaker: NA
Text: pal Act, and due to be effective from 20

Speaker: NA
Text: September. The substance of those changes is

Speaker: NA
Text: that, from 20 September, an increase in the

Speaker: NA
Text: value of shares or other listed securities held

Speaker: NA
Text: by a person will be included in the calculation

Speaker: NA
Text: of the person's income for the purposes of

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits.

Speaker: NA
Text: If the Senate amendment is agreed to, from

Speaker: NA
Text: 20 September a beneficiary would not have a

Speaker: NA
Text: change in the value of shares, et cetera,

Speaker: NA
Text: included in his or her income calculations.

Speaker: NA
Text: Looked at from the point of view of section

Speaker: NA
Text: 53, the matter is unclear. The burden on the

Speaker: NA
Text: people after 20 September would, in this

Speaker: NA
Text: aspect, be no greater than it would be before

Speaker: NA
Text: that date. After 20 September the impact is

Speaker: NA
Text: uncertain. Still, it is probable that some

Speaker: NA
Text: persons would become eligible for a benefit

Speaker: NA
Text: or for an increased benefit, but a person will

Speaker: NA
Text: not necessarily be better off being on a

Speaker: NA
Text: dividend basis, as at present, rather than on a

Speaker: NA
Text: share value basis. Further, notional losses that

Speaker: NA
Text: would otherwise be allowed will not be

Speaker: NA
Text: available if the amendment is made, thus

Speaker: NA
Text: affecting entitlements.

Speaker: NA
Text: Similar issues arise in respect of the Senate

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment to the Veterans' Affairs Legisla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion Amendment Bill. It is for this House to

Speaker: NA
Text: decide whether it wishes to take any action on

Speaker: NA
Text: these matters. In my view, it needs to be

Speaker: NA
Text: recognised that it is very difficult to be

Speaker: NA
Text: confident about the eventual financial impact

Speaker: NA
Text: of the proposals. It also has to be recognised

Speaker: NA
Text: that the burden on the people may, in this

Speaker: NA
Text: aspect, be no greater after 20 September than

Speaker: NA
Text: it will be before then. I present a copy of a

Speaker: NA
Text: short paper on this matter. It can be incorpo-

Speaker: NA
Text: rated in Hansard, if it suits the convenience

Speaker: NA
Text: of the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: The paper read as /ollows-

Speaker: NA
Text: SENATE AMENDMENT TO THE SOCIAL

Speaker: NA
Text: SECURITY AMENDMENT BILL 1993

Speaker: NA
Text: The Senate's amendment to the Social Security

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendment Bill 1993 raises the issue of the

Speaker: NA
Text: requirement of the third paragraph of s. 53 of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Constitution which provides that the Senate may

Speaker: NA
Text: not amend any proposed law so as to increase any

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed charge or burden on the people.

Speaker: NA
Text: By its inclusion of a new Part lA in the Social

Speaker: NA
Text: Security Amendment Bill 1993 the Senate has

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed a change in the provisions of the Principal

Speaker: NA
Text: Act in so far as the treatment of shares and other

Speaker: NA
Text: listed securities is concerned.

Speaker: NA
Text: The background is that by Social Security Legisla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion Amendment Act (No.3) 1992 the Parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: inserted changes in the Principal Act to come into

Speaker: NA
Text: effect from 20 September 1993. 1 The particular

Speaker: NA
Text: changes in question were to the effect that, from 20

Speaker: NA
Text: September, changes in the value of shares and other

Speaker: NA
Text: listed securities were to be treated in the same way

Speaker: NA
Text: as changes in the value of certain other types of

Speaker: NA
Text: investments. One of the effects would be that from

Speaker: NA
Text: that date an increase in the value of shares would

Speaker: NA
Text: need to be included in the calculation of a person's

Speaker: NA
Text: income and this will mean that in many cases a

Speaker: NA
Text: person's notional income will be increased, and so

Speaker: NA
Text: their entitlement to a benefit reduced (it also has to

Speaker: NA
Text: be recognised that the reverse could happen and a

Speaker: NA
Text: decline in the value of a person's shares could lead

Speaker: NA
Text: to a notional reduction in income and thus an

Speaker: NA
Text: entitlement to a greater benefit). The purpose of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate amendment is to ensure that the changes

Speaker: NA
Text: already made in the Principal Act and due to be

Speaker: NA
Text: effective from 20 September do not proceed.

Speaker: NA
Text: A private Senators' Bill introduced by Senator

Speaker: NA
Text: Patterson2 and subsequently passed by the Senate

Speaker: NA
Text: contained very similar provisions except that it had

Speaker: NA
Text: an additional provision to the effect that although

Speaker: NA
Text: the details of the law would be changed no benefits

Speaker: NA
Text: could be paid or payable until the Parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: passed a law to appropriate the necessary money.3

Speaker: NA
Text: This important qualification has not been included

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Senate amendment to the Social Security

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendment Bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: The issue for consideration is a difficult one

Speaker: NA
Text: because:

Speaker: NA
Text: the amendment does not deal immediately with

Speaker: NA
Text: or alter the particular proposals put before the

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament in the Social Security Amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill 1993, rather it changes, in the way de-

Speaker: NA
Text: scribed, provisions already inserted in the Princi-

Speaker: NA
Text: pal Act but provisions which have not yet come

Speaker: NA
Text: into effect;

Speaker: NA
Text: as is often the case in these matters it is impos-

Speaker: NA
Text: sible to be precise about the financial impact of

Speaker: NA
Text: the change (although it is noted that when the

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions which are now in prospect of being

Speaker: NA
Text: reversed were introduced it was estimated that

Speaker: NA
Text: significant savings would be made4 -but this has

Speaker: NA
Text: been a matter of dispute in so far as it has arisen

Speaker: NA
Text: in connection with the Social Security (Listed

Speaker: NA
Text: Securities) BillS;

Speaker: NA
Text: the change resulting from the Senate amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: could have an effect either way, depending on

Speaker: NA
Text: whether shares held by beneficiaries increase or

Speaker: NA
Text: decrease in value-ie. only some might receive

Speaker: NA
Text: an increased benefit;

Speaker: NA
Text: the effect in practice is that a particular benefi1993

Speaker: NA
Text: ciary in receipt of a pension before 20 September

Speaker: NA
Text: this year will, if the Senate amendment is agreed

Speaker: NA
Text: to, not have an increase in the value of shares

Speaker: NA
Text: included in income calculations after 20 Septem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber. On the other hand, if it were not for the

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment, such a person would have this fact

Speaker: NA
Text: taken into account from 20 September and in

Speaker: NA
Text: some cases a lower benefit would be payable. In

Speaker: NA
Text: other words the effect of the amendment will be

Speaker: NA
Text: that the "burden on the people" will be no

Speaker: NA
Text: greater than it would otherwise be in the period

Speaker: NA
Text: up to 20 September but it will probably be

Speaker: NA
Text: greater than it would otherwise have been in the

Speaker: NA
Text: period after 20 September.

Speaker: NA
Text: A similar amendment has been made by the Senate

Speaker: NA
Text: in respect of the Veteran's Affairs Legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendment Bill. The points made in relation to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Social Security Amendment Bill are also relevant

Speaker: NA
Text: in that case.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the paper prepared in this office and tabled on

Speaker: NA
Text: 9 November 1992, the view was expressed that in

Speaker: NA
Text: considering such matters (ie., whether any particu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lar proposal by the Senate should be made by way

Speaker: NA
Text: of an amendment or a request) the only satisfactory

Speaker: NA
Text: approach waS for each case to be looked at on its

Speaker: NA
Text: merits; the detail of a proposed amendment needed

Speaker: NA
Text: to be looked at in the context of the bill in question

Speaker: NA
Text: and with reference to any existing principal

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. It proposed that, rather than applying a strict

Speaker: NA
Text: test of logic, regard had to be had to the intended

Speaker: NA
Text: and expected practical outcome of the proposed

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments.

Speaker: NA
Text: In these particular cases, the outcome is by no

Speaker: NA
Text: means clear. It is certainly possible, and indeed

Speaker: NA
Text: probable, that, should the amendments be agreed to,

Speaker: NA
Text: because the effect of the 1992 amendments will be

Speaker: NA
Text: negated, the burden on the people will be greater

Speaker: NA
Text: than it would otherwise be in the period after 20

Speaker: NA
Text: September this year. As noted above however the

Speaker: NA
Text: burden will not be changed by these amendments

Speaker: NA
Text: from the burden applying before that date. In

Speaker: NA
Text: addition, the effect of the amendment:

Speaker: NA
Text: would be to continue the present regime under

Speaker: NA
Text: which dividends from shares are included in

Speaker: NA
Text: income calculations (the 1992 changes would

Speaker: NA
Text: have "income" calculated on the basis of changed

Speaker: NA
Text: values, regardless of dividends);

Speaker: NA
Text: could be to allow a fall in the value of a person's

Speaker: NA
Text: shares to be offset llgainst other investment

Speaker: NA
Text: income for the purposes of any entitlement.

Speaker: NA
Text: Whilst this is certainly a matter which should be

Speaker: NA
Text: drawn to the attention of Members, the issues are

Speaker: NA
Text: such that it is difficult to predict with any confi-

Speaker: NA
Text: dence what the impact will be in so far as the

Speaker: NA
Text: "burden on the people" is concerned.

Speaker: NA
Text: Clerk's Office House of Representatives 26 May

Speaker: NA
Text: NOTES

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. Act No. 230, 1992 (Division B), and see

Speaker: NA
Text: subsection 2(12).

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. Social Security (Listed Securities) Bill 1993.

Speaker: NA
Text: A bill in the same terms has been introduced

Speaker: NA
Text: in the House by Mr Ruddock.

Speaker: NA
Text: 3. Journals of the Senate, 12 May 1993, p.131.

Speaker: NA
Text: 4. The explanatory memorandum presented on

Speaker: NA
Text: the Social Security Legislation Amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill (No.3) put "estimated program savings" at

Speaker: NA
Text: 5. Senator Patterson has mentioned an estimate

Speaker: NA
Text: of $6Om but noted that a figure of $85m had

Speaker: NA
Text: been quoted-Senate Hansard, 6 May 1993, p.

Speaker: Mr SCIACCA
Text: Bowman-Parliamentary

Speaker: NA
Text: Secretary to the Minister for Social Securi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ty)- Mr Speaker, with your indulgence, may

Speaker: NA
Text: I make some remarks in respect of your

Speaker: NA
Text: statement. Thank you for letting the House

Speaker: NA
Text: know about this matter. The Government will

Speaker: NA
Text: shortly move that the amendment be con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sidered forthwith. As you have indicated, the

Speaker: NA
Text: matter is far from clear, but the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: will not object on the grounds that the amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: legisla- ment should have been made as a request.

Speaker: Mr RUDDOCK
Text: Berowra)-I note the

Speaker: NA
Text: words you have offered, Mr Speaker. I thank

Speaker: NA
Text: you for them, and for drawing this matter to

Speaker: NA
Text: our attention. I emphasise the correctness of

Speaker: NA
Text: your conclusion that it would be very difficult

Speaker: NA
Text: to be confident that this amendment would

Speaker: NA
Text: involve additional costs to the revenue. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: one of the major issues of contention between

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government and the Opposition, as to

Speaker: NA
Text: what the impact of this proposal might be.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government has, from time to time,

Speaker: NA
Text: offered some views as to estimated savings

Speaker: NA
Text: that might be made as a result of this· meas-

Speaker: NA
Text: ure. Therefore, I imagine it would argue that

Speaker: NA
Text: .there will be a cost to revenue if these propo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sals are to be reinstated.

Speaker: NA
Text: The shortcoming-which will be a major

Speaker: NA
Text: matter in the debate that follows-is the basis

Speaker: NA
Text: upon which the Government's calculations are

Speaker: NA
Text: made. It made assumptions that there will be

Speaker: NA
Text: absolutely no changes in the behaviour of

Speaker: NA
Text: people who presently own shares and their

Speaker: NA
Text: ability to assume that the savings that they

Speaker: NA
Text: estimate are likely. It is certainly beyond

Speaker: NA
Text: doubt that pensioners who are shareholders

Speaker: NA
Text: will change their behaviour as a result of any

Speaker: NA
Text: legislative changes left in place after this

Speaker: NA
Text: debate. The impact of those changes will

Speaker: NA
Text: mean that the estimated savings will not be

Speaker: NA
Text: present. Therefore, Mr Speaker, your com-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments and observations are quite correct, and

Speaker: NA
Text: I thank you for the support you have given

Speaker: NA
Text: me. It is very difficult to be confident that

Speaker: NA
Text: there are savings to the revenue involved in

Speaker: NA
Text: this measure.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ordered that the amendment be taken into

Speaker: NA
Text: consideration in Committee of the Whole

Speaker: NA
Text: House forthwith.

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate s amendment-

Speaker: NA
Text: After clause 3, page 2, insert the following Part:

Speaker: NA
Text: "PART lA-SHARES AND OTHER LISTED

Speaker: NA
Text: SECURITIES

Speaker: NA
Text: Index of definitions

Speaker: NA
Text: "3A. Section 3 of the Principal Act is amended

Speaker: NA
Text: by omitting the following entry from the Index:

Speaker: NA
Text: 'listed security 9(1)'.

Speaker: NA
Text: Investment product-definition

Speaker: NA
Text: "3D. Section 9 of the Principal Act is amended:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) by omitting the definition of 'investment

Speaker: NA
Text: product' in subsection (1) and substituting

Speaker: NA
Text: the following definition:

Speaker: NA
Text: "'investment product", in relation to a

Speaker: NA
Text: managed investment, means all the invest-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments that are:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) with the same body corporate or in the

Speaker: NA
Text: same trust fund; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) subject to substantially the same tenns

Speaker: NA
Text: and conditions as the managed

Speaker: NA
Text: ment;';

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) by omitting the definition of 'listed

Speaker: NA
Text: security' in subsection (1).

Speaker: NA
Text: Heading to Subdivision AA of Division 1 of Part

Speaker: NA
Text: "3C. The heading to Subdivision AA of Division

Speaker: NA
Text: 1 of Part 3.10 is amended by omitting 'and listed

Speaker: NA
Text: securities' .

Speaker: NA
Text: Structure of Division

Speaker: NA
Text: "3D. Section 1073 of the Principal Act is amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ed by omitting from the table 'STRUCTURE OF

Speaker: NA
Text: DIVISION' the following figures and words:

Speaker: NA
Text: '4. Shares and other listed securities 1084-

Speaker: NA
Text: Investments to which Subdivision applies

Speaker: NA
Text: "3E. Section 1074A of the Principal Act is

Speaker: NA
Text: amended by omitting subsection (2).".

Speaker: Mr SCIACCA
Text: Bowman-Parliamentary

Speaker: NA
Text: Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

Speaker: NA
Text: That the amendment be disagreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: The current legislation, which was passed in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1992, contains a definition of an investment

Speaker: NA
Text: product and provides for all investment

Speaker: NA
Text: products to have capital gain or loss and

Speaker: NA
Text: income distributions counted when working

Speaker: NA
Text: out a rate of return to be used for that invest-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment under the income test. A listed security

Speaker: NA
Text: is currently included within the definition of

Speaker: NA
Text: 'investment product', thus allowing capital

Speaker: NA
Text: gain or capital loss on a listed security to be

Speaker: NA
Text: counted under the income test. The Senate

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment will remove the word 'listed

Speaker: NA
Text: security' from the definition of an investment

Speaker: NA
Text: product. This will mean that a listed security

Speaker: NA
Text: can only be assessed for income test purposes

Speaker: NA
Text: under the general definition of 'income',

Speaker: NA
Text: which is not specific enough to allow inclu-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion of capital gain or capital loss.

Speaker: NA
Text: The subject of this amendment has been

Speaker: NA
Text: added on by the Opposition to an election

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill, where a number of measures are being

Speaker: NA
Text: taken by this Government to ensure that

Speaker: NA
Text: people such as self-funded retirees who are

Speaker: NA
Text: income poor and asset rich might be able to

Speaker: NA
Text: access some parts of social security. There are

Speaker: NA
Text: a number of other measures which are benefi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cial to our elderly and senior citizen popula-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion in this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: In 1992, the Opposition accepted these

Speaker: NA
Text: invest- measures, which were passed in December

Speaker: NA
Text: 1992-only some four months ago-yet, for

Speaker: NA
Text: some reason, straight after the election it put

Speaker: NA
Text: in an amendment which agrees with what the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Democrats have been saying, that

Speaker: NA
Text: shares should not be treated for the purposes

Speaker: NA
Text: of income in terms of the income test rules of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Department of Social Security.

Speaker: NA
Text: I find it very difficult to understand how the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition can possibly take this stance

Speaker: NA
Text: when, even over the last couple of days, it has

Speaker: NA
Text: been saying to the Government, 'You need to

Speaker: NA
Text: cut your spending'. The Opposition went to

Speaker: NA
Text: the election on Fightback. It talked about $1

Speaker: NA
Text: billion worth of cuts to the social security

Speaker: NA
Text: budget. Yet it is now saying that it will not

Speaker: NA
Text: let us bring in an Act-similar provisions are

Speaker: NA
Text: already in existence-which will allow us to

Speaker: NA
Text: treat invested shares in the same way as other

Speaker: NA
Text: managed investments have been treated since

Speaker: NA
Text: 1988. The Opposition will not allow us to

Speaker: NA
Text: have a situation where we have projected

Speaker: NA
Text: savings of approximately $80 million-$60

Speaker: NA
Text: million in the Department of Social Security

Speaker: NA
Text: budget and approximately $20 million in the

Speaker: NA
Text: veterans affairs budget.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Opposition cannot have it both ways.

Speaker: NA
Text: It cannot say on one hand that it was prepared

Speaker: NA
Text: to cut $1 billion off the social security budget

Speaker: NA
Text: and that it wants the Government to cut

Speaker: NA
Text: spending, and on the other hand not allow us

Speaker: NA
Text: to equitably target what we consider to be

Speaker: NA
Text: situations where some people who do not

Speaker: NA
Text: need to access the social security system are

Speaker: NA
Text: using shares as a means of circumventing the

Speaker: NA
Text: income test.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Opposition cannot have it both ways.

Speaker: NA
Text: It cannot whinge today when in December

Speaker: NA
Text: 1992 it passed the legislation in the Senate.

Speaker: NA
Text: Even Senator Patterson-who still has some-

Speaker: NA
Text: thing to do with social security in the Opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion-agreed with the relevant points of the

Speaker: NA
Text: argument for bringing in these measures.

Speaker: NA
Text: I look forward to hearing what the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Berowra ( Mr Ruddock) has

Speaker: NA
Text: to say with respect to the so-called exodus of

Speaker: NA
Text: people who are going to leave the share

Speaker: NA
Text: market and invest their moneys in such things

Speaker: NA
Text: as antiques, collectibles, real estate and

Speaker: NA
Text: antique clocks. We are simply bringing these

Speaker: NA
Text: share treatments into line with other managed

Speaker: NA
Text: investments. As a result of our treating man-

Speaker: NA
Text: aged investments in a certain way since 1988,

Speaker: NA
Text: the pensioner population has not stopped

Speaker: NA
Text: investing in such things as equity trusts,

Speaker: NA
Text: property trusts and other sorts of managed

Speaker: NA
Text: investments. In fact, quite the opposite has

Speaker: NA
Text: happened: there has been an increase in those

Speaker: NA
Text: sorts of investments.

Speaker: NA
Text: Today the honourable member for Berowra

Speaker: NA
Text: has already signalled that the Opposition does

Speaker: NA
Text: not believe that the projected savings will be

Speaker: NA
Text: achieved by these measures. The fact is that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition would not have a clue as to

Speaker: NA
Text: what savings will be achieved. The Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, however, is aware of the extent of the

Speaker: NA
Text: savings because we already have the informa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion on record. Whether the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Berowra knows it or not, people

Speaker: NA
Text: do give us details of their assets. We have

Speaker: NA
Text: been able to ascertain, as best we can, what

Speaker: NA
Text: we believe the savings will be. Since these

Speaker: NA
Text: measures were introduced there has already

Speaker: NA
Text: been an increase in the number of pensioners

Speaker: NA
Text: who will be affected, and that increase will

Speaker: NA
Text: probably bring in further savings.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Department of Social Security con-

Speaker: NA
Text: siders that the estimated savings are fairly

Speaker: NA
Text: robust. A lot of this information has already

Speaker: NA
Text: been supplied to the Opposition. Pensioners

Speaker: NA
Text: do not appear to be divesting themselves of

Speaker: NA
Text: shares, despite the widespread publicity this

Speaker: NA
Text: matter has received. A fear campaign has

Speaker: NA
Text: been generated by some financial planners,

Speaker: NA
Text: ably assisted by members of the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: who are obviously trying to score some cheap

Speaker: NA
Text: political points. They have lost the election,

Speaker: NA
Text: they are devoid of ideas and absolutely

Speaker: NA
Text: devoid of any policy, but they will come back

Speaker: NA
Text: and change their minds on something for

Speaker: NA
Text: which they have already voted. What is more,

Speaker: NA
Text: they will actually add it on as an amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: to a Bill that is going to be of benefit to our

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioner community.

Speaker: NA
Text: I find it ridiculous and unconscionable that

Speaker: NA
Text: those opposite will play politics with a situa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion where we need to ensure that we bring in

Speaker: NA
Text: some of these good measures-which they

Speaker: NA
Text: themselves supported-by a certain time.

Speaker: NA
Text: They will stop that. If anything, the opposite

Speaker: NA
Text: is occurring to what I am sure Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: members have been saying publicly and what

Speaker: NA
Text: they will say here today. Historically, when

Speaker: NA
Text: similar rules were introduced to managed

Speaker: NA
Text: investments pensioners contirtued to invest in

Speaker: NA
Text: that area. It is not in the interests of pension-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers to gift away their assets, to leave the stock

Speaker: NA
Text: market, or to run around and put those invest-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments where they will not be getting the same

Speaker: NA
Text: rate of return. They would be worse off if

Speaker: NA
Text: they did that. Regardless of what the Opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion thinks, pensioners are pretty smart.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have to try to target what moneys we

Speaker: NA
Text: have available to those who need it. We have

Speaker: NA
Text: to ensure that that scarce dollar is made

Speaker: NA
Text: available to those who need it. We cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: have a situation where we have some pension-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers advised-quite properly, I guess, under the

Speaker: NA
Text: existing rules-by financial planners that they

Speaker: NA
Text: can divest themselves of income, or circum-

Speaker: NA
Text: vent the social security and the DVA income

Speaker: NA
Text: test, by arranging to place their moneys in

Speaker: NA
Text: certain shares where they can get capital gain

Speaker: NA
Text: which is not counted for the purposes of

Speaker: NA
Text: social security.

Speaker: NA
Text: The fact is that the number of people who

Speaker: NA
Text: will be affected by this situation will be able

Speaker: NA
Text: to make investment decisions on the basis of

Speaker: NA
Text: the intrinsic value of the investment, not on

Speaker: NA
Text: the basis of whether, by investing in a certain

Speaker: NA
Text: investment product, they will be able to

Speaker: NA
Text: circumvent the income test of the Social

Speaker: NA
Text: Security Department or indeed be able to say,

Speaker: NA
Text: 'Well, we can access entitlement if we do it

Speaker: NA
Text: this way'. The social security system is there

Speaker: NA
Text: for those people who need it, not for those

Speaker: NA
Text: who can access their investment to be able to

Speaker: NA
Text: look after themselves first.

Speaker: NA
Text: It does not matter what the Opposition says.

Speaker: NA
Text: It knows that we cannot have it both ways.

Speaker: NA
Text: We cannot say, on the one hand, open it up

Speaker: NA
Text: to everybody, let every loophole still remain,

Speaker: NA
Text: and on the other hand say that we have got to

Speaker: NA
Text: cut social security expenditure. I know it is

Speaker: NA
Text: popular out there with the 107,000 pensioners

Speaker: NA
Text: who may well be affected. I know it is very

Speaker: NA
Text: popular for the honourable member for Be-

Speaker: NA
Text: rowra and all his henchmen, the people in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition who are running around scaring

Speaker: NA
Text: everybody, to say, 'You are going to be

Speaker: NA
Text: absolutely wiped out on this'. Of course it is

Speaker: NA
Text: politically popular. The Opposition has got no

Speaker: NA
Text: policies; it has got no ideas. It has got to do

Speaker: NA
Text: something. I guess that is what it has got to

Speaker: NA
Text: do.

Speaker: NA
Text: The fact is that at the end of the day the

Speaker: NA
Text: people who will be affected by these meas-

Speaker: NA
Text: ures will simply have to make investments. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is their personal choice as to whether they

Speaker: NA
Text: keep their money in shares. If they want to

Speaker: NA
Text: keep their money in shares, that is fine. They

Speaker: NA
Text: can go to their financial planner and, I would

Speaker: NA
Text: say that in many instances, they would get to

Speaker: NA
Text: keep their shares. The average portfolio of

Speaker: NA
Text: shares of pensioners, I understand, is not

Speaker: NA
Text: much more than $10,000. Yet there are

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioners with shareholdings of over

Speaker: NA
Text: $100,000 who are drawing the full pension.

Speaker: NA
Text: I know that we do have isolated circum-

Speaker: NA
Text: stances where some pensioners have large

Speaker: NA
Text: shareholdings but they have been able to

Speaker: NA
Text: structure their situation in such a way that

Speaker: NA
Text: they are able to circumvent the income test.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not think that the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Berowra can really sit there and look me

Speaker: NA
Text: straight in the eye and say that that is fair,

Speaker: NA
Text: because he knows that it is not fair. He knows

Speaker: NA
Text: that if the Opposition were in government the

Speaker: NA
Text: first thing it would do is to look at these

Speaker: NA
Text: loopholes which we have been doing now for

Speaker: NA
Text: some time. Already we are trying to target

Speaker: NA
Text: those scarce dollars as best we possibly can.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bottom line of this whole argument is

Speaker: NA
Text: that the social security system is there as a

Speaker: NA
Text: safety net; it is not there to be played politics

Speaker: NA
Text: with. The Opposition is saying to us that we

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot realise those savings that we want to

Speaker: NA
Text: arrange to save. As a result of those savings

Speaker: NA
Text: we have been able to do a lot of other things.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have been able to extend Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: fringe benefits and we are still arranging

Speaker: NA
Text: discussions with the States to see whether we

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot come to a deal with them to get them

Speaker: NA
Text: to extend their fringe benefits as well.

Speaker: NA
Text: I will conclude my remarks at the moment

Speaker: NA
Text: and see what our colleagues on the other side

Speaker: NA
Text: have got to say. I want to say that the Gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment definitely will not accept this amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. The Australian Democrats at least have

Speaker: NA
Text: been consistent on this-I have got to give

Speaker: NA
Text: them that-but the Opposition has changed its

Speaker: NA
Text: mind and I think one needs to wonder why.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is grasping for anything at the moment. It

Speaker: NA
Text: tells the Government to stop spending and

Speaker: NA
Text: then it says, 'But you cannot have all these

Speaker: NA
Text: savings because as far as we are concerned it

Speaker: NA
Text: is unfair'. We will wait and see what the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition has to say. The Government

Speaker: NA
Text: definitely does not accept the amendment.

Speaker: Mr RUDDOCK
Text: Berowra) (10.39 a.m.)-

Speaker: NA
Text: The Opposition of course presses this amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. I can assure the Parliamentary Secretary

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Minister for Social Security ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Sciacca) that in relation to this it does so

Speaker: NA
Text: good conscience. I do not know how the

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliamentary Secretary, given what he and

Speaker: NA
Text: his colleagues did with the most vulnerable

Speaker: NA
Text: people during this last election in terms of

Speaker: NA
Text: exciting their interest in a whole range of

Speaker: NA
Text: policies proposals-which the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: walked away from after the election-can

Speaker: NA
Text: come in here and accuse us of playing politics

Speaker: NA
Text: in relation to these matters.

Speaker: NA
Text: The grossest politics that have ever been

Speaker: NA
Text: played with the most vulnerable people in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia were those played by the Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Party when it promised, in good faith one

Speaker: NA
Text: thought, that it would remove all pensioners

Speaker: NA
Text: from the taxation system, but immediately

Speaker: NA
Text: walked away from that promise after the

Speaker: NA
Text: election; it promised pensioners a dental

Speaker: NA
Text: health system, which we now know it is

Speaker: NA
Text: walking away from as hard as it can go; it

Speaker: NA
Text: promised the charities that work amongst the

Speaker: NA
Text: most vulnerable people that, for every dollar

Speaker: NA
Text: they raised to look after the needy and the

Speaker: NA
Text: destitute in our community, it would subsidise

Speaker: NA
Text: them dollar for dollar. But what did the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government do after the election? It walked

Speaker: NA
Text: away from that promise as fast as it could and

Speaker: NA
Text: said, 'Oh, no. We don't have to give you as

Speaker: NA
Text: much if we only subsidise the expenditure

Speaker: NA
Text: that you actually make on the needy. Any

Speaker: NA
Text: money you raise for your running costs won't

Speaker: NA
Text: be covered'. Those opposite are the ones who

Speaker: NA
Text: are trying to suggest that in handling this

Speaker: NA
Text: matter in this way we are playing politics. I

Speaker: NA
Text: have never heard so much humbug in my life.

Speaker: NA
Text: .We are dealing here with a Bill with a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of proposals about which the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment is now saying, 'They were promises,

Speaker: NA
Text: and you, the Opposition, should feel honour

Speaker: NA
Text: bound to implement those promises that we

Speaker: NA
Text: made, when all the others are promises that

Speaker: NA
Text: we feel we can walk away from'. What

Speaker: NA
Text: humbug!

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me make it very clear to the Parliamen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tary Secretary, as the Speaker made clear in

Speaker: NA
Text: his own statement, that these particular provi-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions will not in any way produce savings for

Speaker: NA
Text: this Government. The Government will be as

Speaker: NA
Text: successful in recouping savings in this area as

Speaker: NA
Text: it was with its sales tax imposed on luxury

Speaker: NA
Text: motor vehicles. When the Government legis-

Speaker: NA
Text: in lated and introduced those provisions, it found

Speaker: NA
Text: that people changed their behaviour. It then

Speaker: NA
Text: had to walk away from those provisions and

Speaker: NA
Text: to repeal them. That is what is going to

Speaker: NA
Text: happen in this very area; the cost of imple-

Speaker: NA
Text: menting these proposals over three years is

Speaker: NA
Text: $3.5 million.

Speaker: NA
Text: Computer. people are gearing up special

Speaker: NA
Text: programs-and I think this probably under-

Speaker: NA
Text: states it-in order that they can trace people's

Speaker: NA
Text: shareholdings. On top of that, they are gear-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing up to analyse the yields on shares to be

Speaker: NA
Text: able to make certain assumptions about

Speaker: NA
Text: whether or not there have been capital in-

Speaker: NA
Text: creases in the value of the shares that are held

Speaker: NA
Text: by pensioners.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Parliamentary Secretary is saying that,

Speaker: NA
Text: in relation to these capital increases that occur

Speaker: NA
Text: in the value of shares, the impact of the

Speaker: NA
Text: proposals will be to reduce the income-that

Speaker: NA
Text: is, the pension-that is paid to pensioners

Speaker: NA
Text: who own shares. The pensioners will not have

Speaker: NA
Text: sold their shares, but the Government is

Speaker: NA
Text: deeming that the pensioners will have made

Speaker: NA
Text: a profit on the value of those shares, and it

Speaker: NA
Text: will reduce the pension as income. On the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's own estimates, it is taking

Speaker: NA
Text: 60,000 people-something of the order of 400

Speaker: NA
Text: people in each of our electorates-and reduc-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing their income by, on average, $1,000 a

Speaker: NA
Text: year. The Government is saying to those

Speaker: NA
Text: people, 'We know you are going to have a

Speaker: NA
Text: thousand dollars less. You are living on a

Speaker: NA
Text: very meagre income but you can sell your

Speaker: NA
Text: shares in order to survive. Shares are market-

Speaker: NA
Text: able. Sell your shares in order to survive. You

Speaker: NA
Text: can live off that capital increment in lieu of

Speaker: NA
Text: the reduced pension'.

Speaker: NA
Text: Yet in another breath the Government wants

Speaker: NA
Text: us to believe that we can do some calcula-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions-the Parliamentary Secretary has kindly

Speaker: NA
Text: given me these calculations-in which people

Speaker: NA
Text: can estimate program savings. The assumption

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government has made is· that with every

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioner who owns shares it can estimate

Speaker: NA
Text: capital gains and assume that there will

Speaker: NA
Text: always be capital gains in place. It does not

Speaker: NA
Text: ever look at the prospect, I suppose,

Speaker: NA
Text: will be a share collapse, as we saw in recent

Speaker: NA
Text: years, that nobody will change their behav-

Speaker: NA
Text: iour, or whether the impact of these proposals

Speaker: NA
Text: will yield those savings that it estimates are

Speaker: NA
Text: there to be made.

Speaker: NA
Text: Yet in the other breath the Parliamentary

Speaker: NA
Text: Secretary told us that people will sell their

Speaker: NA
Text: shares in order to supplement their income.

Speaker: NA
Text: He knows in his own mind that people will

Speaker: NA
Text: change their behaviour. In fact, he is telling

Speaker: NA
Text: us that, in order to survive, pensioners will

Speaker: NA
Text: sell their shares. He cannot make the assump-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions that he made in relation to the savings

Speaker: NA
Text: that will be made once they sell their shares.

Speaker: NA
Text: The whole point is that the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: made no assumptions about changes in behav-

Speaker: NA
Text: iour when it produced these estimated sav-

Speaker: NA
Text: ings. The Parliamentary Secretary finds some

Speaker: NA
Text: solace in the fact that because additional

Speaker: NA
Text: people have become eligible for pensions-in

Speaker: NA
Text: many cases they would be only part-pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions-there has been an increase in the

Speaker: NA
Text: number of people who own shares. From his

Speaker: NA
Text: brief, he told us that 60 per cent of those

Speaker: NA
Text: people were new pensioners-something of

Speaker: NA
Text: the order of 16,000 new pensioners who had

Speaker: NA
Text: shareholdings had come into the system-and

Speaker: NA
Text: a smaller figure, 40 per cent or about 10,000

Speaker: NA
Text: existing pensioners presumably, had acquired

Speaker: NA
Text: shares.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Parliamentary Secretary says that no-

Speaker: NA
Text: one is deterred from owning shares because

Speaker: NA
Text: of the proposal that the Government intro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duced last September. During the election

Speaker: NA
Text: campaign in March I did not hear a peep out

Speaker: NA
Text: of pensioners or other individuals because

Speaker: NA
Text: they were essentially unaware of these propo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sals. I can assure the Parliamentary Secretary

Speaker: NA
Text: that since the election there has been a good

Speaker: NA
Text: deal of publicity associated with these propo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sals. That is what is hurting the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: so much. That is why some government

Speaker: NA
Text: members are not in the chamber to take part

Speaker: NA
Text: in this debate. I will produce the letters that

Speaker: NA
Text: they are writing to their constituents in which

Speaker: NA
Text: they say, 'We will have another look at this'.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is what members on the other side are

Speaker: NA
Text: saying as they try to placate the concerned

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioners who are worried about the impact

Speaker: NA
Text: of this measure upon their very meagre

Speaker: NA
Text: that there survival income.

Speaker: NA
Text: The fact is that we support very strongly

Speaker: NA
Text: the amendment to the Bill. We believe the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government ought to accept it. We do not

Speaker: NA
Text: believe it will cost the Government in the

Speaker: NA
Text: long term anything at all to accede to this

Speaker: NA
Text: request.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to make it very clear that it is not

Speaker: NA
Text: our intent to deny the benefits that were

Speaker: NA
Text: provided for in the original Bill to people

Speaker: NA
Text: who receive newstart and the other benefi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciary arrangements in place for those who are

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployed; nor do we want to inhibit the

Speaker: NA
Text: assets changes that the Government promised

Speaker: NA
Text: during the election. Our view is that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government should implement its policy by

Speaker: NA
Text: supporting this Bill with our amendment. It

Speaker: NA
Text: can be done. The Government can support

Speaker: NA
Text: this Bill with our amendment, and its promis-

Speaker: NA
Text: es will be implemented. That is clear and

Speaker: NA
Text: unassailable. It is for· the Government to

Speaker: NA
Text: decide whether it sees its promises as promis-

Speaker: NA
Text: es worthy of implementation because it can

Speaker: NA
Text: pass the Bill as amended. If this Bill fails, the

Speaker: NA
Text: failure occurs because of the rigidity of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government in relation to this matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: We think our arguments are very persua-

Speaker: NA
Text: sive. We think the Government will see the

Speaker: NA
Text: error of its ways and our arguments will cause

Speaker: NA
Text: it to accept this amendment in the context of

Speaker: NA
Text: this debate. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr SCIACCA
Text: Bowman-Parliamentary

Speaker: NA
Text: Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

Speaker: NA
Text: (10.49 a.m.)-I want to make a few com-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments on what was said by the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Berowra ( Mr Ruddock). He ended

Speaker: NA
Text: up doing what he normally does: he got

Speaker: NA
Text: involved in theatrics, thumping the table and

Speaker: NA
Text: that sort of thing. He talked about the humbug

Speaker: NA
Text: of this Government in respect of broken

Speaker: NA
Text: promises. He knows full well that the reality

Speaker: NA
Text: is that the so-called broken promises are not

Speaker: NA
Text: broken promises at all. The only matter in

Speaker: NA
Text: respect of which there has been any change

Speaker: NA
Text: is the matter of the treatment of taxation. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has decided to have some further

Speaker: NA
Text: discussions to see whether we can use the

Speaker: NA
Text: money better.

Speaker: NA
Text: In terms of the dental health scheme and

Speaker: NA
Text: other promises that we have made, the cash-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing out of the home child-care allowance and

Speaker: NA
Text: that sort of thing, we have not broken promis-

Speaker: NA
Text: es at all. In some cases, for good reasons, we

Speaker: NA
Text: have had to postpone implementation of those

Speaker: NA
Text: promises, but we have not got rid of them at

Speaker: NA
Text: all. .

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable member for Berowra says

Speaker: NA
Text: that these savings will not be obtained. The

Speaker: NA
Text: fact is that in the past the Department of

Speaker: NA
Text: Social Security has been able to make certain

Speaker: NA
Text: assumptions, because the department does

Speaker: NA
Text: have a lot of information on record in terms

Speaker: NA
Text: of pensioner assets and income. In most cases

Speaker: NA
Text: those assumptions have been fairly well

Speaker: NA
Text: correct. We brought in similar treatment of

Speaker: NA
Text: managed investments in 1988. We made

Speaker: NA
Text: certain assumptions and those assumptions, as

Speaker: NA
Text: I understand it, were basically correct. There

Speaker: NA
Text: is absolutely no reason to suggest that the

Speaker: NA
Text: assumptions in this case will not be correct.

Speaker: NA
Text: In accordance with the figures and calcula-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions that have been given to the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member and to the Opposition we .have

Speaker: NA
Text: estimated that in the Department of Social

Speaker: NA
Text: Security alone there will be savings to the

Speaker: NA
Text: tune of $57.47 million. If anything, it is the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's contention that people have not

Speaker: NA
Text: been frightened, because they have continued

Speaker: NA
Text: to invest in shares, although the Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: intention was announced in the Budget last

Speaker: NA
Text: year and they have had plenty of time to look

Speaker: NA
Text: at the matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: Certainly financial planners have had plenty

Speaker: NA
Text: of time to look at it. They are the ones who

Speaker: NA
Text: have been criticising it because they see that

Speaker: NA
Text: some avenues of their business will be affect-

Speaker: NA
Text: ed. They will have to look for other loop-

Speaker: NA
Text: holes. A lot of people have looked at this and

Speaker: NA
Text: decided that it is not as bad as the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: makes out. We have made assumptions about

Speaker: NA
Text: the investment behaviour of certain people-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Ruddock-Have you? Where is it?

Speaker: Mr SCIACCA
Text: We have made certain

Speaker: NA
Text: assumptions on the basis of what people did

Speaker: NA
Text: when we brought in changes to the treatment

Speaker: NA
Text: of other managed investments in 1988. People

Speaker: NA
Text: did not completely leave managed invest-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments. In fact, they looked at the intrinsic

Speaker: NA
Text: value of that investment and realised that,

Speaker: NA
Text: although in some way it would affect their

Speaker: NA
Text: pension entitlement, at the end of the day they

Speaker: NA
Text: would be better off. Contrary to what the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Berowra says, the fact

Speaker: NA
Text: is that, if people sell their shares and if their

Speaker: NA
Text: investment behaviour is changed, they arrange

Speaker: NA
Text: to make other investments which will give

Speaker: NA
Text: them an income that will make their lives

Speaker: NA
Text: better. At the end of the day shares are

Speaker: NA
Text: different to property investments and all that

Speaker: NA
Text: sort of thing.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Opposition' makes all these sorts of

Speaker: NA
Text: assumptions. It talks about our making as-

Speaker: NA
Text: sumptions. We have made assumptions on the

Speaker: NA
Text: figures, on the basis of what is on the record,

Speaker: NA
Text: what has happened in the past with other

Speaker: NA
Text: types of managed investments. According to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition, those assumptions are incor-

Speaker: NA
Text: rect. Its assumptions as to what might happen,

Speaker: NA
Text: as to what might be the case, are plucked out

Speaker: NA
Text: of the air. At best they are very, very hypo-

Speaker: NA
Text: thetical. Our assumptions are based on avail-

Speaker: NA
Text: able, detailed information. We reject the

Speaker: NA
Text: argUments put forward by the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Berowra. There is absolutely no

Speaker: NA
Text: way the Opposition can make the assumptions

Speaker: NA
Text: it is making. We consider that this measure

Speaker: NA
Text: has to be introduced if we are to properly

Speaker: NA
Text: target the welfare dollar.

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Text: O'Cornior) (10.54 a.m.)-I

Speaker: NA
Text: love to hear the Parliamentary Secretary to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Social Security ( Mr Sciacca) talk

Speaker: NA
Text: about assumptions. There have been some

Speaker: NA
Text: wonderful assumptions made. The honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Berowra ( Mr Ruddock) drew our

Speaker: NA
Text: attention to the assumptions as to how much

Speaker: NA
Text: revenue would be achieved by increasing the

Speaker: NA
Text: sales tax on luxury cars. In fact, the figure

Speaker: NA
Text: was negative. That assumption was no doubt

Speaker: NA
Text: based on exactly the same sort of information

Speaker: NA
Text: to which the Parliamentary Secretary refers.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those assumptions, of course, are like the

Speaker: NA
Text: assumptions the Government made that it had

Speaker: NA
Text: the right sort of contract for pay TV; now that

Speaker: NA
Text: assumption is seen to be wrong.

Speaker: NA
Text: Then there was the assumption that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government had the right to collect tariff on

Speaker: NA
Text: fully built-up motor cars. It assumed it had

Speaker: NA
Text: written that into the legislation. It now discov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers that it has not and it has a little problem,

Speaker: NA
Text: I am told, worth about $1.5 billion. That

Speaker: NA
Text: makes the figures mentioned in this debate

Speaker: NA
Text: pale into insignificance.

Speaker: NA
Text: In recent times the Minister for Employ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, Education and Training ( Mr Beazley)

Speaker: NA
Text: made an assumption that his department knew

Speaker: NA
Text: how to send money down to the universities.

Speaker: NA
Text: He said that there had been a little technical

Speaker: NA
Text: fault and that $900 million had been sent

Speaker: NA
Text: illegally. The assumptions made by this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government are becoming very worrying

Speaker: NA
Text: because they have an administrative vacuum.

Speaker: NA
Text: We know all about the Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: ability to talk; we would like to know when

Speaker: NA
Text: it is going to start running the country. That

Speaker: NA
Text: is the first thing. The Parliamentary Secretary

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Minister for Social Security talks about

Speaker: NA
Text: assumptions but, if he has received the best

Speaker: NA
Text: advice, I hope it has done him more good

Speaker: NA
Text: than it has done the Minister for Transport

Speaker: NA
Text: and Communications (Senator Collins).

Speaker: NA
Text: The simple facts are that we are talking

Speaker: NA
Text: about a change which will stop a travesty of

Speaker: NA
Text: justice. The Parliamentary Secretary said

Speaker: NA
Text: something about fairness. I thought that was

Speaker: NA
Text: the principle that applied to all the decisions

Speaker: NA
Text: we made here, and this is not fair. It is not

Speaker: NA
Text: fair because it sets out to tax-I underline the

Speaker: NA
Text: word 'tax'-unrealised gains. That, to me, is

Speaker: NA
Text: a wealth tax. If it has feathers, swims like a

Speaker: NA
Text: duck and walks like a duck, it is a duck. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Government is introducing the first wealth tax

Speaker: NA
Text: ever to be implemented in Australia because

Speaker: NA
Text: it is taxing people on something they have not

Speaker: NA
Text: got.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Sciacca-It doesn't affect their entitle-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments to social security.

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Text: So there is a difference.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government says to a person, 'Last week

Speaker: NA
Text: you earned or were paid $100 by government.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have now made a decision that because

Speaker: NA
Text: the value of some BHP shares you hold'-

Speaker: NA
Text: which he probably paid more for than they

Speaker: NA
Text: are presently valued at-'has increased, we

Speaker: NA
Text: are going to reduce that $100 to $80'. As I

Speaker: NA
Text: said, if it walks like a duck and quacks like

Speaker: NA
Text: a duck, it is a duck.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government is applying a tax to those

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioners by reducing a government entitle-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. The Government makes some reference

Speaker: NA
Text: to the fact that these people are avoiding

Speaker: NA
Text: some sort of capital gain. Of course they are

Speaker: NA
Text: not avoiding it. Clearly the department can

Speaker: NA
Text: add that value to their asset value and, as

Speaker: NA
Text: such, under the assets test the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: can adjust entitlements, but it wants both. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Government wants to be able to adjust their

Speaker: NA
Text: entitlement under the assets test and get them

Speaker: NA
Text: a bit more regularly.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government is attacking a specific

Speaker: NA
Text: group of people-those who have chosen to

Speaker: NA
Text: structure their retirement income on the basis

Speaker: NA
Text: of a shareholding. I remind government

Speaker: NA
Text: members that many of these people bought in

Speaker: NA
Text: at a higher price than currently exists, but the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government is using that low base for the

Speaker: NA
Text: purpose of assessing any increase in the value

Speaker: NA
Text: of these assets. The Government is telling

Speaker: NA
Text: these people to sell off their income base little

Speaker: NA
Text: by little until they approach starvation. That

Speaker: NA
Text: is silly. The honourable member for Berowra

Speaker: NA
Text: is quite right: as they sell off this asset to

Speaker: NA
Text: compensate for the reduction in their income,

Speaker: NA
Text: the point will eventually. be reached where

Speaker: NA
Text: these people are lOOper cent on the pension.

Speaker: NA
Text: Compulsory superannuation has been

Speaker: NA
Text: introduced by the Labor Government, at quite

Speaker: NA
Text: a cost to the productive sector, on the grorinds

Speaker: NA
Text: that it wants to increase Australia's savings.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government is directing that money to

Speaker: NA
Text: superannuation companies. Why? Because

Speaker: NA
Text: these companies will invest in shares. At the

Speaker: NA
Text: very same time the Government is telling

Speaker: NA
Text: people in another segment of the community

Speaker: NA
Text: that they had better get out of shares.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable member for Berowra is

Speaker: NA
Text: quite right. It is all right for the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: to say that it announced this in the Budget. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is unfortunate that every pensioner in Austral-

Speaker: NA
Text: ia does not read the Budget; in fact, many do

Speaker: NA
Text: not even read newspapers. They will first

Speaker: NA
Text: discover this when they are hit between the

Speaker: NA
Text: eyes with a letter from the social security

Speaker: NA
Text: department saying, 'Because your share-

Speaker: NA
Text: holding has increas.ed in value according to

Speaker: NA
Text: our calculations and assumptions, your pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion entitlement is decreased by X dollars per

Speaker: NA
Text: fortnight'. That is when they will learn about

Speaker: NA
Text: it and they will find it very difficult to do

Speaker: NA
Text: something about it.

Speaker: NA
Text: If I can come back to the Parliamentary

Speaker: NA
Text: Secretary's assumptions for a minute: he

Speaker: NA
Text: made quite a bit about managed investment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me tell him a bit about some of those

Speaker: NA
Text: managed investments. Firstly, as the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Berowra points out, they are

Speaker: NA
Text: often contracted arrangements; and, secondly,

Speaker: NA
Text: because of the disaster of the recession we

Speaker: NA
Text: had to have, many people find they cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: escape them. Some are unsaleable and others,

Speaker: NA
Text: of course, have values at which people cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: afford to part with them. I do not think nearly

Speaker: NA
Text: as many of them-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Cleeland interjecting-

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Text: We are not discussing

Speaker: NA
Text: managed investments today. That has already

Speaker: NA
Text: been dealt with. We are discussing the cir-

Speaker: NA
Text: cumstances of people holding shares. I think

Speaker: NA
Text: the only certainty in all of this is that

Speaker: NA
Text: will vacate that area of investment. If they

Speaker: NA
Text: do it in a hurry, there will be an effect on

Speaker: NA
Text: share markets of Australia; and that, of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, is not interesting.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Sciacca-Wrong.

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Text: The Parliamentary Secre-

Speaker: NA
Text: tary says, 'Wrong'. As I said, he comes from

Speaker: NA
Text: a background of about five mess-ups. He

Speaker: NA
Text: comes from the background of the pay TV

Speaker: NA
Text: fiasco. Why should we trust his judgment on

Speaker: NA
Text: anything? I am telling the Parliamentary

Speaker: NA
Text: Secretary that, once people get the message

Speaker: NA
Text: that they are to be taxed on their unrealised

Speaker: NA
Text: gains, they will immediately find

Speaker: NA
Text: ments where that does not apply. That will

Speaker: NA
Text: remove a substantial level of investment for

Speaker: NA
Text: the share market, which I thought the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment wanted to encourage.

Speaker: NA
Text: These sorts of situations have to be con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sidered. First, is it true that it will generate

Speaker: NA
Text: the level of revenue for the Government? Our

Speaker: NA
Text: belief is that it will not. Of course, we can

Speaker: NA
