Text: produce precedents where these sorts of

Speaker: NA
Text: decisions have been taken in the past. People

Speaker: NA
Text: have a choice.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Sciacca-In social security?

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Text: It does not matter whether

Speaker: NA
Text: it is in social security or somewhere else. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is a case of people making a decision. Years

Speaker: NA
Text: ago when our Government increased the tax

Speaker: NA
Text: on alcohol and put a figure in the Budget we

Speaker: NA
Text: got a terrible shock. People jacked up and for

Speaker: NA
Text: a period of time the reve-ue of that increased

Speaker: NA
Text: percentage was actually less. People do make

Speaker: NA
Text: these sorts of decisions.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Gibson-It did recover.

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Text: Oh, the honourable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Moreton reckons it will recover over

Speaker: NA
Text: the next 20 years. It might. We are talking

Speaker: NA
Text: about an area where there is no obligation.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Parliamentary Secretary was at pains to

Speaker: NA
Text: tell us that they can sell out. The simple fact

Speaker: NA
Text: is they will, at which time the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: will not have the necessary revenue.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the meantime, we are generating substan-

Speaker: NA
Text: tial hardship for people, particularly those

Speaker: NA
Text: who made their share investments in more

Speaker: NA
Text: prosperous times, before the recession we had

Speaker: NA
Text: people to have, and who are sticking with those

Speaker: NA
Text: all shares, as many have stuck with their man-

Speaker: NA
Text: the aged investments, hoping to simply recover

Speaker: NA
Text: their original investment. The Government is

Speaker: NA
Text: saying, 'If you want to be in that position and

Speaker: NA
Text: your shares have to increase possibly 100 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent in value before you recover your original

Speaker: NA
Text: investment, we will tax you through reduced

Speaker: NA
Text: pensions for every cent of gain'. That is what

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government is on about. I think it is

Speaker: NA
Text: outrageous. I think at the very least it should

Speaker: NA
Text: have taken the position of valuing those

Speaker: NA
Text: shares at what they cost, not what they are

Speaker: NA
Text: presently worth. But even then I would

Speaker: NA
Text: perceive it as introducing the thin end of the

Speaker: NA
Text: other invest- wedge for a wealth tax.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government had the academics out on

Speaker: NA
Text: the hustings for a little while, using a

Speaker: NA
Text: Hawkeism, saying that it was an obscenity

Speaker: NA
Text: that we did not have death duties and wealth

Speaker: NA
Text: taxes. I bet the Parliamentary Secretary will

Speaker: NA
Text: not deny to this Parliament that there has

Speaker: NA
Text: been a little bit of backchat in the corridors

Speaker: NA
Text: relating to that as a prospective means of

Speaker: NA
Text: increasing its revenue. But the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: has done it already through this measure, and

Speaker: NA
Text: there is every reason why the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: should oppose it on those grounds.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government is attacking investment in

Speaker: NA
Text: shares. The Government is being specific

Speaker: NA
Text: about it and is reducing it. We read about the

Speaker: NA
Text: mums and dads trying to get into the

Speaker: NA
Text: Woolworths float at this time. We should be

Speaker: NA
Text: encouraging the community in that regard.

Speaker: NA
Text: (llme expired)

Speaker: Mr CLEELAND
Text: MCEwen) (11.04 a.m.)-

Speaker: NA
Text: I listened with interest to the discussion of

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for O'Connor ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Tuckey) about ducks. He said that if it flies

Speaker: NA
Text: like a duck, if it quacks like a duck, if it has

Speaker: NA
Text: feathers like a duck, it is a duck. That might

Speaker: NA
Text: make the honourable member in fact a goose,

Speaker: NA
Text: because the main duck flies like a duck,

Speaker: NA
Text: quacks like a duck and has feathers like a

Speaker: NA
Text: duck, but it is a goose. I think the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: gentleman is rather confused not just about

Speaker: NA
Text: ducks but about geese. If this is the quality of

Speaker: NA
Text: debate we get in this place from the Opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, it is a great worry.

Speaker: NA
Text: These are the fiscal dragons of Australia;

Speaker: NA
Text: these are the people who, only a short time

Speaker: NA
Text: ago, were going to cut $10 billion from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth's expenditure base. They

Speaker: NA
Text: were out there saying to the Australian peo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple, 'Don't run away from it now-$10

Speaker: NA
Text: billion'. Those opposite said, 'We can do it.

Speaker: NA
Text: We can do this and deliver to you because we

Speaker: NA
Text: have $10 billion worth of tax cuts'. These

Speaker: NA
Text: were the big conservative promises by the

Speaker: NA
Text: fiscal dragons who were going to make this

Speaker: NA
Text: magnificent cut to Commonwealth expendi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture. Those opposite were going to cut $1

Speaker: NA
Text: billion from the social security base-

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Text: What about the pensioners?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Ruddock-Tell us what you are going

Speaker: NA
Text: to tax the pensioners of MCEwen.

Speaker: The DEPUTY CHAIRMAN
Text: Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Hollis)-Order! The honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Berowra knows that he should not interject,

Speaker: NA
Text: and so does the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: O'Connor.

Speaker: Mr CLEELAND
Text: It is all cant and hypoc-

Speaker: NA
Text: risy so it does not matter that much in terms

Speaker: NA
Text: of this debate. Those opposite come here

Speaker: NA
Text: without clean hands; they come to this debate

Speaker: NA
Text: with very dirty hands indeed. The Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: was going to cut $1 billion from the social

Speaker: NA
Text: seturity budget. But did it tell the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: people, or indeed has it told this House,

Speaker: NA
Text: where the $1 billion cut would have come

Speaker: NA
Text: from? If we start at page 1 of Fightback and

Speaker: NA
Text: go right through to the end, nowhere will we

Speaker: NA
Text: find any statement about $1 billion worth of

Speaker: NA
Text: savings from social security. There is no

Speaker: NA
Text: detailed explanation-none whatsoever. So

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition ran to the election promising

Speaker: NA
Text: a $10 billion tax cut and a $1 billion cut to

Speaker: NA
Text: the social security. These are the big fiscal dra-

Speaker: NA
Text: gons.

Speaker: NA
Text: In this House today we are debating a very

Speaker: NA
Text: rational approach to reducing the demand on

Speaker: NA
Text: the public purse in social security, but those

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite oppose it. It is typical of honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: members opposite-typical of their hypocrisy,

Speaker: NA
Text: typical of their cant and typical of the fact

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Australian people cannot trust any-

Speaker: NA
Text: thing those opposite say or do. The Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: people understand that.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are talking about a form of investment

Speaker: NA
Text: which is no different in terms of capital

Speaker: NA
Text: growth to a managed investment as defined in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Act. For example, pensioners can invest

Speaker: NA
Text: in what is defined in the Act as a managed

Speaker: NA
Text: investment where the capital growth is

Speaker: NA
Text: brought into account for income as termed

Speaker: NA
Text: under the Act. Equity trusts come within the

Speaker: NA
Text: managed investment phraseology and termi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nology of the Act. I have not heard anyone on

Speaker: NA
Text: the other side of the House say that it is

Speaker: NA
Text: wrong to do that.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable gentleman from Berowra

Speaker: NA
Text: has not said that it is wrong to bring managed

Speaker: NA
Text: investment capital growth into income defini-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional terms for the purposes of assessing the

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit to be paid under the Act. So there is

Speaker: NA
Text: no difference. Very simply, we are talking

Speaker: NA
Text: about the fact that shares are a security which

Speaker: NA
Text: is transferable at will. Many people use shares

Speaker: NA
Text: as a means of making income by buying and

Speaker: NA
Text: selling. It is very simple. Those opposite

Speaker: NA
Text: know that and we know that, and I take it that

Speaker: NA
Text: those opposite do not disagree that people do

Speaker: NA
Text: that in the share market. People go into the

Speaker: NA
Text: market, buy low, sell high and make a profit.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Ruddock-If the pensioner did it, the

Speaker: NA
Text: income test would apply.

Speaker: Mr CLEELAND
Text: They declare that for

Speaker: NA
Text: income tax purposes. That is what people use

Speaker: NA
Text: the market for. Some people invest on the

Speaker: NA
Text: market to gain a dividend growth-an income

Speaker: NA
Text: growth-or they invest in a different quality

Speaker: NA
Text: of share and gain income. Of course, the

Speaker: NA
Text: dividends from shares are already brought to

Speaker: NA
Text: account as income through the income test

Speaker: NA
Text: under the Act. So the Opposition is saying it

Speaker: NA
Text: is okay to bring in dividend accounts, but

Speaker: NA
Text: when people are using the share market to

Speaker: NA
Text: buy and sell, using the capital growth to form

Speaker: NA
Text: income, that is somehow different-there

Speaker: NA
Text: a different quality to that kind of investment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Truss-Wrong.

Speaker: Mr CLEELAND
Text: Honourable members billion

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite are great, are they not? They are

Speaker: NA
Text: saying that somehow that is different, but

Speaker: NA
Text: have listened to the speakers from the other

Speaker: NA
Text: side and they have not quantified or 'qualified

Speaker: NA
Text: why it is different. For example, the honourWe

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Berowra said earlier that

Speaker: NA
Text: proposal will not produce any savings. I think

Speaker: NA
Text: he spoke for about 20 minutes, but the whole

Speaker: NA
Text: theme of his speech was that this will not

Speaker: NA
Text: produce any savings. He did not quantify

Speaker: NA
Text: what he m-t by that; nor did he produce

Speaker: NA
Text: one iota of evidence to this House to indicate

Speaker: NA
Text: that the figures produced by the department

Speaker: NA
Text: are wrong. He simply got up in the House

Speaker: NA
Text: and said that it will not produce any savings,

Speaker: NA
Text: and he then spent 20 minutes not defining

Speaker: NA
Text: what he meant by 'savings'.

Speaker: NA
Text: A lot of other speakers, in the usual

Speaker: NA
Text: vatiw, hypocritical way-jumping on the

Speaker: NA
Text: political bandwagon-will stand up here and

Speaker: NA
Text: say, 'Look how we are looking after

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioners'. The newspapers will be full of

Speaker: NA
Text: stories of opposition members saying they tion members.

Speaker: NA
Text: care about and love pensioners while at the

Speaker: NA
Text: same time claiming to be the fiscal

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian political scene. So they will go

Speaker: NA
Text: out there and say to pensioners, 'We oppose

Speaker: NA
Text: this dreadful measure. But, mind you, we

Speaker: NA
Text: think the Government will cut $1 billion off

Speaker: NA
Text: you somewhere down the line'. However,

Speaker: NA
Text: those opposition members will oppose it for

Speaker: NA
Text: political purposes right now, knowing they

Speaker: NA
Text: will cop it out in the electorate. But their

Speaker: NA
Text: logic is just as crazy; they supported the

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation last year.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Ruddock-We haven't broken promisyet

Speaker: NA
Text: es like you.

Speaker: Mr CLEELAND
Text: They supported the sy.

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation last year.

Speaker: The DEPUTY CHAIRMAN
Text: Order! The and

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Berowra

Speaker: NA
Text: interject.

Speaker: Mr CLEELAND
Text: They supported the -This

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation last year before the election.

Speaker: NA
Text: had an election in which the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: people said, 'You belong on that side of the

Speaker: NA
Text: is House' -and they put those 0ppQsite there,

Speaker: NA
Text: quite properly in my view. They come back

Speaker: NA
Text: into this Parliament after supporting the

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation and having been told, 'Your $10

Speaker: NA
Text: cuts are unacceptable'. When the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government comes back in, opposition sena-

Speaker: NA
Text: I tors get up in the Senate, change their minds

Speaker: NA
Text: after the election and say, 'We really do care

Speaker: NA
Text: about giving benefits to people, not cutting.

Speaker: NA
Text: really care about this after all'. They then

Speaker: NA
Text: the come back in, bring it down to this House-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Sciacca-Their new found heart.

Speaker: Mr CLEELAND
Text: Their new found heart.

Speaker: NA
Text: Over here one can just about hear it beating-

Speaker: NA
Text: pumping and palpitating while they care for

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioners. They come back in here and now

Speaker: NA
Text: they oppose it. What must people out there

Speaker: NA
Text: really think of you lot. How can any of you

Speaker: NA
Text: sit there and feel comfortable about what you

Speaker: NA
Text: are doing? How can you really do that? How

Speaker: NA
Text: can you really believe and support what you

Speaker: NA
Text: conserare saying in this chamber today?

Speaker: The DEPUTY CHAIRMAN
Text: Order! I

Speaker: NA
Text: am loathe to interrupt the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: but he really should address his remarks

Speaker: NA
Text: through the Chair and not directly to opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Ruddock-If you do it to me, I will

Speaker: NA
Text: giants of object on the spot.

Speaker: The DEPUTY CHAIRMAN
Text: The honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Berowra will remain silent,

Speaker: NA
Text: not interject and not protoke.

Speaker: Mr CLEELAND
Text: I will not take up the

Speaker: NA
Text: time of the committee for too long because,

Speaker: NA
Text: quite frankly, we are listening to a political

Speaker: NA
Text: debate. It is a debate through which opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion members will gain a bit of politics out

Speaker: NA
Text: there among pensioners to try to frighten them

Speaker: NA
Text: again. Opposition members should be

Speaker: NA
Text: ashamed for running such a debate because,

Speaker: NA
Text: once again, they have exposed their hypocri-

Speaker: NA
Text: I hope the debate is finished quickly so

Speaker: NA
Text: that we can get this Bill back to the Senate

Speaker: NA
Text: impose the legislation as people fully

Speaker: NA
Text: should not expect it to be imposed.

Speaker: Mr CONNOLLY
Text: Bradfield) (11.14 a.m.)

Speaker: NA
Text: debate on the Social Security Amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: We ment Bill is another example of a government

Speaker: NA
Text: which has made an art form of the politics of

Speaker: NA
Text: compassion on the one hand and, since the

Speaker: NA
Text: election, the politics of deception on the

Speaker: NA
Text: other. When this legislation was first intro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duced into the chamber in November last

Speaker: NA
Text: year, it was no less than a Trojan horse; it

Speaker: NA
Text: was a political piece of paper. It was a docu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment brought in here deliberat-ly to try to

Speaker: NA
Text: embarrass the Opposition. It was couched in

Speaker: NA
Text: terms which said to the Opposition, 'If you

Speaker: NA
Text: oppose the nasties in this Bill, we will be able

Speaker: NA
Text: to go to the 900,000 or so pensioner benefi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciaries in this legislation and say, "It is the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition which is stopping you getting your

Speaker: NA
Text: pension increases'" -a blatant, clear-cut,

Speaker: NA
Text: political act.

Speaker: NA
Text: This morning the Parliamentary Secretary

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Minister for Social Security ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Sciacca) came in here and suggested to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition, 'But you supported the Bill'.

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable gentleman has chosen to forget

Speaker: NA
Text: that of course we supported the proposals

Speaker: NA
Text: increase benefits to welfare recipients. Most

Speaker: NA
Text: of them are there because of the policies

Speaker: NA
Text: this Labor Government. Of course we supand,

Speaker: NA
Text: ported those people getting improvements

Speaker: NA
Text: their standard of living, small though they

Speaker: NA
Text: may be. But we also took the opportunityfixed

Speaker: NA
Text: and many opposition speakers did so, includsecurities.

Speaker: NA
Text: ing myself when I led the debate-to make

Speaker: NA
Text: the point that the proposals on the inclusion

Speaker: NA
Text: of unrealisable capital gains had some serious

Speaker: NA
Text: problems.

Speaker: NA
Text: For us to do anything less than that

Speaker: NA
Text: be to deny our resp&.sibility to the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: people, especially to those 107,000 pension-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers-a new figure on the 80,000 referred to in

Speaker: NA
Text: November last year-who are facing the

Speaker: NA
Text: reality of a fundamental change in the strucrushing

Speaker: NA
Text: ture of their income. I made it clear on that

Speaker: NA
Text: occasion that the Opposition believed that this

Speaker: NA
Text: aspect of the Bill should be reviewed. We

Speaker: NA
Text: gave a commitment then that in the event of

Speaker: NA
Text: our winning the election there would most country.

Speaker: NA
Text: certainly be a review. As the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Berowra ( Mr Ruddock) has

Speaker: NA
Text: clearly identified in his private member's

Speaker: NA
Text: since then, if we were in government we

Speaker: NA
Text: would simply remove these proposals from investor

Speaker: NA
Text: the legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: I also called on the Government on that

Speaker: NA
Text: occasion to carry out a thorough review of

Speaker: NA
Text: assets test because the fundamental problem

Speaker: NA
Text: in all of this is the assets test itself and the

Speaker: NA
Text: way in which that test is being applied by this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Ruddock-It is just shifting the boun-

Speaker: NA
Text: daries.

Speaker: Mr CONNOLLY
Text: That is correct. One of

Speaker: NA
Text: the documents given to the shadow Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: noted the following: 72 per cent of pensioners

Speaker: NA
Text: most commonly invested in bank investments,

Speaker: NA
Text: 11 per cent in bonds and debentures, and

Speaker: NA
Text: seven per cent in managed investments; less

Speaker: NA
Text: than six per cent of pensioners own real

Speaker: NA
Text: estate, apart from their own home; and only

Speaker: NA
Text: approximately one per cent of pensioners

Speaker: NA
Text: receive income from real estate. Most pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sioners who hold real estate are likely to do

Speaker: NA
Text: so for lifestyle reasons-for example, holiday

Speaker: NA
Text: The homes-rather than investment purposes. The

Speaker: NA
Text: reason the Government wanted to make this

Speaker: NA
Text: to reform is that, consequent to the changes in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1988, it noted an increase in the number of

Speaker: NA
Text: of people making investments through shares

Speaker: NA
Text: therefore, a decreased number of people

Speaker: NA
Text: in making investments through fixed interest

Speaker: NA
Text: securities; in other words, a transfer from

Speaker: NA
Text: interest securities to market linked

Speaker: NA
Text: Clearly, that demonstrates that the market

Speaker: NA
Text: out there-that is, the shareholder component

Speaker: NA
Text: of pensioners and people who had additional

Speaker: NA
Text: investments-was perfectly capable of making

Speaker: NA
Text: would judgments in its best interests.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Ruddock-Rational decisions.

Speaker: Mr CONNOLLY
Text: That is correct. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Government simply spends its time madly

Speaker: NA
Text: around trying to put plugs in empty

Speaker: NA
Text: bottles. It finds one bottle which has a prob-

Speaker: NA
Text: lem so it looks for another sized cork to fit

Speaker: NA
Text: into it. The problem is really the structure of

Speaker: NA
Text: the assets test as it currently applies in this

Speaker: NA
Text: I made some observations on 5 November

Speaker: NA
Text: last year which I think need to be repeated in

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill this context. I gave some examples of what

Speaker: NA
Text: effect these proposals will have on actual

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioners. It is also worth noting the

Speaker: NA
Text: figures which were quoted then by the Gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment. It said six per cent would be affect-

Speaker: NA
Text: the ed. One of the estimates given to me by the

Speaker: NA
Text: department was that 84,000 pensioners would

Speaker: NA
Text: be affected; now we know the figure is

Speaker: NA
Text: 107,000. Of that number, 20,000 would have

Speaker: NA
Text: a pension reduction of less than $10 a week;

Speaker: NA
Text: 1,500 would have a reduction of $100 a

Speaker: NA
Text: week; and 150, with shareholdings of $60,000

Speaker: NA
Text: or more, would be liable to have their part-

Speaker: NA
Text: pensions cancelled unless they fundamentally

Speaker: NA
Text: changed the structure of their holdings. A

Speaker: NA
Text: press report suggested that the average pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sioner would lose up to $700 per year in

Speaker: NA
Text: pension. Of course, that was disputed by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government, but as the numbers have now

Speaker: NA
Text: gone up I think the Parliamentary Secretary

Speaker: NA
Text: should once again state, for the benefit of the

Speaker: NA
Text: chamber, precisely what the anticipated

Speaker: NA
Text: statistics are.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the examples I gave, which goes to

Speaker: NA
Text: the crux of this whole problem, concerned a

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioner with a mixed portfolio of say

Speaker: NA
Text: $20,000-we were told that the average at

Speaker: NA
Text: that time was $15,000 and I would like the

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliamentary Secretary to tell us what the

Speaker: NA
Text: average is now; it may have gone up-

Speaker: NA
Text: returning a fully franked dividend of say

Speaker: NA
Text: $1,000 and an unrealised capital gain of

Speaker: NA
Text: $2,000. At present the dividend of $1,000 is

Speaker: NA
Text: counted under the income test, reducing the

Speaker: NA
Text: pension by $500 at the rate of SOc in the

Speaker: NA
Text: dollar. That is the current arrangement. We all

Speaker: NA
Text: understand that.

Speaker: NA
Text: But under the legislation as proposed

Speaker: NA
Text: time and as it will be implemented, that same

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioner's unrealised capital gain of $2,000

Speaker: NA
Text: will cost a further loss of $1,000 on that

Speaker: NA
Text: pension. The net overall effect, counting

Speaker: NA
Text: dividend and capital gain, is therefore a net

Speaker: NA
Text: loss of $1,500. That is clearly, by any stretch

Speaker: NA
Text: of the imagination,. a fundamental change in

Speaker: NA
Text: the potential for disposable income of a

Speaker: NA
Text: person on that income level.

Speaker: NA
Text: Alternatively, to protect the pension, the

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioner could realise the capital gain-as

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government obviously wishes-and pay

Speaker: NA
Text: capital gains tax plus the SOc in the dollar

Speaker: NA
Text: withdrawal rate on the pension, resulting in an

Speaker: NA
Text: effective marginal rate of tax of approximate-

Speaker: NA
Text: ly 66c in the dollar. I ask my colleagues: is

Speaker: NA
Text: anybody in the work force in this country

Speaker: NA
Text: asked to pay 66c in the dollar income tax?

Speaker: NA
Text: The answer is clearly no. But if a pensioner

Speaker: NA
Text: has some shareholdings and some small

Speaker: NA
Text: dividend income it is hard luck, because that

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioner will be up for 66c in the dollar.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have not given all the bad news yet. In

Speaker: NA
Text: addition to that, there are brokerage charges

Speaker: NA
Text: of approximately one per cent to two per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: In November last year, I asked the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment to make the necessary amendments to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Act-they were not there; I looked very

Speaker: NA
Text: closely at that-to exclude at least those

Speaker: NA
Text: additional costs from the considerations.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Sciacca-We did.

Speaker: Mr CONNOLLY
Text: It may have been done

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Senate, but it was certainly not in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill when it came before the House of Repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sentatives. If that is now deductible, I am

Speaker: NA
Text: pleased. It is at least some demonstration of

Speaker: NA
Text: commonsense in an otherwise pretty hopeless

Speaker: NA
Text: situation.

Speaker: NA
Text: The overall outcome is that the only way to

Speaker: NA
Text: avoid the assessment of unrealised capital

Speaker: NA
Text: gain would be. to invest in property to circum-

Speaker: NA
Text: vent the income test. We have been told in

Speaker: NA
Text: the statistics I quoted earlier that very few

Speaker: NA
Text: people-six per cent-do that. The other

Speaker: NA
Text: point which has been raised by people in the

Speaker: NA
Text: industry and which I think is worth noting is

Speaker: NA
Text: that a pensioner could buy shares offshore and

Speaker: NA
Text: therefore circumvent these proposals. Again,

Speaker: NA
Text: this is an issue which I think the Parliamen-

Speaker: NA
Text: at that tary Secretary should refer to.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to put to bed once and for all this

Speaker: NA
Text: furphy coming from government members

Speaker: NA
Text: about our allowing the passage of this Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: last year for very sound, ethical, equity and

Speaker: NA
Text: political reasons because, as I said, we were

Speaker: NA
Text: not going to be caught in the Trojan horse

Speaker: NA
Text: trap that the Government had set for us. We

Speaker: NA
Text: raised these fundamental problems then and

Speaker: NA
Text: we have gone even further. We have devel-

Speaker: NA
Text: oped a private member's Bill to reinforce the

Speaker: NA
Text: fact that those problems are still very much in

Speaker: NA
Text: place. Here we are for the second time simply

Speaker: NA
Text: asking the GoveIll11lent to face up to the fact

Speaker: NA
Text: that there are problems here. The formula

Speaker: NA
Text: which is being applied must be reviewed.

Speaker: NA
Text: (TIme expired)

Speaker: Mr GIBSON
Text: Moreton) (11.24 a.m.)-

Speaker: NA
Text: Probably the only thing about the contribution

Speaker: NA
Text: to this debate by the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Bradfield ( Mr Connolly) that I agreed with

Speaker: NA
Text: was his comment that this debate was domi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nated by a blatant act of political expediency.

Speaker: NA
Text: One has to make the point that the most

Speaker: NA
Text: blatant act of political expediency is occurring

Speaker: NA
Text: on the part of the Opposition.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us get down to brass tacks as to. why

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition has reversed the position that

Speaker: NA
Text: it took a couple of months ago. The pension-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers of this country saw through the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: and deserted it in droves at the last election.

Speaker: NA
Text: The pensioners of this country knew exactly

Speaker: NA
Text: what the Opposition would do to them if it

Speaker: NA
Text: ever got into power. They saw what the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition had in its platform and they knew

Speaker: NA
Text: that they would suffer dramatic falls in their

Speaker: NA
Text: living standards and income if they allowed

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition to gain power. Those opposite

Speaker: NA
Text: lost the pensioner vote across this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: Now we have this desperate scrambling by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition to try to curry favour with

Speaker: NA
Text: some pensioner groups because it realises that

Speaker: NA
Text: it is in desperate straits as far as its political

Speaker: NA
Text: support amongst older Australians is con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerned. That is why we now have this back-

Speaker: NA
Text: flip by the Opposition and why this beat-up

Speaker: NA
Text: debate is occurring once more in this chamber

Speaker: NA
Text: about this issue.

Speaker: NA
Text: This debate has been absolutely dominated

Speaker: NA
Text: by furphies and by conspiracy theories, and

Speaker: NA
Text: each opposition spokesman has trotted out a

Speaker: NA
Text: whole series of allegations about what is

Speaker: NA
Text: going to happen. It is said that·history repeats

Speaker: NA
Text: itself, and in this chamber we have history

Speaker: NA
Text: once more repeating itself in this debate about

Speaker: NA
Text: social security measures. Every time this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has introduced new measures to

Speaker: NA
Text: better target social security provisions in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country, the Opposition has been beating its

Speaker: NA
Text: chest and filling the whole community with

Speaker: NA
Text: fear and hysteria about how awful and dread-

Speaker: NA
Text: ful this measure will be and how thousands of

Speaker: NA
Text: people will suffer.

Speaker: NA
Text: We remember the way in which the Opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion totally abused the pensioner community

Speaker: NA
Text: in this country over the assets test; the way in

Speaker: NA
Text: which the Opposition led the community by

Speaker: NA
Text: the nose and filled people with fear about the

Speaker: NA
Text: impact of that test. Members of the Opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion now know that none of those fears were

Speaker: NA
Text: realised, but the way they acted in that debate

Speaker: NA
Text: was a total disgrace. A lot of people were

Speaker: NA
Text: scared about what was going to happen and

Speaker: NA
Text: what impact the assets test would have.

Speaker: NA
Text: A couple of years ago we had a similar

Speaker: NA
Text: instance with the Opposition taking great

Speaker: NA
Text: pains to scare people over the deeming

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions that were brought in to impact on

Speaker: NA
Text: social security payments. Again we had the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition beating up a scare campaign and

Speaker: NA
Text: telling pensioners that all sorts of dreadful

Speaker: NA
Text: things were going to happen with the deeming

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions. Once more, none of those fearful

Speaker: NA
Text: things occurred. The deeming provisions were

Speaker: NA
Text: introduced and pensioners found that they

Speaker: NA
Text: made more money through those provisions

Speaker: NA
Text: than they had previously. They found that

Speaker: NA
Text: their savings were starting to earn a reason-

Speaker: NA
Text: able income from bank interest rather than the

Speaker: NA
Text: paltry amounts that the banks had been

Speaker: NA
Text: paying in the past.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us have a look at the way in which the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition goes on in these debates. In its

Speaker: NA
Text: Fightback package the Opposition put forward

Speaker: NA
Text: to the people of this country that it wanted to

Speaker: NA
Text: slash some $10 billion from social welfare

Speaker: NA
Text: payments; yet each time the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: looks at better targeting social security pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments and making reasonable cost savings it

Speaker: NA
Text: is attacked and vilified by the Opposition. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Government is not looking to save money but

Speaker: NA
Text: is trying to spread the benefits of social

Speaker: NA
Text: security to more people. Money is not put

Speaker: NA
Text: back into Consolidated Revenue. Even though

Speaker: NA
Text: this measure was introduced, in the last

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget the amount of money paid in social

Speaker: NA
Text: welfare was increased.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Opposition wanted to slash $10 billion

Speaker: NA
Text: from social welfare payments. That is an

Speaker: NA
Text: absolute disgrace and exposes the hypocrisy

Speaker: NA
Text: of every member of the Opposition taking

Speaker: NA
Text: part in this debate. The honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for O'Connor ( Mr Tuckey) came up with this

Speaker: NA
Text: idea of a wealth tax. Talk about drawing a

Speaker: NA
Text: longbow-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Sciacca-And ducks.

Speaker: Mr GIBSON
Text: Yes, maybe he was going

Speaker: NA
Text: to use the longbow to shoot down the ducks.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is absolute poppycock to consider that this

Speaker: NA
Text: is some sort of conspiracy to introduce a

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth tax, and the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: O'Connor knows that. We had other furphies

Speaker: NA
Text: introduced by the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Berowra ( Mr Ruddock). On the one hand, he

Speaker: NA
Text: talked about all these pensioners who will be

Speaker: NA
Text: badly affected, how much money they will

Speaker: NA
Text: lose and how unfair it is. On the other hand,

Speaker: NA
Text: he says that the Government will not make

Speaker: NA
Text: the savings anyway. If as a result of this

Speaker: NA
Text: measure we are to affect the pensions of all

Speaker: NA
Text: these people, how is it that we are not making

Speaker: NA
Text: the savings? That conflict has not been

Speaker: NA
Text: explained. I would be interested to find out

Speaker: NA
Text: how those two conflicting positions can be

Speaker: NA
Text: reconciled. The savings-modest as they

Speaker: NA
Text: are-will be realised, as they have been with

Speaker: NA
Text: every other targeted measure. The Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: knows that.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us not forget why we are making those

Speaker: NA
Text: savings and the purpose that the savings are

Speaker: NA
Text: being put to. It was announced in the Budget

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Government was to extend fringe

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits to part-pensioners, and that measure

Speaker: NA
Text: has been introduced. In looking at the ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of the fairness and the operation of assets

Speaker: NA
Text: that some pensioners have in the form of

Speaker: NA
Text: shares and bringing them into line with other

Speaker: NA
Text: treatments that we have now for other forms

Speaker: NA
Text: of investment that pensioners have, the sav-

Speaker: NA
Text: ings that we are introducing for a small

Speaker: NA
Text: number of pensioners in this area will now be

Speaker: NA
Text: utilised to benefit a whole host of additional

Speaker: NA
Text: people who will now be eligible for fringe

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits through the part-pension system.

Speaker: NA
Text: So the savings that we make from this

Speaker: NA
Text: small segment of the pensioner community

Speaker: NA
Text: are then being used to benefit a whole host of

Speaker: NA
Text: additional people in our social welfare net. I

Speaker: NA
Text: think that is a very important point that needs

Speaker: NA
Text: to be realised. The savings that we make here

Speaker: NA
Text: are not just going back into Consolidated

Speaker: NA
Text: Revenue; they are being utilised by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government to extend additional benefits to

Speaker: NA
Text: other people.

Speaker: NA
Text: I assure the Opposition that the many

Speaker: NA
Text: thousands of part-pensioners, who are now

Speaker: NA
Text: receiving the services through the health-care

Speaker: NA
Text: card and the other fringe benefits provided by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth, are very much apprecia-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive of that fact. What we have got here is an

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition measure designed to take that

Speaker: NA
Text: away. The Opposition has not explained what

Speaker: NA
Text: it would do. If we lose this income how do

Speaker: NA
Text: we then pay for some of those other benefits?

Speaker: NA
Text: Does the Opposition intend to talk to all the

Speaker: NA
Text: part-pensioners in the electorate of Moreton

Speaker: NA
Text: and elsewhere around this country and ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: plain, 'Sorry, we had to take the health care

Speaker: NA
Text: card off you. We had to take all these other

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits off you because three per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioners who earned some extra income

Speaker: NA
Text: through shares were not prepared to pay their

Speaker: NA
Text: way in relation to having that income recog-

Speaker: NA
Text: nised.'

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Sciacca-Because they wanted to play

Speaker: NA
Text: politics.

Speaker: Mr GIBSON
Text: That is right, because the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition wanted to play politics in this

Speaker: NA
Text: issue. It wanted to change and take a new

Speaker: NA
Text: position on this after the election when it

Speaker: NA
Text: realised that the pensioner community in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country had abandoned the Opposition in the

Speaker: NA
Text: election campaign.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have also had the other furphy intro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duced in this debate, 'Oh, here we have one

Speaker: NA
Text: more broken promise by the Government'.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us not forget when this measure was

Speaker: NA
Text: introduced by the Government. It was an-

Speaker: NA
Text: nounced in the Budget and was introduced in

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation in this House in November or

Speaker: NA
Text: December last year. So the people of Austral-

Speaker: NA
Text: ia, when they went to the polls on 13 March,

Speaker: NA
Text: knew exactly what they were voting for. This

Speaker: NA
Text: was part of the policy platform of the Govem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. They knew what they wanted and we

Speaker: NA
Text: got increased support from the aged com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity around this country. That is the

Speaker: NA
Text: reality.

Speaker: NA
Text: This was part of our platform when we

Speaker: NA
Text: went to the election, and the people of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia supported it because they recognised

Speaker: NA
Text: that it was a fundamental part of our social

Speaker: NA
Text: justice objective to better target our social

Speaker: NA
Text: security payments and to make sure that it

Speaker: NA
Text: was a fair and equitable system. They knew

Speaker: NA
Text: that we were the ones that would introduce

Speaker: NA
Text: .that. They also knew that what the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: would do would have a massive impact on

Speaker: NA
Text: their income and their living standards by

Speaker: NA
Text: slashing so much money off social welfare-

Speaker: NA
Text: some $10 billion. So let us not talk about

Speaker: NA
Text: broken promises. We went to the people of

Speaker: NA
Text: this country telling them clearly what we were

Speaker: NA
Text: going to do and they reelected us with an

Speaker: NA
Text: increased majority. So do not tell us that this

Speaker: NA
Text: is some fonn of broken promise. The second

Speaker: NA
Text: thing is that the savings -e are making here

Speaker: NA
Text: are implementing another promise that we

Speaker: NA
Text: made and that is to introduce the fringe

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits to all part-pensioners. (1ime expired)

Speaker: Mr TRUSS
Text: Wide Bay) (11.34 a.m.)-The

Speaker: NA
Text: Government likes to use words like 'fairness',

Speaker: NA
Text: 'justice' and 'equity' to justify its policy

Speaker: NA
Text: development. Indeed, we have heard those

Speaker: NA
Text: sorts of words used by the Parliamentary

Speaker: NA
Text: Secretary to the Minister for Social Security

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Sciacca) and by government members in

Speaker: NA
Text: defence of this quite unjustifiable action

Speaker: NA
Text: part in including unrealised capital gain on

Speaker: NA
Text: shares in the income test for social security

Speaker: NA
Text: purposes.

Speaker: NA
Text: This proposal is not fair. It treats shares

Speaker: NA
Text: a different way from almost all other assets.

Speaker: NA
Text: It treats shares differently from the family

Speaker: NA
Text: home, antique clocks, the boat in the back-

Speaker: NA
Text: yard, art works, racehorses, a stamp collection

Speaker: NA
Text: and property. It is therefore not fair.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is picking out one fonn of asset and

Speaker: NA
Text: treating it differently from other assets.

Speaker: NA
Text: Indeed, the proposal is not even treating all

Speaker: NA
Text: shares in the same way. Listed shares are to

Speaker: NA
Text: be included in this income test but not unlist-

Speaker: NA
Text: ed shares, so there is no equity and no justice.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government frequently refers to align-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the treatment of shares with managed

Speaker: NA
Text: investment and equity trusts, but there is a

Speaker: NA
Text: vast difference between the way in which

Speaker: NA
Text: managed investments and equity trusts operate

Speaker: NA
Text: compared with shares. Indeed, the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for MCEwen ( Mr Cleeland) referred

Speaker: NA
Text: to the most fundamental of those differences

Speaker: NA
Text: in his own defence of this action: that is, the

Speaker: NA
Text: ability for people to buy and sell shares at

Speaker: NA
Text: will. The freedom to move in and out of

Speaker: NA
Text: managed investment and equity trusts does

Speaker: NA
Text: not exist in that way, so there is a vast differher

Speaker: NA
Text: ence in those particular styles of investment.

Speaker: NA
Text: They do not have the flexibility that exists

Speaker: NA
Text: with shares.

Speaker: NA
Text: In a letter to me only last month, the Parliain

Speaker: NA
Text: mentary Secretary said that 'unrealised capital

Speaker: NA
Text: gain on shares reduces the real need of the

Speaker: NA
Text: person for social security assistance'. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: absolute nonsense. Unrealised gain, unrealised

Speaker: NA
Text: income, is of absolutely no value in protecting

Speaker: NA
Text: a person from the need for social security

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance. It does not buy bread; it does not

Speaker: NA
Text: pay rent; it does not meet the daily expenses.

Speaker: NA
Text: Income is worth while only when it is real-

Speaker: NA
Text: ised. When it is realised it is included-and

Speaker: NA
Text: rightly so-in the income test when the shares

Speaker: NA
Text: are sold. When there has been an increase in

Speaker: NA
Text: the value of the shares, the assets test increas-

Speaker: NA
Text: es. That is perfectly fair. It is quite reasonable

Speaker: NA
Text: to include capital gain in asset tests; it is

Speaker: NA
Text: totally unreasonable to include unreallsed gain

Speaker: NA
Text: in the income tests. Unearned, non-existent

Speaker: NA
Text: income is being treated as though it were

Speaker: NA
Text: on its actually there and able to be used to buy

Speaker: NA
Text: bread, food and clothing when, in reality, it

Speaker: NA
Text: is not there.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government is introducing this measure

Speaker: NA
Text: in in a totally unfair way. It is assuming that all

Speaker: NA
Text: shares have an opening value. That value has

Speaker: NA
Text: been assessed as at September 1992. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Government knows that share values were at

Speaker: NA
Text: a historically low level at that time, so pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sioners are going to be accused of having a

Speaker: NA
Text: capital gain on shares when in fact the value

Speaker: NA
Text: of those shares may well be lower than the

Speaker: NA
Text: purchase price. The Government is assuming

Speaker: NA
Text: that pensioners have had a gain, that the

Speaker: NA
Text: shares have earned money, when in fact they

Speaker: NA
Text: are worth less than was paid for thel!'.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me relate to honourable members an

Speaker: NA
Text: example of a constituent of mine who inherit-

Speaker: NA
Text: ed some Coles Myer shares. Those shares are

Speaker: NA
Text: of great personal value to her, largely in the

Speaker: NA
Text: same way that some people regard their stamp

Speaker: NA
Text: collections as having a great deal of sentimen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tal value. She acquired these shares from her

Speaker: NA
Text: grandfather, whose company was one of those

Speaker: NA
Text: swallowed up in the development of the Coles

Speaker: NA
Text: Myer empire. She has no intention or wish

Speaker: NA
Text: ever to sell the shares. She wants to pass

Speaker: NA
Text: them through the family as a recognition of

Speaker: NA
Text: grandfather'S business. She will no longer

Speaker: NA
Text: be able to keep those shares and retain her

Speaker: NA
Text: pension, because the gain on those inherited

Speaker: NA
Text: shares is going to be assessed and will result

Speaker: NA
Text: a loss of income for her from her pension.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is the kind of measure that this Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment considers fair. It is all right to collect

Speaker: NA
Text: clocks, stamps, boats, et cetera, as that sort of

Speaker: NA
Text: capital gain will not be taken into account.

Speaker: NA
Text: But people who happen to inherit shares will

Speaker: NA
Text: lose their pension.

Speaker: NA
Text: People can own multi-million dollar houses

Speaker: NA
Text: on the North Shore of Sydney gaining enor-

Speaker: NA
Text: mously in capital value each year, and it will

Speaker: NA
Text: not affect their pension, but people who dare

Speaker: NA
Text: have a modest share portfolio are going to

Speaker: NA
Text: have their pension reduced. The Government

Speaker: NA
Text: also likes to boast about the value of its

Speaker: NA
Text: deeming provisions, which it claims have

Speaker: NA
Text: helped to increase pensioners' income-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Sciacca-They have.

Speaker: Mr TRUSS
Text: I notice that the Parliamen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tary Secretary is· nodding. He is therefore

Speaker: NA
Text: putting his head in the noose, because he is

Speaker: NA
Text: now introducing a measure which will force

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioners to reduce their income. To satisfy

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government, they will have to sell their

Speaker: NA
Text: shares, which are earning perhaps six, eight,

Speaker: NA
Text: or 10 per cent, and put the money somewhere

Speaker: NA
Text: where it will earn four per cent. That is the

Speaker: NA
Text: kind of measure the Government is proposing

Speaker: NA
Text: to put in place.

Speaker: NA
Text: Is the Parliamentary Secretary suggesting

Speaker: NA
Text: that pensioners are just going to sit there

Speaker: NA
Text: allow their income to be reduced when there

Speaker: NA
Text: are measures that they can undertake to lower

Speaker: NA
Text: their income artificially and therefore qualify

Speaker: NA
Text: for a higher pension? The sort of measure the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government is proposing to introduce demon-

Speaker: NA
Text: strates total inconsistency. Of course if pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sioners go out and sell their shares, they will

Speaker: NA
Text: have to pay capital gains tax on them as well

Speaker: NA
Text: if those shares were purchased after Septem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber of 1985.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government claims that a pensioner

Speaker: NA
Text: rort has been going on, and that pensioners

Speaker: NA
Text: have been using capital gains on shares to

Speaker: NA
Text: avoid the income test. The Government thinks

Speaker: NA
Text: that as a result of stopping this rort $60

Speaker: NA
Text: million will be saved-although the figure has

Speaker: NA
Text: now been raised to $80 million. I am amused

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Parliamentary Secretary again claiming

Speaker: NA
Text: he has all these detailed mathematical calcula-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions so he can guarantee that he can deliver

Speaker: NA
Text: these savings to the Government. If they are

Speaker: NA
Text: so detailed, why does he keep changing the

Speaker: NA
Text: numbers? When this Bill was introduced back

Speaker: NA
Text: in November 60,000 people were going to be

Speaker: NA
Text: affected. The Minister for Social Security ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Baldwin) issued a press release on 6 May,

Speaker: NA
Text: putting the number of 84,000. The Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: now has it at 107,000. It is about time they

Speaker: NA
Text: made up their mind if those numbers are

Speaker: NA
Text: supposed to have been so accurately calculat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ed.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government has not taken into account

Speaker: NA
Text: in its numbers the reaction of pensioners to

Speaker: NA
Text: these new measures. Clearly pensioners will

Speaker: NA
Text: alter their patterns of investment. They will

Speaker: NA
Text: change their arrangements so that the alleged

Speaker: NA
Text: savings will, in reality, not exist. Another fact

Speaker: NA
Text: that has to be taken into account is that if the

Speaker: NA
Text: value of pensioners' shares drop, they may

Speaker: NA
Text: become eligible for a pension that they are

Speaker: NA
Text: not currently able to receive. Indeed, had this

Speaker: NA
Text: measure been introduced about three years

Speaker: NA
Text: ago and not today, it would have cost the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government money every year rather than

Speaker: NA
Text: achieved any savings. Clearly there will be

Speaker: NA
Text: occasions in the future, too, when this meas-

Speaker: NA
Text: ure will end up being a liability for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government. That will occur in those years

Speaker: NA
Text: when share values drop, and as a result the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's own income will have dropped.

Speaker: NA
Text: This measure is clearly a very poor example

Speaker: NA
Text: and of risk management. The Government will

Speaker: NA
Text: have increased liabilities in times when the

Speaker: NA
Text: value of pensioners' shares drops and when

Speaker: NA
Text: they will therefore start to apply for higher

Speaker: NA
Text: pensions. That will occur at times when the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government can ill afford it.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable member for Moreton ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Gibson), .in his defence of this system, ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: knowledged that savings would be minimal.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Speaker, in his comments on this meas-

Speaker: NA
Text: ure, indicated that it was impossible to ascer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tain whether there would actually be any

Speaker: NA
Text: savings at all or whether there would be

Speaker: NA
Text: liabilities for the Government. So, clearly,

Speaker: NA
Text: independent observers and the Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: own speakers have acknowledged that the

Speaker: NA
Text: savings are likely to be negligible, if they

Speaker: NA
Text: exist at all.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government's measures are being

Speaker: NA
Text: introduced with only one thought in mind,

Speaker: NA
Text: and that is to spitefully treat those pensioners

Speaker: NA
Text: who have put aside during their working days

Speaker: NA
Text: for their own retirement. I thought we should

Speaker: NA
Text: be encouraging people to provide for their

Speaker: NA
Text: own retirement. This Government gives lip

Speaker: NA
Text: service to that principle with its compulsory

Speaker: NA
Text: superannuation arrangements. But, in reality,

Speaker: NA
Text: when pensioners actually take such measures

Speaker: NA
Text: on their own account and buy shares so they

Speaker: NA
Text: will have something to live on in their retire-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, this Government is introducing meas-

Speaker: NA
Text: ures which will penalise those people. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: encouraging welfare dependency, a reliance

Speaker: NA
Text: on the Government and taxpayers, rather than

Speaker: NA
Text: rewarding those who make the extra effort to

Speaker: NA
Text: care for themselves. (TIme expired)

Speaker: Mr SCIACCA
Text: Bowman-Parliamentary

Speaker: NA
Text: Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

Speaker: NA
Text: (11.44 a.m.)-The honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Wide Bay (Me Truss) clearly does not under-

Speaker: NA
Text: stand what is going on here, with respect.

Speaker: NA
Text: These measures were announced in the Budg-

Speaker: NA
Text: et of 1992. He is putting up the proposition

Speaker: NA
Text: that somehow the Government knew that the

Speaker: NA
Text: stock market was going to go up and that we

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly sought September 1993 as the

Speaker: NA
Text: implementation date for these measures

Speaker: NA
Text: because all of a sudden there has been an

Speaker: NA
Text: increase in the stock market. I remind him

Speaker: NA
Text: that this decision was made in the Budget

Speaker: NA
Text: process of August 1992, and the date in terms

Speaker: NA
Text: of the treatment of the value of the shares in

Speaker: NA
Text: this measure was fixed at September 1993. If

Speaker: NA
Text: he is trying to suggest that the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: somehow knew that there would be an in-

Speaker: NA
Text: crease in the stock market during that period,

Speaker: NA
Text: I wish I had known that myself.

Speaker: NA
Text: The fact is that no-one knows how the

Speaker: NA
Text: stock market is going to go. At the moment

Speaker: NA
Text: it is in a profit situation but the stock market

Speaker: NA
Text: is such that people, if they want to, can divest

Speaker: NA
Text: themselves of some of their shares, but not all

Speaker: NA
Text: of them. They would have to do that if they

Speaker: NA
Text: had property, collectables or antiques. They

Speaker: NA
Text: would have to sell the whole of the invest-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. With shares they only need a portion of

Speaker: NA
Text: their investment and they can readily sell

Speaker: NA
Text: shares on the stock market from day to day.

Speaker: NA
Text: So it is not comparing oranges with oranges

Speaker: NA
Text: to say that a collectable, a property or an

Speaker: NA
Text: antique clock is the same as shares. It is a

Speaker: NA
Text: nonsense to suggest that.

Speaker: NA
Text: As the honourable for MCEwen ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Cleeland) said before, the Opposition is

Speaker: NA
Text: simply making politics out of this issue. If

Speaker: NA
Text: those opposite go out into the electorate at

Speaker: NA
Text: large, there will be 400 people spread across

Speaker: NA
Text: the electorate who would say that we are

Speaker: NA
Text: being tough. I will comment further about that

Speaker: NA
Text: later, but people have had a very long time to

Speaker: NA
Text: decide what they will do. This legislation is

Speaker: NA
Text: not a Trojan horse. The Government went to

Speaker: NA
Text: the public in March and the public knew what

Speaker: NA
Text: the proposal was. An investor who is astute

Speaker: NA
Text: enough to want to buy shares and have large

Speaker: NA
Text: shareholdings does not do it off his or her

Speaker: NA
Text: own back; that investor would go to financial

Speaker: NA
Text: planners and investment advisers. If it is

Speaker: NA
Text: being suggested that investment advisers did

Speaker: NA
Text: not know of these provisions, then they are

Speaker: NA
Text: not much good and I suggest that people

Speaker: NA
Text: should not be going to them.

Speaker: Mr CAMERON
Text: Stirling) (11.46 a.m.)-

Speaker: NA
Text: Exactly a week ago today, with my colleagues

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member for Cowan ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Evans) and the honourable member for Moore

Speaker: NA
Text: (Me Filing), I met with a very large group of

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioners in Western Australia. A large

Speaker: NA
Text: section of that group. were self-funded retirees

Speaker: NA
Text: and if there was ever a disincentive for

Speaker: NA
Text: younger Australians to take out provision for

Speaker: NA
Text: their retirement it would be this Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: handling of the self-funded retirees, many of

Speaker: NA
Text: whom are affected by what we are talking

Speaker: NA
Text: about here today. .

Speaker: NA
Text: At present pensioners receive dividends

Speaker: NA
Text: from the shares they own and these dividends

Speaker: NA
Text: are regarded as income earned by the pension-

Speaker: NA
Text: er. Any growth in the value of shares was

Speaker: NA
Text: previously regarded as an increase in one's

Speaker: NA
Text: assets. However, the changes made by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government last year regard growth in the

Speaker: NA
Text: value of shares as increased income for the

Speaker: NA
Text: purposes of working out one's pension entitle-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments.

Speaker: NA
Text: When this was first brought to my attention

Speaker: NA
Text: I thought I was being had. I could not believe

Speaker: NA
Text: it. I said, 'No, I think you have misunderstood

Speaker: NA
Text: what they are on about'. Unfortunately, I was

Speaker: NA
Text: wrong. This legislation, in essence, distin-

Speaker: NA
Text: guishes pensioners from all other groups with

Speaker: NA
Text: regard to the holding of shares. If, for exam-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple, the Prime Minister (Me Keating) held

Speaker: NA
Text: shares in a piggery company, he would be

Speaker: NA
Text: taxed on any dividends he received from that

Speaker: NA
Text: company. However, if the value of the shares

Speaker: NA
Text: rose he would not be penalised in any other

Speaker: NA
Text: way until he sold them, when he would of

Speaker: NA
Text: course be liable for capital gains tax.

Speaker: NA
Text: The situation therefore arises where, for

Speaker: NA
Text: every $1 increase in the value of shares,

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioners will lose 57.5c of their existing

Speaker: NA
Text: age pension. This is despite the fact that the

Speaker: NA
Text: shares have not been sold and the pensioners

Speaker: NA
Text: have not actually received any increase in

Speaker: NA
Text: their income. If honourable members think for

Speaker: NA
Text: one moment that people will hold on to these

Speaker: NA
Text: shares, they can think again. It was stated to

Speaker: NA
Text: me quite categorically at the meeting last

Speaker: NA
Text: week that they would be selling their shares,

Speaker: NA
Text: because they are embattled enough as it is

Speaker: NA
Text: trying to get by under the treatment that has

Speaker: NA
Text: been meted out to them, and this was just

Speaker: NA
Text: another brick in the wall.

Speaker: NA
Text: Essentially, this legislation ignores

Speaker: NA
Text: flow for pensioners which is so important to

Speaker: NA
Text: consider. Many pensioners will be left out of

Speaker: NA
Text: pocket because the shares they own will have

Speaker: NA
Text: increased in value. While they would not have

Speaker: NA
Text: received any extra income, they will lose part

Speaker: NA
Text: of their pension because, of course, it is

Speaker: NA
Text: assumed that their income has increased.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are a lot of assumptions going on.

Speaker: NA
Text: This has a vicious cycle effect in that

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioners who have their pensions reduced

Speaker: NA
Text: will eventually be forced to sell their shares-

Speaker: NA
Text: as they surely will-and this will subsequent-

Speaker: NA
Text: ly mean that they will be forced to pay capital

Speaker: NA
Text: gains tax. Eventually the pensioners will

Speaker: NA
Text: spend the funds they have accumulated from

Speaker: NA
Text: selling their shares and be forced to go back

Speaker: NA
Text: on the full pension, resulting in any expected

Speaker: NA
Text: savings by the Government being wiped out.

Speaker: NA
Text: There will be no windfall; you can bet on

Speaker: NA
Text: that.

Speaker: NA
Text: I was reading the May edition of Personal

Speaker: NA
Text: Investment magazine, not only to gloat over

Speaker: NA
Text: the story about the former member for Stirling

Speaker: NA
Text: losing his seat but also to read its analysis of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government's idea to treat unrealised

Speaker: NA
Text: capital gains as income. The story mentions

Speaker: NA
Text: Bleakleys The Investment Planners and that

Speaker: NA
Text: firm's suggestion to pensioners to 'sell their

Speaker: NA
Text: shares and take gains prior to 23 September

Speaker: NA
Text: While this is the best option for pensioners,

Speaker: NA
Text: for many it is not the desired option, as we

Speaker: NA
Text: have heard in some convincing argument from

Speaker: NA
Text: this side of the chamber. Unfortunately, it is

Speaker: NA
Text: the only option for pensioners and it is unfor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunate that they are left with little choice but

Speaker: NA
Text: to sell their shares. I would like to mention a

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioner in my electorate, a gentleman

Speaker: NA
Text: named Bill. He has owned shares for some 30

Speaker: NA
Text: years. Based on the price of shares a few

Speaker: NA
Text: weeks ago and the price of those same shares

Speaker: NA
Text: in September last year, Bill has worked out

Speaker: NA
Text: that his pension will be cut by approximately

Speaker: NA
Text: $140 a week. While the actual value of the

Speaker: NA
Text: shares rose, Bill's income would not have

Speaker: NA
Text: increased at all, but he will still be penal-

Speaker: NA
Text: ised-and a significant penalty that will be.

Speaker: NA
Text: He has very few choices other than to give

Speaker: NA
Text: the shares to his children, sell them or accept

Speaker: NA
Text: a lower pension-and, at $140 per week less

Speaker: NA
Text: than what he normally earns, I cannot imagine

Speaker: NA
Text: the cash that that would be a viable option.

Speaker: NA
Text: I also put questions on notice to both the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer ( Mr Dawkins) and the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Social Security ( Mr Baldwin), neither of

Speaker: NA
Text: whom has yet answered these questions-but

Speaker: NA
Text: I have already been warned that Ministers do

Speaker: NA
Text: take a great deal of time to answer their

Speaker: NA
Text: questions, which does make it difficult for

Speaker: NA
Text: one to assist constituents. Nevertheless, I put

Speaker: NA
Text: the case to both Ministers of a pensioner and

Speaker: NA
Text: a PAYE taxpayer who both own the same

Speaker: NA
Text: shares. The question in essence asked what

Speaker: NA
Text: effect fluctuations in shares would have on

Speaker: NA
Text: both if they bought those shares in 1990 for

Speaker: NA
Text: $5, the shares fell in value to $3 on 23 Sep-

Speaker: NA
Text: tember 1992 and rose to $4 one year later.

Speaker: NA
Text: The answer I expected-and that I imagine is

Speaker: NA
Text: correct-is that, while a taxpayer would not

Speaker: NA
Text: be penalised, the pensioner would lose part of

Speaker: NA
Text: his pension due to the increase in value over

Speaker: NA
Text: the past year even though, firstly, he has not

Speaker: NA
Text: sold his shares and, secondly, if he did sell

Speaker: NA
Text: his shares, he would have made a loss.

Speaker: NA
Text: In this situation, the pensioner is hit with a

Speaker: NA
Text: double whammy. If he or she receives any

Speaker: NA
Text: dividend, it is treated as income. I cannot say

Speaker: NA
Text: for sure but I also assume-seeing that there

Speaker: NA
Text: are a lot of assumptions going on-that the

Speaker: NA
Text: dividend imputation credits would also artifi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cially increase that income and therefore

Speaker: NA
Text: further reduce the pension the person is

Speaker: NA
Text: entitled to. If the value of the shares rises

Speaker: NA
Text: over the year, the pensioner loses part of his

Speaker: NA
Text: or her pension and, finally, if the pensioner

Speaker: NA
Text: sells the shares for a profit, he or she pays

Speaker: NA
Text: capital gains tax.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is harsher than if a PAYE taxpayer

Speaker: NA
Text: owned shares. The PAYE taxpayer does not

Speaker: NA
Text: get penalised for any unrealised capital gains

Speaker: NA
Text: and nor should he; neither should a pensioner.

Speaker: NA
Text: I assume that, if these amendments are not

Speaker: NA
Text: accepted, many pensioners will sell their

Speaker: NA
Text: shares and invest in real estate or other items

Speaker: NA
Text: which do not penalise them if their value

Speaker: NA
Text: increases. Unfortunately, this may have a

Speaker: NA
Text: detrimental effect on investment by individu-

Speaker: NA
Text: als at a time when we certainly do not need

Speaker: NA
Text: such disincentives for investment.

Speaker: NA
Text: I will conclude by reiterating that this is

Speaker: NA
Text: unfair legislation which deserves to be re-

Speaker: NA
Text: pealed. It lacks compassion, it defies logic, it Melham, D.

Speaker: NA
Text: is unnecessary and it will achieve absolutely

Speaker: NA
Text: zilch in the long term. I would encourage all

Speaker: NA
Text: members, including those opposite, to support

Speaker: NA
Text: these amendments to ensure the pensioners in

Speaker: NA
Text: our electorates are not treated unfairly. I

Speaker: NA
Text: challenge any honourable members opposite

Speaker: NA
Text: who oppose these amendments to write to the

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioners in their electorates telling them

Speaker: NA
Text: why they should be penalised if the shares

Speaker: NA
Text: they own rise in price-even if they do not

Speaker: NA
Text: sell their shares. It is a challenge that I am

Speaker: NA
Text: quite sure that none will accept, including-

Speaker: NA
Text: and probably especially-the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for MCEwen ( Mr Cleeland), who

Speaker: NA
Text: perhaps has lost his calling, because he is

Speaker: NA
Text: quite an amusing speaker and does a great

Speaker: NA
Text: duck impression, albeit it unintentionally. In

Speaker: NA
Text: view of all that, I would urge Government

Speaker: NA
Text: members to accept these amendments.

Speaker: NA
Text: Motion (by Mr Sciacca) put:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the question be now put.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Committee divided. [11.57 a.m.]

Text: (The Deputy Chairman- Mr C. Hollis)

Text: Crean, S. F. Crosio, J. A.

Text: Cunningham, B. T. Dawkins, J. S.

Speaker: NA
Text: Deahm, M. Dodd, P.

Speaker: NA
Text: Duffy, M. J. Duncan, P.

Speaker: NA
Text: Elliott, R. P. Fatin, W. F.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ferguson, L D. T. Fitzgibbon, E. J.

Speaker: NA
Text: Free, R. V. Gear, G.

Speaker: NA
Text: Gibson, G. D. Gorman, R. N. J.

Speaker: NA
Text: Grace, E. L. * Griffm, A.

Speaker: NA
Text: Griffiths, A. G. Haviland, C. D.

Text: Henzell, M. Holding, A. C.

Speaker: NA
Text: Home, R. Humphreys, B. C.

Speaker: NA
Text: Jenkins, H. A. Johns, G. T.

Speaker: NA
Text: Kelly, R. J. Kerin, J. C.

Speaker: NA
Text: Kerr, D. 1. C. Knott, M. P. 1.

Speaker: NA
Text: Lavarch, M. H. Lindsay, E. J.

Speaker: NA
Text: MCHugh, J. MCLeay, L B. *

Speaker: NA
Text: Morris, A. A.

Speaker: NA
Text: Morris, P. F. Newell, N. J.

Text: O'Connor, G. M. O'Keefe, N. P.

Text: That the report be adopted.

Speaker: Mr BRADFORD
Text: MCPherson) (12.12

Speaker: NA
Text: p.m.)-I wish to oppose the adoption of this

Speaker: NA
Text: report. The Social Security Amendment Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: is an absolute disgrace. I do not know what

Speaker: NA
Text: it would take to convince the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: that what it is doing to pensioners as a result

Speaker: NA
Text: of this legislation is disgraceful. The Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: mentary Secretary to the Minister for Social

Speaker: NA
Text: Security ( Mr Sciacca) has sat there through

Speaker: NA
Text: speaker after speaker and listened, I think,

Speaker: NA
Text: reason, yet he has failed to accept our argu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments. I do not know why. He has not ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: plained in any cogent form why we should

Speaker: NA
Text: proceed with this legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable member for Moreton ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Gibson), when he was speaking in this debate,

Speaker: NA
Text: talked about better targeting of welfare. That

Speaker: NA
Text: has really hit the bullseye here. This is aimed

Speaker: NA
Text: directly at the heart of pensioners. Those

Speaker: NA
Text: 86,000 or so pensioners of this country who

Speaker: NA
Text: have share portfolios are very concerned. We

Speaker: NA
Text: have been accused this morning of s<;>mething

Speaker: NA
Text: of a beat-up in expressing our concern, but I

Speaker: NA
Text: want to assure the House that this is not a

Speaker: NA
Text: beat-up. We are speaking here because pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sioners all over Australia have made their

Speaker: NA
Text: concerns known to us. They are very con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerned. The speakers in this debate, which the

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Social Security gagged a moment ago, I

Speaker: NA
Text: believe have been totally genuine in express-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the concerns of pensioners everywhere.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Parliamentary Secretary's arguments in

Speaker: NA
Text: favour of the proposition that unrealised

Speaker: NA
Text: capital gains on pensioners' share portfolios

Speaker: NA
Text: be taxed have been pathetic. The arguments

Speaker: NA
Text: that he has put forward are gross distortions.

Speaker: NA
Text: I thought this Government was big on anti-

Speaker: NA
Text: discrimination and big on fairness and equity.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want the Parliamentary Secretary to tell me

Speaker: NA
Text: what is fair about taxing unrealised capital

Speaker: NA
Text: gains. In any sense, what is fair about taxing

Speaker: NA
Text: unrealised capital·gains? Why, if the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment is to tax unrealised capital gains, does

Speaker: NA
Text: it discriminate against pensioners? Why has

Speaker: NA
Text: it chosen only to tax unrealised capital gains

Speaker: NA
Text: on pensioners' shares? What is fair about

Speaker: NA
Text: that? That is discrimination. Our concern

Speaker: NA
Text: about this legislation is that it is blatantly

Speaker: NA
Text: unfair. Speaker after speaker has illustrated

Speaker: NA
Text: the effect of the Government's proposal. If

Speaker: NA
Text: that has not sunk in yet, I do not know what

Speaker: NA
Text: it will take for it to sink in. I have put the

Speaker: NA
Text: question on a number of occasions when this

Speaker: NA
Text: matter has been discussed here: how does the

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioner who loses his pension as a result of

Speaker: NA
Text: this mechanism live?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Sciacca-Sell some of their shares.

Speaker: Mr BRADFORD
Text: Yes, he sells some of

Speaker: NA
Text: his shares; that is the very point that we are

Speaker: NA
Text: to making. I thank the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: helping me to make it. The point is that the

Speaker: NA
Text: intention of the Government in this matter is

Speaker: NA
Text: to ensure that 86,000 pensioners in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country who have share portfolios will sell

Speaker: NA
Text: them or sell part of them.

Speaker: NA
Text: At least we have come to the point in this

Speaker: NA
Text: debate where the Government is prepared to

Speaker: NA
Text: be honest about that. All morning members of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government have been getting up and

Speaker: NA
Text: distorting the truth. The Government's inten-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion is for pensioners not to have the privilege

Speaker: NA
Text: of owning shares-a privilege which is

Speaker: NA
Text: enjoyed by every other Australian. That is the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's intention and that will be the

Speaker: NA
Text: effect of the amendment. The reason that will

Speaker: NA
Text: be the effect of it, let me assure the House, is

Speaker: NA
Text: the same reason we are putting forward-

Speaker: NA
Text: Motion (by Mr Beazley) put:

Speaker: NA
Text: :rhat the question be now put.

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee of Reasons

Speaker: NA
Text: Motion (by Mr Sciacca) agreed to:

Speaker: NA
Text: That Ms Henzell, Mr Gibson, and the mover be

Speaker: NA
Text: appointed a committee to draw up reasons for the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives disagreeing to the amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of the Senate.

Speaker: Mr SCIACCA
Text: Bowman-Parliamentary

Speaker: NA
Text: Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

Speaker: NA
Text: (12.28 p.m.)-On behalf of the committee

Speaker: NA
Text: appointed to draw up reasons for the House

Speaker: NA
Text: disagreeing to the amendment of the Senate,

Speaker: NA
Text: I present the reasons, which are being circu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lated to honourable members.

Speaker: NA
Text: The reasons read as follows-

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate amendment No. 1 is not acceptable

Speaker: NA
Text: because:

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. It excludes shares and other listed securities

Speaker: NA
Text: from the definition of investment product in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Social Security Act and thereby prevents

Speaker: NA
Text: the equitable assessment of the ongoing gains

Speaker: NA
Text: made on shares and other investments listed on

Speaker: NA
Text: the Stock Exchange compared with indirect

Speaker: NA
Text: investments in shares through equity trusts.

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. The amendment will reduce the equity of the

Speaker: NA
Text: social security income test. The assessment of

Speaker: NA
Text: ongoing capital gains on shares ensures that

Speaker: NA
Text: equity of the social security system is en-

Speaker: NA
Text: hanced. Pensioners with the same means and

Speaker: NA
Text: the same financial resources available to them

Speaker: NA
Text: should have the same amount of income

Speaker: NA
Text: assessed for social security purposes. People

Speaker: NA
Text: who invest in shares should not be treated

Speaker: NA
Text: more beneficially than those who invest in

Speaker: NA
Text: equity trusts or other managed investments,

Speaker: NA
Text: and they should not be treated more beneficial-

Speaker: NA
Text: ly than those pensioners who invest in income

Speaker: NA
Text: generating investments such as bank accounts.

Speaker: NA
Text: 3. The amendment would result in the expendi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture of approximately $60 million within the

Speaker: NA
Text: Social Security portfolio in a full year and a

Speaker: NA
Text: further $20 million for a full year within the

Speaker: NA
Text: Department of Veterans' Affairs portfolio on

Speaker: NA
Text: a group of clients with substantial financial

Speaker: NA
Text: resources.

Speaker: NA
Text: PAIRS 4. There is no reason why shares should be

Speaker: NA
Text: excluded and given privileged treatment. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: a principle of the social security income test

Speaker: NA
Text: that ongoing gains are treated as income for

Speaker: NA
Text: all investments that can be readily realised and

Speaker: NA
Text: utilised by pensioners for their support. Only

Speaker: NA
Text: those investments which are not readily reali-

Speaker: NA
Text: sable, such as real estate and shares held in

Speaker: NA
Text: private companies are currently exempt. Listed

Speaker: NA
Text: shares can be sold in small or large bundles at

Speaker: NA
Text: any time allowing gains on listed shares to be

Speaker: NA
Text: readily utilised by a pensioner.

Speaker: NA
Text: Motion (by Mr Sciacca) proposed:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the Committee's reasons be adopted.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr DEPU TY SPEAKER-The question

Speaker: NA
Text: is that the motion be agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Ruddock - Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise

Speaker: NA
Text: a point of order. I have not had a chance to

Speaker: NA
Text: read them yet. I think that honourable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers ought to be given an opportunity to read

Speaker: NA
Text: the reasons before they are asked to vote on

Speaker: NA
Text: the question of the adoption of this report. I Newell, N. J.

Speaker: NA
Text: have just had the reasons handed to me.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Order! The

Speaker: NA
Text: House will remain silent while the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member reads the reasons.

Speaker: Mr RUDDOCK
Text: Berowra) (12.29 p.m.)-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Deputy Speaker, for these reasons-

Speaker: NA
Text: Motion (by Mr Beazley) put:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the question be now put.

Text: point of order. The sound system is not

Text: working. We cannot hear your rulings or

Speaker: NA
Text: directions.

Text: Dohie)-The division bells will ring for four

Text: minutes. That is all the honourable member

Text: needs to know at this time.
