Speaker: NA
Text: VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION

Speaker: NA
Text: AMENDMENT BILL 1993

Speaker: NA
Text: Consideration of Senate Message

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill returned from the Senate with an

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ordered that the amendment be taken into

Speaker: NA
Text: consideration in Committee of the Whole

Speaker: NA
Text: House forthwith.

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate s amendment-

Speaker: NA
Text: After clause 4, page 2, insert the following Divi-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion:

Speaker: NA
Text: "Division lA-Shares and other listed securities

Speaker: NA
Text: Investment product-definition

Speaker: NA
Text: "4A. Section 5J of the Principal Act is amended:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) by omitting the definition of 'investment

Speaker: NA
Text: product' in subsection (1) and substituting

Speaker: NA
Text: the following definition:

Speaker: NA
Text: ", investment product", in relation to a

Speaker: NA
Text: managed investment, means all the invest-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments that are:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) with the same body corporate or in the

Speaker: NA
Text: same trust fund; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) subject to substantially the same terms

Speaker: NA
Text: and conditions as the managed invest-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment;';

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) by omitting the definition of 'listed

Speaker: NA
Text: security' in subsection (1).

Speaker: NA
Text: Beading to Subdivision AA of Division 8 of Part

Speaker: NA
Text: ill

Speaker: NA
Text: "4B. The heading to Subdivision AA of Division

Speaker: NA
Text: 8 of Part III of the Principal Act is amended by

Speaker: NA
Text: omitting 'and listed securities'.

Speaker: NA
Text: Structure of Division

Speaker: NA
Text: "4C. Section 46 of the Principal Act is amended

Speaker: NA
Text: by omitting from the table 'STRUCTURE OF

Speaker: NA
Text: DIVISION' the following figures and words:

Speaker: NA
Text: '4. Shares and other listed securities (from

Speaker: NA
Text: September 1993) 46AA-46AG'.

Speaker: NA
Text: Investments to which Subdivision applies

Speaker: NA
Text: "4D. Section 46AA of the Principal Act is

Speaker: NA
Text: amended by omitting subsection (2).".

Speaker: Mr SCIACCA
Text: Bowman-Parliamentary

Speaker: NA
Text: Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

Speaker: NA
Text: That the amendment be disagreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: I will not speak at length on this amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: because the matters contained in it are exactly

Speaker: NA
Text: the same as those which we just debated,

Speaker: NA
Text: namely, the change in the treatment of shares,

Speaker: NA
Text: which was made law as and from December

Speaker: NA
Text: 1992. For all the reasons that we have already

Speaker: NA
Text: discussed and to save the time of the cham-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber, I wi11leave my remarks at that.

Speaker: Mr TIM FISCHER
Text: Farrer-Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: National Party of Australia) (12.42 p.m.)-I

Speaker: NA
Text: rise to speak briefly to the Veterans' Affairs

Speaker: NA
Text: Legislation Amendment Bill and the Senate

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment thereto. Interestingly enough, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill contains the original provisions contained

Speaker: NA
Text: when the House debated it last, including

Speaker: NA
Text: extension of benefits to the peacekeeping

Speaker: NA
Text: forces in Cambodia and Yugoslavia and

Speaker: NA
Text: adjustments to, the assets test and the like. It

Speaker: NA
Text: now has attached to it an excellent proposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion which effectively moves to end the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's introduction of notional capital

Speaker: NA
Text: gains tax on pensioners.

Speaker: NA
Text: Much has been said about capital gains tax

Speaker: NA
Text: during the debate on the related Social Securi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ty Amendment Bill. Let me make two addi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional points only. Firstly, the Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: approach is a tip of the iceberg approach. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is a stab at the whole concept of notional

Speaker: NA
Text: capital gains tax once proposed by the British

Speaker: NA
Text: Labour Party and variously proposed by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Labor Party in one form or an-

Speaker: NA
Text: other. That tip of the iceberg approach will

Speaker: NA
Text: flow on, if the Government gets away with it,

Speaker: NA
Text: to other areas of statute to the disadvantage of

Speaker: NA
Text: good tax law in Australia and what is a fair

Speaker: NA
Text: go in terms of business not actually gaining

Speaker: NA
Text: the gain but still being subjected to a fonn of

Speaker: NA
Text: notional capital gains tax. I believe that

Speaker: NA
Text: concept is absolutely repugnant.

Speaker: NA
Text: Secondly, to think that pensioners, including

Speaker: NA
Text: veteran service pensioners, will somehow go

Speaker: NA
Text: 20 scot-free if they hold shares is incorrect. I say

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Minister for Social Security ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Baldwin) and to the Parliamentary Secretary

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Minister for Social Security ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Sciacca): the Government already has on the

Speaker: NA
Text: statute books its basic assets test legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: It already has on the statute books the income

Speaker: NA
Text: test provisions, so that pensioners with a

Speaker: NA
Text: portfolio-and good luck to them if they find

Speaker: NA
Text: shares paying a sufficient dividend to trigger

Speaker: NA
Text: the income threshold-will be clobbered in

Speaker: NA
Text: terms of the service pension. It already has on

Speaker: NA
Text: the statute books the capital gains tax provi-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions, which means that if pensioners actually

Speaker: NA
Text: trade in shares, their service or age pension

Speaker: NA
Text: will be adjusted.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to say to the House in very clear-cut

Speaker: NA
Text: terms that the pensioner is already catered

Speaker: NA
Text: Those pensioners holding shares-and they

Speaker: NA
Text: are entitled to hold shares-who have fought

Speaker: NA
Text: for their country are now service pensioners.

Speaker: NA
Text: They might hold some shares in a range of

Speaker: NA
Text: stocks. We are about protecting their right to

Speaker: NA
Text: hold those shares and not be subjected to

Speaker: NA
Text: notional capital gains tax, that is, a notional

Speaker: NA
Text: adjustment leading to the circumstance where

Speaker: NA
Text: their pension would be reduced-and that is

Speaker: NA
Text: what notional capital gains tax is. It is for

Speaker: NA
Text: these reasons that I support the Senate's

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment to the Bill now being considered

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Committee of the Whole.

Speaker: Mr RUDDOCK
Text: Berowra) (12.45 p.m.)-I

Speaker: NA
Text: want to take a couple of moments to add to

Speaker: NA
Text: some of the points raised on the Senate

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment to the Veterans' Affairs Legisla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion Amendment Bill. It is important to

Speaker: NA
Text: recognise that gains on shares can sometimes

Speaker: NA
Text: be illusory and based on short-tenn and

Speaker: NA
Text: extraneous matters rather than underlying

Speaker: NA
Text: value. One of the problems we have with this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's proposal is that it singles out

Speaker: NA
Text: those service pensioners who seek to preserve

Speaker: NA
Text: their capital in the fonn of shares, as distinct

Speaker: NA
Text: from other forms of investment, such as real

Speaker: NA
Text: estate and other properties. In fact, it moves

Speaker: NA
Text: the test which at the moment excludes shares,

Speaker: NA
Text: to one that now enables-

Speaker: The DEPUTY CHAIRMAN
Text: Mr New-

Speaker: NA
Text: ell)-Orderl It being past 12.45 p.m., in

Speaker: NA
Text: accordance with standing order lOlA, I shall

Speaker: NA
Text: report progress.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Deputy Chairman having reported

Speaker: NA
Text: accordingly-

Speaker: NA
Text: Sitting suspended from 12.46 to 2 p.m.

Text: MINISTERIAL ARRANGEMENTS

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Text: Blaxland-Prime Minister)

Speaker: NA
Text: for - I infonn the House that the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Resources and Tourism, Mr Lee, will be

Speaker: NA
Text: absent from Question Time today.

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition members-Ha, hal

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Text: Opposition members are

Speaker: NA
Text: easily amused.

Speaker: Dr HEWSON
Text: The start of an impeccable

Speaker: NA
Text: career.

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Text: It is terrific that you are

Speaker: NA
Text: amused and feeling happy in opposition. In

Speaker: NA
Text: his absence, questions on resources should be

Speaker: NA
Text: directed to the Minister for Primary Industries

Speaker: NA
Text: and Energy, Mr Crean. Questions on tourism

Speaker: NA
Text: should be directed to the Minister for Indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try, Technology and Regional Development,

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Griffiths.

Speaker: NA
Text: STANDING ORDER 145

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: During my very first

Speaker: NA
Text: question period as Speaker on 5 May 1993

Speaker: NA
Text: the matter of standing order 145 in respect of

Speaker: NA
Text: the relevance of an answer to a question

Speaker: NA
Text: without notice was raised. It had been raised

Speaker: NA
Text: frequently during the previous Parliament. On

Speaker: NA
Text: 10 May I was asked questions by both the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable members for Moncrieff and Curtin

Speaker: NA
Text: on the same issue and indicated that I would

Speaker: NA
Text: be considering the matter and making a

Speaker: NA
Text: statement to the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: Standing order 145 is the only standing

Speaker: NA
Text: order which deals specifically with an answer

Speaker: NA
Text: to a question without notice. It provides

Speaker: NA
Text: simply:

Speaker: NA
Text: An answer shall be relevant to the question.

Speaker: NA
Text: As indicated in House of Representatives

Speaker: NA
Text: Practice, the Standing Orders and practice of

Speaker: NA
Text: the House have been criticised in that restric-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions similar to those applying to the fonn

Speaker: NA
Text: and content of questions do not apply to

Speaker: NA
Text: answers. Although it has been argued that the

Speaker: NA
Text: provision in standing order 144 which pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vides that questions cannot be debated should

Speaker: NA
Text: be read as meaning a prohibition of debate in

Speaker: NA
Text: answering, as well as in putting, a question,

Speaker: NA
Text: it has not been so interpreted by the Chair.

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives Practice goes on

Speaker: NA
Text: to say that the latitude pennitted to Ministers

Speaker: NA
Text: has often been quite considerable in the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives. Speakers have

Speaker: NA
Text: ruled consistently that, provided an answer is

Speaker: NA
Text: relevant and is not couched in unparliamen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tary language, Ministers may answer ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions without notice in virtually any way they

Speaker: NA
Text: choose. The interpretation of 'relevant' has at

Speaker: NA
Text: times been very wide. In practice the word

Speaker: NA
Text: has been frequently accepted by the Chair as

Speaker: NA
Text: meaning relevant in some way, or relevant in

Speaker: NA
Text: part, rather than directly or completely rel-

Speaker: NA
Text: evant.

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives Practice records

Speaker: NA
Text: that there have been occasions when Ministers

Speaker: NA
Text: have been asked to resume their seats as their

Speaker: NA
Text: answers have not been relevant. The Chair

Speaker: NA
Text: has also held that a Minister 'should not

Speaker: NA
Text: engage in irrelevancies' such as contrasting

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government and the Opposition. Past

Speaker: NA
Text: Speakers have directed a Minister so doing

Speaker: NA
Text: not to proceed, although on many other

Speaker: NA
Text: occasions such comments have been permit-

Speaker: NA
Text: ted.

Speaker: NA
Text: In view of the foregoing, I propose to allow

Speaker: NA
Text: references to subjects over which Ministers do

Speaker: NA
Text: not exercise direct control but which may

Speaker: NA
Text: impact upon their area of responsibility: for

Speaker: NA
Text: example, comments on the foreign policy of

Speaker: NA
Text: another nation, comments on the international

Speaker: NA
Text: economic situation, and references to opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion attitude where appropriate. The House

Speaker: NA
Text: itself could take some initiative in this matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Standing Committee on Procedure in

Speaker: NA
Text: both 1986 and 1992 made recommendations

Speaker: NA
Text: in respect of standing order 145. In 1992 the

Speaker: NA
Text: report recommended that the standing order

Speaker: NA
Text: should be amended to read:

Speaker: NA
Text: The answer to a question without notice:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) shall be concise and confined to the subject

Speaker: NA
Text: matter of the question; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) shall not debate the subject to which the

Speaker: NA
Text: question refers.

Speaker: NA
Text: An answer to a question on notice shall be relevant

Speaker: NA
Text: to the question".

Speaker: NA
Text: Passage of this recommendation would con-

Speaker: NA
Text: fine answers to questions more than the

Speaker: NA
Text: practice I have enunciated and which I have

Speaker: NA
Text: indicated current Standing Orders effectively

Speaker: NA
Text: oblige me to pursue. In the absence of any

Speaker: NA
Text: action, the Chair is left in the position that it

Speaker: NA
Text: has to be guided to a large extent by the

Speaker: NA
Text: practice that has developed in the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, I have to say that I will be

Speaker: NA
Text: looking to Ministers to be more relevant than

Speaker: NA
Text: they have been on some occasions in the past.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would hope that the experience of the last

Speaker: NA
Text: two sitting weeks, when an average of about

Speaker: NA
Text: 14 questions was asked each day, will con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinue. In this regard, I intend to adopt the

Speaker: NA
Text: practice of earlier Speakers who, on a number

Speaker: NA
Text: of occasions, invited Ministers to wind up

Speaker: NA
Text: lengthy answers. By the same token, I would

Speaker: NA
Text: suggest that points of order and interjections

Speaker: NA
Text: do not encourage Ministers to wind up their

Speaker: NA
Text: answers; on the contrary, they tend to prolong

Speaker: NA
Text: the answers.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have been aware of changing community

Speaker: NA
Text: perceptions in relation to Question Time,

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly since it has been televised live.

Speaker: NA
Text: As citizens of Australia expect that Question

Speaker: NA
Text: Time will provide an insight into the current

Speaker: NA
Text: issues facing the nation, I hope to facilitate

Speaker: NA
Text: that process and I seek the cooperation of all

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable members in attempting so to do.

Speaker: NA
Text: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE

Speaker: NA
Text: Income Tax Cuts

Speaker: Mr DOWNER
Text: I direct my question to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer. I refer the Treasurer to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's Budget problems, which are

Speaker: NA
Text: well known, and ask: will the Treasurer give

Speaker: NA
Text: a categorical assurance that the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: is still committed to providing the One Nation

Speaker: NA
Text: income tax cuts?

Speaker: Mr DAWKINS
Text: The Government has no

Speaker: NA
Text: intention of rescinding the provisions which

Speaker: NA
Text: were put in the tax scales last year. That was

Speaker: NA
Text: said at the time; I repeat it now.

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget Deficit

Speaker: Mr SWAN
Text: My question is directed to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer. Has the Treasurer's attention been

Speaker: NA
Text: drawn to media reports of calls for rapid and

Speaker: NA
Text: radical action to move the Budget towards

Speaker: NA
Text: surplus? Can the Treasurer infonn the House

Speaker: NA
Text: of practical differences between a rapid and

Speaker: NA
Text: radical approach and a medium-tenn ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: proach?

Speaker: Mr DAWKINS
Text: I have seen some discus-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion in the media about these apparently

Speaker: NA
Text: various calls for a rapid and radical series of

Speaker: NA
Text: actions to move the Budget towards surplus.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have also seen other reports embracing the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's view that in repairing the

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget we should approach it on the basis of

Speaker: NA
Text: a medium-term strategy.

Speaker: NA
Text: I notice that most of the claims about the

Speaker: NA
Text: need for a rapid and radical approach have

Speaker: NA
Text: come either from the Opposition itself or from

Speaker: NA
Text: various of its diminishing cheer squad outside

Speaker: NA
Text: this place-most particularly, the renowned

Speaker: NA
Text: Des Moore of the Institute of Public Affairs.

Speaker: NA
Text: In fact, Des Moore seems to be about the

Speaker: NA
Text: only outside commentator who is proposing

Speaker: NA
Text: this rapid and radical approach. A number of

Speaker: NA
Text: other professional economists, other commen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tators, have actually said that it would be

Speaker: NA
Text: counterproductive for us to follow the pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: scriptions as proposed by Mr Moore and

Speaker: NA
Text: apparently sometimes embraced by the Oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition. The reason is that to take this radical

Speaker: NA
Text: and rapid action would be counterproductive

Speaker: NA
Text: to the requirements of economic policy at the

Speaker: NA
Text: moment.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government took a very deliberate

Speaker: NA
Text: decision last year, both in the One Nation

Speaker: NA
Text: context and in the Budget, to provide a fiscal

Speaker: NA
Text: stimulus in order to promote economic recov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ery in this country. That process is still

Speaker: NA
Text: place. It was always the Government's inten-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, as was spelled out on both of those

Speaker: NA
Text: occasions, that following the economic stimu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lus provided by those measures it would be

Speaker: NA
Text: moving the deficit down to a point where it

Speaker: NA
Text: reached about one per cent of GDP by the

Speaker: NA
Text: 1996-97 financial year.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have already said that the prospective

Speaker: NA
Text: deficit for next year could be as high as $18

Speaker: NA
Text: billion if no action were taken. I have also

Speaker: NA
Text: said that the deficit for next year should be

Speaker: NA
Text: around the level of that in prospect for this

Speaker: NA
Text: year. So what that means is that the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment is firmly fixed on that medium-term

Speaker: NA
Text: strategy-a strategy which has been embraced

Speaker: NA
Text: by people such as the Chief Economist for

Speaker: NA
Text: Legal and General, Mr Jolly from Syntec and

Speaker: NA
Text: even Mr Truglia from Moodys.

Speaker: NA
Text: The process of going towards that medium-

Speaker: NA
Text: term objective will commence in this Budget

Speaker: NA
Text: round as the Government examines both

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure reductions and the revenue side

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Budget in order to make a credible start

Speaker: NA
Text: on the achievement of that objective. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: important to understand that Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: members do not have a clue about any of

Speaker: NA
Text: these issues. They are confused amongst

Speaker: NA
Text: themselves and, indeed, even individual

Speaker: NA
Text: spokespersons for the Opposition are saying

Speaker: NA
Text: entirely contradictory things.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think the message from all this was

Speaker: NA
Text: perhaps best spelt out when the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition was asked whether, in making his

Speaker: NA
Text: criticisms of the Government, he had some

Speaker: NA
Text: higher responsibility towards the national

Speaker: NA
Text: interest. Of course, he denied that he did. He

Speaker: NA
Text: said, 'We tried that and it failed'. So the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition is now firmly into the business of

Speaker: NA
Text: irresponsible opposition, internally inconsis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tent opposition. It is clear from what the

Speaker: NA
Text: person asking this question has said in just

Speaker: NA
Text: the last few days. He said that we should cut

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure on the one hand and increase

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure on the other hand. Whilst propos-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing those two measures, he is suggesting that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition has its own candidates for

Speaker: NA
Text: increased expenditure. When asked how to

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Text: a fact that, using his own estimates, the Gov-

Text: year-I will repeat that: $8 to $10 billion per

Speaker: NA
Text: year-in extra revenue before its proposed tax

Speaker: NA
Text: cuts to fulfil its commitment to reduce the

Speaker: NA
Text: deficit to one per cent of GOP by 1996-977

Speaker: NA
Text: Is it also a fact that the tax cuts he has prom-

Speaker: NA
Text: ised will reduce government revenue by $16

Speaker: NA
Text: billion by 1996-977

Speaker: Mr DAWKINS
Text: Once again, we have the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition doing what only it can do, and

Text: that is to speculate about what might be the

Text: consequences of certain policy initiatives. The

Speaker: NA
Text: in family allowance-

Speaker: Mr HOWARD

Text: it-

Speaker: NA
Text: Shipbuilding

Speaker: Mr STEPHEN SMITH
Text: My question is

Speaker: NA
Text: directed to the Minister for Industry, Technol-

Speaker: NA
Text: ogy and Regional Development. What action

Speaker: NA
Text: has the Minister taken to encourage the

Speaker: NA
Text: development of the Australian shipbuilding

Speaker: NA
Text: industry? Can the Minister also inform the

Speaker: NA
Text: House about the impact of this action on the

Speaker: NA
Text: industry in Western Australia?

Speaker: Mr GRIFFITHS
Text: I thank the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Perth for his question. Shipbuild-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing is an extremely important industry in

Speaker: NA
Text: Western Australia, as it is in the rest of the

Speaker: NA
Text: country. This particular industry is without

Speaker: NA
Text: doubt one of Australia's manufacturing

Speaker: NA
Text: success stories. The industry has changed

Speaker: NA
Text: since the 1970s when it was characterised by

Speaker: NA
Text: industrial unrest, high levels of government

Speaker: NA
Text: support and the production of large steel

Speaker: NA
Text: vessels for a declining international market.

Speaker: NA
Text: Today the industry is a major export earner,

Speaker: NA
Text: specialising in products for niche markets.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some producers are already recognised as

Speaker: NA
Text: world leaders due to their innovative approach

Speaker: NA
Text: to design and production technology. The next

Speaker: NA
Text: two years promise to be years of strong

Speaker: NA
Text: export growth coupled with increased employ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment for the industry. The value of vessels

Speaker: NA
Text: expected to be completed by shipbuilders this

Speaker: NA
Text: year is nearly $300 million, which is about

Speaker: NA
Text: double the industry outcome of the previous

Speaker: NA
Text: year.

Speaker: NA
Text: By way of contrast, the Opposition would

Speaker: NA
Text: have had that perfonnance under considerable

Speaker: NA
Text: threat by removing any semblance of govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment assistance for the industry. The Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, however, believes that Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: shipbuilders deserve at least the same level of

Speaker: NA
Text: backing from government as other Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: manufacturers get while they tackle the

Speaker: NA
Text: challenges before them. The industry's ability

Speaker: NA
Text: to successfully respond is best illustrated by

Speaker: NA
Text: the reputation for quality and perfonnance

Speaker: NA
Text: enjoyed by companies such as Oceanfast,

Speaker: NA
Text: Austral and Wavemaster in Perth, Incat in

Speaker: NA
Text: Tasmania, and NQEA and Lloyds in Queens-

Speaker: NA
Text: land.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am pleased to be able to advise the House

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Government will legislate to extend

Speaker: NA
Text: the bounty in line with general manufacturing

Speaker: NA
Text: tariffs from 1 July 1993. To honour the

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment made by the Prime Minister in

Speaker: NA
Text: the course of the election campaign, we will

Speaker: NA
Text: introduce the legislation into the Parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: tomorrow. The cost of this assistance-I

Speaker: NA
Text: regard it more as an investment-will be

Speaker: NA
Text: $43.8 million over four years. In order to

Speaker: NA
Text: pursue further some of the associated issues

Speaker: NA
Text: in the industry, next week I will be visiting

Speaker: NA
Text: shipyards in Western Australia-with the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Perth-and Queens-

Speaker: NA
Text: land to see for myself the leading edge of this

Speaker: NA
Text: new industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: Government Finances

Speaker: Dr HEWSON
Text: My question is directed to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Treasurer, and again it is in the national

Speaker: NA
Text: interest. I ask the Treasurer: given the inde-

Speaker: NA
Text: pendent findings of the Auditor-General that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government has financial obligations of

Speaker: NA
Text: at least $127 billion against liquid assets of

Speaker: NA
Text: just $57 billion, how can he justify trying to

Speaker: NA
Text: fund the Government's debts by bludging on

Speaker: NA
Text: the future of our children?

Speaker: Mr DAWKINS
Text: Of course this discloses

Speaker: NA
Text: the absolute irresponsibility of the Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition, because he knows just how

Speaker: NA
Text: wrong and conceptually inaccurate this report

Speaker: NA
Text: is. He knows that, and yet he is proposing to

Speaker: NA
Text: continue to highlight these entirely inaccurate

Speaker: NA
Text: propositions. On 13 April my department was

Speaker: NA
Text: asked to comment on this report and, amongst

Speaker: NA
Text: other things, the department indicated the

Speaker: NA
Text: following to the authors of the report:

Speaker: NA
Text: I particularly draw your attention to the statement

Speaker: NA
Text: in the first paragraph of the draft report which

Speaker: NA
Text: carries a clear implication that the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: may not be able to meet its obligations in the

Speaker: NA
Text: future. This is unwarranted, unprofessional and

Speaker: NA
Text: irresponsible.

Speaker: NA
Text: Whilst to some extent the authors toned down

Speaker: NA
Text: the paragraph in question, they left the clear

Speaker: NA
Text: impression that the Commonwealth might

Speaker: NA
Text: have some difficulties in meeting its future

Speaker: NA
Text: obligations. This is untrue. The Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition knows it is untrue, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: authors-if they were properly qualified, if

Speaker: NA
Text: they were capable of dealing with the is-

Speaker: NA
Text: sues-would have known so as well.

Speaker: NA
Text: The responsibility for drawing together a

Speaker: NA
Text: government response to this report rests with

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for Finance, and I am sure that

Speaker: NA
Text: if the Leader of the Opposition were to ask

Speaker: NA
Text: him further questions about this he would be

Speaker: NA
Text: only too happy to respond. I would make this

Speaker: NA
Text: observation: the burden of this report is all

Speaker: NA
Text: about the need to disclose the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth's financial obligations-the need for

Speaker: NA
Text: disclosure. What, on this central topic, is the

Speaker: NA
Text: conclusion and recommendation of this

Speaker: NA
Text: report? This report says at recommendation

Speaker: NA
Text: The ANAO recommends that the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: continues to develop plans for the introduction of

Speaker: NA
Text: whole of government reporting on an accrual basis

Speaker: NA
Text: with a view to implementing whole of government

Speaker: NA
Text: reporting by the end of the 1994-95 financial year.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is precisely what the Government is

Speaker: NA
Text: doing. Indeed, the Minister for Finance, in a

Speaker: NA
Text: statement he made last year, announced that

Speaker: NA
Text: we were moving in that direction. It is one

Speaker: NA
Text: thing for the Auditor-General and his

Speaker: NA
Text: authors-in this case, Warren, Lynne, Mal-

Speaker: NA
Text: colm and Susi-to draw attention to issues of

Speaker: NA
Text: importance to the public, but it should be

Speaker: NA
Text: noted that the infonnation in this report is

Speaker: NA
Text: public infonnation. It is drawn from public

Speaker: NA
Text: information largely available within the

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget. If the Auditor-General believes that

Speaker: NA
Text: that infonnation should be presented in a

Speaker: NA
Text: different way, he is entitled to say so. All that

Speaker: NA
Text: the authors are saying on this occasi()n is that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government should proceed with its

Speaker: NA
Text: already announced plans about the presenta-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of this infonnation. In the words of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasury, it is neither warranted, professional

Speaker: NA
Text: nor responsible for the Auditor-General or

Speaker: NA
Text: those in his office to raise speculation that

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth is unable to meet its emerging

Speaker: NA
Text: financial obligations. This morning one of the

Speaker: NA
Text: authors was asked:

Speaker: NA
Text: Does this mean that the Commonwealth is techni-

Speaker: NA
Text: cally insolvent?

Speaker: NA
Text: And she said:

Speaker: NA
Text: No, certainly not.

Speaker: NA
Text: She went on to say:

Speaker: NA
Text: We also have not taken into account in the report

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth's power to tax, which of course

Speaker: NA
Text: should always ensure that the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: remains solvent.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is hardly an irrelevant point that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth in every Budget makes the

Speaker: NA
Text: decision about the extent to which it will

Speaker: NA
Text: borrow, the extent to which it will pay back,

Speaker: NA
Text: and the extent to which it will balance its

Speaker: NA
Text: recurrent and future obligations. It is hardly

Speaker: NA
Text: a small point that the Commonwealth, unlike

Speaker: NA
Text: a private business, does have the power to tax

Speaker: NA
Text: and does have the power to arrange the

Speaker: NA
Text: finances of the Commonwealth as suits the

Speaker: NA
Text: economic circumstances of the time. So there

Speaker: NA
Text: are some conceptual inaccuracies in this

Speaker: NA
Text: report, and I am quite sure the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Finance will be pointing out those problems

Speaker: NA
Text: and inaccuracies in the response that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth will make to this report.

Speaker: NA
Text: Government Programs

Speaker: Mr CLEELAND
Text: I direct my question to something

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister. Has the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: seen reports that the Opposition intends

Speaker: NA
Text: oppose government reforms and legislative

Speaker: NA
Text: changes as an act of vengeance for losing the

Speaker: NA
Text: so-called unlosable 13 March election? Can

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister say what effects such a

Speaker: NA
Text: policy would have on the delivery of governreally

Speaker: NA
Text: ment programs and whether it would impede

Speaker: NA
Text: the democratic right of the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: fulfil its mandate?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Tim Fischer- Mr Speaker, I take a

Speaker: NA
Text: point of order in respect of the question from

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member for MCEwen. The

Speaker: NA
Text: second part of his question falls well outside

Speaker: NA
Text: the responsibility of the Prime Minister as

Speaker: NA
Text: relates to the Opposition in pure and simple

Speaker: NA
Text: form and as such should be ruled out

Speaker: NA
Text: order.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: No, there is no point of

Speaker: NA
Text: the order. The question was clearly in order in

Speaker: NA
Text: that it asked for the Prime Minister to talk

Speaker: NA
Text: about the Government.

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Text: I must say I was very

Speaker: NA
Text: surprised to hear the Leader of the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: saying that the Opposition would be 'very

Speaker: NA
Text: revengeful'. He said the Government would

Speaker: NA
Text: be-and he repeated it-revengeful.

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition members-The Government?

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Text: No, the Opposition would

Speaker: NA
Text: be 'very revengeful'. That is what he said.

Speaker: NA
Text: Revenge is a politically very violent word and

Speaker: NA
Text: one that I would have thought the Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition would. have done well to have

Speaker: NA
Text: stayed away from. Why does he wish to be

Speaker: NA
Text: revengeful? The answer is because he was

Speaker: NA
Text: rejected by the Australian people, because he

Speaker: NA
Text: lost the election his party said was unlosable.

Speaker: NA
Text: So now he will sit back and sulk and sabotage

Speaker: NA
Text: public policy to be, as he put it, revengeful.

Speaker: NA
Text: In a recent interview he said, 'Our job now

Speaker: NA
Text: is to oppose'. So this is the Opposition we

Speaker: NA
Text: have, an Opposition which says its lot in life

Speaker: NA
Text: is to oppose and be revengeful. That is no

Speaker: NA
Text: exaggeration-it is a direct quote: your job is

Speaker: NA
Text: to oppose and be revengeful. And why, if not

Speaker: NA
Text: simply to straighten up the public for reject-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing him? He said in the book which is written

Speaker: NA
Text: by Ms Wallace:

Speaker: NA
Text: If we can't win by doing what's right there is

Speaker: NA
Text: fundamentally wrong with Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: The country is wrong, not him. He has been

Speaker: NA
Text: to put back in his place. What is his motive

Speaker: NA
Text: now? Revenge; to be revengeful; to oppose.

Speaker: NA
Text: His new contribution to Australian political

Speaker: NA
Text: leadership is to be revengeful and to oppose.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is the person who told us he was not

Speaker: NA
Text: a political figure; he was a consultant

Speaker: NA
Text: who was hired to give Australia good public

Speaker: NA
Text: to policy and he would not worry about the

Speaker: NA
Text: political impacts of these things. But one

Speaker: NA
Text: democratic judgment by the electorate and he

Speaker: NA
Text: sulks back to the recesses of the darkness of

Speaker: NA
Text: the liberal mind, to be what? To be revenge-

Speaker: NA
Text: ful and to oppose. We are seeing this in the

Speaker: NA
Text: it irresponsibility which the Treasurer referred

Speaker: NA
Text: to in what has already been the rejection of a

Speaker: NA
Text: of number of measures for which the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment had a clear and specific mandate in the

Speaker: NA
Text: election. Let me just infonn the House that

Speaker: NA
Text: the income test free area for jobsearch,

Speaker: NA
Text: newstart and sickness allowance-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Ruddock-Taking pensioners out of

Speaker: NA
Text: the tax system.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Order!

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Ruddock-Well, he did, Mr Speaker.

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Text: You are heading for your

Speaker: NA
Text: second 20 years in opposition. The introducWhole

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of an earned income-free area of $30

Speaker: NA
Text: fortnight for single people, and an increase in Minister-

Speaker: NA
Text: Members' and Senators: Ethics

Speaker: Mr MACK
Text: I direct my question to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister. I refer to the working group

Speaker: NA
Text: convened in the 36th Parliament by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker and the President· of the Senate to

Speaker: NA
Text: draw up ethical guidelines for members and

Speaker: NA
Text: senators. Is it the intention of the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister to continue this initiative? Is he March 1990.

Speaker: NA
Text: aware of the recent recommendations on

Speaker: NA
Text: ethics by a committee of the .Queensland

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament and the decision of the Goss

Speaker: NA
Text: Government to establish in legislation mandathe

Speaker: NA
Text: tory ethical codes for both parliamentarians

Speaker: NA
Text: and public serVants? Will the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that the ethics working group of this

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament is reconvened and that its scope

Speaker: NA
Text: extended to include the conduct of public

Speaker: NA
Text: servants?

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Text: On the latter point, I am

Speaker: NA
Text: not certain whether any issue that has arisen

Speaker: NA
Text: of recent times reflects upon the conduct of

Speaker: NA
Text: public servants in terms of ethics. Be that as

Speaker: NA
Text: it may, I am quite happy to see the Parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: continue to look at the question of ethics in

Speaker: NA
Text: this cycle. Perhaps we could start by having

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the Opposition in the Senate

Speaker: NA
Text: with the rest of the Parliament in tabling their

Speaker: NA
Text: interests, so that at least people know where

Speaker: NA
Text: they stand as a point of reference for

Speaker: NA
Text: operation of such a regime. There are many

Speaker: NA
Text: issues involved and I know that the commitWomen's

Speaker: NA
Text: tee has been working on this for some time.

Speaker: NA
Text: No doubt at some appropriate time it will

Speaker: NA
Text: present its report to the Parliament.

Speaker: NA
Text: Parental Leave

Speaker: Ms CRAWFORD
Text: My question is directed

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Can

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister advise the House as to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's intentions in relation to providthe

Speaker: NA
Text: ing Australian workers with an entitlement

Speaker: NA
Text: unpaid parental leave.

Speaker: Mr BRERETON
Text: The honourable member there,

Speaker: NA
Text: will be pleased to know that the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: will introduce legislation guaranteeing the

Speaker: NA
Text: right to unpaid parental leave, as announced

Speaker: NA
Text: during the election campaign. I notice that

Speaker: NA
Text: there have been reports in the press recently

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Government had backed away from

Speaker: NA
Text: that pledge. Whilst the matter does involve

Speaker: NA
Text: some serious and complex legal issues I am

Speaker: NA
Text: able to inform the House that these complexi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties have now been overcome in consultation

Speaker: NA
Text: with the acting Solicitor-General. I can now

Speaker: NA
Text: advise the House that such legislation can be

Speaker: NA
Text: based on the external affairs powers of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Constitution. This will give effect

Speaker: NA
Text: to Australia's obligation as a party to ILO

Speaker: NA
Text: convention 156 ratified by Australia on 30

Speaker: NA
Text: Parental leave allows a parent to leave the

Speaker: NA
Text: work force after the birth of a child to care

Speaker: NA
Text: for the child without having to resign from

Speaker: NA
Text: parent's job. The ILO convention requires

Speaker: NA
Text: government to take measures so that the needs

Speaker: NA
Text: of workers who have family responsibilities

Speaker: NA
Text: are properly taken into account in their terms

Speaker: NA
Text: is and conditions of employment. The conven-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion also requires, I am able to inform the

Speaker: NA
Text: House, governments to take measures to

Speaker: NA
Text: enable those workers to re-enter the labour

Speaker: NA
Text: force after an absence caused by their family

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibilities. The legislation guaranteeing

Speaker: NA
Text: parental leave will therefore be a very import-

Speaker: NA
Text: ant part of the Government's comprehensive

Speaker: NA
Text: strategy for implementing its ILO obligations.

Speaker: NA
Text: In developing the legislation, there will be

Speaker: NA
Text: join detailed discussions with the States and

Speaker: NA
Text: Territories, employer and union bodies, and

Speaker: NA
Text: other interested groups. Yesterday I was able

Speaker: NA
Text: the to give an assurance of the Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment to legislate in this area to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Electoral Lobby. I will now be

Speaker: NA
Text: refining the details with the Minister Assisting

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister for the Status of Women,

Speaker: NA
Text: as well as discussing arrangements for further

Speaker: NA
Text: consultation with women about industrial

Speaker: NA
Text: relations change.

Speaker: NA
Text: Investment

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr -DOWNER-My question is directed to

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer. I remind the Treasurer of the

Speaker: NA
Text: to Prime Minister's statements in the election

Speaker: NA
Text: campaign: 'investment is picking up', 'sitting

Speaker: NA
Text: $130 billion of registered investment',

Speaker: NA
Text: 'all about to move like a big avalanche'. I

Speaker: NA
Text: also refer the Treasurer to today's disastrous

Speaker: NA
Text: private capital expenditure figures showing a

Speaker: NA
Text: 10 per cent real fall in equipment expenditure

Speaker: NA
Text: in just one quarter. Is this the big avalanche

Speaker: NA
Text: which the Prime Minister had in mind, or is

Speaker: NA
Text: this just another one of Labor's avalanche of

Speaker: NA
Text: broken promises that the Prime Minister has

Speaker: NA
Text: become the superstar of!

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr DAWKlNS'-Once again the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Mayo reveals the paucity of

Speaker: NA
Text: his understanding of some of the weighty

Speaker: NA
Text: issues which he is supposed to be able to deal

Speaker: NA
Text: with. Of course, I have seen the investment

Speaker: NA
Text: figures as revealed by the ABS today. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: true that they do reveal a fall from a very

Speaker: NA
Text: high rise a quarter ago.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the most elementary things which

Speaker: NA
Text: any aspiring shadow Treasurer should under-

Speaker: NA
Text: stand is the danger in making assessments on

Speaker: NA
Text: the basis of one month's or even one quarter's

Speaker: NA
Text: figures. Also, any aspiring shadow Treasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: should realise and not discount that there is

Speaker: NA
Text: an element of responsibility involved in not

Speaker: NA
Text: immediately assuming that the country is

Speaker: NA
Text: confronting massive gloom on the basis of

Speaker: NA
Text: one quarter's investment figures.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government is looking forward to an

Speaker: NA
Text: improvement in investment perfonnance in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia and, indeed, it will be an essential

Speaker: NA
Text: part of the recovery as it strengthens. When

Speaker: NA
Text: that happens will depend on decisions of the

Speaker: NA
Text: private sector, bearing in mind that there is

Speaker: NA
Text: very strong productivity growth being record-

Speaker: NA
Text: ed in the Australian economy at the moment,

Speaker: NA
Text: which in a way serves to postpone in some

Speaker: NA
Text: businesses the need for additional capital

Speaker: NA
Text: investment.

Speaker: NA
Text: But that is an entirely different point to

Speaker: NA
Text: point that the Prime Minister was making

Speaker: NA
Text: about investment projects down the track, as

Speaker: NA
Text: revealed by applications for the development

Speaker: NA
Text: allowance. That was about applications for the

Speaker: NA
Text: allowance which had to be in by the end of

Speaker: NA
Text: December last year. It was not about invest-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in the last quarter or even in the next

Speaker: NA
Text: quarter; it was about investment which was

Speaker: NA
Text: going to take place over the next several

Speaker: NA
Text: years in order to qualify for the investment

Speaker: NA
Text: allowance.

Speaker: NA
Text: I will be publishing the latest report of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Development Allowance Authority which will

Speaker: NA
Text: spell out, in more detail than the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister was able to before the election, the

Speaker: NA
Text: scheduling of that investment. What it will

Speaker: NA
Text: reveal is just how solid those investment

Speaker: NA
Text: proposals are as proposed by the corporations

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australia which have applied for the

Speaker: NA
Text: development allowance.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would have thought that this is not an

Speaker: NA
Text: occasion for the Opposition, and particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: the shadow Treasurer, simply to be latching

Speaker: NA
Text: onto any negative statistic and producing this

Speaker: NA
Text: as evidence of poor perfonnance in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian economy. Rather one would have

Speaker: NA
Text: thought that the Opposition would have been

Speaker: NA
Text: pleased to play its part in indicating what

Speaker: NA
Text: great promise there is in Australia and what

Speaker: NA
Text: great promise has been identified by a large

Speaker: NA
Text: number of corporations in Australia which are

Speaker: NA
Text: prepared to commit billions of dollars towards

Speaker: NA
Text: the development of this great country.

Speaker: NA
Text: .Youth Initiatives

Speaker: Mr ADAMS
Text: My question is addressed to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for Employment, Education and

Speaker: NA
Text: Training. We are coming up to the anniversa-

Speaker: NA
Text: ry of the youth summit. Can the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: infonn the House of progress in the imple-

Speaker: NA
Text: mentation of youth summit initiatives?

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Text: Yes, I can do that for the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member. Under the package we

Speaker: NA
Text: expected that by the end of this year some

Speaker: NA
Text: 96,300 places in a mixture of programs will

Speaker: NA
Text: be provided for young people and we are well

Speaker: NA
Text: on track in achieving that target. There are

Speaker: NA
Text: some notable features of it that are worth the

Speaker: NA
Text: consideration of the House,· particularly in the

Speaker: NA
Text: area of apprentices and trainees. There has

Speaker: NA
Text: the been a rise of some 16 per cent in apprentice-

Speaker: NA
Text: ships in the period July 1992 to March 1993

Speaker: NA
Text: above the equivalent period the year before.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the case of traineeships for the same period

Speaker: NA
Text: there has been a lift of some 94 per cent over

Speaker: NA
Text: the previous period. So almost 17,500 unem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployed apprentices and apprentices at risk of

Speaker: NA
Text: losing their jobs have been helped through

Speaker: NA
Text: special assistance measures.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another program, the landcare and environ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment action program, was slated for some

Speaker: NA
Text: 6,000 places by the end of 1993. It has

Speaker: NA
Text: proved so popular that we expect that be-

Speaker: NA
Text: tween 10,000 and 11,000 young people will

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit in the course of this year. In the youth

Speaker: NA
Text: career and infonnation advice program we

Speaker: NA
Text: have had some 60,000 young people take

Speaker: NA
Text: advantage of opportunities for career advice.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some 3,000 students and over 1,600 trainees

Speaker: NA
Text: have now signed up in some 100 pilot pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: grams associated with the new vocational

Speaker: NA
Text: certificate program.

Speaker: NA
Text: Since the youth summit in July 1992 the

Speaker: NA
Text: number of 15to 19-year-olds unemployed

Speaker: NA
Text: and looking for full-time work has fallen by

Speaker: NA
Text: some 16,300, a reduction of 12.2 per cent,

Speaker: NA
Text: and the proportion of teenagers who are full-

Speaker: NA
Text: time unemployed has fallen from 10.1 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent to nine per cent. There are now 41,000

Speaker: NA
Text: fewer unemployed teenagers than when Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: came to office, and the proportion of teenag-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers unemployed has fallen from 12.3 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: to nine per cent. Of course, one cannot say

Speaker: NA
Text: from of any of these statistics that the job

Speaker: NA
Text: been completed, but they are a pretty fair

Speaker: NA
Text: indication that the objectives set by the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister in the youth summit that he organ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ised have, to a very substantial degree, been

Speaker: NA
Text: met.

Speaker: NA
Text: Trans-Tasman Shipping

Speaker: Mr SHARP
Text: My question is directed to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister. I remind the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister that' he has identified micro-

Speaker: NA
Text: economic refonn as one of his Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: highest priorities. I also remind him that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Business Council has identified the

Speaker: NA
Text: scrapping of the expensive and illegal trade

Speaker: NA
Text: union restrictions on Trans-Tasman shipping

Speaker: NA
Text: as one of the highest priorities for micro-

Speaker: NA
Text: economic reform. What did the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister do about fixing this during his trip

Speaker: NA
Text: to New Zealand last week? Does the illegal

Speaker: NA
Text: union agreement still stand?

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Text: One has to have a lot of

Speaker: NA
Text: front to come from the Opposition and talk

Speaker: NA
Text: about the maritime industries of this country,

Speaker: NA
Text: because every bad habit, every bit of sclerosis

Speaker: NA
Text: that was in the waterfront and in the oper-

Speaker: NA
Text: ations of the shipping services around this

Speaker: NA
Text: country, was there over the 30-odd years that

Speaker: NA
Text: the coalition was in office. It was quite happy

Speaker: NA
Text: to let the P&Os of this world run the place

Speaker: NA
Text: with a spare pool of labour that belonged to

Speaker: NA
Text: no-one in particular but cost everyone in

Speaker: NA
Text: general, and it was quite happy for this to be

Speaker: NA
Text: a dead hand upon Australia. But all of a

Speaker: NA
Text: sudden when this Government arrived it was

Speaker: NA
Text: all our job to fix. Of course, largely fix it we

Speaker: NA
Text: have, with a turnaround time now for contain-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers in Sydney comparable to ports such as

Speaker: NA
Text: Rotterdam, a 50 per cent decline in the

Speaker: NA
Text: number of people in the waterfront in the last

Speaker: NA
Text: 12 months, and now DECO levels on crew

Speaker: NA
Text: manning on Australian ships that have fallen

Speaker: NA
Text: from around 30 crew per vessel to 21 and

Speaker: NA
Text: heading for 19. The problem of uncompetitive

Speaker: NA
Text: shipping services has been repaired· at source

Speaker: NA
Text: by dealing with the structure of the manning

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australian line vessels, and the result is

Speaker: NA
Text: that they are eminently more competitive.

Speaker: NA
Text: Need I say that as a result of these develop-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments we are also seeing other services. There

Speaker: NA
Text: are ones now not just from Melbourne and

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney to New Zealand but one from Bris-

Speaker: NA
Text: has bane to New Zealand and, as a consequence,

Speaker: NA
Text: we are seeing a more competitive structure

Speaker: NA
Text: come into place.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Sharp-What about the Trans-Tasman

Speaker: NA
Text: accord?

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Text: The honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Hume asks about, as he puts it, the Trans-

Speaker: NA
Text: Tasman accord. The Government has no bar

Speaker: NA
Text: on anyone using a ship anywhere in the

Speaker: NA
Text: country. If a shipper wants to use a service

Speaker: NA
Text: other than the current services, then he will.

Speaker: NA
Text: But he probably will not, and will not need

Speaker: NA
Text: to, while ever we are seeing a substantial shift

Speaker: NA
Text: in the competitiveness of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: maritime fleet.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Sharp-Come on, come on. That's not

Speaker: NA
Text: the answer.

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Text: That is the answer. That

Speaker: NA
Text: is the answer that matters.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Sharp-You didn't do anything about

Speaker: NA
Text: it.

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Text: The Opposition did

Speaker: NA
Text: nothing about the whole industry for 30 years.

Speaker: NA
Text: Members of the Opposition have some front;

Speaker: NA
Text: they really have. They sat there with this

Speaker: NA
Text: clogged up waterfront, with a pool of labour

Speaker: NA
Text: which was not even company hired, which

Speaker: NA
Text: had loyalties to no-one in particular and was

Speaker: NA
Text: a general cost to the whole waterfront. They

Speaker: NA
Text: saw the stevedoring companies and the unions

Speaker: NA
Text: playoff the shippers like a break, and what

Speaker: NA
Text: did they do about all those years when the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Bennelong was

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer or, dare I say it, when the Leader

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Opposition was his adviser? Did we

Speaker: NA
Text: ever see any changes from them? No, it took

Speaker: NA
Text: a bit of ticker, a little bit of intellect-in

Speaker: NA
Text: short, a bit of courage-to do something

Speaker: NA
Text: about it. The coalition did not do anything

Speaker: NA
Text: about it, and it was never able to. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: I am quite sure the conservative party in New

Speaker: NA
Text: Zealand holds this Opposition in the general

Speaker: NA
Text: contempt we hold it in.

Speaker: NA
Text: Energy Efficiency

Speaker: Mr TANNER
Text: I direct my question to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy.

Speaker: NA
Text: What action is being taken· by the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment to improve energy efficiency in Austral-

Speaker: NA
Text: ia?

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Text: I thank the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for his question. The House may be

Speaker: NA
Text: interested to know that Australians spend

Speaker: NA
Text: annually $35 billion on energy in this country,

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Government has an energy manage-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment program that aims to target some $1.5

Speaker: NA
Text: billion per annum in savings through more

Speaker: NA
Text: efficient management practices. In relation to

Speaker: NA
Text: the way in which we have worked with

Speaker: NA
Text: industry to drive this program, we have

Speaker: NA
Text: undertaken on a cost sharing basis the intro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duction of industry audits that have the

Speaker: NA
Text: potential to yield up to thirtyfold benefits

Speaker: NA
Text: industry from the government subsidy.

Speaker: NA
Text: So far as the community is concerned, we

Speaker: NA
Text: have the Energy.guide that gives indications

Speaker: NA
Text: to consumers as to how they might be more

Speaker: NA
Text: efficient in the management of the way in

Speaker: NA
Text: which they use energy and, more importantly,

Speaker: NA
Text: a recently announced program, the local

Speaker: NA
Text: energy efficiency program, that is funding

Speaker: NA
Text: community responses. I know the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Melbourne has expressed some

Speaker: NA
Text: keen interest in this program. I am pleased

Speaker: NA
Text: about that and I urge other honourable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers in the House to take advantage of it as

Speaker: NA
Text: well.

Speaker: NA
Text: So far as the States are concerned-this is

Speaker: NA
Text: where some of the programs have not taken

Speaker: NA
Text: off as quickly as we would have liked-:-we

Speaker: NA
Text: are seeking to develop, with the States,

Speaker: NA
Text: ratings schemes and codes in relation to

Speaker: NA
Text: houses, house building, appliances and com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mercial buildings. As for renewables, the

Speaker: NA
Text: alternative to the traditional forms of energy

Speaker: NA
Text: production, the House should also be pleased

Speaker: NA
Text: to know that we have developed a series of

Speaker: NA
Text: programs to promote and demonstrate renew-

Speaker: NA
Text: able energy technology where it is cost

Text: effective. I am taking a particular interest in

Speaker: NA
Text: why this area, not only for the efficiency it can

Speaker: NA
Text: yield but also for the industry opportunities

Speaker: NA
Text: and exports that it can develop.

Text: I will have the. opportunity tomorrow to

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: under this scheme. At the ministerial entrance

Speaker: NA
Text: to the House between 10 and 12 tomorrow-I

Text: would again invite all honourable members to

Speaker: NA
Text: National Flag

Speaker: Mr TIM FISCHER
Text: My question is

Speaker: NA
Text: directed to the Prime Minister. I ask whether

Speaker: NA
Text: it is true, as press reports have indicated, that

Speaker: NA
Text: when the Prime Minister was offered an Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian flag at the Sydney Town Hall last year

Speaker: NA
Text: to by RSL President, Brigadier Alf Garland, he

Speaker: NA
Text: said:

Speaker: NA
Text: No good giving it to me, give it back to one of

Speaker: NA
Text: your Pommy mates.

Speaker: NA
Text: What is the Prime Minister's current position

Speaker: NA
Text: on our Australian flag with his stampede for

Speaker: NA
Text: a republic?

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Text: Last year when I was in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Sydney Town Hall with the United States

Speaker: NA
Text: Secretary of Defense, Mr Cheney, walking to

Speaker: NA
Text: a reception in his honour, the President of the

Speaker: NA
Text: RSL jumped from the crowd in the aisle to

Speaker: NA
Text: force on me a flag to make a very lousy

Speaker: NA
Text: political point at the expense of the reception

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Secretary of Defense of the United

Speaker: NA
Text: States. Apparently the Leader of the National

Speaker: NA
Text: Party supports that kind of behaviour.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Ruddock-Of course I would proudly

Speaker: NA
Text: carry the nation's flag.

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Text: Yes, but you do not shove

Speaker: NA
Text: it under the US Defense Secretary's nose

Speaker: NA
Text: when he is bounding around to a reception

Speaker: NA
Text: held in his honour in the Sydney Town Hall.

Speaker: NA
Text: Apparently the Leader of the National Party

Speaker: NA
Text: supports that sort of behaviour. That is why

Speaker: NA
Text: the President of the RSL has become the Alf

Speaker: NA
Text: Garnett of the RSL and why he is held gener-

Speaker: NA
Text: ally, I think, in very low esteem by the RSL

Speaker: NA
Text: community.

Speaker: NA
Text: When Mr Garland came to see me not long

Speaker: NA
Text: after I became Prime Minister and we had the

Speaker: NA
Text: celebrations of the various comniemorative

Speaker: NA
Text: events during 1992, after 50 years-the fall

Speaker: NA
Text: of Singapore, the battle of Kokoda, et cete-

Speaker: NA
Text: ra-one of his requests to me was to pay for

Speaker: NA
Text: him to visit the United Kingdom to go to

Speaker: NA
Text: some ceremony that he said was important to

Speaker: NA
Text: him. The fact is that Mr Garland comes from

Speaker: NA
Text: that area of the RSL where people think the

Speaker: NA
Text: only place you can really hold your head up

Speaker: NA
Text: high is walking down Whitehall-and I have

Speaker: NA
Text: made that very clear to him every time I have

Speaker: NA
Text: seen him.

Speaker: NA
Text: Housing Products: Exports

Speaker: Mr LES SCOTT
Text: Can the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Housing, Local Government and Community

Speaker: NA
Text: Services inform the House of the prospects

Speaker: NA
Text: for the export of housing products and ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vices to the Asian markets? What action is the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government taking to develop the export

Speaker: NA
Text: prospects for this industry?

Speaker: Mr HOWE
Text: The issue of potential for

Speaker: NA
Text: exports in relation to the housing industry is

Speaker: NA
Text: a very important one for this Parliament.

Speaker: NA
Text: Progress on the Government's housing export

Speaker: NA
Text: strategy is proceeding strongly on a number

Speaker: NA
Text: of fronts, including support for Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: early involvement in a $1 billion World Bank

Speaker: NA
Text: housing project in China, which could have

Speaker: NA
Text: very important spin-offs for Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: try.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government is also considering the

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed establishment of an industry-govern- Paper.

Speaker: NA
Text: ment joint venture facility in Jakarta, Indo-

Speaker: NA
Text: nesia, to market Australian building product

Speaker: NA
Text: systems technology and training. The fast

Speaker: NA
Text: growing economies of Asia provide signifi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cant market opportunity for housing and

Speaker: NA
Text: related industries to take advantage of

Speaker: NA
Text: disposable incomes and a greater demand

Speaker: NA
Text: which is occurring for quality housing.

Speaker: NA
Text: Our housing industry is very efficient. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: highly skilled but its strong domestic perform-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance simply has not been reflected interna-

Speaker: NA
Text: tionally. The housing industry in Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: represents of the order of five per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: GDP and yet a very small proportion of its

Speaker: NA
Text: product is exported overseas. If one took

Speaker: NA
Text: comparable European countries, the percent-

Speaker: NA
Text: age of their domestic activity which results in

Speaker: NA
Text: export is of the order of 40 per cent-not a

Speaker: NA
Text: very minor percentage as is true in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: We want to work in partnership with industry

Speaker: NA
Text: to change that situation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some Australian firms are already directly

Speaker: NA
Text: involved in a range of overseas projects. For

Speaker: NA
Text: example, apartment complexes in Thailand

Speaker: NA
Text: and Malaysia, a plasterboard factory in Indo-

Speaker: NA
Text: nesia and even the export of bricks and pavers

Speaker: NA
Text: to Japan. In addition, Vietnam wants to

Speaker: NA
Text: develop a national building code based on the

Speaker: NA
Text: building code of Australia, while the Bangkok

Speaker: NA
Text: metropolitan administration is interested in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian assessments in the development of

Speaker: NA
Text: their building regulations.

Speaker: NA
Text: To realise these opportunities, clearly a

Speaker: NA
Text: national strategic approach is required which

Speaker: NA
Text: will draw on the expertise of industry, help

Speaker: NA
Text: companies to grasp early market opportuni-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties, coordinate export activities, better assess

Speaker: NA
Text: the market environments, and promote an

Speaker: NA
Text: understanding of the essentials of success in

Speaker: NA
Text: exporting. I am hoping to an,nounce the

Speaker: NA
Text: details of Australia's export strategy in rela-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to housing in August. It is important that

Speaker: NA
Text: we take this very significant, quite efficient

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian industry and turn it into an export

Speaker: NA
Text: industry as part of a broader approach to the

Speaker: NA
Text: region, where Australia's experience in

Speaker: NA
Text: housing and urban development can translate

Speaker: NA
Text: indusinto very significant export dollars.

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Text: Mr Speaker, I ask that

Speaker: NA
Text: further questions be placed on the l{otice

Text: PRIVILEGE

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Text: O'Connor)- Mr Speaker, I

Speaker: NA
Text: wish to raise a matter of privilege. Today the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer ( Mr Dawkins) read from a letter

Speaker: NA
Text: higher which was sent to the Auditor-General,

Speaker: NA
Text: presumably with the Treasurer's authority, in

Speaker: NA
Text: regard to a report on government debt pre-

Speaker: NA

Text: result of this letter certain changes by way

Speaker: NA
Text: moderation of this report to parliament

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Text: I will consider the matter

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: I call the Treasurer, on the same matter,

Speaker: NA
Text: indulgence.

Text: Fremantle-Treasurer)-

Text: Mr Speaker, I am quite happy for you to

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: as I am sure you will.

Text: It is not for the Treasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: to determine it. I will determine it.

Text: I am talking about what

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member for O'Connor said.

Text: Mr Thckey- Mr Speaker, on a point

Speaker: NA

Text: The honourable member point.

Text: for O'Connor will resume his seat until the

Text: I do so on this basis:

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: MINISTERIAL STATEMENTS

Speaker: NA
Text: Rio Earth Summit

Speaker: Mrs KELLY
Text: Canberra-Minister for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Environment, Sport and Territories)-by

Speaker: NA
Text: leave-My purpose in making this statement

Speaker: NA
Text: is to provide the House with infonnation on

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government's responses to the outcomes

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Earth Summit, or the United Nations

Speaker: NA
Text: Conference on Environment and Develop-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, which was held in June 1992. The

Speaker: NA
Text: centrepiece documents of the summit-the

Speaker: NA
Text: UN conventions on climate change and

Speaker: NA
Text: biological diversity, a statement of forest

Speaker: NA
Text: principles and the action plan, agenda 21-are

Speaker: NA
Text: only the first steps in a process which we all

Speaker: NA
Text: acknowledge will occupy the global com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity well into the next century. Neverthe-

Speaker: NA
Text: less, they are crucial and historic steps. They

Speaker: NA
Text: involve commitment to the environment and

Speaker: NA
Text: to the needs and welfare of people. They

Speaker: NA
Text: involve challenges and opportunities for all

Speaker: NA
Text: countries. These international developments

Speaker: NA
Text: are paving the way to a sustainable future.

Speaker: NA
Text: Just as important for Australians is the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mitment of this Government to our national

Speaker: NA
Text: environment.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Prime Minister ( Mr Keating) recently

Speaker: NA
Text: made two important statements on the envi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ronment-on 21 December 1992 and 9 March

Speaker: NA
Text: 1993-which refocused oUr vision and our

Speaker: NA
Text: energies on the fundamental problems in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian environment, and on the results we

Speaker: NA
Text: can obtain through cooperation. He said:

Speaker: NA
Text: Nothing better illustrates the interdependence of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians and their communities than the environ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Nothing more emphatically makes the point that all

Speaker: NA
Text: our State borders and provincial differences still

Speaker: NA
Text: leave one fact unassailable-that this is one

Speaker: NA
Text: continent and one nation.

Speaker: NA
Text: And for good or bad, what we do in one part of it

Speaker: NA
Text: very often affects another.

Speaker: NA
Text: What one Australian does to the environment

Speaker: NA
Text: affects another Australian.

Speaker: NA
Text: He added:

Speaker: NA
Text: The environment is central, it is part of the main

Speaker: NA
Text: game, the main issue in which all Australians are

Speaker: NA
Text: being involved.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is no doubt that this main game, in

Speaker: NA
Text: which we are a player, is a global one. The

Speaker: NA
Text: outcomes of the Rio Earth Summit are the

Speaker: NA
Text: starting point from which all countries must

Speaker: NA
Text: now pursue an ecologically sustainable future.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me start by outlining the action we have

Speaker: NA
Text: already taken in Australia to give effect to the

Speaker: NA
Text: two conventions and to agenda 21. Along

Speaker: NA
Text: with 153 other countries, we signed the

Speaker: NA
Text: climate change convention in Rio. Although

Speaker: NA
Text: called a framework convention, indicating that

Speaker: NA
Text: there is much left to negotiate and agree, the

Speaker: NA
Text: climate change convention represents the end

Speaker: NA
Text: of a phase of global consensus building and

Speaker: NA
Text: education on the rationale and need for action

Speaker: NA
Text: on greenhouse gas emissions.

Speaker: NA
Text: The convention will enter into force and

Speaker: NA
Text: become legally binding on parties 90 days

Speaker: NA
Text: after· it has been ratified by 50 countries.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia ratified the convention in December

Speaker: NA
Text: 1992 and is one of 19 countries so far to have

Speaker: NA
Text: done so. Our expectation is that the conven-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion will achieve the necessary 50 ratifications

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia played an active and significant

Speaker: NA
Text: role in the development of and negotiations

Speaker: NA
Text: on the convention. I, in collaboration with the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth

Speaker: NA
Text: Evans) and the Minister for Primary Industries

Speaker: NA
Text: and Energy ( Mr Crean), have responsibility

Speaker: NA
Text: for further developing Australia's approach to

Speaker: NA
Text: the convention, bearing in mind the particular

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian interests arising from our fossil

Speaker: NA
Text: fuel dependency and unique natural environ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. We will continue to participate actively

Speaker: NA
Text: in the further development of the convention

Speaker: NA
Text: and in the bodies set up to guide its imple-

Speaker: NA
Text: mentation. In doing so, we shall draw upon

Speaker: NA
Text: emerging scientific infonnation on climate

Speaker: NA
Text: change and its impacts.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government has decided upon a broad

Speaker: NA
Text: set of objectives for this phase of negotiations

Speaker: NA
Text: on the development of the convention. These

Speaker: NA
Text: are based on well-known policies that have

Speaker: NA
Text: provided consistent guidance in fonnulating

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's national. and international respones

Speaker: NA
Text: on climate change.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government believes development of

Speaker: NA
Text: the convention should proceed in a manner

Speaker: NA
Text: that acknowledges the important principles

Speaker: NA
Text: already embedded in the convention, such as

Speaker: NA
Text: the need for a comprehensive approach to

Speaker: NA
Text: limiting all greenhouse gas emissions, as well

Speaker: NA
Text: as enhancing and protecting greenhouse gas

Speaker: NA
Text: sinks; the need for equitable burden sharing

Speaker: NA
Text: amongst countries that takes into account the

Speaker: NA
Text: special circumstances of individual countries;

Speaker: NA
Text: the importance of increasing our -owledge

Speaker: NA
Text: about the science and potential impacts of

Speaker: NA
Text: climate change; a strong commitment to

Speaker: NA
Text: public education; and the importance of

Speaker: NA
Text: global action.

Speaker: NA
Text: The first conference of parties is expected

Speaker: NA
Text: to beheld early in 1995. In this phase of

Speaker: NA
Text: negotiations, leading up to the first conference

Speaker: NA
Text: of parties, Australia sees as the immediate

Speaker: NA
Text: priority the need to identify and gain agree-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment to mechanisms to implement the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mitments currently contained in the conven-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. Some of the implementation details still

Speaker: NA
Text: to be decided include issues of significant

Speaker: NA
Text: importance to Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: These include agreement·on guidelines for

Speaker: NA
Text: countries to jointly implement emissions

Speaker: NA
Text: commitments, and agreement on an inventory

Speaker: NA
Text: methodology that allows all greenhouse gas

Speaker: NA
Text: emissions and sink activities to be measured.

Speaker: NA
Text: Within Australia, the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Government, working with the States and

Speaker: NA
Text: local government, has already put in place the

Speaker: NA
Text: mechanisms neceSsary to give effect to our

Speaker: NA
Text: convention obligations. These include the

Speaker: NA
Text: national greenhouse response strategy; the

Speaker: NA
Text: framework for action provided by the

Speaker: NA
Text: intergovernmental agreement oh the environ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, which was concluded in 1992; a pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: gram of scientific research; and the develop-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of a national inventory of greenhouse

Speaker: NA
Text: gases.

Speaker: NA
Text: The first phase of the national greenhouse

Speaker: NA
Text: response strategy was endorsed by heads of

Speaker: NA
Text: government in December. That first phase

Speaker: NA
Text: concentrates on 'no regrets' measures-in

Speaker: NA
Text: other words, those measures that have net

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits, or at least no net cost, in addition

Speaker: NA
Text: addressing the greenhouse effect, and that are

Speaker: NA
Text: therefore worth doing .in their own right.

Speaker: NA
Text: These include: improving the efficiency of

Speaker: NA
Text: energy production and use; diversifying our

Speaker: NA
Text: sources of energy; developing sustainable and

Speaker: NA
Text: greenhouse effective agricultural practices;

Speaker: NA
Text: improving our national transport system;

Speaker: NA
Text: better urban planning; natural environment

Speaker: NA
Text: conservation; research into climate change;

Speaker: NA
Text: and community information and education.

Speaker: NA
Text: The national greenhouse response strategy

Speaker: NA
Text: is based on the Australian interim planning

Speaker: NA
Text: target on greenhouse gas emissions which we

Speaker: NA
Text: adopted in 1990, and which the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister reaffirmed in his environtnent state-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in December 1992. Our target aims to

Speaker: NA
Text: stabilise emissions of greenhoU$e gases, based

Speaker: NA
Text: on 1988 levels, by the year 2000 and to

Speaker: NA
Text: reduce these emissions by 20 per cent by the

Speaker: NA
Text: year 2005.

Speaker: NA
Text: . The Government also holds to its decision

Speaker: NA
Text: that, while recognising the need to restrict

Speaker: NA
Text: greenhouse gas emissions, Australia will not

Speaker: NA
Text: proceed with the adoption of response meas-

Speaker: NA
Text: ures which would have net adverse economic

Speaker: NA
Text: impacts nationally or· on Australia's trade

Speaker: NA
Text: competitive-ess, in the absence of similar

Speaker: NA
Text: action by major greenhouse gas producing

Speaker: NA
Text: countries. In that context I note the announce-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment by US President Clinton on 21 April

Speaker: NA
Text: that the US would be adopting a policy to

Speaker: NA
Text: stabilise greenhouse gas emissions. This

Speaker: NA
Text: means that all OECD countries, with the

Speaker: NA
Text: exception of Turkey, have now adopted

Speaker: NA
Text: national greenhouse gas emission targets.

Speaker: NA
Text: The US also pledged to provide to the next

Speaker: NA
Text: convention negotiating session in August a

Speaker: NA
Text: report on domestic actions planned to give

Speaker: NA
Text: effect to its commitments under the conven-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. Let me also say that I welcome the

Speaker: NA
Text: stated intention of the US to pursue a vigo-

Speaker: NA
Text: rous and progressive environment policy both

Speaker: NA
Text: domestically and internationally.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have already transmitted to the climate

Speaker: NA
Text: change convention negotiators Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: interim report on the measures we have taken

Speaker: NA
Text: consistent with the convention. For this

Speaker: NA
Text: purpose the national greenhouse response

Speaker: NA
Text: strategy formed Australia's interim report. I

Speaker: NA
Text: am pleased to report that last Saturday the

Speaker: NA
Text: to environment Ministers of all Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: governments, State and Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: together, endorsed a work program to imple-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment a range of measures contained in the

Speaker: NA
Text: national greenhouse response strategy. I

Speaker: NA
Text: understand that similar work plans are being

Speaker: NA
Text: developed and implemented by a range of

Speaker: NA
Text: agencies and bodies responsible for making

Speaker: NA
Text: the first phase of the strategy a success.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of course, implementing our national

Speaker: NA
Text: greenhouse response strategy is not the only

Speaker: NA
Text: means of addressing our convention obliga-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions. Initiatives such as the one billion trees

Speaker: NA
Text: program, the national soil conservation pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: gram, the national electricity grid, the build-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing better cities program, our ecologically

Speaker: NA
Text: sustainable development strategy and the

Speaker: NA
Text: national forest policy statement all contribute

Speaker: NA
Text: to achieving our greenhouse goals.

Speaker: NA
Text: The challenges and opportunities presented

Speaker: NA
Text: by greenhouse-induced climate change are

Speaker: NA
Text: real and highly significant for Australia, as
