Speaker: NA
Text: they are for the entire global community. I do

Speaker: NA
Text: not underestimate the adjustment issues we

Speaker: NA
Text: are facing. The very public debate that has

Speaker: NA
Text: occurred over the last few years is evidence

Speaker: NA
Text: of the valid concerns and different viewpoints

Speaker: NA
Text: about the amount and speed of adjustment

Speaker: NA
Text: needed. The Government's policies explicitly

Speaker: NA
Text: recognise these adjustment issues. And I

Speaker: NA
Text: believe that with genuine cooperation and

Speaker: NA
Text: goodwill on all sides, and with acknowledg-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of others' interests, the challenges can

Speaker: NA
Text: indeed be met.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are also significant opportunities. Our

Speaker: NA
Text: comprehensive and strategic approach to both

Speaker: NA
Text: our international and domestic obligations

Speaker: NA
Text: gives rise to opportunities for industry and for

Speaker: NA
Text: the nation. Renewable forms of energy are an

Speaker: NA
Text: area of real opportunity for investment and

Speaker: NA
Text: employment that Australia is well placed to

Speaker: NA
Text: exploit. Australia is already at the forefront

Speaker: NA
Text: the development of solar technologies and

Speaker: NA
Text: renewable transport fuels.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is a similar story to tell for the

Speaker: NA
Text: biodiversity convention. The biodiversity

Speaker: NA
Text: convention recognises the global imperative

Speaker: NA
Text: in the conservation and sustainable use of

Speaker: NA
Text: species, genetic resources and ecosystems for

Speaker: NA
Text: the benefit of present and future generations.

Speaker: NA
Text: It too was signed in Rio by over 150 count-

Speaker: NA
Text: ries. Again, Australia played a leading role in

Speaker: NA
Text: the development of the convention and is

Speaker: NA
Text: continuing to play a key role in its implemen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tation both internationally and, more specifi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cally, in the Asia-Pacific region. Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: considers it vital to maintain the impetus for

Speaker: NA
Text: the convention's early entry into force and

Speaker: NA
Text: implementation and I am encouraging other

Speaker: NA
Text: countries to take action in this regard.

Speaker: NA
Text: I was greatly encouraged when President

Speaker: NA
Text: Clinton announced the US intention to sign

Speaker: NA
Text: the convention and that the US would be

Speaker: NA
Text: taking a prominent role in global actions to

Speaker: NA
Text: conserve biodiversity. The Australian Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment welcomes the US initiative which will

Speaker: NA
Text: provide added momentum to the global effort.

Speaker: NA
Text: I see this as another example of US commit- .

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, vision and leadership on these vital

Speaker: NA
Text: issues.

Speaker: NA
Text: The convention needs 30 ratifications for it

Speaker: NA
Text: to come into effect. We believe that the

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary number 'will be reached during

Speaker: NA
Text: 1994. Our own ratification of the convention

Speaker: NA
Text: was foreshadowed in the Prime Minister's

Speaker: NA
Text: environment statement in December. M 0 s t

Speaker: NA
Text: States have now responded favourably to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth's proposal to ratify the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: vention. We will be in a position to. ratify

Speaker: NA
Text: following final consideration of the conven-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion at the meeting of the Council of Austral-

Speaker: NA
Text: ian Governments in June.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government is firmly committed to the

Speaker: NA
Text: development of a national strategy on biologi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cal diversity with a view to developing a

Speaker: NA
Text: biodiversity program. A Commonwealth, State

Speaker: NA
Text: and Territory task force is currently in the

Speaker: NA
Text: process of finalising a draft. The process has

Speaker: NA
Text: involved extensive consultation with a wide

Speaker: NA
Text: range of interest groups and the public-from

Speaker: NA
Text: Government at all levels to business and

Speaker: NA
Text: in industry, the scientific community and the

Speaker: NA
Text: conservation movement.

Speaker: NA
Text: I view the strategy as a key element for

Speaker: NA
Text: implementing the Government's environment

Speaker: NA
Text: policy. It will be available for consideration

Speaker: NA
Text: by governments. within the next few months

Speaker: NA
Text: and will hopefully be adopted by the end of

Speaker: NA
Text: this year. The strategy will provide an effec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive framework, involving all sectors of the

Speaker: NA
Text: community, for achieving biological conserva-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion goals. It proposes a mix of short-and

Speaker: NA
Text: long-term actions on conservation, sustainable

Speaker: NA
Text: use, the management of threats, improving

Speaker: NA
Text: knowledge and community involvement. The

Speaker: NA
Text: strategy and the subsequent program will be

Speaker: NA
Text: two of the major measures for implementing

Speaker: NA
Text: our obligations under the convention. They

Speaker: NA
Text: will strengthen and add to the wide range of

Speaker: NA
Text: current Commonwealth programs in the area

Speaker: NA
Text: of nature conservation and biological protec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia is in a unique position. We are the

Speaker: NA
Text: only developed country which is also

Speaker: NA
Text: megadiverse. Many of our primary industries,

Speaker: NA
Text: essential to our export earnings, are dependent

Speaker: NA
Text: either directly or indirectly on our biological

Speaker: NA
Text: diversity and that of other countries. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: therefore in Australia's interests, environmentment

Speaker: NA
Text: al and economic, to take strong and decisive

Speaker: NA
Text: actions to conserve biological diversity and to

Speaker: NA
Text: maximise the benefits to be gained. Aust-

Speaker: NA
Text: ralia's leadership in this field creates oppor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunities. Not only are we maximising the

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits to be gained from a well-managed

Speaker: NA
Text: and conserved natural heritage, but the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mercial opportunities are also highly signifi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cant. Australia possesses significant expertise,

Speaker: NA
Text: in both the private and public sectors, in

Speaker: NA
Text: biological research, assessment and manage-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, as well as in associated and enabling

Speaker: NA
Text: techniques and technologies, such as remote

Speaker: NA
Text: sensing. The potential benefits of using our

Speaker: NA
Text: own genetic resources in areas of science,

Speaker: NA
Text: medicine and agriculture are enormous.

Speaker: NA
Text: I tum now to the Earth Summit's action

Speaker: NA
Text: plan for sustainable development in the 21st

Speaker: NA
Text: century-agenda 21. Agenda 21 is a truly

Speaker: NA
Text: massive document-40 chapters covering

Speaker: NA
Text: matters as diverse as poverty, population,

Speaker: NA
Text: technology transfer, consumption patterns,

Speaker: NA
Text: forests, freshwater, pollution avoidance,

Speaker: NA
Text: transboundary air pollution, and radioactive

Speaker: NA
Text: waste. It is a blueprint or set of guidelines,

Speaker: NA
Text: not just for individual countries but, import-

Speaker: NA
Text: antly, for the entire United Nations system as

Speaker: NA
Text: well as for individuals and organisations of

Speaker: NA
Text: every size and type. Australia contributed

Speaker: NA
Text: significantly to its preparation and negotia-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions. The adoption of agenda 21 at the Rio

Speaker: NA
Text: summit marks an important step in global

Speaker: NA
Text: cooperation on environment and development

Speaker: NA
Text: matters. While agenda 21 does not impose

Speaker: NA
Text: binding legal commitments on governments,

Speaker: NA
Text: we will be doing our best to ensure that it is

Speaker: NA
Text: adopted in Australia, provided of course that

Speaker: NA
Text: individual activities proposed accord with our

Speaker: NA
Text: domestic economic interests and international

Speaker: NA
Text: priorities for sustainable development.

Speaker: NA
Text: Essentially the process for implementing

Speaker: NA
Text: agenda 21 will be one of analysing the recom-

Speaker: NA
Text: mendations, assessing their relevance and

Speaker: NA
Text: applicability to Australia and ensuring that the

Speaker: NA
Text: high priority recommendations are being acted

Speaker: NA
Text: upon through existing programs and institu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions. The recommendations of agenda 21

Speaker: NA
Text: cover a wide range of issues and responsibili-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties for implementation, cutting across virtual-

Speaker: NA
Text: ly every Commonwealth and State govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: agency as well as local government and

Speaker: NA
Text: the non-government sector. It will be neces-

Speaker: NA
Text: sary to ensure that all of these parties have

Speaker: NA
Text: input to the process. My department has the

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility for the overall coordination of

Speaker: NA
Text: the domestic follow-up of agenda 21, al-

Speaker: NA
Text: though other agencies will have a more direct

Speaker: NA
Text: implementation task. It is not envisaged that

Speaker: NA
Text: a major new process will be required on the

Speaker: NA
Text: part of Australia to implement agenda 21.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are already a number of processes and

Speaker: NA
Text: mechanisms which will make a major contri-

Speaker: NA
Text: bution to its implementation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Chief among them will be the consultative

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangements established under the 1992

Speaker: NA
Text: intergovernmental agreement on the environ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment and the processes under the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's ecologically sustainable development

Speaker: NA
Text: policy, which brought together government,

Speaker: NA
Text: industry, unions and broad based community

Speaker: NA
Text: representatives to report on the policies and

Speaker: NA
Text: structures necessary to achieve ESD· in Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia. The preparation of national sustainable

Speaker: NA
Text: development strategies or plans is a key

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendation of agenda 21 and I believe

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's own ESD strategy is already being

Speaker: NA
Text: seen as something of a model. During my

Speaker: NA
Text: visit to Washington, for example, I found

Speaker: NA
Text: keen interest in our experience amongst the

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the Administration I spoke with.

Speaker: NA
Text: A key feature of this Government's ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: proach to the development of policies on

Speaker: NA
Text: international environment and sustainable

Speaker: NA
Text: development issues has been community

Speaker: NA
Text: consultation. Following the Earth Summit and

Speaker: NA
Text: the conclusion of the two conventions we

Speaker: NA
Text: recognised that past practices and methods

Speaker: NA
Text: would need to be upgraded and given new

Speaker: NA
Text: life. The Minister for Foreign Affairs and I

Speaker: NA
Text: have decided to formalise and enhance a

Speaker: NA
Text: process to receive the views of the non-

Speaker: NA
Text: government community on these very import-

Speaker: NA
Text: ant international environment issues. An

Speaker: NA
Text: international environment non-government

Speaker: NA
Text: organisations consultative forum has now

Speaker: NA
Text: been established and will meet for the first

Speaker: NA
Text: time on Friday this week. Its 17 members

Speaker: NA
Text: comprise senior representatives of business,

Speaker: NA
Text: environment, aid and community groups. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: pleased to announce that the forum will be

Speaker: NA
Text: chaired by our friend and colleague the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Werriwa ( Mr Kerin),

Speaker: NA
Text: who brings to the position a unique blend of

Speaker: NA
Text: personal experience and commitment. His task

Speaker: NA
Text: will be a challenging one and one which

Speaker: NA
Text: Senator Evans and I very much value and

Speaker: NA
Text: appreciate.

Speaker: NA
Text: Our efforts to give effect to the internation-

Speaker: NA
Text: al obligations arising from the two conven-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions and the imperatives of agenda 21 are

Speaker: NA
Text: closely linked to the many other domestic

Speaker: NA
Text: environment initiatives and policies of this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government, in particular, the initiatives

Speaker: NA
Text: announced through both the Prime Minister's

Speaker: NA
Text: December 1992 environment statement and

Speaker: NA
Text: the March 1993 election statement on the

Speaker: NA
Text: environment. Both statements recognise the

Speaker: NA
Text: important, indeed essential, part the environ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has to play in Australia's growth.

Speaker: NA
Text: The initiatives revolve around the key role

Speaker: NA
Text: of ecologically sustainable development,

Speaker: NA
Text: recognising as they do the need to conserve

Speaker: NA
Text: and preserve our stock and use the income

Speaker: NA
Text: wisely for future generations, rather than

Speaker: NA
Text: depleting our assets for short-term gain.

Speaker: NA
Text: Examples such as the acquisition of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Calperum pastoral lease, feral animal and

Speaker: NA
Text: weed control, the cleaner production demon-

Speaker: NA
Text: stration program, a national halon bank and

Speaker: NA
Text: national state of the environment reporting

Speaker: NA
Text: show that this Government will not be slow

Speaker: NA
Text: in taking the necessary environmental deci-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions where they are central to the issue of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's development as a nation. Each

Speaker: NA
Text: initiative also helps to build our domestic

Speaker: NA
Text: response to the conventions and to agenda 21.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the key outcomes of the summit was

Speaker: NA
Text: its recognition of the need to build interna-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional partnerships for sustainable develop-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, partnerships between developed and

Speaker: NA
Text: developing countries and between the devel-

Speaker: NA
Text: oping countries themselves. Of course, well

Speaker: NA
Text: before UNCED Australia was focusing atten-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion on our immediate region. The summit

Speaker: NA
Text: and the processes leading up to it gave a

Speaker: NA
Text: considerable boost to the environmental

Speaker: NA
Text: dimension of that relationship.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia has been actively expanding its

Speaker: NA
Text: environmental cooperation with Asia, espe-

Speaker: NA
Text: cially with the members of ASEAN. I have

Speaker: NA
Text: signed bilateral arrangements with Indonesia

Speaker: NA
Text: and Singapore and there have been exchanges

Speaker: NA
Text: of ministerial visits. Discussions are under

Speaker: NA
Text: way with senior officials of ASEAN member

Speaker: NA
Text: countries to establish cooperative arrange-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments that address regional environmental

Speaker: NA
Text: issues. Negotiations have begun with China

Speaker: NA
Text: on a memorandum of understanding.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Commonwealth Environment Protection

Speaker: NA
Text: Agency has participated in a number of

Speaker: NA
Text: environmental exhibitions in countries in the

Speaker: NA
Text: region. It has run, in close conjunction with

Speaker: NA
Text: the environmental industries, environmental

Speaker: NA
Text: workshops and seminars with Korea, Taiwan

Speaker: NA
Text: and Singapore and is planning to run similar

Speaker: NA
Text: activities in Indonesia in the near future.

Speaker: NA
Text: These types of activities on issues such as

Speaker: NA
Text: pollution avoidance, environmental technolo-

Speaker: NA
Text: gies, standards setting and environmental

Speaker: NA
Text: impact assessment will continue to increase,

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly in the South-East Asian region.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia also contributes to climate change

Speaker: NA
Text: and related studies being undertaken or

Speaker: NA
Text: planned in the Asia region. One current study

Speaker: NA
Text: is the Asian Development Bank regional

Speaker: NA
Text: study on global environment issues. It is an

Speaker: NA
Text: eight-country project financed by the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments of Australia, Japan and Norway. Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia has provided $500,000, approximately

Speaker: NA
Text: one-third of the total funding.

Speaker: NA
Text: Closely allied to the issue of conservation

Speaker: NA
Text: of biological diversity is the urgent need to

Speaker: NA
Text: reduce the rate of global deforestation. The

Speaker: NA
Text: UNCED statement of forest principles pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vides direction for addressing this issue in the

Speaker: NA
Text: broadest social and economic context. We are

Speaker: NA
Text: committed to continuing our work in interna-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional fora in order to find ways in which to

Speaker: NA
Text: reduce the rate of deforestation and to facili-

Speaker: NA
Text: tate the conservation and ecological sustain-

Speaker: NA
Text: able use of forests.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another project, originally known as the

Speaker: NA
Text: regional program for the development of

Speaker: NA
Text: least-cost greenhouse emissions reduction

Speaker: NA
Text: plans in Asia, is planned to begin this year

Speaker: NA
Text: through the global environment facility and

Speaker: NA
Text: the UN development program. Australia will

Speaker: NA
Text: be contributing about one-third of the total

Speaker: NA
Text: budget of $9 million. Australia is also con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sidering co-financing the global environment

Speaker: NA
Text: facility project on east Asian seas.

Speaker: NA
Text: Under the development assistance program

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia has committed expenditure totalling

Speaker: NA
Text: nearly $200 million over four years for

Speaker: NA
Text: environmental activities in ASEAN member

Speaker: NA
Text: countries. 1\\'0 major regional projects which

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia is supporting are an $8.4 million

Speaker: NA
Text: marine science project and a $5.3 million

Speaker: NA
Text: energy project. We expect that our regional

Speaker: NA
Text: involvement through the ASEAN-Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: economic cooperation program will include a

Speaker: NA
Text: substantial environmental component in its

Speaker: NA
Text: next phase which starts in 1994.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is also a wide range of bilateral

Speaker: NA
Text: environmental projects with countries of the

Speaker: NA
Text: region. For example, in Indonesia alone

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia is funding seven projects totalling

Speaker: NA
Text: $122.7 million. In the Pacific region the focus

Speaker: NA
Text: has been on support for the South Pacific

Speaker: NA
Text: regional environment program, or SPREP, and

Speaker: NA
Text: on individual high priority projects in the

Speaker: NA
Text: developing island countries. Australia is a

Speaker: NA
Text: major supporter of SPREP. In 1992-93 a total

Speaker: NA
Text: of $1.8 million was provided by Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia has played an important role in

Speaker: NA
Text: the South Pacific on biodiversity issues. We

Speaker: NA
Text: assisted Pacific island countries to develop a

Speaker: NA
Text: regional position on biological diversity and

Speaker: NA
Text: to be represented at negotiating sessions on

Speaker: NA
Text: the convention. Many of the Pacific island

Speaker: NA
Text: countries have signed the convention and

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia is providing advice on ratification.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have also played an active role in

Speaker: NA
Text: developing the South Pacific biodiversity

Speaker: NA
Text: project, a $10 million global environment

Speaker: NA
Text: facility project which Australia will be co-

Speaker: NA
Text: financing. The project aims to conserve

Speaker: NA
Text: biodiversity in the region through the estab-

Speaker: NA
Text: lishment of multiple use conservation areas,

Speaker: NA
Text: drawing heavily on the skills and knowledge

Speaker: NA
Text: of traditional owners and users of biodiversity

Speaker: NA
Text: in the region.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia also supported the participation

Speaker: NA
Text: the Pacific island countries in negotiating on

Speaker: NA
Text: the climate change convention. An Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: funded feasibility study on climate monitoring

Speaker: NA
Text: and impacts in the south-west Pacific arose

Speaker: NA
Text: from concerns about the impact of the green-

Speaker: NA
Text: house effect raised at the 1988 meeting of the

Speaker: NA
Text: South Pacific Forum. This study, which was

Speaker: NA
Text: undertaken by the World Meteorological

Speaker: NA
Text: Organisation, is described in the report The

Speaker: NA
Text: changing climate in paradise published by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Bureau of Meteorology. I recom-

Speaker: NA
Text: mend it to people.

Speaker: NA
Text: In listing what Australia is doing in our

Speaker: NA
Text: region to give effect to the Earth Summit

Speaker: NA
Text: outcomes, I am not suggesting that we are the

Speaker: NA
Text: only players in the process. But Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: efforts over the past few years are indicative

Speaker: NA
Text: of the types of changes and new programs

Speaker: NA
Text: already in the pipeline. Recent announce-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments by other donors, such as Japan and the

Speaker: NA
Text: US, have clearly indicated that they too see

Speaker: NA
Text: their bilateral and regional assistance pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: grams being increasingly supportive and

Speaker: NA
Text: complementary to global efforts in sustainable

Speaker: NA
Text: development and as adjuncts to convention

Speaker: NA
Text: funding.

Speaker: NA
Text: I will now describe briefly, for the benefit

Speaker: NA
Text: of honourable members, the key actions

Speaker: NA
Text: which have been taken by the United Nations

Speaker: NA
Text: at the global level to give effect to the out-

Speaker: NA
Text: comes of the Earth Summit. The key player

Speaker: NA
Text: in starting the follow-up to UNCED was the

Speaker: NA
Text: UN General Assembly. At its 1992 session,

Speaker: NA
Text: the General Assembly examined the UNCED

Speaker: NA
Text: outcomes and established certain directions

Speaker: NA
Text: and priorities. The General Assembly wel-

Speaker: NA
Text: comed the finalisation of the conventions and

Speaker: NA
Text: urged countries which had not signed them in

Speaker: NA
Text: Rio to do so soon. The General Assembly

Speaker: NA
Text: also urged ratification and a prompt start to

Speaker: NA
Text: both the climate change and biological di-

Speaker: NA
Text: versity conventions.

Speaker: NA
Text: The General Assembly then looked at

Speaker: NA
Text: agenda 21 as the principle action document

Speaker: NA
Text: from UNCED and identified a number of

Speaker: NA
Text: issues or recommendations requiring immedi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ate action. It took action to establish a com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mission for sustainable development as a

Speaker: NA
Text: senior body within the UN system. The

Speaker: NA
Text: establishment of the commission was a centre-

Speaker: NA
Text: of piece of agenda 21. The commission has been

Speaker: NA
Text: formally established and will now meet

Speaker: NA
Text: annually in June. The main role of the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mission will be to monitor the implementation

Speaker: NA
Text: of agenda 21. Countries are expected to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide reports on their own efforts and the

Speaker: NA
Text: operational agencies of the UN system,such

Speaker: NA
Text: as the UN development program, the Food

Speaker: NA
Text: and Agriculture Organisation and the UN

Speaker: NA
Text: environment program, as well as organisations

Speaker: NA
Text: such as the World Bank, will be reporting to

Speaker: NA
Text: the commission on their own efforts to give

Speaker: NA
Text: effect to the recommendations of agenda 21.

Speaker: NA
Text: The commission will ultimately report to

Speaker: NA
Text: the General Assembly and to the UN Secre-

Speaker: NA
Text: tary-General on that process. It will be ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: pected to make recommendations on overcom-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing problems or gaps in implementation and

Speaker: NA
Text: will actually review agenda 21 in 1997.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia was elected to the 53-member

Speaker: NA
Text: commission for a two-year tenn. At its first

Speaker: NA
Text: meeting in June this year, the commission

Speaker: NA
Text: will be establishing a work program to thor-

Speaker: NA
Text: oughly review the implementation of agenda

Speaker: NA
Text: 21 over the next four years. A system of

Speaker: NA
Text: national reporting will be a fundamental

Speaker: NA
Text: element of that work program. Countries will

Speaker: NA
Text: be asked to provide detailed reports to the

Speaker: NA
Text: commission on their domestic efforts to

Speaker: NA
Text: achieve sustainable development and the

Speaker: NA
Text: commission will be monitoring and reporting

Speaker: NA
Text: on national progress.

Speaker: NA
Text: The other key elements in the General

Speaker: NA
Text: Assembly'S decisions on UNCED related to

Speaker: NA
Text: the immediate establishment of three import-

Speaker: NA
Text: ant international processes which could not

Speaker: NA
Text: wait until the commission was established and

Speaker: NA
Text: operating. Those processes were: firstly, the

Speaker: NA
Text: establishment of a special intergovernmental

Speaker: NA
Text: negotiating committee to develop an interna-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional convention on desertification. The

Speaker: NA
Text: primary focus of the negotiations is

Speaker: NA
Text: international consensus on the measures

Speaker: NA
Text: needed to deal with the problems of land

Speaker: NA
Text: degradation in those countries experiencing

Speaker: NA
Text: drought and/or desertification, particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: Africa.

Speaker: NA
Text: Secondly, the General Assembly also

Speaker: NA
Text: established a special conference to deal with

Speaker: NA
Text: problems of management of high seas fisher-

Speaker: NA
Text: ies, notably the problems of managing the

Speaker: NA
Text: exploitation of highly migratory species and

Speaker: NA
Text: species which straddle the 200-mile exclusive

Speaker: NA
Text: economic zones of coastal states. A third

Speaker: NA
Text: process was also a conference on the particU-

Speaker: NA
Text: lar problems of small island states. UNCED

Speaker: NA
Text: recognised that small island states face very

Speaker: NA
Text: special problems in their efforts to achieve

Speaker: NA
Text: sustainable development.

Speaker: NA
Text: The preparations for that conference have

Speaker: NA
Text: already commeIlcl(d in earnest and involve

Speaker: NA
Text: most of the island countries of the South

Speaker: NA
Text: Pacific, the Indian Ocean and the Caribbean.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's Ambassador for the Environment,

Speaker: NA
Text: Penny Wensley, is chairing the committee

Speaker: NA
Text: which will prepare for the final conference in

Speaker: NA
Text: Barbados in 1994. The Commission for

Speaker: NA
Text: Sustainable Development will no doubt

Speaker: NA
Text: identify other key issues and processes. There

Speaker: NA
Text: is, for example, already some talk of further

Speaker: NA
Text: action being required on the issue of forest

Speaker: NA
Text: management and conservation as a follow-up

Speaker: NA
Text: to the statement of forest principles and also

Speaker: NA
Text: on the issue of fresh water.

Speaker: NA
Text: Apart from the UN, there are a few other

Speaker: NA
Text: key players worthy of mention, in particular

Speaker: NA
Text: the global environment facility. The GEF, as

Speaker: NA
Text: it is called, is a joint project of the World

Speaker: NA
Text: Bank, UNEP and UNDP and was established

Speaker: NA
Text: in 1990 with around $US1.5 billion of donor

Speaker: NA
Text: funds specifically to help developing countries

Speaker: NA
Text: undertake projects to deal with global envi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ronmental issues. The GEF is already per-

Speaker: NA
Text: forming an interim role for the conventions by

Speaker: NA
Text: funding activities such as the country

Speaker: NA
Text: biodiversity studies and the greenhouse gas

Speaker: NA
Text: inventories as well as providing funds for

Speaker: NA
Text: large-scale conservation and energy efficiency

Speaker: NA
Text: or conversion programs in developing count-

Speaker: NA
Text: ries. The GEF will be refonned and replen-

Speaker: NA
Text: ished this year so that it is capable of taking

Speaker: NA
Text: on the extra roles allocated to it once the

Speaker: NA
Text: to achieve conventions come into force.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia committed $30 million to the pilot

Speaker: NA
Text: phase of the GEF, which ends this year, and

Speaker: NA
Text: is an active participant in the replenishment

Speaker: NA
Text: in negotiations. That replenishment is likely to

Speaker: NA
Text: expand even further the scope for technology

Speaker: NA
Text: transfer and funding assistance for developing

Speaker: NA
Text: countries in our own region. Current papers

Speaker: NA
Text: on the replenishment suggest that a doubling,

Speaker: NA
Text: or even more, of the pilot phase funding level

Speaker: NA
Text: to around $5 billion may be achievable.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have now outlined the actions being

Speaker: NA
Text: undertaken at the national, regional and global

Speaker: NA
Text: levels to give effect to the outcomes of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Earth Summit. I will now conclude with a

Speaker: NA
Text: few words about our priorities for the future.

Speaker: NA
Text: Clearly, the actions I have described must

Speaker: NA
Text: inevitably be regarded as work in progress.

Speaker: NA
Text: Nothing is finished. Our first priority must

Speaker: NA
Text: to see that the conventions come into force

Speaker: NA
Text: and are operating effectively as soon as

Speaker: NA
Text: possible, that our national strategies are

Speaker: NA
Text: progressing effectively and are implemented,

Speaker: NA
Text: and that the framework provided by agenda

Speaker: NA
Text: 21, the ESD strategy and the initiatives of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister's environment statements are

Speaker: NA
Text: given full effect.

Speaker: NA
Text: Our regional program will be strengthened

Speaker: NA
Text: and we will be working within the Commis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion for Sustainable Development, the UN

Speaker: NA
Text: environment program and the global environ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment facility to ensure a rapid and effective

Speaker: NA
Text: uptake of the summit's priority recommenda-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions. Regionally, we will continue to build

Speaker: NA
Text: partnerships with the countries of our immedi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ate region and with countries such as the US

Speaker: NA
Text: and Germany where strategic alliances can

Speaker: NA
Text: advance our international objectives.

Speaker: NA
Text: During this, my second, term as environ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment Minister, I will be pursuing a number of

Speaker: NA
Text: key priorities both domestically and interna-

Speaker: NA
Text: tionally. Issues of the state of our urban

Speaker: NA
Text: environment, touching as they do the lives of

Speaker: NA
Text: most Australians, must be a key area for

Speaker: NA
Text: action. Lead in petrol, energy production and

Speaker: NA
Text: use, pollution avoidance, urban transport and

Speaker: NA
Text: environmental health are some of tile matters

Speaker: NA
Text: I am committed to addressing. I will also be

Speaker: NA
Text: actively pursuing the Government's policies

Speaker: NA
Text: in the area of nature conservation, including

Speaker: NA
Text: our protected areas policy, and ensuring that

Speaker: NA
Text: there is a national reserves system and rapid

Speaker: NA
Text: implementation of the Commonwealth's

Speaker: NA
Text: endangered species legislation in conjunction

Speaker: NA
Text: with the continuation of the endangered

Speaker: NA
Text: species program.

Speaker: NA
Text: New issues arise continually. As a nation,

Speaker: NA
Text: we must be prepared to meet the challenges

Speaker: NA
Text: posed and to create the opportunities for

Speaker: NA
Text: environmental and economic gain. The sea

Speaker: NA
Text: change that we are seeing in the international

Speaker: NA
Text: community has its roots in the realisation

Speaker: NA
Text: environment IUld economic policies can and

Speaker: NA
Text: must be mutually supporting. Areas such as

Speaker: NA
Text: trade, employment and fiscal policy, and even

Speaker: NA
Text: subjects as basic as the measurement of our

Speaker: NA
Text: GOP, are increasingly concerned with envi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ronmental impacts and environmental better-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. Environmental policy can assist in

Speaker: NA
Text: be removing barriers to greater economic effi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciency and can be a driving force behind

Speaker: NA
Text: many micrQ-economic reforms. International

Speaker: NA
Text: competitiveness and high environmental

Speaker: NA
Text: standards are not incompatible. They are two

Speaker: NA
Text: sides of the same coin.

Speaker: NA
Text: In a world which cooperates in the area of

Speaker: NA
Text: environmental goal setting and management,

Speaker: NA
Text: free trade and s"UStainable development can be

Speaker: NA
Text: mutually supportive. That means development

Speaker: NA
Text: and jobs-jobs in environmentally sustainable

Speaker: NA
Text: industries from all sectors and new jobs in

Speaker: NA
Text: industries providing the technology and

Speaker: NA
Text: services to clean up the environment. These

Speaker: NA
Text: new industries are export oriented from the

Speaker: NA
Text: outset and are supported by the increasing

Speaker: NA
Text: level of international cooperation on the

Speaker: NA
Text: environment and by Australia's pro-active and

Speaker: NA
Text: progressive role in international forums.

Speaker: NA
Text: This integration of environmental .and

Speaker: NA
Text: economic policy is the wave of the future. I

Speaker: NA
Text: will be giving increased attention to, and

Speaker: NA
Text: upgrading my portfolio's capabilities in, the

Speaker: NA
Text: field of environmental economics, resource

Speaker: NA
Text: accounting and state of the environment

Speaker: NA
Text: reporting so that we are better placed as a

Speaker: NA
Text: nation to reap both the environmental and

Speaker: NA
Text: economic benefits of sound policies-the

Speaker: NA
Text: fundamental goal of ecologically sustainable

Speaker: NA
Text: development. I present a copy of my

Speaker: NA
Text: ministerial statement.

Speaker: NA
Text: Motion (by Mr Beddall) proposed:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the House take note of the paper.

Speaker: NA
Text: Motion (by Mr Beddall)-by leave-

Speaker: NA
Text: agreed to:

Speaker: NA
Text: That so much of the Standing and Sessional

Speaker: NA
Text: Orders be suspended as would prevent the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Hindmarsh speaking for a period

Speaker: NA
Text: not exceeding 32 minutes.

Speaker: Mrs GALLUS
Text: Hindmarsh) (3.45 p.m.)-

Speaker: NA
Text: Last year the United Nations convened a

Speaker: NA
Text: world conference in Rio de Janeiro called the

Speaker: NA
Text: United Nations Conference on the Environ-

Speaker: NA
Text: that ment and Development, better known as the

Speaker: NA
Text: Earth Summit. At the conclusion of this

Speaker: NA
Text: conference, most of the nations of the world

Speaker: NA
Text: signed the Rio declaration, which is a com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mitment to a set of principles requiring

Speaker: NA
Text: development to be sensitive to the environ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. The Earth Summit also endorsed agen-

Speaker: NA
Text: da 21, a wide-ranging program of national

Speaker: NA
Text: and international actions to be taken by its

Speaker: NA
Text: principals into the 21st century. During the

Speaker: NA
Text: summit, Australia signed the conventions on

Speaker: NA
Text: climate change and biological diversity. In her

Speaker: NA
Text: speech today, the Minister for the Environ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, Sport and Territories ( Mrs Kelly)

Speaker: NA
Text: addressed the responses the Government has

Speaker: NA
Text: taken to give effect to these two conventions

Speaker: NA
Text: and to agenda 21.

Speaker: NA
Text: Firstly, I will deal with climate change.

Speaker: NA
Text: climate change convention, which 153 count-

Speaker: NA
Text: ries signed, is an agreement to act together

Speaker: NA
Text: with all other nations to reduce the production

Speaker: NA
Text: of greenhouse gases. The coalition strongly

Speaker: NA
Text: supports the signing of this convention and its

Speaker: NA
Text: aims. We support government action to

Speaker: NA
Text: inform the community, industry, State and

Speaker: NA
Text: local governments of the implications of

Speaker: NA
Text: increasing amounts of carbon dioxide, me-

Speaker: NA
Text: thane and CFCs in the atmosphere.

Speaker: NA
Text: As part of the coalition's election policy,

Speaker: NA
Text: we stressed the importance of reducing green-

Speaker: NA
Text: house emissions from government, industry

Speaker: NA
Text: and the home;·the need for better use of our

Speaker: NA
Text: natural resources; in substituting, where

Speaker: NA
Text: appropriate, renewable for non-renewable

Speaker: NA
Text: resources, including the greater use of solar

Speaker: NA
Text: power and natural light; improving the effi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciency to conversion from primary industry

Speaker: NA
Text: sources such as coal, oil and gas to end use

Speaker: NA
Text: energy such as electricity, petrol and diesel

Speaker: NA
Text: fuel; and, finally, and very importantly,

Speaker: NA
Text: improving the layout of our cities in ways

Speaker: NA
Text: that reduce energy use in transport and other

Speaker: NA
Text: services.

Speaker: NA
Text: In her speech the Minister said that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Government has already put in place

Speaker: NA
Text: the mechanisms necessary to give effect to the

Speaker: NA
Text: national greenhouse response strategy. In this

Speaker: NA
Text: regard the Government's actions do not

Speaker: NA
Text: always match its rhetoric. In October 1990 as

Speaker: NA
Text: an interim response to the threat of global

Speaker: NA
Text: warming the Government announced an

Speaker: NA
Text: energy efficiency package which could be

Speaker: NA
Text: implemented immediately to save on energy

Speaker: NA
Text: use in Australia. However, in a report tabled

Speaker: NA
Text: in Parliament on 18 May this year, the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian National Audit Office concluded that

Speaker: NA
Text: in regard to the 1990 announcement insuffi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cient implementary action had been taken. In

Speaker: NA
Text: particular, the Government's own operations

Speaker: NA
Text: had failed to set an example. I would like to

Speaker: NA
Text: quote from the report of the Australian Na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional Audit Office:

Speaker: NA
Text: The department's own research has shown that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government was seen to be asking for action by

Speaker: NA
Text: other energy consumers but was not active in

Speaker: NA
Text: improving its own energy use.

Speaker: NA
Text: The report said that the Federal Government

Speaker: NA
Text: can hardly expect prompt responses from the

Speaker: NA
Text: The community to increase energy efficiency in

Speaker: NA
Text: curbing greenhouse gas emissions when it was

Speaker: NA
Text: dragging its own feet. The report said that

Speaker: NA
Text: after two years the department given the

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility for responding to the green-

Speaker: NA
Text: house agenda-

Speaker: Mrs KELLY
Text: Which department?

Speaker: Mrs GALLUS
Text: The Department of Pri-

Speaker: NA
Text: mary Industries and Energy-was one year

Speaker: NA
Text: behind what was achievable. The report went

Speaker: NA
Text: on to say that manufacturing industry had

Speaker: NA
Text: been neglected, although there was scope to

Speaker: NA
Text: greatly expand understanding of energy use in

Speaker: NA
Text: the home, in transport and in commercial

Speaker: NA
Text: buildings, and also there was a lack of coordi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nation on energy ratings and standards for

Speaker: NA
Text: appliances and buildings. I think an important

Speaker: NA
Text: point to make is that it is very nice to have

Speaker: NA
Text: all these strategies but when we give depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments the job of implementing the strategies

Speaker: NA
Text: something has to be done, and it has to be

Speaker: NA
Text: done reasonably quickly.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister is inclined to make statements

Speaker: NA
Text: about Australia's lead on environmental issues

Speaker: NA
Text: including greenhouse. The. truth is that per

Speaker: NA
Text: person Australia sends more greenhouse gases

Speaker: NA
Text: into the atmosphere than any other Western

Speaker: NA
Text: country. At 11 tonnes per person, Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: emits more greenhouse gases per person per

Speaker: NA
Text: annum than the United States at 10 tonnes

Speaker: NA
Text: and three times as much as Japan with three

Speaker: NA
Text: tonnes. I think most Australians would be

Speaker: NA
Text: somewhat stunned to note that.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, in making this observation I wish

Speaker: NA
Text: to note that Australia has many energy-inten-

Speaker: NA
Text: sive industries which add to our greenhouse

Speaker: NA
Text: gases. For instance, the Japanese use our

Speaker: NA
Text: aluminium, but we smelt· it here and the

Speaker: NA
Text: greenhouse gas emissions are added to our

Speaker: NA
Text: total rather than that of the Japanese who are

Speaker: NA
Text: the end users. Acknowledging the dependence

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia on energy intensive industries, we

Speaker: NA
Text: still cannot take the state of our greenhouse

Speaker: NA
Text: emissions lightly, and I would ask the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister to address this problem as a matter

Speaker: NA
Text: of urgency.

Speaker: NA
Text: It gives me no pleasure to point out that

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's exhaust emission standards are

Speaker: NA
Text: more like those of a Third World country.

Speaker: NA
Text: Our cars are allowed to spew twice as many

Speaker: NA
Text: hydrocarbons into the air as US cars, and

Speaker: NA
Text: three times as many as Japanese cars. I would

Speaker: NA
Text: ask the Minister to perhaps follow up on this

Speaker: NA
Text: with our car companies to see what they are

Speaker: NA
Text: best able to do, and I myself have already

Speaker: NA
Text: initiated conversations with Mitsubishi on this

Speaker: NA
Text: very issue.

Speaker: NA
Text: At present there appears to be a great deal

Speaker: NA
Text: of attention in the climate change section of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister's department focused upon

Speaker: NA
Text: international aspects of greenhouse-and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister. referred to that in her speech. As

Speaker: NA
Text: desirable as this may be, I ask the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: whether this is a wise use of our limited

Speaker: NA
Text: resources when to date so little has been done

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australia to explore the extent of the

Speaker: NA
Text: problem and to address the possible impact on

Speaker: NA
Text: our shores and coastal towns. In future, in the

Speaker: NA
Text: matter of greenhouse, I would like to see a

Speaker: NA
Text: statement by the Minister identifying potential

Speaker: NA
Text: areas of risks on possible sea level rise.

Speaker: NA
Text: In international negotiations on the environcommitment

Speaker: NA
Text: ment can the Minister ensure that Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: competitive position is given due regard? The

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister's desire to make an international

Speaker: NA
Text: impact is understandable. However, if the end

Speaker: NA
Text: result is that Australia lowers her competitive

Speaker: NA
Text: position in regard to other nations while they

Speaker: NA
Text: pursue their own economic agenda at the

Speaker: NA
Text: expense of environmental issues, then Austral-

Speaker: NA
Text: ia will be the loser.

Speaker: NA
Text: Poor economies are in no position to ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: dress the large number of environmental

Speaker: NA
Text: issues that they have to face. Australia has a

Speaker: NA
Text: large number of such issues: desertification;

Speaker: NA
Text: the degradation of the Murray-Darling Basin;

Speaker: NA
Text: soil erosion; and dry land salinity being only

Speaker: NA
Text: a few. We need a strong economy and a good

Speaker: NA
Text: trading position to address these problems.

Speaker: NA
Text: The coalition welcomes the Minister's com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mitment to addressing the problems of green-

Speaker: NA
Text: house and looks forward to the detail about

Speaker: NA
Text: implementation of the greenhouse strategy.

Speaker: NA
Text: I turn now to the biodiversity convention in

Speaker: NA
Text: which the Minister noted that Australia played

Speaker: NA
Text: a leading role in the development of the

Speaker: NA
Text: convention and is continuing to play a key

Speaker: NA
Text: role in its implementation both internationally

Speaker: NA
Text: and, more specifically, in the Asia-Pacific

Speaker: NA
Text: region. The Minister points out that the

Speaker: NA
Text: convention needs only 30 ratifications for it

Speaker: NA
Text: to come into effect and says she is greatly

Speaker: NA
Text: encouraged that President Clinton has an-

Speaker: NA
Text: nounced the intention of the United States to

Speaker: NA
Text: sign the convention. I endorse the Minister's

Speaker: NA
Text: comment-the coalition is also extremely

Speaker: NA
Text: pleased to see President Clinton's interest in

Speaker: NA
Text: this convention and his agreement to sign it.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, I ask the Minister: why has

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia delayed so long in signing the

Speaker: NA
Text: convention? We have ratified the climate

Speaker: NA
Text: change convention but have yet to ratify the

Speaker: NA
Text: biodiversity convention. Why has it taken so

Speaker: NA
Text: long? What is the hold-up? The Minister, in

Speaker: NA
Text: her speech, said that she was going to New

Speaker: NA
Text: York in June when there is a possibility that

Speaker: NA
Text: she will ratify the convention. If not, we

Speaker: NA
Text: would suggest to the Minister that this would

Speaker: NA
Text: be a good time for her to. present the paper-

Speaker: NA
Text: work required for ratification of the conven-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion.

Speaker: NA
Text: The coalition welcomes the Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: to maintaining biodiversity but

Speaker: NA
Text: we would like more details. The goals of the

Speaker: NA
Text: maintenance of biodiversity are fully support-

Speaker: NA
Text: ed. We would like to see more of the specif-

Speaker: NA
Text: ics. In particular, the coalition believes that

Speaker: NA
Text: not enough has been done on feral animal

Speaker: NA
Text: control. The extension of national parks and

Speaker: NA
Text: world heritage areas are all very well but of

Speaker: NA
Text: little use if these parks and world heritage

Speaker: NA
Text: areas are ravaged by feral foxes, rabbits,

Speaker: NA
Text: goats, pigs, cats and brumbies. We would also

Speaker: NA
Text: welcome a statement from the Minister on

Speaker: NA
Text: sustainable agriculture.

Speaker: NA
Text: The coalition hopes that opportunities are

Speaker: NA
Text: provided to business and industry groups to

Speaker: NA
Text: participate extensively in the finalisation of

Speaker: NA
Text: the biodiversity strategy. Affected parties such

Speaker: NA
Text: as pastoralists, mining and exploration bodies,

Speaker: NA
Text: as well as conservation groups, must be given

Speaker: NA
Text: the opportunity to contribute effectively to

Speaker: NA
Text: such strategy. I shall return to community

Speaker: NA
Text: consultation later in agenda 21.

Speaker: NA
Text: I turn now to the Minister's statements on

Speaker: NA
Text: agenda 21. The Minister is confident that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government can meet the obligations that

Speaker: NA
Text: agenda 21 places on Australia through the

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangements established under the 1992

Speaker: NA
Text: intergovernmental agreement on the environ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. By abolishing the cabinet committee on

Speaker: NA
Text: sustainable development, the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Keating) has cast some doubt on the

Speaker: NA
Text: genuineness of his commitment to the ESD

Speaker: NA
Text: process. The Minister indicated that she

Speaker: NA
Text: believed Australia's only ESD strategy is

Speaker: NA
Text: already see- as something of a model in

Speaker: NA
Text: implementing the recommendations of agenda

Speaker: NA
Text: I believe what has been praised is not so

Speaker: NA
Text: much the strategy itself but the consultative

Speaker: NA
Text: process that went into it. We would hope that

Speaker: NA
Text: this consultation process continues, although

Speaker: NA
Text: we note with concern that earlier in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister's speech she referred to receiving

Speaker: NA
Text: comments from parties outside the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. I think the actual words were 'to

Speaker: NA
Text: receive'. We believe there is a need to do

Speaker: NA
Text: more than receive comments but to actively

Speaker: NA
Text: involve parties outside government in the

Speaker: NA
Text: development of strategies that deal with the

Speaker: NA
Text: environment.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister mentions using the IGAE and

Speaker: NA
Text: ESD policy as mechanisms to implement

Speaker: NA
Text: agenda 21. We would like further details from

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister on how this will actually take

Speaker: NA
Text: place. We naturally are more interested in the

Speaker: NA
Text: details than the broad assertions. For instance,

Speaker: NA
Text: we would like to hear more about the oppor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunities Rio provides for environmentally

Speaker: NA
Text: friendly industries, green jobs and utilisation

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australian expertise overseas. I would

Speaker: NA
Text: welcome a statement by the Minister on what

Speaker: NA
Text: we are doing about these key issues, also the

Speaker: NA
Text: major issue of the urban environment, and

Speaker: NA
Text: perhaps what progress the Minister has made

Speaker: NA
Text: in her department in looking at green account-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing and how we can put into the national

Speaker: NA
Text: accounts system the environmental values that

Speaker: NA
Text: are so important for the future of this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister's statement is welcome inas-

Speaker: NA
Text: much as it sets out the Government's response

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Earth Summit. We give notice that we

Speaker: NA
Text: will be closely monitoring the Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: activities to ensure that the rhetoric is

Speaker: NA
Text: matched by action.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate (on motion by Mr Chynoweth)

Speaker: NA
Text: adjourned.

Speaker: NA
Text: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE

Speaker: NA
Text: Economy

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Speaker has

Speaker: NA
Text: received a letter from the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Higgins ( Mr Costello) proposing that a

Speaker: NA
Text: definite matter of public importance. be

Speaker: NA
Text: submitted to the House for discussion, name-

Speaker: NA
Text: ly:

Speaker: NA
Text: The deplorable financial mismanagement of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government as highlighted by the Auditor-

Speaker: NA
Text: General's report on the financial obligations of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Federal Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: I call upon those members who approve of

Speaker: NA
Text: the proposed diScussion to rise in their places.

Speaker: NA
Text: More than the number o/members required

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Standing Orders having risen in their

Speaker: NA
Text: places-

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Text: Higgins) (3.58 p.m.)-

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government's economic policy is in a

Speaker: NA
Text: shambles. Whether you look at the current

Speaker: NA
Text: account, the foreign debt, the Budget deficit

Speaker: NA
Text: or the Government's financial obligations, it

Speaker: NA
Text: is clear that this is a government driven by

Speaker: NA
Text: debt. It is a debt driven government. The

Speaker: NA
Text: tragedy of Australia is that the legacy of 10

Speaker: NA
Text: years of Keating mismanagement is that

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia is haunted by debt. There is a

Speaker: NA
Text: spectre that is haunting the Australian people,

Speaker: NA
Text: and it is the debt that has been run up under

Speaker: NA
Text: 10 years of mismanagement by the Keating

Speaker: NA
Text: Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: The latest blow came yesterday when report

Speaker: NA
Text: No. 34 of the Auditor-General entitled The

Speaker: NA
Text: national Bankcard: who will pay the piper?

Speaker: NA
Text: was tabled in the Senate. It has been tabled

Speaker: NA
Text: today in the House. The Auditor-General has

Speaker: NA
Text: savaged this Government, its reporting mecha-

Speaker: NA
Text: nism, its accountability and the way in which

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government reports to the Parliament and

Speaker: NA
Text: to the taxpayers. The Auditor-General has

Speaker: NA
Text: found that the Government has entered obli-

Speaker: NA
Text: gations of around $125 billion and has set

Speaker: NA
Text: aside only about $57 billion of liquid assets

Speaker: NA
Text: to meet them. The report says that the figure

Speaker: NA
Text: is known to be understated. The question is

Speaker: NA
Text: by how much. How much has this Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment run up on the Bankcard? How much

Speaker: NA
Text: will future generations of Australians have to

Speaker: NA
Text: pay for the Government's mismanagement?

Speaker: NA
Text: Who will pay the piper, as the Auditor-Gener-

Speaker: NA
Text: al says?

Speaker: NA
Text: We find that the Government has no plan

Speaker: NA
Text: to stabilise debt, let alone pay it back, and no

Speaker: NA
Text: plan which can service the debts that have

Speaker: NA
Text: been run up in the last 10 years of Keating

Speaker: NA
Text: mismanagement. This Government has a

Speaker: NA
Text: policy in relation to debt which says, 'Let the

Speaker: NA
Text: children pay; run the debts up today and put

Speaker: NA
Text: the debts onto the children tomorrow'. It is a

Speaker: NA
Text: let the children pay policy of running up debt

Speaker: NA
Text: on Bankcard and asking future generations of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians to bail out this profligate Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment.

Speaker: NA
Text: We saw an absolutely shameful perform-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance in Question Time today when the Treas-

Speaker: NA
Text: urer ( Mr Dawkins) came in here and launched

Speaker: NA
Text: a savage attack on the Auditor-General. It was

Speaker: NA
Text: a disgraceful attack. Let me make it clear: the

Speaker: NA
Text: Auditor-General of the Commonwealth is

Speaker: NA
Text: appointed by the Government; he is given

Speaker: NA
Text: statutory protection; but the Auditor-General

Speaker: NA
Text: reports to the Parliament. The Auditor-Gener-

Speaker: NA
Text: al is one of those independent statutory

Speaker: NA
Text: officers reporting to the Parliament. The

Speaker: NA
Text: office of the Auditor-General was designed to

Speaker: NA
Text: be free of government influence, to provide

Speaker: NA
Text: a check on government waste, and to provide

Speaker: NA
Text: a check on government mismanagement.

Speaker: NA
Text: In relation to the Auditor-General, this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has made exactly the same

Speaker: NA
Text: response that it makes to the Parliament. It

Speaker: NA
Text: resents checks - on its authority; it resents

Speaker: NA
Text: independent statutory officers; it resents those

Speaker: NA
Text: independent mechanisms that force it to be

Speaker: NA
Text: accountable. This Government treats the

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament with contempt; and today we saw

Speaker: NA
Text: evidence that this Government treats the

Speaker: NA
Text: Auditor-General with contempt. I say to this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government that the Opposition, which

Speaker: NA
Text: believes the Parliament is here for a purpose,

Speaker: NA
Text: believes that the Auditor-General is here for

Speaker: NA
Text: a purpose. The Auditor-General is here to

Speaker: NA
Text: keep the Government honest and we will not

Speaker: NA
Text: brook any attack on his independence. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Auditor-General is here to keep a check on

Speaker: NA
Text: runaway government.

Speaker: NA
Text: What does the Treasurer say about it? The

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer comes into this place and accuses

Speaker: NA
Text: the Auditor-General of making unwarranted

Speaker: NA
Text: remarks, of being neither professional nor

Speaker: NA
Text: responsible. I want to tell the people of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia who it is that is being unprofession-

Speaker: NA
Text: al. It is the Treasurer, who comes into a place

Speaker: NA
Text: where he enjoys parliamentary privilege and

Speaker: NA
Text: who starts attacking public servants because

Speaker: NA
Text: they tell the truth.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is reminiscent of the dying days of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Kirner Government in Victoria-another

Speaker: NA
Text: government in financial difficulty, and another

Speaker: NA
Text: government which, in its dying days,

Speaker: NA
Text: launched attacks on the Auditor-General. We

Speaker: NA
Text: will see more of these attacks-attacks on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament, attacks on the Opposition, attacks

Speaker: NA
Text: on the Auditor-General, attacks on the

Speaker: NA
Text: messengers-because the Government does

Speaker: NA
Text: not like the truth.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us be clear about why this attack was

Speaker: NA
Text: made in the Parliament today. This attack was

Speaker: NA
Text: made in the Parliament today because this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government is trying to intimidate the Audi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tor-General out of telling the truth. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: why the attack was made. The Government

Speaker: NA
Text: does not want the Auditor-General to disclose

Speaker: NA
Text: to the people of Australia, to the taxpayers of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, why the Government has got into

Speaker: NA
Text: this particular financial situation. It is nothing

Speaker: NA
Text: more than straight intimidation.

Speaker: NA
Text: The people of Australia need the Auditor-

Speaker: NA
Text: General. They need the Auditor-General to be

Speaker: NA
Text: fearless because they need somebody who is

Speaker: NA
Text: prepared to tell the truth about the debt and

Speaker: NA
Text: economic mismanagement of this Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. The Opposition will not stand by and

Speaker: NA
Text: let the Government attack the Auditor-Gener-

Speaker: NA
Text: al. We will not stand by and let it try to shoot

Speaker: NA
Text: the messengers. We will not stand by and let

Speaker: NA
Text: it cover up all the profligacy and all of the

Speaker: NA
Text: debt because we will stand up and speak the

Speaker: NA
Text: truth and tell the people of Australia, 'This

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has let you down'.

Speaker: NA
Text: This Government is building up debt on a

Speaker: NA
Text: bankcard which will have to be paid back by

Speaker: NA
Text: future generations. It is a form of robbing the

Speaker: NA
Text: future. The Government has not only robbed

Speaker: NA
Text: the current generation, but also is now rob-

Speaker: NA
Text: bing the future. It is building up unfunded

Speaker: NA
Text: liabilities-liabilities of today-but not

Speaker: NA
Text: aside money to pay for them. There is only

Speaker: NA
Text: one way that they can be honoured; there is

Speaker: NA
Text: only one way that those unfunded liabilities

Speaker: NA
Text: can be brought to fruition in the futurethat

Speaker: NA
Text: is, by taxing the future generations of Australgovernment

Speaker: NA
Text: ia. Future generations of Australians are being

Speaker: NA
Text: robbed today by the profligacy of this Gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government's reaction is not only in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to the most recent Auditor-General's

Speaker: NA
Text: report. There is a foreign debt problem which,

Speaker: NA
Text: under the Keating treasurership, started off at

Speaker: NA
Text: $23 billion and after 10 years has gone to

Speaker: NA
Text: $168 billion, soaking up about three times our

Speaker: NA
Text: export earnings. There was the current ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: count figure in March of $2.1 billion. If the

Speaker: NA
Text: IMF is beginning to knock on doors in Cana-

Speaker: NA
Text: da, we hear an eerie silence in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Watch out for those knocks because this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has taken debt out of hitherto

Speaker: NA
Text: acceptable levels.

Speaker: NA
Text: Then there is the Budget deficit. When the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Finance ( Mr Willis) came to that

Speaker: NA
Text: portfolio he inherited a surplus of $8 billion.

Speaker: NA
Text: Over the three years of the last Parliament he

Speaker: NA
Text: turned that around to a $16 billion deficit,

Speaker: NA
Text: largest in Australian history. Even if he brings

Speaker: NA
Text: in all the projections, between 1991 and 1997

Speaker: NA
Text: he will run up a deficit of about $80 billion.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the last financial year, this Government

Speaker: NA
Text: was overspending on revenue-that is, spend:-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing more than it raised-by about $45 million

Speaker: NA
Text: a day. Over that six-year period the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment will rack up a deficit of about $80

Speaker: NA
Text: billion, comparable only to the Whitlam

Speaker: NA
Text: period. They will be saying, 'Willis is greater

Speaker: NA
Text: than Whitlam' in the financial history of the

Speaker: NA
Text: years to come.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are no redeeming features whatso-

Speaker: NA
Text: ever. At least Whitlam went broke keeping

Speaker: NA
Text: his promise, but this Government is going to

Speaker: NA
Text: go broke breaking its promises. We have seen

Speaker: NA
Text: the already littered history of broken promis-

Speaker: NA
Text: es. Remember the promise about the free

Speaker: NA
Text: dental scheme? Remember the promise about

Speaker: NA
Text: the home-care child allowance, now on the

Speaker: NA
Text: never-never? Remember the matching funds

Speaker: NA
Text: for the charities? Remember what the Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Party said in the election, that it was going to

Speaker: NA
Text: setting take pensioners out of the tax system?

Speaker: NA
Text: The breaking of that promise is going to

Speaker: NA
Text: leave a bitter winter of betrayal for Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioners. It is going to be a bitter winter of

Speaker: NA
Text: betrayal for all those people who look to

Speaker: NA
Text: to keep its promises. We know

Speaker: NA
Text: what the Government is up to. The Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment is trying to soften up the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: public for new taxes. It cannot honour its

Speaker: NA
Text: promises, it cannot get its deficits under

Speaker: NA
Text: control, and it is trying to soften up Austral-

Speaker: NA
Text: ians for new taxes. It asks whether it should

Speaker: NA
Text: bring in an energy tax, an extended goods tax,

Speaker: NA
Text: a wealth tax that the ACTU wants, or death

Speaker: NA
Text: duties, which the Labor Party loves.

Speaker: NA
Text: We say the answer is none of the above

Speaker: NA
Text: because when the Australian public voted in

Speaker: NA
Text: that election they did not vote for any new

Speaker: NA
Text: taxes. They did not want the Government to

Speaker: NA
Text: increase taxes to pay for tax cuts. The Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian people voted against taxes in the

Speaker: NA
Text: election. So the Government should read

Speaker: NA
Text: those votes: no new taxes. It should read them

Speaker: NA
Text: well, because the Australian public are not

Speaker: NA
Text: going to be benign on this Government when

Speaker: NA
Text: it goes into higher taxes. Let us make it

Speaker: NA
Text: absolutely clear that there is only one reason

Speaker: NA
Text: the for higher taxes: if the Government will not

Speaker: NA
Text: cut its own spending, it will have to cut the

Speaker: NA
Text: taxpayers' spending. It is going to cut the

Speaker: NA
Text: taxpayers' spending by taking taxes out of

Speaker: NA
Text: taxpayers' pockets so that they cannot spend.

Speaker: NA
Text: This Government will not control its own

Speaker: NA
Text: spending, and so it intends to cut the spending

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Australian taxpayers.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me come to the Auditor-General's

Speaker: NA
Text: report-the Auditor-General who gave this

Speaker: NA
Text: report the title The national Bankcard: who

Speaker: NA
Text: will pay the piper? This was a first attempt to

Speaker: NA
Text: report on the financial obligations of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government, and it was scathing. In fact, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Auditor-General said he did not even have

Speaker: NA
Text: enough information to state clearly and

Speaker: NA
Text: precisely how large the obligations were. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Auditor-General said:

Speaker: NA
Text: The ANAO considers that the information

Speaker: NA
Text: currently provided is deficient to such an extent

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Parliament and the taxpayer is not in a

Speaker: NA
Text: position to assess the Government's management.

Speaker: NA
Text: He went on to say:

Speaker: NA
Text: And what of concerns that future generations

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians will be made to pay for the excesses

Speaker: NA
Text: todays generation? Again the Parliament and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian taxpayers are not provided with informa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion necessary to determine the extent of

Speaker: NA
Text: intergenerational transfers resulting from current

Speaker: NA
Text: policy decisions.

Speaker: NA
Text: Then the Auditor-General went on to talk

Speaker: NA
Text: about accountability and the infonnation that

Speaker: NA
Text: has to be given to this Parliament to get that

Speaker: NA
Text: kind of accountability. He went on to say that

Speaker: NA
Text: the infonnation-which the Government does

Speaker: NA
Text: not have-would be essential for good man-

Speaker: NA
Text: agement of a company. If the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: were running a company it would have to do

Speaker: NA
Text: better than this. This Government has a Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: before the Parliament to ensure that com-

Speaker: NA
Text: panies engage in continuous financial disclos-

Speaker: NA
Text: ure. But, even on an annual budgetary basis,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government cannot disclose liabilities in

Speaker: NA
Text: superannuation. What hypocrites I How can

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government possibly lecture Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: business on the need for continuous financial

Speaker: NA
Text: disclosure when it is not even disclosing on

Speaker: NA
Text: an annual basis the infonnation that its audi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tor requires to make an assessment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me give a hypothetical example. When

Speaker: NA
Text: the Westpac Bank was getting into trouble

Speaker: NA
Text: and Sir Eric Neal was reporting as the chair-

Speaker: NA
Text: man, how would the Australian financial

Speaker: NA
Text: community have reacted if he had stood up

Speaker: NA
Text: and said, 'Well, our auditor is unprofessional.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is all the fault of our auditor. '? If a com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pany director behaved like that he would

Speaker: NA
Text: probably find himself in a court of law. Yet

Speaker: NA
Text: that is exactly what this Government is doing.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is standing up and saying, 'We can't give

Speaker: NA
Text: you the infonnation that would even be

Speaker: NA
Text: required in the management of a good com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pany, but let's tell you all about our auditor.

Speaker: NA
Text: He's unprofessional. Don't take any notice of

Speaker: NA
Text: him. He's belled the cat. He's disclosed the

Speaker: NA
Text: financial situation. We don't like people like

Speaker: NA
Text: that. We stand up in parliament and we attack

Speaker: NA
Text: people like that. We don't want the Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment and the taxpayer to know that kind of

Speaker: NA
Text: infonnation'.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us also make this clear: the Auditor-

Speaker: NA
Text: General did not say that Australia was insol-

Speaker: NA
Text: vent; he said it would be insolvent if it were

Speaker: NA
Text: not for the power to tax. We know that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government can solve its solvency problems

Speaker: NA
Text: of by expropriating the property of taxpayers.

Speaker: NA
Text: of We know that. The Government has this

Speaker: NA
Text: unique ability when it gets into financial

Speaker: NA
Text: situations to take money from others to rectify

Speaker: NA
Text: the problem.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bottom line of that is, as we see in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget deficit, that all roads lead to tax. But

Speaker: NA
Text: the worst feature of those roads that are

Speaker: NA
Text: leading to tax is that they are not just the

Speaker: NA
Text: taxes of today's citizens, they are not just

Speaker: NA
Text: today's taxes, because, as the Auditor-General

Speaker: NA
Text: makes entirely clear, this Government is

Speaker: NA
Text: engaged in an intergenerational transfer. It has

Speaker: NA
Text: not set aside the money today for the liabili-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties of today. It will have to get those taxes

Speaker: NA
Text: from future generations of Australians. Future

Speaker: NA
Text: generations of Australians under the 'Let the

Speaker: NA
Text: children pay policy' will be given a legacy of

Speaker: NA
Text: debt and obligation. As if it were not bad

Speaker: NA
Text: enough to run debts on this generation of

Speaker: NA
Text: voters, this Government has decided to finan-

Speaker: NA
Text: cially abuse the next one as well.

Speaker: NA
Text: We say to the Government, 'Come clean

Speaker: NA
Text: with the Australian people. Provide that

Speaker: NA
Text: information. Come clean on your obligations.

Speaker: NA
Text: Thoroughly audit your liabilities. Announce

Speaker: NA
Text: a debt strategy. Attend to the burgeoning

Speaker: NA
Text: outlays. And, above all, keep your hands off

Speaker: NA
Text: future generations of Australians because they

Speaker: NA
Text: know that the current ones have suffered

Speaker: NA
Text: badly enough'.

Speaker: Mr WILLIS
Text: Gellibrand-Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Finance) (4.12 p.m.)-We just heard a quarter

Speaker: NA
Text: of an hour of diatribe. I did not hear a sen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sible remark in the whole quarter of an hour.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us get this in some sort of perspective.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable member for Higgins ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Costello) talks about the Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: financially abusing the children because there

Speaker: NA
Text: is some government debt-running up debt in

Speaker: NA
Text: our period of office and putting it on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Bankcard. As the report makes clear, the level

Speaker: NA
Text: of government debt at 30 June 1992 was 11.8

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent of GOP, which compares favourably

Speaker: NA
Text: with the average of the last 10 years of 13.2

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent-it has come down.

Speaker: NA
Text: We had four years of budget surpluses, the

Speaker: NA
Text: only surpluses that have ever been produced

Speaker: NA
Text: by a government in the history of this country

Speaker: NA
Text: since we have had the modem budgeting

Speaker: NA
Text: system. Through the 1950s, 1960s, 1970s and

Speaker: NA
Text: 1980s when the Opposition was in govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment it could never produce one budget

Speaker: NA
Text: surplus. We produced four budget surpluses,

Speaker: NA
Text: with a collective $18 billion of surplus in

Speaker: NA
Text: time. The honourable member for Higgins

Speaker: NA
Text: should not stand here lecturing us about

Speaker: NA
Text: financial propriety. We are the ones who

Speaker: NA
Text: produced the budget surpluses. We are the

Speaker: NA
Text: ones who actually reduced the debt compared

Speaker: NA
Text: with the average of the last 10 years. Let us

Speaker: NA
Text: get that in some perspective.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us also look at the way that other

Speaker: NA
Text: governments have their debt structures and

Speaker: NA
Text: how we sit in relation to them. The OECD

Speaker: NA
Text: Economic Outlook for December .1992 pub-

Speaker: NA
Text: lished gen-ral government net debt for 18

Speaker: NA
Text: OECD countries. It lists them in groups of

Speaker: NA
Text: high debt countries, medium debt countries

Speaker: NA
Text: and low debt countries. The high debt count-

Speaker: NA
Text: ries are Belgium, Italy, Ireland and Greece,

Speaker: NA
Text: with a range of government debt to GOP of

Speaker: NA
Text: 124 per cent to 82 per cent. The medium debt

Speaker: NA
Text: countries are Netherlands, Canada, Austria,

Speaker: NA
Text: United States, Spain and the United Kingdom,

Speaker: NA
Text: with a range of government debt to GOP of

Speaker: NA
Text: 60 per cent to 36 per cent. The low debt

Speaker: NA
Text: countries are Denmark at 29 per cent, France

Speaker: NA
Text: at 29 per cent, Germany at 23 per cent and

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia at 15.8 per cent. There are four

Speaker: NA
Text: countries below us: Finland, Japan, Sweden

Speaker: NA
Text: and Norway. The average government debt as

Speaker: NA
Text: a proportion of GOP of all the countries is

Speaker: NA
Text: 43.6 per cent. Australia's debt is 15.8-about

Speaker: NA
Text: a third of the average of all the OECD count-

Speaker: NA
Text: ries.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those opposite should not give us this

Speaker: NA
Text: absolute garbage about our being financially

Speaker: NA
Text: irresponsible. This Government has a relative-

Speaker: NA
Text: ly low level of debt compared with that of

Speaker: NA
Text: most other OECD Western developed count-

Speaker: NA
Text: ries and, financially, it has behaved very

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibly in its period in office. Of course

Speaker: NA
Text: there has been an increase in the deficit in

Speaker: NA
Text: reCent times and that has meant an increase in

Speaker: NA
Text: debt. But that has been the experience of

Speaker: NA
Text: every Westerri country in the last few years.

Speaker: NA
Text: There has been an international economic

Speaker: NA
Text: recession which has meant that all govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments have suffered losses of tax revenue and

Speaker: NA
Text: increases in government expenditure, particu-

Speaker: NA
Text: larly on unemployment benefits. Therefore,

Speaker: NA
Text: most countries have run up bigger budget

Speaker: NA
Text: deficits and a couple have reduced surpluses.

Speaker: NA
Text: The budgetary situations in all of those

Speaker: NA
Text: that countries have deteriorated in recent times.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is nothing unique about Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: experience in that regard. It is what happens

Speaker: NA
Text: when the economic cycle turns down.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have added to that a little by our efforts

Speaker: NA
Text: to stimulate the economy, and various other

Speaker: NA
Text: countries have done exactly the same thing.

Speaker: NA
Text: Even the United Kingdom Conservative

Speaker: NA
Text: Government had a massive change in its

Speaker: NA
Text: budget outcome from a budget surplus to a

Speaker: NA
Text: deficit of about six per cent of GOP. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: well above ours as a proportion of GOP. That

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has done that largely because of

Speaker: NA
Text: the automatic blow-out of the budget due to

Speaker: NA
Text: recession and also due to the action it has

Speaker: NA
Text: taken to try to stimulate the economy. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: happening in just about all of the Western

Speaker: NA
Text: countries. So this absurd notion that Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: is somehow uniquely suffering some increase

Speaker: NA
Text: in its deficit and that the Government is

Speaker: NA
Text: therefore culpable in the extreme and is

Speaker: NA
Text: laying a terrible burden on future generations

Speaker: NA
Text: is just total garbage.

Speaker: NA
Text: Obviously, it is not a matter of no concern

Speaker: NA
Text: that there has been an increase in the deficit.

Speaker: NA
Text: We recognise the importance of getting the

Speaker: NA
Text: deficit down. We have made the declaration

Speaker: NA
Text: that we will reduce it to one per cent of GDP

Speaker: NA
Text: over the medium term-by 1996-97. That

Speaker: NA
Text: point has been made amply in recent times;

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not need to go into it any further.

Speaker: NA
Text: I return to the Auditor-General's report.

Speaker: NA
Text: Essentially, it says that the Government needs

Speaker: NA
Text: to make some changes to government ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: counting procedures so as to provide a full

Speaker: NA
Text: view of the Government's true financial

Speaker: NA
Text: position. We accept that it is desirable to do

Speaker: NA
Text: that. In fact; we have already adopted the

Speaker: NA
Text: major reforms needed to bring that about-

Speaker: NA
Text: that is, a move to a system of accrual ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: counting. It is already happening. It happens

Speaker: NA
