Text: in most of the GBBs and government authori-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties. I said last year that we were going to

Speaker: NA
Text: introduce it as from 1994-95 in reports of all

Speaker: NA
Text: government departments. Once we move to an

Speaker: NA
Text: accrual system all the departments will give

Speaker: NA
Text: a full assessment of assets and liabilities-I

Speaker: NA
Text: stress the assets as well as the liabilities;

Speaker: NA
Text: assets are remarkably lacking in this analy-

Speaker: NA
Text: sis-and then we will have full accounting,

Speaker: NA
Text: department by department, of their overall

Speaker: NA
Text: balances.

Speaker: NA
Text: Putting all that together, along with the

Speaker: NA
Text: GBBs and authorities-most of which have

Speaker: NA
Text: already moved to accrual accounting-we can

Speaker: NA
Text: get whole of government reporting. Research

Speaker: NA
Text: is already going on to see what is involved in

Speaker: NA
Text: bringing all of that together to get whole of

Speaker: NA
Text: government accounting happening in a proper

Speaker: NA
Text: way. If that research comes up with the right

Speaker: NA
Text: result, we may well be able to move, as the

Speaker: NA
Text: Auditor-General would like, to a whole of

Speaker: NA
Text: government reporting process by 1995. That

Speaker: NA
Text: will be fine; we have no problems with that

Speaker: NA
Text: whatever. In fact, virtually all the information

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Auditor-General says is lacking at the

Speaker: NA
Text: present time will come to light through the

Speaker: NA
Text: move to accrual accounting. We have no

Speaker: NA
Text: problem with that point. That is not to say

Speaker: NA
Text: that all of the recommendations are accept-

Speaker: NA
Text: able; they are not, and I will come to a couple

Speaker: NA
Text: of those.

Speaker: NA
Text: While it has been in office the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: has made various improvements to its finan-

Speaker: NA
Text: cial management so as to provide more

Speaker: NA
Text: information to the public. Before we came to

Speaker: NA
Text: office there were no forward estimates of

Speaker: NA
Text: outlays showing what expenditures would be,

Speaker: NA
Text: department by department, for the Budget

Speaker: NA
Text: year plus three more years; that did not exist.

Speaker: NA
Text: We publish those outlays in the Budget

Speaker: NA
Text: papers each year so that the people of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia are aware of where all of those outlays

Speaker: NA
Text: for program expenditures are going.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government has that knowledge. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Government, I might say, has knowledge

Speaker: NA
Text: beyond that. As appropriate, we look at

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditures in a longer time frame. Where

Speaker: NA
Text: we think that there may be something going

Speaker: NA
Text: to happen if we pursue a certain course which

Speaker: NA
Text: might have consequences in the out years that

Speaker: NA
Text: would be of concern, then we might do some

Speaker: NA
Text: analysis of that for our own internal purposes.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is not a matter of the Government not

Speaker: NA
Text: knowing beypnd the four-year period. We do

Speaker: NA
Text: know where it matters but it is just not rel-

Speaker: NA
Text: evant or necessary to do it for every program.

Speaker: NA
Text: The assessment of superannuation liability

Speaker: NA
Text: is also something that has been produced

Speaker: NA
Text: consistently since we have been in office. It

Speaker: NA
Text: was first produced in 1982, before we came

Speaker: NA
Text: into office, but we have updated it regularly

Speaker: NA
Text: since. So the amount of unfunded superannua-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion liability is something which comes to

Speaker: NA
Text: light every few years. We have a three-year

Speaker: NA
Text: cycle, which has become a five-year cycle at

Speaker: NA
Text: the moment because of the· big changes that

Speaker: NA
Text: were made to government superannuation in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1990. The introduction of the public sector

Speaker: NA
Text: superannuation scheme and the changes to

Speaker: NA
Text: invalidity requirements meant that there was

Speaker: NA
Text: a considerable cut in the costs of public sector

Speaker: NA
Text: superannuation and until that new scheme

Speaker: NA
Text: settles down it is appropriate to delay the

Speaker: NA
Text: recalculation of the unfunded liability. But

Speaker: NA
Text: that will take place next year and then be on

Speaker: NA
Text: a three-year cycle. So we will continually

Speaker: NA
Text: have the actuary doing that update and pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: viding that information. It is not a matter of

Speaker: NA
Text: hiding information. We have produced it

Speaker: NA
Text: several times since we have been in office

Speaker: NA
Text: and we will continue to do so.

Speaker: NA
Text: As a consequence of the changes that we

Speaker: NA
Text: have already made the Government publishes

Speaker: NA
Text: most of the information contained in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Auditor-General's report. Where do honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able members think he got these figures from?

Speaker: NA
Text: He got them from government reports of one

Speaker: NA
Text: sort or another. In a couple of cases he had to

Speaker: NA
Text: make some estimates-and he did that with

Speaker: NA
Text: the assistance of my department, I might

Speaker: NA
Text: say-but mostly it was publicly available

Speaker: NA
Text: information. What he has done here is to

Speaker: NA
Text: draw it all together. In the case of the unfund-

Speaker: NA
Text: ed liability he updated it with advice from my

Speaker: NA
Text: department.

Speaker: NA
Text: So we do not see that where there are

Speaker: NA
Text: deficiencies in the availability of information

Speaker: NA
Text: there is a problem; because most of that will

Speaker: NA
Text: become available anyway with the decisions

Speaker: NA
Text: already taken. Departments have been told,

Speaker: NA
Text: for instance, that next year they must account

Speaker: NA
Text: for employee entitlements. After that they will

Speaker: NA
Text: be on full accrual accounting and so the

Speaker: NA
Text: information will all be available.

Speaker: NA
Text: This report does have a number of deficien-

Speaker: NA
Text: cies. While seeking to assess total financial

Speaker: NA
Text: obligations, it does not take full account of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government's assets or indeed some

Speaker: NA
Text: revenues that are legally to flow to the Gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment. The report refers only to available

Speaker: NA
Text: liquid assets of $57 billion. It says, 'Here

Speaker: NA
Text: all these obligations' -some of them involve

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditures going out 30 or 40 years- 'but

Speaker: NA
Text: you have got only $57 billion in the bank

Speaker: NA
Text: pay for it'. These are expenditures which

Speaker: NA
Text: be 40 years away. It is stupid to compare cash

Speaker: NA
Text: assets with liabilities going out in 30 or

Speaker: NA
Text: years time. Of course, what we need is full

Speaker: NA
Text: accounting. That will involve government

Speaker: NA
Text: assets being brought into the picture-and

Speaker: NA
Text: that will be possible with accrual account-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing-and also bringing in revenue, which is

Speaker: NA
Text: not done in this report. That is revenue

Speaker: NA
Text: is legally obliged to be paid to the Governknow

Speaker: NA
Text: ment.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have mentioned international comparisons,

Speaker: NA
Text: which are patently lacking in the Auditorprogram

Speaker: NA
Text: General's report. The report also implies that

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget deficits that go beyond the expendiyears.

Speaker: NA
Text: ture on infrastructure are inappropriate be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause they impose a burden on future genera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions. It seems to say that the whole General

Speaker: NA
Text: countercyclical approach of fiscal policy

Speaker: NA
Text: wrong. That seems to be a terribly narrow obligation,

Speaker: NA
Text: accounting based approach to the role of

Speaker: NA
Text: government in terms of budgetary policy.

Speaker: NA
Text: Budgetary policy is not just about each year

Speaker: NA
Text: producing a balanced book, but also about

Speaker: NA
Text: making sure that the economy runs as well as

Speaker: NA
Text: it possibly can. That means that at times there

Speaker: NA
Text: will be Budget deficits and at times, hopefulback

Speaker: NA
Text: ly, Budget surpluses according to the economsuperannuation

Speaker: NA
Text: ic cycle. It does not mean a rigid adherence

Speaker: NA
Text: to Budget outcomes which are balanced or

Speaker: NA
Text: near to.

Speaker: NA
Text: The report claims that funding decisions

Speaker: NA
Text: taken by the Government lack the benefit

Speaker: NA
Text: the information that would normally be

Speaker: NA
Text: available in any well-run company which

Speaker: NA
Text: manages the level and impact of its obliga-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions on future cash flows, costs and invest-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment decisions. I think that is not a true

Speaker: NA
Text: statement. It is patently untrue in my view.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government takes decisions in the full

Speaker: NA
Text: knowledge of the likely costs of funding

Speaker: NA
Text: various programs over a four-year period.

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Text: You've never got a Budget

Speaker: NA
Text: right yet.

Speaker: Mr WILLIS
Text: Does the honourable membenefits

Speaker: NA
Text: ber want us to make the estimates over a

Speaker: NA
Text: longer period, like five to 20 years, as the

Speaker: NA
Text: are Auditor-General suggests? Does he think there

Speaker: NA
Text: would not be even bigger errors involved

Speaker: NA
Text: there? Of course we can only make estimates.

Speaker: NA
Text: to We cannot make entirely accurate forecasts;

Speaker: NA
Text: can we can make the best estimates available.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is what we do in relation to those For-

Speaker: NA
Text: 40 ward Estimates. Obviously, they have errors

Speaker: NA
Text: and the longer one goes out, the more likely

Speaker: NA
Text: there are to be errors in them.

Speaker: NA
Text: We also have a lot of other information that

Speaker: NA
Text: is available to us, and I suspect much more

Speaker: NA
Text: which than is available to many businesses. We

Speaker: NA
Text: all about our debts; they are published

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Budget each year. We know all about

Speaker: NA
Text: our guarantees; they are published in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget each year. We know all about our

Speaker: NA
Text: outlays to the extent that we need to

Speaker: NA
Text: know, and we do calculations beyond the out

Speaker: NA
Text: In relation to superannuation, the Auditor-

Speaker: NA
Text: suggests a number of things. Firstly,

Speaker: NA
Text: is he says that there is a $40 billion unfunded

Speaker: NA
Text: but there is no reference to the fact

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Government changed the scheme in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1990 and in doing so reduced unfunded

Speaker: NA
Text: liabilities when it did so by $5 billion and

Speaker: NA
Text: new entrants costs by one-third. There was no

Speaker: NA
Text: mention of that and that is a deficiency in the

Speaker: NA
Text: report. There is no recognition of the .claw-

Speaker: NA
Text: saving resulting from tax payable on

Speaker: NA
Text: paid, and there are reduced

Speaker: NA
Text: pension payouts because people are on super-

Speaker: NA
Text: annuation and not on pensions. In fact, on our

Speaker: NA
Text: best estimate that clawback cuts the cost by

Speaker: NA
Text: $19 billion of that $40 billion. Almost half

Speaker: NA
Text: of the costs are saved by the clawback which

Speaker: NA
Text: gets no mention whatever in this report.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is also the case that the Government is

Speaker: NA
Text: not a private or a public company and there-

Speaker: NA
Text: fore it will not go broke. The security prob-

Speaker: NA
Text: lem relating to the need for funded superan-

Speaker: NA
Text: nuation in companies so that people can be

Speaker: NA
Text: sure that they have their retirement· benefits

Speaker: NA
Text: when they retire is not an issue for a govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment which will be in place for the long term.

Speaker: NA
Text: People can have unfUJided liability knowing

Speaker: NA
Text: that they will - able to get their retirement

Speaker: NA
Text: when they are due. This report has a

Speaker: NA
Text: lot of shortcomings, but the basic recommen-

Speaker: NA
Text: dations are generally acceptable. (TIme ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: pired)

Speaker: Mr NEHL
Text: Cowper) (4.27 p.m.)-I have

Speaker: NA
Text: listened with absolute amazement-and I will

Speaker: NA
Text: give the words of the Minister for Finance

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Willis) straight back to him-to this

Speaker: NA
Text: garbage. He started off fulminating against the

Speaker: NA
Text: Auditor-General and us by saying, 'Do not

Speaker: NA
Text: give us this garbage'. He wants to provide

Speaker: NA
Text: some perspective about government debt, but

Speaker: NA
Text: I have a message for the Minister: we are not

Speaker: NA
Text: talking about debt. The Auditor-General's

Speaker: NA
Text: report is not about debt or deficit, yet for the

Speaker: NA
Text: last 15 minutes the Minister has carried on

Speaker: NA
Text: talking about debt and deficit. We are not

Speaker: NA
Text: here about that. We are here about obliga-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions, arrangements and commitments. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: what the Auditor-General's report is about. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is not about government debt as a proportion

Speaker: NA
Text: of GOP.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister suggested fairly early on that

Speaker: NA
Text: the whole thing was an absurd notion. The

Speaker: NA
Text: way the Minister has approached this matter

Speaker: NA
Text: is ,absurd. The reality is that today during

Speaker: NA
Text: Question Time the Treasurer ( Mr Dawkins)

Speaker: NA
Text: delivered a most disgraceful attack on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Auditor-General of this country. Having been

Speaker: NA
Text: associated with and a member of the Joint

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee of Public Accounts for the last

Speaker: NA
Text: three parliaments, I know what a good job the

Speaker: NA
Text: Auditor-General does and how much the

Speaker: NA
Text: people of Australia and the Parliament of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia depend on the Auditor-General.

Speaker: NA
Text: Every member of this House should react

Speaker: NA
Text: adversely to the attack of the Treasurer on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Auditor-General today. It was totally inappro-

Speaker: NA
Text: priate.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister for Finance, in winding up his

Speaker: NA
Text: contribution, said that there were no interna-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional comparisons in the report. Why does he

Speaker: NA
Text: want international comparisons? Does he want

Speaker: NA
Text: to be able to say that we are not as badly off

Speaker: NA
Text: as Somalia or somewhere else? What does he

Speaker: NA
Text: want them for? What value are they? We are

Speaker: NA
Text: concerned about the level of obligation and

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment of this Government to the people

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia. Quite frankly, the Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: obligations are about $16,000 for every

Speaker: NA
Text: taxpayer. The Australian National Audit

Speaker: NA
Text: Office has identified-I repeat the figures-

Speaker: NA
Text: that outstanding Federal Government obliga-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions are in excess of $125 billion, and we

Speaker: NA
Text: know that this figure is understated. Nobody

Speaker: NA
Text: knows what the real figure is.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are getting accrual accounting in a year

Speaker: NA
Text: or two. Some government departments are

Speaker: NA
Text: bringing in accrual accounting, and it is about

Speaker: NA
Text: time. I applaud the Minister for doing that; it

Speaker: NA
Text: is the right way to go. We should have been

Speaker: NA
Text: doing it a long time ago. We can be critical

Speaker: NA
Text: of past g()vernments that they did not bring in

Speaker: NA
Text: accrual accounting.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are now dealing with a government that

Speaker: NA
Text: has been in power for 10 years. We are

Speaker: NA
Text: dealing with this Government that is guilty of

Speaker: NA
Text: financial mismanagement. The Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: demonstrated that this afternoon when ,he

Speaker: NA
Text: talked about debt and deficit. The matter of

Speaker: NA
Text: public importance is not about debt and

Speaker: NA
Text: deficit; it is about obligations, arrangements

Speaker: NA
Text: and commitments. It is quite obvious that any

Speaker: NA
Text: board of direCtors running a company the way

Speaker: NA
Text: the present and past Cabinet have run this

Speaker: NA
Text: country would not just be sacked; they would

Speaker: NA
Text: be gaoled.

Speaker: NA
Text: This afternoon the Treasurer, in his dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: graceful attack, said just how wrong and

Speaker: NA
Text: conceptually inaccurate that report is and' he

Speaker: NA
Text: referred to the people producing it as irre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponSible. His throwaway line was 'if they

Speaker: NA
Text: were properly qualified'. I think that is a

Speaker: NA
Text: disgraceful attack on public servants who

Speaker: NA
Text: serve our society so well.

Speaker: NA
Text: On the need to disclose, he said, 'Oh well,

Speaker: NA
Text: we are moving in that direction', but he said

Speaker: NA
Text: that it was neither professional nor responsible

Speaker: NA
Text: of the auditor to raise the possibility that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government could not meet its obligations.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Treasurer finished by saying that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth has the power to tax. Yes;we

Speaker: NA
Text: know that the Commonwealth does have the

Speaker: NA
Text: power to tax. I want to put on the record that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Auditor-General in that report made that

Speaker: NA
Text: particular point. He said:

Speaker: NA
Text: The Commonwealth's· power to tax should en-

Speaker: NA
Text: sure-

Speaker: NA
Text: it 'should' ensure actually; that is interest-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing-

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Commonwealth remains solvent at all

Speaker: NA
Text: times.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us hope so. But the auditor then went on

Speaker: NA
Text: to raise three possibilities for the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: to remain solvent. It can do it by increasing

Speaker: NA
Text: receipts by options such as increasing taxation

Speaker: NA
Text: levels or privatising government assets. Is it

Speaker: NA
Text: going to increase the taxation levels? Is it

Speaker: NA
Text: going to privatise again and again? The next

Speaker: NA
Text: one was:

Speaker: NA
Text: . the Federal Government being forced to reduce

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure in other areas of government, such as

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure, thereby lowering the future standards

Speaker: NA
Text: of living of Australians,

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not debate that. I accept that, because

Speaker: NA
Text: blind Freddy knows that it is true, right and

Speaker: NA
Text: correct. We know-and we knew before the

Speaker: NA
Text: last election-that this country is broke. All

Speaker: NA
Text: we have now is infonnation of future disaster.

Speaker: Mr LLOYD
Text: And they lied to Australia.

Speaker: Mr NEHL
Text: They certainly lied to Austral-

Speaker: NA
Text: ia. There is no doubt about that. Obligation

Speaker: NA
Text: levels are increasing. This report does not

Speaker: NA
Text: attempt to examine the Commonwealth's

Speaker: NA
Text: obligations over a period of time, but certain-

Speaker: NA
Text: ly the obligations will result in an escalation

Speaker: NA
Text: of servicing costs, and that can have wider

Speaker: NA
Text: economic implications, particularly with

Speaker: NA
Text: increased dependence on foreign debt by both

Speaker: NA
Text: private and public sectors.

Speaker: NA
Text: For the Auditor-General to make those

Speaker: NA
Text: points, quite contrary to what the Treasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: said, I believe was professional and respon-

Speaker: NA
Text: sible. It certainly sounds professional and

Speaker: NA
Text: responsible to me. But we have an increasing

Speaker: NA
Text: dependence on foreign debt, and we all know

Speaker: NA
Text: of our foreign debt. It is now $168 billion net.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is interesting that, although the figures are

Speaker: NA
Text: different-they are very much higher-they

Speaker: NA
Text: put us in mind of Whitlam. There is a little

Speaker: NA
Text: sniff of Whitlam in the air with all of this. In

Speaker: NA
Text: fact, I can say to honourable members in this

Speaker: NA
Text: chamber that the Government might be

Speaker: NA
Text: asking, 'Khemlani, where are you? We need

Speaker: NA
Text: you'. That is what the Government needs. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister (Me Keating) needs Khemlani

Speaker: NA
Text: because our country is going to go even

Speaker: NA
Text: further down the drain.

Speaker: NA
Text: This matter of public importance on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Auditor-General's report is all about financial

Speaker: NA
Text: mismanagement. Again the Minister at the

Speaker: NA
Text: table does not speak to the issue or about the

Speaker: NA
Text: contents of the report. He concentrates on

Speaker: NA
Text: debt and deficits when we are talking about

Speaker: NA
Text: obligations.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Braithwaite-And sell more bananas.

Speaker: Mr NEHL
Text: I always respond to an inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: jection about selling marvellous bananas from

Speaker: NA
Text: my electorate, but we are concerned that

Speaker: NA
Text: future generations will be made to pay for the

Speaker: NA
Text: eX(fesses of today's generation. I believe that

Speaker: NA
Text: to be true. The cost of servicing central

Speaker: NA
Text: government borro-ings is estimated to in-

Speaker: NA
Text: crease by 60 per cent over the next four

Speaker: NA
Text: years. That estimate is at the current interest

Speaker: NA
Text: rates. Can honourable members imagine what

Speaker: NA
Text: that will do when we get, as we probably

Speaker: NA
Text: will, an increase in interest rates?

Speaker: NA
Text: Superannuation outlays have virtually

Speaker: NA
Text: doubled over the past 10 years. What about

Speaker: NA
Text: the next 10 years? I am particularly interested

Speaker: NA
Text: in this because unfunded superannuation and

Speaker: NA
Text: government obligations are rising as a per-

Speaker: NA
Text: centage of GDP. Of course, we have not even

Speaker: NA
Text: mentioned the Government's liabilities for

Speaker: NA
Text: long service leave, annual leave or 171h per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent annual leave loading.

Speaker: NA
Text: I ask whether superannuation is a govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment priority. I am particularly interested in

Speaker: NA
Text: this point because I recently had a visit from

Speaker: NA
Text: an Australian Taxation Office official who

Speaker: NA
Text: asked me to help him advise small businesses

Speaker: NA
Text: in my electorate which are going broke to pay

Speaker: NA
Text: their superannuation levy. If they do not pay

Speaker: NA
Text: it by 30 June they will lose tax deductibility

Speaker: NA
Text: in this financial year. Then they have until 14

Speaker: NA
Text: August, and if they are one day late they not

Speaker: NA
Text: only lose tax deductibility altogether but also

Speaker: NA
Text: have interest imposed on them straight away.

Speaker: NA
Text: As well as that, I think there is a fee of $50

Speaker: NA
Text: per employer and $30 per employee. I believe

Speaker: NA
Text: it is fair enough that the Taxation Office

Speaker: NA
Text: should help people to realise that D-day is

Speaker: NA
Text: coming: deduction day, doomsday-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Truss-Disaster day.

Speaker: Mr NEHL
Text: Disaster day indeed. I am busy

Speaker: NA
Text: in my electorate helping to infonn employers

Speaker: NA
Text: and employees about the need to meet their

Speaker: NA
Text: obligations in relation to superannuation.

Speaker: NA
Text: What is the Minister doing? Where is the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's obligation, where is its commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment and where are its accruals to meet the

Speaker: NA
Text: superannuation that will have to be paid out

Speaker: NA
Text: before too long?

Speaker: NA
Text: I conclude by saying that it is unlikely that

Speaker: NA
Text: even the smallest Australian business would

Speaker: NA
Text: base decisions on the limited information-

Speaker: NA
Text: the limited knowledge and the limited facts-

Speaker: NA
Text: upon which this Government is running this

Speaker: NA
Text: country. I commend what the Auditor-General

Speaker: NA
Text: and his officers have done; they have high-

Speaker: NA
Text: lighted something that needed to be highlight-

Speaker: NA
Text: ed. We need more open government and more

Speaker: NA
Text: information, and I think' it is about time that

Speaker: NA
Text: this present Government faced up to its

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibilities. It should no longer continue

Speaker: NA
Text: to distort the issue, as the Minister did today

Speaker: NA
Text: in talking about debt and the deficit when we

Speaker: NA
Text: are talking about obligations and commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments.

Speaker: Mr ELLIOTT
Text: parramatta) (4.37 p.m.)-In

Speaker: NA
Text: speaking to the matter of public importance

Speaker: NA
Text: today, I think it is important at the outset to

Speaker: NA
Text: give some recognition to the positive steps

Speaker: NA
Text: that have been taken. I do not believe the

Speaker: NA
Text: Auditor-General's report No. 34 adequately

Speaker: NA
Text: reflects the reforms that have been undertaken

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Government in terms of disclosure of

Speaker: NA
Text: the accrual accounting arrangements and so

Speaker: NA
Text: on to which the Minister for Finance ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Willis) has referred, the general provisioning

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Government in relation to superannua-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, and the changes that have been undertak-

Speaker: NA
Text: en constantly in that area. We can go a step

Speaker: NA
Text: further and say that the Auditor-General's

Speaker: NA
Text: report is framed in the most narrow account-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing terms. It does not take account of the

Speaker: NA
Text: broader economic issues one would have

Speaker: NA
Text: thought that a report which is trying to deal

Speaker: NA
Text: with these issues and which carries the emo-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive title that it does would have sought to

Speaker: NA
Text: reflect.

Speaker: NA
Text: In speaking to the matter of public import-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance today, as in all these economic discus-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions, opposition members continue to. decry

Speaker: NA
Text: the economic recovery and continue to pour

Speaker: NA
Text: scorn on what positive economic news there

Speaker: NA
Text: may be. Indeed, the coverage of the Auditor-

Speaker: NA
Text: General's report in today's newspapers simi-

Speaker: NA
Text: larly misrepresents many of the constructive

Speaker: NA
Text: points and overstates some of the criticisms

Speaker: NA
Text: that are contained in the report. As far as I

Speaker: NA
Text: can see, that is really the problem in this

Speaker: NA
Text: debate: not enough regard has been given to

Speaker: NA
Text: the positive steps which have been taken. It

Speaker: NA
Text: seems to me that the Auditor's report reflects

Speaker: NA
Text: an historical perspective more than a current

Speaker: NA
Text: perspective of the initiatives and reforms that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government has undertaken.

Speaker: NA
Text: I turn first to the area of accrual accounting.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Auditor-General's report makes some

Speaker: NA
Text: worthwhile recommendations in this area, but

Speaker: NA
Text: it fails to give credit to the Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: recent initiatives. It fails to recognise that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Finance has taken major steps in

Speaker: NA
Text: this area. For example, some 35 government

Speaker: NA
Text: departments have volunteered to take part in

Speaker: NA
Text: a pilot program to produce financial state-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments on an accrual basis in 1992-93. The

Speaker: NA
Text: remaining departments will be doing the same

Speaker: NA
Text: in their 1993-94 statements.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are several reasons why the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has moved to accrual accounting ar-

Speaker: NA
Text: rangements: to identify the cost of govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment programs; provide cost control and

Speaker: NA
Text: efficiency methods; improve asset manage-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment; assist in determining. pricing policies

Speaker: NA
Text: for user charging; monitor increased produc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tivity; enhance accountability; and so on. We

Speaker: NA
Text: did not have to wait for the Auditor-General

Speaker: NA
Text: to produce this report before addressing these

Speaker: NA
Text: matters. These steps have been put in place

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Minister for Finance and the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment for a significant time. This report does

Speaker: NA
Text: not give adequate weight to those sorts of

Speaker: NA
Text: issues.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable member for Cowper ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Nehl) spoke about the level of deficit, obliga-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions issues and so on. The Auditor-General's

Speaker: NA
Text: report is notable for not clearly defining the

Speaker: NA
Text: cyclical issues relating to the economy, the

Speaker: NA
Text: deficit and the obligations that might flow

Speaker: NA
Text: from that and the more significant structural

Speaker: NA
Text: issues.

Speaker: NA
Text: Looking at the deficit, what really matters

Speaker: NA
Text: is the capacity of the Government to manage

Speaker: NA
Text: the economy over time. The Auditor-

Speaker: NA
Text: General's report suggests that a long-term

Speaker: NA
Text: view should be taken about the management

Speaker: NA
Text: of the economy in the same way that a private

Speaker: NA
Text: company would develop its arrangements.

Speaker: NA
Text: Analysing what the Government has done

Speaker: NA
Text: through the 1980s and early 1990s, that is the

Speaker: NA
Text: sort of management the Government has

Speaker: NA
Text: regarded as important. The Government did

Speaker: NA
Text: plan Budget surpluses throughout the growth

Speaker: NA
Text: period of the late 1980s and has recognised

Speaker: NA
Text: that present cyclical conditions mean that we

Speaker: NA
Text: have to move into deficit to regain stimulus

Speaker: NA
Text: and growth in the economy.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable member for Cowper sug-

Speaker: NA
Text: gested an alternative strategy which, he says,

Speaker: NA
Text: is implied in the report. The alternative to

Speaker: NA
Text: having stimulus when the economy is re-

Speaker: NA
Text: cessed is to prolong that recession to make it

Speaker: NA
Text: more difficult to get the necessary growth·in

Speaker: NA
Text: the economy, which creates hardship for the

Speaker: NA
Text: people the honourable member spoke about.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government, quite rightly in my view,

Speaker: NA
Text: has said that it will get the Budget balanced

Speaker: NA
Text: over time rather than adopt the knee-jerk

Speaker: NA
Text: reaction that some appear to advocate; that is,

Speaker: NA
Text: it can all be achieved in one Budget. Clearly,

Speaker: NA
Text: a threeto four-year strategy needs to be

Speaker: NA
Text: developed to get the Budget balanced. It

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot be achieved overnight. The net effect

Speaker: NA
Text: of trying to achieve that overnight would be

Speaker: NA
Text: to create more economic mayhem.

Speaker: NA
Text: What would be the result of that mayhem?

Speaker: NA
Text: All that would happen is that revenue would

Speaker: NA
Text: fall and more government expenditure would

Speaker: NA
Text: be needed to meet those liabilities. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: big problem with this report. The clear impli-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation of a recession, such as the one we have

Speaker: NA
Text: now, is that revenues fall because less tax is

Speaker: NA
Text: paid, more unemployment benefits are paid

Speaker: NA
Text: and so on. That is precisely why the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has acted in the way it has to create the

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary economic stimulus.

Speaker: NA
Text: The other aspect of why this report is so

Speaker: NA
Text: narrow can best be illustrated by the way in

Speaker: NA
Text: which a household budget is dealt with.

Speaker: NA
Text: Working on the sorts of presumptions con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tained in the Auditor-General's report, it

Speaker: NA
Text: suggests that a household can fully meet

Speaker: NA
Text: every one of its obligations at a given point,

Speaker: NA
Text: even though the house mortgage is planned to

Speaker: NA
Text: be paid over 15 to 20 years. Not one house-

Speaker: NA
Text: hold in the country would plan its decision

Speaker: NA
Text: making on that basis and, quite frankly, nor

Speaker: NA
Text: would we expect it to. Yet it appears from the

Speaker: NA
Text: report that major public infrastructure should

Speaker: NA
Text: be accounted for and the Government should

Speaker: NA
Text: be meeting its superannuation commitment.

Speaker: NA
Text: That assumes that the complete liability for

Speaker: NA
Text: superannuation will fall due tomorrow, which

Speaker: NA
Text: is most unlikely and is quite narrow in con-

Speaker: NA
Text: text anyway. It also assumes that the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment is not moving towards meeting its

Speaker: NA
Text: ongoing superannuation commitments. Both

Speaker: NA
Text: of those assumptions are wrong.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government has taken positive steps

Speaker: NA
Text: over time to ensure that its superannuation

Speaker: NA
Text: commitments are more directly accounted for.

Speaker: NA
Text: Earlier, the Minister for Finance referred to

Speaker: NA
Text: the reporting process that is in train for that

Speaker: NA
Text: to occur. It has occurred in the past and will

Speaker: NA
Text: occur in the future. Those things are there and

Speaker: NA
Text: are being done.

Speaker: NA
Text: To. suggest that one can take that in the

Speaker: NA
Text: fashion the auditor refers to again reflects an

Speaker: NA
Text: inappropriate application of what the audit

Speaker: NA
Text: report really should be designed to achieve.

Speaker: NA
Text: Certainly what we do need to achieve is

Speaker: NA
Text: greater emphasis on disclosure and accounta-

Speaker: NA
Text: bility through those processes, but I do not

Speaker: NA
Text: think we need to conduct economic and fiscal

Speaker: NA
Text: policy with the narrowness suggested in this

Speaker: NA
Text: report.

Speaker: NA
Text: Certainly, I think it relevant, as the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Finance said in his speech, to provide

Speaker: NA
Text: some comparative reflection of Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: the position as against those of our international

Speaker: NA
Text: competitors on these sorts of issues. It is only

Speaker: NA
Text: through that process that we can really get to

Speaker: NA
Text: put aside some of the nonsense that is being

Speaker: NA
Text: talked about, to put back into perspective

Speaker: NA
Text: where our Budget position is, to understand

Speaker: NA
Text: why we had those surpluses in the 19808,

Speaker: NA
Text: why we have had the deficits in more recent

Speaker: NA
Text: times, and why we can manage our way

Speaker: NA
Text: through that process and get economic recov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ery going.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Opposition's approach to all these

Speaker: NA
Text: issues has been interesting. In the last three

Speaker: NA
Text: years of the Parliament, what sorts of things

Speaker: NA
Text: did the Opposition say would occur? It said

Speaker: NA
Text: there would be a double-dip recession. It was

Speaker: NA
Text: wrong on that one. It said we would have a

Speaker: NA
Text: run on the dollar. It has been wrong on that

Speaker: NA
Text: one. It said interest rates would be going up

Speaker: NA
Text: repeatedly through all that process, yet we

Speaker: NA
Text: have interest rates at the lowest level in 25

Speaker: NA
Text: years. So it was wrong on that one.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Opposition has gone on to make other

Speaker: NA
Text: sorts of similarly erroneous claims as to what

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government was going to do to the

Speaker: NA
Text: economy. It has referred constantly to the fact

Speaker: NA
Text: that the growth in the economy w- not going

Speaker: NA
Text: to be sustained. Clearly, the Government is

Speaker: NA
Text: detennined to make sure that growth is

Speaker: NA
Text: sustained. One of the mechanisms to make

Speaker: NA
Text: sure that growth is sustained is to have re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponsible Budget processes over a period of

Speaker: NA
Text: years, with a medium-tenn strategy that

Speaker: NA
Text: demonstrates how we overcome the economic

Speaker: NA
Text: difficulties we have in Australia but at the

Speaker: NA
Text: same time recognises that Australia's position,

Speaker: NA
Text: as compared with that of countries that we

Speaker: NA
Text: deal with, is certainly responsible and sound.

Speaker: NA
Text: Indeed, the auditor's report effectively demon-

Speaker: NA
Text: strates the soundness of our economy and

Speaker: NA
Text: makes the pointnot as strongly as it should

Speaker: NA
Text: be made-that the revenue side also has to be

Speaker: NA
Text: taken into account in these sorts of issues. It

Speaker: NA
Text: has not been, as far as the actual report

Speaker: NA
Text: documentation is concerned.

Speaker: NA
Text: For those reasons this MPI represents a

Speaker: NA
Text: further attempt by the Opposition to talk

Speaker: NA
Text: down economic recovery in Australia, at the

Speaker: NA
Text: very time when we need the Opposition to be

Speaker: NA
Text: prepared to come in here and support sustain-

Speaker: NA
Text: able economic recovery, built on low infla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, low interest rates and with the clear

Speaker: NA
Text: objective of ensuring our competitive position

Speaker: NA
Text: is enhanced versus those of our competitors.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Hollis) -

Speaker: NA
Text: Order! The time allotted for the discussion

Speaker: NA
Text: has expired.

Speaker: NA
Text: SOCIAL SECURITY AMENDMENT

Speaker: NA
Text: LEGISLATION

Speaker: NA
Text: Suspension of Standing Orders

Speaker: Mr RUDDOCK
Text: Berowra) (4.47 p.m)-I

Speaker: NA
Text: move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That so much of the Standing and Sessional

Speaker: NA
Text: Orders be suspended as would prevent the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister explaining to the House why he deliberatetest

Speaker: NA
Text: ly misled the House in claiming that the coalition

Speaker: NA
Text: 'rejected' and 'knocked back' the Social Security

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendment Bill 1993 which provides:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) an additional free area of $30 per fortnight for Bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: earned income for single recipients of

Speaker: NA
Text: jobsearch, newstart and sickness allowance and

Speaker: NA
Text: increases the free area applicable to such a

Speaker: NA
Text: partnered allowee from $30 to $50 a fortnight;

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) lifts the assets limit for pensioners;

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) rationalises certain waiting period provisions

Speaker: NA
Text: for the unemployed;

Speaker: NA
Text: when the fact is that the Opposition has not voted

Speaker: NA
Text: against the Bill in the Senate but has only voted in

Speaker: NA
Text: favour of adding to the Bill its amendment to

Speaker: NA
Text: repeal sections of the Social Security Act which

Speaker: NA
Text: treat unrealised capital gains as income for the

Speaker: NA
Text: purposes of the income test for pensioners, and,

Speaker: NA
Text: further, the Bill as amended was supported by the

Speaker: NA
Text: coalition. Similarly in the House of Representatives

Speaker: NA
Text: the coalition supported the Bill at its second

Speaker: NA
Text: reading and today in the House voted to maintain

Speaker: NA
Text: the Senate amendment.

Speaker: NA
Text: The purpose of this motion is to give the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister ( Mr Keating) the opportunity

Speaker: NA
Text: to come into this House and explain why he

Speaker: NA
Text: so misled it today.

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Text: Why are you so stunned?

Speaker: Mr RUDDOCK
Text: Why am I stunned that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister misled the House? I am

Speaker: NA
Text: stunned that any Prime Minister would be so

Speaker: NA
Text: cavalier as to mislead the House-and know-

Speaker: NA
Text: ingly mislead the House-when it is a hang-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing offence in this place. According to

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister Collins in the Senate this week, it is

Speaker: NA
Text: clearly a matter that would lead to the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister's resignation, unless he is able, in

Speaker: NA
Text: some way, to ameliorate the severity of the

Speaker: NA
Text: matter by apologising to the House and indi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cating how he came to make a mistake in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to this.

Speaker: NA
Text: Clearly, the Prime Minister made no

Speaker: NA
Text: mistake. I remind the House that he has been

Speaker: NA
Text: a member of this place longer than most of

Speaker: NA
Text: us. He knows better than any of us the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: ventions, the proprieties and the arrangements

Speaker: NA
Text: for carrying a Bill through the Parliament. He

Speaker: NA
Text: knows better than anybody else that simply to

Speaker: NA
Text: amend a Bill does not lead to its rejection. To

Speaker: NA
Text: simply amend a Bill does not-

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Text: We will test it.

Speaker: Mr RUDDOCK
Text: The Government may

Speaker: NA
Text: it in another place at another time, but

Speaker: NA
Text: that is a separate issue. At this stage, the

Speaker: NA
Text: coalition has not rejected, not knocked back,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Social Security Legislation Amendment

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Text: We don't know yet.

Speaker: Mr RUDDOCK
Text: The Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: seems to know. If the Prime Minister had

Speaker: NA
Text: said, 'We don't know but maybe, when the

Speaker: NA
Text: matter is called on for a vote, we will oppose

Speaker: NA
Text: it', that would have been a very different

Speaker: NA
Text: proposition from his saying categorically, as

Speaker: NA
Text: he did, that we rejected and knocked back the

Speaker: NA
Text: Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: When Prime Minister Hawke was caught in

Speaker: NA
Text: exactly the same situation he was a big

Speaker: NA
Text: enough man to come into the House and

Speaker: NA
Text: admit that he had misled us.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Tim Fischer-Bob Hawke did.

Speaker: Mr RUDDOCK
Text: Yes, former Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister Hawke, in relation to a matter raised

Speaker: NA
Text: by one of my colleagues, was a big enough

Speaker: NA
Text: man to come in and admit where he was

Speaker: NA
Text: wrong. Perhaps the present Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: was badly briefed, but I noticed in an answer

Speaker: NA
Text: to a question in the Senate this week that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government admitted to employing 310

Speaker: NA
Text: additional staff who are in a position to assist,

Speaker: NA
Text: counsel and advise Ministers and to monitor

Speaker: NA
Text: what happens. One would think that with all

Speaker: NA
Text: those staffers the Prime Minister could get

Speaker: NA
Text: accurate advice about what happened in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate.

Speaker: NA
Text: The only vote in the Senate was a vote on

Speaker: NA
Text: an amendment to the Bill-a vote called by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government and a vote which it lost. The

Speaker: NA
Text: only votes we have had called here today

Speaker: NA
Text: were those moved by government members,

Speaker: NA
Text: such as the Leader of the House ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Beazley), gagging honourable members on

Speaker: NA
Text: this side of the House. The only ones moved

Speaker: NA
Text: by this side of the House related to whether

Speaker: NA
Text: or not the amendment from the Senate should

Speaker: NA
Text: be maintained.

Speaker: NA
Text: Clearly, the Prime Minister was badly

Speaker: NA
Text: briefed. If he informed us that he was misled

Speaker: NA
Text: by his advisers, I am sure we would be big

Speaker: NA
Text: enough to accept that. The Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: could come in and say, 'I have been here for

Speaker: NA
Text: 20 years or more' -something he disparages

Speaker: NA
Text: in others, although he even got that wrong

Speaker: NA
Text: because I spent eight years in government, not

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition-'but I didn't understand the

Speaker: NA
Text: procedures and I made a mistake'. We will

Speaker: NA
Text: give him that opportunity in relation to this

Speaker: NA
Text: particular motion.

Speaker: NA
Text: I remind honourable members that I had

Speaker: NA
Text: something to say on this very issue before we

Speaker: NA
Text: voted on it. It may have been a little convo-

Speaker: NA
Text: luted because I was delivering my comments

Speaker: NA
Text: without the aid of notes, but the intention was

Speaker: NA
Text: clear and unambiguous. I said:

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to make it very clear that it is not our intent

Speaker: NA
Text: to deny the benefits that were provided for in the

Speaker: NA
Text: original Bill to people who receive newstart and the

Speaker: NA
Text: other beneficiary arrangements in place for those

Speaker: NA
Text: who are unemployed. ''-

Speaker: NA
Text: There is no ambiguity about that. I said:

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to make it very clear that it is not our

Speaker: NA
Text: intent-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Sciacca interjecting-

Speaker: Mr RUDDOCK
Text: The Parliamentary

Speaker: NA
Text: Secretary to the Minister for Social Security

Speaker: NA
Text: was here when I said it. Perhaps he was the

Speaker: NA
Text: one who so briefed the Prime Minister on this

Speaker: NA
Text: matter that he misled the House. Perhaps he

Speaker: NA
Text: is the culprit. Perhaps the Prime Minister can

Speaker: NA
Text: make him the sacrificial lamb. The Parliamen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tary Secretary should apologise· to the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for so grievously failing in the brief

Speaker: NA
Text: that he obviously prepared for him. The fact

Speaker: NA
Text: is that I made our position very clear. I

Speaker: NA
Text: continued:

Speaker: NA
Text: . . . nor do we want to inhibit the assets changes

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Government promised during the election.

Speaker: NA
Text: Our view is that the Government should implement

Speaker: NA
Text: its policy by supporting this Bill with our amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is the fact of the matter. There was no

Speaker: NA
Text: rejection by the Opposition of the proposals.

Speaker: NA
Text: They were not knocked back by the Opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, as the Prime Minister has asserted. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: astounded that a Prime Minister would put

Speaker: NA
Text: himself in a position where he comes into the

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament, so clearly misleads it and so

Speaker: NA
Text: clearly imputes to the Opposition an intention

Speaker: NA
Text: which cannot be imputed from anything we

Speaker: NA
Text: have said, anything we have done, or any

Speaker: NA
Text: vote in which we have participated.

Speaker: NA
Text: If the Prime Minister wants to come in and

Speaker: NA
Text: use words like 'vengeful' and 'vengeance'

Speaker: NA
Text: and impute some conduct to the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition (Dr Hewson) which is totally

Speaker: NA
Text: unreasonable and, on the evidence, totally

Speaker: NA
Text: wrong in every sense, he should not do it in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to an issue of this sort where he is

Speaker: NA
Text: using the vulnerability of the unemployed as

Speaker: NA
Text: a pawn in the political games that he wants to

Speaker: NA
Text: play. That is exactly what the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: was seeking to do: he wanted to use the

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployed and the pensioner community in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia as pawns in his. political game.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Prime Minister was really saying, 'If

Speaker: NA
Text: given the chance the Government would

Speaker: NA
Text: blackmail you, the Opposition, on this parup

Speaker: NA
Text: ticular matter. We don't know what your

Speaker: NA
Text: intention is. We don't know how you are

Speaker: NA
Text: going to handle it. But, if you are to press

Speaker: NA
Text: this matter to a point where ultimately

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation is at risk, we would blackmail you.

Speaker: NA
Text: We would say that the only way this legislathat

Speaker: NA
Text: tion can go through amended is if it had

Speaker: NA
Text: support. We won't give you that

Speaker: NA
Text: Therefore, the other provisions in the Bill will

Speaker: NA
Text: fail, and that is on your head'.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government cannot say that because

Speaker: NA
Text: we have not at any stage voted against the

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation. All we have done is positively

Speaker: NA
Text: vote for our amendments. The Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: clearly misled the House. If he is a man big

Speaker: NA
Text: enough to admit a mistake, he will be in here

Speaker: NA
Text: now to apologise, and he would not leave it

Speaker: NA
Text: to others such as the Leader of the House or

Speaker: NA
Text: the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: Social Security to wear the blame.

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Text: Bennelong-Manager of

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition Business) (4.57 p.m.)-I second

Speaker: NA
Text: the motion. The simple principle involved

Speaker: NA
Text: here boils down to whether the man holding

Speaker: NA
Text: the supreme office in this country tells the

Speaker: NA
Text: truth to this Parliament or not. Not even by

Speaker: NA
Text: using his not inconsiderable verbal skills can

Speaker: NA
Text: the Leader of the House ( Mr Beazley) explain

Speaker: NA
Text: away the fact that the Prime Minister ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Keating), who set out on an orchestrated

Speaker: NA
Text: attempt to discredit the Opposition, got

Speaker: NA
Text: facts hopelessly and completely wrong. As the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Berowra ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Ruddock) said, if the Prime Minister really

Speaker: NA
Text: were the national leader that he aspires to

Speaker: NA
Text: if he really felt a comfortable, secure Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister, a man not subject to the vulneraam

Speaker: NA
Text: bilities of politics, he would be big enough to

Speaker: NA
Text: come into this Parliament and say, 'Look,

Speaker: NA
Text: am sorry, I got it wrong'.

Speaker: NA
Text: His predecessor, Mr Hawke, did that on two

Speaker: NA
Text: occasions. The Leader of the National Party

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia ( Mr Tim Fischer) will remember

Speaker: NA
Text: one celebrated occasion, and I remember

Speaker: NA
Text: another occasion when the fonner Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister made a stupid imitation of place

Speaker: NA
Text: somebody's accent. He later realised that he

Speaker: NA
Text: had made a mistake, he came into the Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, and he was a big enough man to get up

Speaker: NA
Text: and say, 'I am sorry, I got it wrong'. He went

Speaker: NA
Text: in everybody's estimation as a result of

Speaker: NA
Text: that admission. Far be it for me to say that

Speaker: NA
Text: the present Prime Minister could ever go up

Speaker: NA
Text: in my estimation, but if he were to come in

Speaker: NA
Text: this here this afternoon and say, 'Look, I am

Speaker: NA
Text: sorry, I got it wrong; I withdraw, I apologise' ,

Speaker: NA
Text: would be the end of the matter and we

Speaker: NA
Text: our could both go out to Yarralumla and have a

Speaker: NA
Text: support. glass of champagne.

Speaker: NA
Text: But we should not hold our breath because

Speaker: NA
Text: he is not going to do that. To use his own

Speaker: NA
Text: words, he is a spiteful, vengeful man-and

Speaker: NA
Text: spiteful, vengeful people never apologise. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister lives by the doctrine that says

Speaker: NA
Text: you never resign, you never apologise, you

Speaker: NA
Text: never say you are sorry, no matter what the

Speaker: NA
Text: circumstances are. That might be all right in

Speaker: NA
Text: Sussex Street, but it is wearing a bit thin with

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian public. I think the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: for public is fed up with somebody who is not

Speaker: NA
Text: big enough to say he is sorry.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable member for Berowra, on

Speaker: NA
Text: behalf of the Opposition, has been sponsoring

Speaker: NA
Text: an attempt to restore a measure of justice to

Speaker: NA
Text: the pensioners of this country. He made it

Speaker: NA
Text: perfectly clear that he has not been trying to

Speaker: NA
Text: tear down, frustrate or prevent the implemen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tation of increased benefits to those people.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Prime Minister cannot by any stretch of

Speaker: NA
Text: the imagination accuse the Opposition of

Speaker: NA
Text: opposing any of these measures. The Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: his Minister misled the House, and he did it

Speaker: NA
Text: deliberately. He did not do it in the heat of

Speaker: NA
Text: the moment; he had a calculated attack

Speaker: NA
Text: prepared, all written out in front of him. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: be, inexcusable. He ought to come in here and

Speaker: NA
Text: display the guts required of him and say, 'I

Speaker: NA
Text: sorry and I withdraw what I said'.

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Text: Swan-Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: I House) (5.01 p.m.)-The Opposition has been

Speaker: NA
Text: hoist with its own petard absolutely magnifi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cently, and it is writhing in embarrassment at

Speaker: NA
Text: what it confronts with this particular matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: Far be it for the Opposition's spokesman on

Speaker: NA
Text: social security, the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Berowra ( Mr Ruddock), to wander into this

Speaker: NA
Text: and say that the Government trades on

Speaker: NA
Text: the vulnerability of the unemployed and the

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioners, because that is exactly what the

Speaker: NA
Text: smart alecs in the Opposition in the Senate

Speaker: NA
Text: intended to trade on in this regard. What

Speaker: NA
Text: have done, of course, is to compromise

Speaker: NA
Text: honour of the Opposition very

Speaker: NA
Text: compromise it on the point of a Budget

Speaker: NA
Text: measure put in by the Government in 1992 to

Speaker: NA
Text: oppose that-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Ruddock-Deal with the issues.

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Text: Compromise it by holding

Speaker: NA
Text: to ransom the' position of the groups named

Speaker: NA
Text: in the motion put forward by the Opposition.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us not forget that all the propositions

Speaker: NA
Text: forward by the Government in these areas

Speaker: NA
Text: were, one way or another, opposed either in

Speaker: NA
Text: spirit or in detail by the formulations put

Speaker: NA
Text: forward by the Opposition in its election it

Speaker: NA
Text: campaign.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Thckey-Rubbish!

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Text: A load of rubbish, is it,

Speaker: NA
Text: for the honourable member for O'Connor?

Speaker: NA
Text: What does he think the implications are for

Speaker: NA
Text: people who are seeking unemployment benthe

Speaker: NA
Text: efits when the proposition here is

Speaker: NA
Text: for those to be brought on more quickly,

Speaker: NA
Text: when those opposite are .looking for $900

Speaker: NA
Text: million worth of savings off it? Those opposthis

Speaker: NA
Text: ite went into the last election campaign

Speaker: NA
Text: looking for $900 million worth of savings out

Speaker: NA
Text: of the unemployed. These propositions will

Speaker: NA
Text: involve increased outlays in relation to people

Speaker: NA
Text: who are associated with the unemployed.

Speaker: NA
Text: do not try to hide behind some sort of fa-

Speaker: NA
Text: cade-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Ruddock-Not one vote against the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: proposal.

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Text: They should not think in

Speaker: NA
Text: that they can clothe themselves in some sort

Speaker: NA
Text: of rectitude in terms of their views on unemthe

Speaker: NA
Text: ployed people associated with this particular

Speaker: NA
Text: motion. The whole spirit of this legislation is

Speaker: NA
Text: opposed by the Opposition.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Ruddock-Not one vote.

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Text: The fact that the Opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion has chosen to block it in the Senate

Speaker: NA
Text: simply hides its intention for the legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Opposition was correctly flushed out by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister ( Mr Keating)-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Ronaldson-He is a liar.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: The honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: they member for Berowra will stop interjecting.

Speaker: NA
Text: the The honourable member for Ballarat will

Speaker: NA
Text: thoroughlywithdraw that comment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Ronaldson-I withdraw it.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: The honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Berowra was heard in relative

Speaker: NA
Text: silence and I would appreciate it if he would

Speaker: NA
Text: let the Leader of the House be heard.

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Text: The Opposition has been

Speaker: NA
Text: put caught out and it· knows it. It will have

Speaker: NA
Text: another test, of course. Having blocked it

Speaker: NA
Text: once, the test will be whether the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: will block it again. If the Opposition blocks

Speaker: NA
Text: again, then it will find all the consequences

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Prime Minister referred to from a

Speaker: NA
Text: second blockage flowing through to the

Speaker: NA
Text: people who the Opposition says it is not

Speaker: NA
Text: wishing to render vulnerable. We will know

Speaker: NA
Text: all about that very shortly. There will be an

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity to find out the veracity of what

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition says when the next piece of

Speaker: NA
Text: effectively legislation is discussed.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are important things to hand as far as

Speaker: NA
Text: House is concerned relating to the presen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tation to the Governor-General of the Ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: dress-in-Reply in about half an hour or so. I

Speaker: NA
Text: do not wish to disturb that. I notice that the

Speaker: NA
Text: second Opposition speaker did not use his full

Speaker: NA
Text: So time; neither will I.

Speaker: NA
Text: The fact of the matter is that the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister has nothing to apologise for. The

Speaker: NA
Text: has something to apologise for. It

Speaker: NA
Text: will·have an opportunity to render its apology

Speaker: NA
Text: the most effective way possible, to eschew

Speaker: NA
Text: its initial blockage of this legislation, when

Speaker: NA
Text: matter goes back to the Senate some time

Speaker: NA
Text: in the next day or so. I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the question be now put.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question resolved in the affirmative.

Speaker: NA
Text: Original question put:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the motion ( Mr Ruddock's) be agreed to.

Text: 1 MR GIBSON: To move-That this House:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) congratulates the UN Commission on Human

Speaker: NA
Text: Rights for adopting a resolution highly critical

Speaker: NA
Text: of the human rights situation in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Indonesian-occupied territory of East Timor;

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) congratulateS the Australian Government for

Speaker: NA
Text: supporting the resolution;

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) calls upon the Australian Government to

Speaker: NA
Text: persuade the Indonesian Government to com-

Speaker: NA
Text: ply with paragraph 9 of the resolution by

Speaker: NA
Text: enabling the UN special rapporteurs on torture

Speaker: NA
Text: and on extrajudicial, summary or arbitrary

Speaker: NA
Text: executions and the UN working group on

Speaker: NA
Text: arbitrary detention and on enforced or involun-

Speaker: NA
Text: tary disappearances to discharge their man-

Speaker: NA
Text: dates in accordance with the tenns of the

Speaker: NA
Text: resolution; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) welcomes the resumption of talks under the

Speaker: NA
Text: auspices of the Secretary-General of the UN

Speaker: NA
Text: to arrive at a just, comprehensive and

Speaker: NA
Text: tionally acceptable solution to the question of

Speaker: NA
Text: East Timor. (Notice given 10 May 1993.)

Text: (1) notes the visit of Mr Vo Van Kiet, Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister of the Socialist Republic of Vietnam

Speaker: NA
Text: to Australia, and deplores his Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: record of substantial human rights abuses; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) calls on the Government to:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) immediately and unconditionally release all

Speaker: NA
Text: political prisoners and prisoners of con-

Speaker: NA
Text: science, including the Venerable Thich

Speaker: NA
Text: Huyen Quang;

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) introduce basic human rights to Vietnam,

Speaker: NA
Text: including freedom of assembly, religious

Speaker: NA
Text: worship and speech, a free press and free

Speaker: NA
Text: and open elections;

Speaker: NA
Text: (c) provide for the creation of a pluralist free

Speaker: NA
Text: enterprise economy; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (d) demonstrate to the Parliament of Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: how and where aid monies provided to

Speaker: NA
Text: Vietnam by Australia are spent and how

Speaker: NA
Text: that aid encourages the cultivation of a more

Speaker: NA
Text: democratic and free society in Vietnam.

Text: MCPherson) (8.04

Speaker: NA
Text: p.m.)-I am delighted to have the opportunity

Speaker: NA
Text: to speak on the Veterans' Affairs Legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendment Bill, and in particular on the

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment made to the Bill in the Senate. I

Speaker: NA
Text: take every opportunity to speak on veterans

Speaker: NA
Text: affairs in this Parliament; I have a direct inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: est in the matter and, in some respects, one

Speaker: NA
Text: could almost construe a financial interest.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, I believe that I have a responsibility

Speaker: NA
Text: to veterans to speak at every opportunity.

Speaker: NA
Text: As the Leader of the National Party of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia ( Mr Tim Fischer) said earlier, this

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill has been supported by the Opposition and

Speaker: NA
Text: to a very great extent it still has our support.

Speaker: NA
Text: We support the changes that the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed to the assets test. We strongly

Speaker: NA
Text: support the changes to the definitions cover-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing service in Cambodia, in the former Yugo-

Speaker: NA
Text: slavia, and the peacekeeping service in Soma-

Speaker: NA
Text: lia, effectively granting additional benefits

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian servicemen who served and con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinue to serve with distinction in the areas

Speaker: NA
Text: which have now been determined to be

Speaker: NA
Text: operational areas. With the elections going on

Speaker: NA
Text: in Cambodia at the present time, I observe in

Speaker: NA
Text: passing that the United Nations contingent in

Speaker: NA
Text: that country is commanded by an Australian,

Speaker: NA
Text: Lt Gen. Sanderson. The troops under his

Speaker: NA
Text: command have performed with distinction,

Speaker: NA
Text: and pf course a substantial number of those

Speaker: NA
Text: troops are Australians.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, the Opposition remains implac-

Speaker: NA
Text: ably opposed to the Government's proposal to

Speaker: NA
Text: treat unrealised capital gains on veteran

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioners' shareholdings as income. We

Speaker: NA
Text: debated this matter at length this morning in

Speaker: NA
Text: the context of the Social Security Amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill. The Government is treating the proposal

Speaker: NA
Text: in the context of this legislation exactly as

Speaker: NA
Text: treated it in the context of the other legisla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion this morning. In effect, we are being

Speaker: NA
Text: blackmailed-I do not use the word lightly-

Speaker: NA
Text: into ultimately supporting something to which

Speaker: NA
Text: we are strongly opposed.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not think that I will change the mind

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Social Security ( Mr Sciacca) on this point

Speaker: NA
Text: tonight, because we argued about it all morn-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing. It seems that the Government has made

Speaker: NA
Text: up its mind to proceed to tax unrealised

Speaker: NA
Text: capital gains on pensioners' shareholdings.

Speaker: NA
Text: We were informed this morning that 60,000

Speaker: NA
Text: social security pensioners are affected by that

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation. In the context of this Bill, 24,000

Speaker: NA
Text: veterans are affected by the proposal-and

Speaker: NA
Text: that concerns me greatly.

Speaker: NA
Text: Although the matter was argued at length

Speaker: NA
Text: this morning, I do want to reiterate that we

Speaker: NA
Text: are opposed to the measure because it is

Speaker: NA
Text: unfair and it is totally unreasonable for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government to have proceeded in that direc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. Veterans are very special people. Many

Speaker: NA
Text: of them are now aged and, by and large, it is

Speaker: NA
Text: the aged veterans-veterans in receipt of a

Speaker: NA
Text: pension-who will be affected by this particu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lar proposal. As I said, there are 24,000 of

Speaker: NA
Text: them, and almost all will be adversely affect-

Speaker: NA
Text: ed.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not expect that the Parliamentary

Speaker: NA
Text: to Secretary will be able to answer the question

Speaker: NA
Text: any more clearly tonight than he did this

Speaker: NA
Text: morning, but I put it again: does the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment realise that the practical implication of

Speaker: NA
Text: this proposal is that people will be asked to

Speaker: NA
Text: live on less money than they have now?

Speaker: NA
Text: There is no way around that unless, as the

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliamentary Secretary admitted, they sell

Speaker: NA
Text: their shares or part of their shareholding. That

Speaker: NA
Text: is the despicable aspect of this part of the

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation: that we should say to certain

Speaker: NA
Text: people-aged people; in this case the 24,000

Speaker: NA
Text: veteran pensioners-that they can no longer

Speaker: NA
Text: hold shares; that they no longer have the right

Speaker: NA
Text: that every other Australian has to own shares

Speaker: NA
Text: in a public company.

Speaker: NA
Text: I also posed the question of how far the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government is prepared to go in seeking

Speaker: NA
Text: equity, as the Government calls it. When, for

Speaker: NA
Text: instance, will it start to value their homes

Speaker: NA
Text: it each year, or their cars? When does it move

Speaker: NA
Text: on to shares in private companies? The

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliamentary Secretary has already told us

Speaker: NA
Text: that they are not so marketable. Surely homes

Speaker: NA
Text: are marketable, in a sense, although they are

Speaker: NA
Text: not traded on the stock exchange. The princi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple of this proposal is so appallingly wrong

Speaker: NA
Text: that I cannot understand how the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: can argue for it.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am proud to be a member of an Opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion which has clearly spelt out its position.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the Senate the Opposition successfully

Speaker: NA
Text: indicated our complete opposition to this

Speaker: NA
Text: particular proposal as it affects social security

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioners and, in this case, 24,000 veterans.

Speaker: NA
Text: As a veteran, I am concerned that the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has failed us in the past. I would like to

Speaker: NA
Text: think that we could be bipartisan in our

Speaker: NA
Text: treatment of veterans, but it is difficult to

Speaker: NA
Text: bipartisan when we see the treatment that this

Speaker: NA
Text: special group of people receives at the hands

Speaker: NA
Text: of this Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: In Question Time today the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Keating) gave us an example of his

Speaker: NA
Text: attitude to this particular group of people. He

Speaker: NA
Text: underlined the deception that is inherent in

Speaker: NA
Text: this legislation, and the Opposition attempted

Speaker: NA
Text: to take him to task for that before we went to

Speaker: NA
Text: dinner. He denigrates the flag at every oppor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunity, and for very obvious reasons the flag

Speaker: NA
Text: is precious-not in the sense that he is-to

Speaker: NA
Text: almost every veteran. Yet the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: continues his denigration.

Speaker: NA
Text: Today in this Parliament he compounded a

Speaker: NA
Text: previous error by publicly insulting Brigadier

Speaker: NA
Text: Garland who is the head of the premier

Speaker: NA
Text: veterans organisation. What the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister said does not bear repeating. If the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister denigrates the heads of veter-

Speaker: NA
Text: ans organisations and the symbols that veter-

Speaker: NA
Text: ans served and died under, what can they

Speaker: NA
Text: expect of this Government?

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government's knee-jerk reaction to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Bushell case caused considerable anxiety in

Speaker: NA
Text: the veterans community. That piece of legisla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion now appears to have been consigned to

Speaker: NA
Text: the scrap heap where it belonged in the first

Speaker: NA
Text: place. It set out to diminish benefits to veterplaying

Speaker: NA
Text: ans, but there was little consultation with the

Speaker: NA
Text: veterans community. That is a constant source

Speaker: NA
Text: of anxiety. The Government was caught red-

Speaker: NA
Text: handed in attempting to reduce benefits to this

Speaker: NA
Text: very special group of people.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government's next test will be its

Speaker: NA
Text: response to the Auditor-General's report No.

Speaker: NA
Text: 8 on the Department of Veterans' Affairs.

Speaker: NA
Text: Veterans again genuinely fear that some of

Speaker: NA
Text: their benefits may be reduced or removed. I

Speaker: NA
Text: share their fear of the Government's response

Speaker: NA
Text: to that report. We will wait and see.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I said at the start of my limited remarks,

Speaker: NA
Text: this legislation extends the benefits of having

Speaker: NA
Text: served on active service to servicemen who

Speaker: NA
Text: served in Cambodia, the former Yugoslavia

Speaker: NA
Text: and Somalia. However, many World War II

Speaker: NA
Text: veterans are now aged, and some are suffering

Speaker: NA
Text: more each day. This sort of legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: amounts to harassment, and they should not

Speaker: NA
Text: be harassed by this Government. Some of

Speaker: NA
Text: be those veterans have shareholdings, and once

Speaker: NA
Text: again they will be concerned and worried at

Speaker: NA
Text: a time in their lives when they do not deserve

Speaker: NA
Text: to have that imposed upon them. This legisla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion is petty and it should never have been

Speaker: NA
Text: proceeded with.

Speaker: NA
Text: I hope veterans and pensioners will bring

Speaker: NA
Text: enough pressure to bear-it has been brought

Speaker: NA
Text: to bear on backbench members of the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment-to have this particular aspect of this

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation and the former legislation thrown

Speaker: NA
Text: out. It is totally flawed not only in concept

Speaker: NA
Text: but also in execution. Nobody seems to

Speaker: NA
Text: understand how it is worked out. We will

Speaker: NA
Text: remain completely opposed to this legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: (TIme expired)

Speaker: Mr SCIACCA
Text: Bowman-Parliamentary

Speaker: NA
Text: Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

Speaker: NA
Text: (8.14 p.m.)-Let me say to the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for MCPherson ( Mr Bradford) that I

Speaker: NA
Text: have absolutely no problems with his sincerity

Speaker: NA
Text: when he says that these measures are unfair.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, he is dead wrong; these measures

Speaker: NA
Text: are fair. I have already explained my reasons

Speaker: NA
Text: for saying that. This is the first opportunity I

Speaker: NA
Text: have had tonight to say that, if anyone in this

Speaker: NA
Text: House is denigrating anybody, it is not the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister ( Mr Keating), it is those

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite. In the Senate the Opposition, by

Speaker: NA
Text: theatrics and by including an amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment to what is essentially a good news Bill,

Speaker: NA
Text: is in effect risking entitlements to UN peace-

Speaker: NA
Text: keeping forces that we have serving in Yugo-

Speaker: NA
Text: slavia, Somalia and Cambodia-even 50 miles

Speaker: NA
Text: into Laos and Thailand.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those benefits will be at risk if the Opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion'continues to oppose this Bill. Honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: members opposite play semantics. They muck

Speaker: NA
Text: around with theatrics, as the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Berowra ( Mr Ruddock) did today.

Speaker: NA
Text: He made a big deal so that he could go and

Speaker: NA
Text: do a doorstop interview outside and make it

Speaker: NA
Text: look as if the Prime Minister had somehow

Speaker: NA
Text: misled this House. The fact is that the Oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition was just playing semantics-it was

Speaker: NA
Text: playing with words. The reality is that, if the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition continues to oppose both these

Speaker: NA
Text: Bills in their present form, then it is endan-

Speaker: NA
Text: gering the benefits outlined by the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister today which will affect some

Speaker: NA
Text: 200,000 people.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Bradford-That is blackmail.

Speaker: Mr SCIACCA
Text: The honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for MCPherson says that it is blackmail. If

Speaker: NA
Text: there is any blackmail, it is on the part of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition. The fact is that the treatment of

Speaker: NA
Text: shares was something that was passed in

Speaker: NA
Text: December 1992 with the full acquiescence of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition. The Opposition voted for it

Speaker: NA
Text: then, and now it wants to go against it. The

Speaker: NA
Text: ball is clearly in the Opposition's court.

Speaker: NA
Text: If at the end of the day the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: persists with this, we will make sure that

Speaker: NA
Text: every one of those 200,000 people who will

Speaker: NA
Text: not get these benefits will be told whose fault

Speaker: NA
Text: it was-and it was not ours. I hope thatthe

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition has some sense and decides to

Speaker: NA
Text: support the legislation. At the end of .the day

Speaker: NA
Text: the treatment of shares would still be the

Speaker: NA
Text: same because that was passed last year, but

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition would be depriving veterans-

Speaker: NA
Text: the people the Opposition says it wants to

Speaker: NA
Text: help, and I accept the sincerity of the honour- lenkins, H. A.

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for MCPherson-of benefits.

Speaker: NA
Text: I know that some of these measures are

Speaker: NA
Text: perceived by people in the electorate as being

Speaker: NA
Text: harsh. However, there is no bottomless pit.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are in government, not the Opposition.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those ,opposite were rejected quite categori-

Speaker: NA
Text: cally on 13 March. We are in government;

Speaker: NA
Text: they are in opposition. We have to make the

Speaker: NA
Text: decisions. Sometimes those decisions are not

Speaker: NA
Text: going to make us popular with a certain

Speaker: NA
Text: section of the population, but someone has to

Speaker: NA
Text: make those decisions-and we are making

Speaker: NA
Text: them.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are targeting the welfare dollar in the

Speaker: NA
Text: best possible way. We are answerable to the

Speaker: NA
Text: total Australian public; we are answerable to

Speaker: NA
Text: the taxpayer. We have an obligation to ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: that, irrespective of the theatrics that have

Speaker: NA
Text: been going on here all day today, that money

Speaker: NA
Text: is spent correctly.. The Government will be

Speaker: NA
Text: pressing ahead with the Bill the way it is. I

Speaker: NA
Text: move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the question be now put.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Committee divided. [8.22 p.m.]

Speaker: Mrs SULLIVAN
Text: Moncrieft) (8.40 p.m.)-

Speaker: NA
Text: I wish to speak very briefly on this matter. So

Speaker: NA
Text: far as I know I am the only member of this

Speaker: NA
Text: House-

Speaker: NA
Text: Motion (by Mr Sciacca) put:

Text: That the question be now put.
