Speaker: NA
Text: Committee of Reasons

Speaker: NA
Text: Motion (by Mr Sciacca) agreed to:

Speaker: NA
Text: That Mr Lindsay, Mr O'Connor and the mover

Speaker: NA
Text: Home, R.

Speaker: NA
Text: be appointed a committee to draw up reasons for

Speaker: NA
Text: Jenkins, H. A.

Speaker: NA
Text: the House of Representatives disagreeing to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Kerin, J. C.

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment of the Senate.

Speaker: NA
Text: Knott, M. P. J.

Speaker: Mr SCIACCA
Text: Bowman-Parliamentary

Speaker: NA
Text: Secretary'to the Minister for Social Security)

Speaker: NA
Text: (8.51 p.m.)-On behalf of the committee

Speaker: NA
Text: appointed to draw up reasons for the House

Speaker: NA
Text: O'Connor, G. M.

Speaker: NA
Text: disagreeing to the amendment of the Senate,

Speaker: NA
Text: I present the reasons which are being circulat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ed to honourable members.

Speaker: NA
Text: The reasons read as follows-

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) It excludes shares and other listed securities

Speaker: NA
Text: from the definition of investment product in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Veterans' Entitlements Act and thereby

Speaker: NA
Text: prevents the equitable assessment of the

Speaker: NA
Text: ongoing gains made on shares and other

Speaker: NA
Text: investments listed on the Stock Exchange

Speaker: NA
Text: compared with indirect investments in shares

Speaker: NA
Text: through equity trusts.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) The amendment will reduce the equity of the

Speaker: NA
Text: service pension income test. The assessment

Speaker: NA
Text: of ongoing capital gains on shares ensures that

Speaker: NA
Text: equity of the service pension income test is

Speaker: NA
Text: enhanced. Pensioners with the same means and

Speaker: NA
Text: the same financial resources available to them

Speaker: NA
Text: should' have the same amount of income

Speaker: NA
Text: assessed for service pension purposes. People

Speaker: NA
Text: who invest in shares should not be treated

Speaker: NA
Text: more beneficially than those who invest in

Speaker: NA
Text: equity trusts or other managed investments,

Speaker: NA
Text: and they should not be treated more beneficial-

Speaker: NA
Text: ly than those pensioners who invest in income

Speaker: NA
Text: generating investments such as bank accounts.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) The amendment would result in the expendi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture of approximately $20 million in a full

Speaker: NA
Text: year on a group of clients who generally have

Speaker: NA
Text: substantial financial resources.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) There is no reason why shares should be

Speaker: NA
Text: excluded and given privileged treatment. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: a principle of the income test that ongoing

Speaker: NA
Text: gains are treated as income for all investments

Speaker: NA
Text: that can be readily realised and utilised by

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioners for their support. Only those invest-

Speaker: NA
Text: mentswhich are not readily realisable, such as

Speaker: NA
Text: real estate and shares held in private com-

Speaker: NA
Text: panies should be exempt. Listed shares can be

Speaker: NA
Text: sold in small or large bundles at any time

Speaker: NA
Text: allowing gains on listed shares to be readily

Speaker: NA
Text: utilised by a pensioner.

Speaker: NA
Text: Motion (by Mr Sciacca) proposed:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the Committee's reasons be adopted.

Speaker: Mrs SULLIVAN
Text: Moncrieft) (8.51 p.m.)-

Speaker: NA
Text: As these reasons have just been put into my

Speaker: NA
Text: hands, Mr Speaker, may we have the oppor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunity to look at them, as we did earlier

Speaker: NA
Text: today, and decide whether we will adopt

Speaker: NA
Text: them. I do not find this statement acceptable

Speaker: NA
Text: because it misstates the situation, as the

Speaker: NA
Text: situation in relation.· to veterans and our

Speaker: NA
Text: servicemen serving' in Cambodia, Laos,

Speaker: NA
Text: Thailand and Somalia was misstated earlier

Speaker: NA
Text: today. It continues the Government's line-

Speaker: NA
Text: Motion (by Mr Sciacca) agreed to:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the question be now put.

Speaker: NA
Text: Original question resolved in the affmna-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive.

Speaker: NA
Text: PRIVILEGE

Speaker: Mr JOHNS
Text: Petrie-Parliamentary Secre-

Speaker: NA
Text: tary to the Treasurer)--.;. Mr Speaker, I rise on

Speaker: NA
Text: a matter of privilege. Just five minutes ago I

Speaker: NA
Text: witnessed what I believe to be disgusting

Speaker: NA
Text: behaviour by the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: O'Connor ( Mr Tuckey). I was locked out of

Speaker: NA
Text: the division prior to the last one and I wit-

Speaker: NA
Text: nessed the honourable member for O'Connor

Speaker: NA
Text: burst through the door and push an attendant

Speaker: NA
Text: aside when that attendant expressly asked him

Speaker: NA
Text: to remain outside the chamber. Of course, the

Speaker: NA
Text: rest of us obeyed her decision and remained

Speaker: NA
Text: outside.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Thckey- Mr Speaker, I raise a point of

Speaker: NA
Text: order. The honourable member has risen on

Speaker: NA
Text: a point of privilege and I think he should

Speaker: NA
Text: state his case of privilege which applies only

Speaker: NA
Text: to members of this House. If not, he should

Speaker: NA
Text: wait and move the appropriate motion, which

Speaker: NA
Text: is not a motion relating to privilege. I believe

Speaker: NA
Text: this is the ground on which he claimed your

Speaker: NA
Text: attention, Mr Speaker. If he wants to move a

Speaker: NA
Text: formal motion, let him do so and we will deal

Speaker: NA
Text: with it, but let us not have these sorts of

Speaker: NA
Text: situations.

Speaker: Mr JOHNS
Text: I raise this matter of privilege

Speaker: NA
Text: because it offends my rights as a member that

Speaker: NA
Text: someone has burst into this place.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Order! I have listened to

Speaker: NA
Text: what has been said. I will take some advice

Speaker: NA
Text: on the matter and report back to the House

Speaker: NA
Text: shortly.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Thckey- Mr Speaker, on a further

Speaker: NA
Text: point of order, if an allegation is made against

Speaker: NA
Text: me, it is my right to reply.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: No, that is not correct.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Thckey-The requirement of this place

Speaker: NA
Text: is to lock the doors. The doors were not

Speaker: NA
Text: locked and I am entitled to enter.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Order! Resume your seat.

Speaker: NA
Text: CUSTOMS TARIFF AMENDMENT

Speaker: NA
Text: BILL 1993

Speaker: NA
Text: First Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill presented by Mr Lindsay, and read a

Speaker: NA
Text: first time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: Mr LINDSAY
Text: Herbert-Parliamentary

Speaker: NA
Text: Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Tech-

Speaker: NA
Text: nology and Regional Development) (8.59

Speaker: NA
Text: p.m.)-I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: The purpose of the Customs Tariff Amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment Bill 1993 is to amend the Customs

Speaker: NA
Text: Tariff Act 1987 to put beyond doubt the

Speaker: NA
Text: construction of item 41A of schedule 4 to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Act. Item 41A is a key element of the legisla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive mechanism for implementing the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's passenger motor vehicle manu-

Speaker: NA
Text: facturing plan. From its commencement

Speaker: NA
Text: paragraph (a) of item 41A and the customs

Speaker: NA
Text: by-laws made in respect· of that item have

Speaker: NA
Text: always been intended by the Government to

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit only the five 'plan producers' by

Speaker: NA
Text: allowing them duty free importation of certain

Speaker: NA
Text: passenger motor vehicles where they have

Speaker: NA
Text: earned export credits under the export facilita-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion scheme in accordance with the plan and

Speaker: NA
Text: hold the appropriate determinations under that

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme.

Speaker: NA
Text: In extending the scheme with effect from

Speaker: NA
Text: January 1991, item 41A was amended by the

Speaker: NA
Text: addition of a paragraph (d) to allow non-plan

Speaker: NA
Text: producers such as component manufacturers

Speaker: NA
Text: to benefit directly from export credits they

Speaker: NA
Text: had earned under the export facilitation

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme. Previously non-plan producers could

Speaker: NA
Text: only benefit through the sale of their credits

Speaker: NA
Text: to plan producers.

Speaker: NA
Text: It has recently been contended that these

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions and the customs administrative by-

Speaker: NA
Text: law could have allowed the dutyfree impor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tation of such passenger motor vehicles by

Speaker: NA
Text: importers not holding such determinations

Speaker: NA
Text: under the scheme. The Government's automo-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive policy sets out a schedule for the gradual

Speaker: NA
Text: reduction of tariff levels through to the year

Speaker: NA
Text: 2000. The intent of this policy, announced as

Speaker: NA
Text: part of the 1991 industry statement, is abso-

Speaker: NA
Text: lutely clear. The policy reflects the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's commitment to reducing assist-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance to the automotive industry, but at a rate

Speaker: NA
Text: that is manageable and sustainable by that

Speaker: NA
Text: industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: The plan has provided Australia's motor

Speaker: NA
Text: vehicle and component manufacturers with a

Speaker: NA
Text: clear direction in meeting the challenges of

Speaker: NA
Text: motor vehicle and component manufacture in

Speaker: NA
Text: the 1990s. Under the plan, motor vehicle and

Speaker: NA
Text: component exports have reached record

Speaker: NA
Text: levels, exceeding $1.2 billion per annum.

Speaker: NA
Text: Confidence in the industry's future is reflected

Speaker: NA
Text: in recent decisions to upgrade and extend

Speaker: NA
Text: manufacturing facilities.

Speaker: NA
Text: The possibility of uncertainty in the

Speaker: NA
Text: legislative mechanism could seriously under-

Speaker: NA
Text: mine the benefits achieved to date. The

Speaker: NA
Text: industry has every right to expect that the

Speaker: NA
Text: plan will be maintained as previously an-

Speaker: NA
Text: nounced by the Government. The Government

Speaker: NA
Text: is therefore acting to preserve the integrity

Speaker: NA
Text: its automotive industry policy by expressly

Speaker: NA
Text: stating that for an importer to benefit under

Speaker: NA
Text: paragraph 41A(a) of the Act they must be the

Speaker: NA
Text: owner of a determination under the export

Speaker: NA
Text: facilitation scheme.

Speaker: NA
Text: Financial Impact Statement

Speaker: NA
Text: The' amendments will remove a potential

Speaker: NA
Text: liability of the Commonwealth to refund duty

Speaker: NA
Text: paid in respect of motor vehicle importations

Speaker: NA
Text: since 1 January 1991. But for the amendments

Speaker: NA
Text: the extent of that liability could be in the

Speaker: NA
Text: vicinity of $500 million. I commend the Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: to the House and present the explanatory

Speaker: NA
Text: memorandum to the Bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate (on motion by Mr MCGauran)

Speaker: NA
Text: adjourned.

Speaker: NA
Text: SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION

Speaker: NA
Text: AMENDMENT BILL 1993

Speaker: NA
Text: First Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill-by leave-presented by Mr Sciacca,

Speaker: NA
Text: and read a first time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: Mr SCIACCA
Text: Bowman-Parliamentary

Speaker: NA
Text: Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

Speaker: NA
Text: (9.04 p.m.)-I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: This Bill contains a wide range of omnibus

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments to the various programs adminis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tered under the Social Security Act 1991.

Speaker: NA
Text: These amendments will refine the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's .carefully balanced income support

Speaker: NA
Text: policies to make sure that members of our

Speaker: NA
Text: community in need receive the social assist-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance vital to them in difficult economic times.

Speaker: NA
Text: Child disability allowance, or CDA, is paid

Speaker: NA
Text: in recognition of people Who care for disabled

Speaker: NA
Text: children at home. Several reforms in this Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: will improve the effectiveness of this import-

Speaker: NA
Text: ant payment. First, it will become possible for

Speaker: NA
Text: plan's CDA to be shared between two people who

Speaker: NA
Text: share the care and control of a disabled child

Speaker: NA
Text: but one or both of whom do not receive

Speaker: NA
Text: family payment for the child. People who

Speaker: NA
Text: receive family payment as well as CDA for

Speaker: NA
Text: a child can already have both payments split

Speaker: NA
Text: of in this way and this amendment makes sure

Speaker: NA
Text: that the same treatment is given all round.

Speaker: NA
Text: The payment of CDA during a child's

Speaker: NA
Text: temporary absence from home' has proved

Speaker: NA
Text: difficult for administration of the payment. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is to be made clear for all new claimants of

Speaker: NA
Text: CDA that payment is to be made only while

Speaker: NA
Text: the child is being cared for in the family

Speaker: NA
Text: home and during specified respite or hospi-

Speaker: NA
Text: talisation periods. Also, all current recipients

Speaker: NA
Text: of CDA will now continue to qualify for

Speaker: NA
Text: CDA while the child is in short-term hospital

Speaker: NA
Text: care. Lastly, a limit of 12 months is to be

Speaker: NA
Text: placed on the backdating of CDA to the date

Speaker: NA
Text: of another, similar claim. Earlier cases of

Speaker: NA
Text: backdating for five to 10 years had highlight-

Speaker: NA
Text: ed problems with collecting information about

Speaker: NA
Text: a child's disability or care requirements for

Speaker: NA
Text: such a long time in the past.

Speaker: NA
Text: This Bill allows parents who are granted

Speaker: NA
Text: prescribed education scheme payments for

Speaker: NA
Text: their children to be paid, in certain circum-

Speaker: NA
Text: stances, arrears of family payment back to the

Speaker: NA
Text: effective date of grant of the education pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment instead of just to the date on which the

Speaker: NA
Text: education payment was first made as provided

Speaker: NA
Text: now. This is a significant improvement for

Speaker: NA
Text: families in this situation.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of our important responsibilities to the

Speaker: NA
Text: taxpayer is to get maximum value for every

Speaker: NA
Text: dollar of social security expenditure, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: debt recovery provisions in the Social Securi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ty Act help us achieve this. A range of

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments builds on these provisions. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Act will now specify how to calculate the

Speaker: NA
Text: amount of a debt that arises in some cases

Speaker: NA
Text: when a jobsearch or newstart allowance

Speaker: NA
Text: recipient's circumstances change during a

Speaker: NA
Text: public holiday period such as Christmas or

Speaker: NA
Text: Easter for which he or she is prepaid. If the

Speaker: NA
Text: client fails to return the usual fortnightly

Speaker: NA
Text: income statement, there is currently no basis

Speaker: NA
Text: on which to calculate the debt. The debt will

Speaker: NA
Text: now clearly equal the amount of the prepay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in these circumstances.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is also being clarified that the debt

Speaker: NA
Text: arises when family payment clients underesti-

Speaker: NA
Text: mate their taxable income by more than 25

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent, or fail to comply with the notifica-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion provisions, is the difference between

Speaker: NA
Text: what has already been paid and the amount

Speaker: NA
Text: due on re-calculation. Furthermore, an over-

Speaker: NA
Text: payment of family payment following a

Speaker: NA
Text: reassessment of taxable income will become

Speaker: NA
Text: a clearly recoverable debt.

Speaker: NA
Text: A redundant provision enabling the Depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of Social Security to waive or write off

Speaker: NA
Text: Department of Veterans' Affairs debts is

Speaker: NA
Text: being removed. The Department of Social

Speaker: NA
Text: Security will still recover these Department of

Speaker: NA
Text: Veterans' Affairs debts when possible by

Speaker: NA
Text: deductions from current social security pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments, but the department does not generally

Speaker: NA
Text: handle other agencies' debts. Also, overpay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments under the child support scheme when

Speaker: NA
Text: there is no continuing entitlement to child

Speaker: NA
Text: support will become recoverable by deduc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions from social security payments.

Speaker: NA
Text: Each year the department sends over 2,500

Speaker: NA
Text: cases of potential offences under the Social

Speaker: NA
Text: Security Act to the Director of Public Pros-

Speaker: NA
Text: ecutions. The penalty that applies to offences

Speaker: NA
Text: under part 8.1 of the Act is imprisonment for

Speaker: NA
Text: two years, having been increased from 12

Speaker: NA
Text: months in 1991. As a result, cases that had

Speaker: NA
Text: been dealt with summarily-by a magistrate-

Speaker: NA
Text: are often now handled as indictable offences

Speaker: NA
Text: by judge and jury. It has been decided to

Speaker: NA
Text: revert to the 12-month penalty so that the

Speaker: NA
Text: more appropriate means of dealing with

Speaker: NA
Text: offences may be consistently

Speaker: NA
Text: employed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Unemployed people have access to a wide

Speaker: NA
Text: range of labour market programs. The interac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of these programs with the social security

Speaker: NA
Text: system is being refined in this Bill by making

Speaker: NA
Text: sure that people who are paid for participating

Speaker: NA
Text: in the landcare and environment action pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: gram administered by the Department of

Speaker: NA
Text: Employment, Education and Training or the

Speaker: NA
Text: ACT Government's jobskills program cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: simultaneously receive payment under the

Speaker: NA
Text: social security system. When they have

Speaker: NA
Text: finished their training, these people can

Speaker: NA
Text: immediately return to the social security

Speaker: NA
Text: payment they were receiving before.

Speaker: NA
Text: People who are serving a newly arrived

Speaker: NA
Text: that resident's waiting period before being paid

Speaker: NA
Text: jobsearch, newstart or sickness allowance will

Speaker: NA
Text: now be able to serve that waiting period con-

Speaker: NA
Text: currently with the ordinary waiting period that

Speaker: NA
Text: applies to most new grants of these allowan-

Speaker: NA
Text: ces. This will reduce the overall waiting

Speaker: NA
Text: period by around seven days.

Speaker: NA
Text: The New South Wales Medically Acquired

Speaker: NA
Text: mv Trust was established by the New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales Government to provide a package of

Speaker: NA
Text: financial assistance for people infected with

Speaker: NA
Text: medically acquired mv in New South Wales.

Speaker: NA
Text: Through this Bill, the social security system

Speaker: NA
Text: will not be treating payments from the trust

Speaker: NA
Text: as income under the ordinary income test.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is in line with the Government's inten-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion for payments made by the similar Mark

Speaker: NA
Text: Fitzpatrick Trust that was established by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth and covered by identical

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation last year.

Speaker: NA
Text: The rate of pension or benefit paid to

Speaker: NA
Text: someone whose partner is in gaol or psychiat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ric confinement following a criminal charge

Speaker: NA
Text: is to be clarified in this Bill in two respects.

Speaker: NA
Text: First, to recognise the financial realities of

Speaker: NA
Text: living apart from a partner who is confined,

Speaker: NA
Text: a person in this situation will now be paid

Speaker: NA
Text: higher rate that applies to a person without a

Speaker: NA
Text: partner instead of the rate nonnally paid to a

Speaker: NA
Text: member of a couple. Secondly, it is being

Speaker: NA
Text: made clear that an additional amount is not to

Speaker: NA
Text: be added to a person's rate of benefit for a

Speaker: NA
Text: partner who is in gaol or psychiatric confine-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment and therefore being maintained by the

Speaker: NA
Text: State rather than by the beneficiary.

Speaker: NA
Text: Last year, an amendment was made to the

Speaker: NA
Text: review of decisions provisions to channel

Speaker: NA
Text: applications for review by the Social Security

Speaker: NA
Text: Appeals Tribunal through the internal depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: mental review mechanism. This Bill makes a

Speaker: NA
Text: minor enhancement to that initiative to make

Speaker: NA
Text: sure that,· if a person incorrectly applies for time.

Speaker: NA
Text: review to the SSAT instead of to the depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, he or she is taken to have applied to the

Speaker: NA
Text: department for internal review on the same

Speaker: NA
Text: date. This preserves the person's rights to be

Speaker: NA
Text: paid arrears should the review eventually

Speaker: NA
Text: decide in his or her favour as if the correct

Speaker: NA
Text: application had been made in the first place.

Speaker: NA
Text: The dual payment of mobility allowance

Speaker: NA
Text: under t4e Social Security Act and training

Speaker: NA
Text: allowance paid by the Department of Employ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, Education and Training is being pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: vented by this Bill. This dual payment exclu-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion has applied so far only to people under-

Speaker: NA
Text: taking training as part of a Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: rehabilitation service rehabilitation program

Speaker: NA
Text: but is now to apply to all cases of common

Speaker: NA
Text: entitlement to these two allowances. To

Speaker: NA
Text: further protect the integrity of Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: payments, it is being made clear that, where

Speaker: NA
Text: a person receives a payment by the Depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of Employment, Education and Training

Speaker: NA
Text: under the new enterprise incentive scheme or

Speaker: NA
Text: the Aboriginal employment incentive scheme,

Speaker: NA
Text: the person's age or widow B pension will be

Speaker: NA
Text: reduced. If the person receives age pension,

Speaker: NA
Text: his or her partner's pension might also be

Speaker: NA
Text: affected. This is consistent with the approach

Speaker: NA
Text: taken with other social security pensions and

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits.

Speaker: NA
Text: This Bill also makes some purely technical

Speaker: NA
Text: refinements not involving new policy in areas

Speaker: NA
Text: such as investment income, family payment,

Speaker: NA
Text: the employment entry payment for sole parent

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioners and the impairment assessment

Speaker: NA
Text: tables for disability support pension. There are

Speaker: NA
Text: the also some minor technical amendments to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Act to ensure its integrity in terms of correct

Speaker: NA
Text: references and tenninology, notes to the text

Speaker: NA
Text: and similar matters. I commend this Bill to

Speaker: NA
Text: the House and present the explanatory memo-

Speaker: NA
Text: randum.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate (on motion by Mr Ruddock)

Speaker: NA
Text: adjourned.

Speaker: NA
Text: NUCLEAR NON-PROLIFERATION

Speaker: NA
Text: (SAFEGUARDS) AMENDMENT

Speaker: NA
Text: BILL 1993

Speaker: NA
Text: First Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill presented by Mr Gear, and read a first

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: Mr GEAR
Text: Canning-Assistant Treasurer)

Speaker: NA
Text: (9.13 p.m.)-I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: The main purpose of this Bill, the second of

Speaker: NA
Text: two associated Bills, is to amend the Nuclear

Speaker: NA
Text: Non-Proliferation (Safeguards) Act 1987 to

Speaker: NA
Text: set the amount of the charge payable under

Speaker: NA
Text: the previous Bill and to specify when the

Speaker: NA
Text: charge is to be paid. This Bill provides that

Speaker: NA
Text: the annual charge payable for ASO safeguards

Speaker: NA
Text: activities by each uranium producer is

Speaker: NA
Text: $500,000, or a lesser amount if the regula-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions so provide.

Speaker: NA
Text: I will say in my remarks on the next Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: that the uranium companies would pay no

Speaker: NA
Text: more than is reasonable, having regard to the

Speaker: NA
Text: nature and costs of the relevant activities

Speaker: NA
Text: undertaken by ASO. This will be achieved by

Speaker: NA
Text: ensuring that the regulations annually specify

Speaker: NA
Text: an amount, less than the upper limit in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill, which represents the reasonable costs of

Speaker: NA
Text: the relevant activities undertaken by the ASO

Speaker: NA
Text: in that year.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is the Government's clear intention that

Speaker: NA
Text: the uranium companies will be fully consulted

Speaker: NA
Text: each year on the planned program of ASO

Speaker: NA
Text: activities and costs and the charge proposed,

Speaker: NA
Text: before the final charge is set in the regula-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions. In other words, company officials will

Speaker: NA
Text: sit down each year with the Director of

Speaker: NA
Text: Safeguards and other relevant officials and

Speaker: NA
Text: seek to agree on the level of ASO activity in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to the companies' operations.

Speaker: NA
Text: Naturally, the Government must retain the

Speaker: NA
Text: ultimate responsibility to determine the annual

Speaker: NA
Text: charge to ensure that the safeguards and

Speaker: NA
Text: physical protection programs fully meet all

Speaker: NA
Text: requirements and obligations, so that the

Speaker: NA
Text: uranium mining companies may keep operat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing. However, the views of the companies

Speaker: NA
Text: will be fully considered each year, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government will itself continue to pay for

Speaker: NA
Text: ASO activities which benefit the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Australian community generally.

Speaker: NA
Text: The ASO's program of activities for 1993-

Speaker: NA
Text: 94 is of course not determined at this stage,

Speaker: NA
Text: so the charge for 1993-94 cannot yet be

Speaker: NA
Text: specified. We have, however, arrived at an

Speaker: NA
Text: indicative charge based on ASO's 1992-93

Speaker: NA
Text: program. On this basis, we estimate an annual

Speaker: NA
Text: charge of about $340,000 for each of the

Speaker: NA
Text: uranium companies. The maximum charge

Speaker: NA
Text: specified in the Bill-of $500,000 for each

Speaker: NA
Text: uranium producer-has been set to ensure that

Speaker: NA
Text: the legislation will not require freque-t

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment. I emphasise, however, that 1t

Speaker: NA
Text: does not represent in any sense the charge

Speaker: NA
Text: that will in fact be payable by the companies

Speaker: NA
Text: unless and until their reasonable shares of

Speaker: NA
Text: ASO costs should approach this amount.

Speaker: NA
Text: Finally, the intended sanction - the. event

Speaker: NA
Text: of failure to pay the charge prov1ded m the

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill is revocation of the permit to possess

Speaker: NA
Text: relevant nuclear material. Revocation is

Speaker: NA
Text: possible if permit conditions are not complied

Speaker: NA
Text: with, and all relevant permits will require

Speaker: NA
Text: payment of the charge from the date of

Speaker: NA
Text: commencement. I commend this Bill to

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable members, and present the explana-

Speaker: NA
Text: tory memorandum.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate (on motion by Mr MCGauran)

Speaker: NA
Text: adjourned. '

Speaker: NA
Text: NUCLEAR SAFEGUARDS

Speaker: NA
Text: (pRODUCERS OF URANIUM ORE

Speaker: NA
Text: CONCENTRATES) CHARGE

Speaker: NA
Text: BILL 1993

Speaker: NA
Text: First Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill presented by Mr Gear, and read a first

Speaker: NA
Text: time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: Mr GEAR
Text: Canning-Assistant Treasurer)

Speaker: NA
Text: (9.17 p.m.)-I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: The .purpose of this Bill and the associat-d

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill is to impose a charge on commerc1al

Speaker: NA
Text: uranium producers in Australia to recover

Speaker: NA
Text: some of the costs of the Australian Safeguards

Speaker: NA
Text: Office ASO in undertaking nuclear safe-

Speaker: NA
Text: guar- and physical protection activities. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's decision to consider cost recov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ery for these activities was included in the

Speaker: NA
Text: 1992-93 Budget papers.

Speaker: NA
Text: This cost recovery proposal rests on two

Speaker: NA
Text: fundamental principles.· First, those who

Speaker: NA
Text: derive benefit from an activity should pay for

Speaker: NA
Text: it, so long as the amount recovered is reason-

Speaker: NA
Text: able having regard to the nature and costs of

Speaker: NA
Text: the activity. Second, those who pay should

Speaker: NA
Text: have a genuine opportunity to examine and be

Speaker: NA
Text: consulted on the necessity, quality and cost of

Speaker: NA
Text: the activities they are paying for. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: required not only on e9u-ty .gro-ds, -u.t also

Speaker: NA
Text: because it imposes a d1sc1plme, m add1tion to

Speaker: NA
Text: that of normal parliamentary scrutiny, on the

Speaker: NA
Text: provider of the activities-in this case the

Speaker: NA
Text: ASO-to deliver them as effectively and

Speaker: NA
Text: efficiently as possible.

Speaker: NA
Text: The ASO cost recovery arrangements to

Speaker: NA
Text: which the Bills would give effect will be fully

Speaker: NA
Text: consistent with these principles. In particular,

Speaker: NA
Text: the the Government accepts that a substantial

Speaker: NA
Text: proportion of the activities of the ASO pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vides benefits to Government and to the

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian community generally. The costs of

Speaker: NA
Text: ASO activities not specifically directed at or

Speaker: NA
Text: relevant to industry will continue to be met

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Government, which will remain the

Speaker: NA
Text: largest contributor to ASO resources.

Speaker: NA
Text: Other countries charge their industries for

Speaker: NA
Text: nuclear safeguards and related activities,

Speaker: NA
Text: including the United States, Canada and

Speaker: NA
Text: Sweden. Moreover, cost recovery for under-

Speaker: NA
Text: taking regulatory and other activities, based

Speaker: NA
Text: on the same general principles I have o-t­

Speaker: NA
Text: lined, applies quite widely across Austrahan

Speaker: NA
Text: industry. In the prim- ind-tries and -n-r-y

Speaker: NA
Text: portfolio, it currently apphes to a-t1V1t1es

Speaker: NA
Text: undertaken by the Australian Quarantme and

Speaker: NA
Text: Inspection Service and the Australian Fisher-

Speaker: NA
Text: ies Management Authority, as well as to

Speaker: NA
Text: many of the projects of the Australian Bureau

Speaker: NA
Text: of Agricultural and Resource Economics, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Geological Survey Organisation

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Bureau of Resource Sciences. Activi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties of the National Residue Survey and the

Speaker: NA
Text: registration of agricultural and veterinary

Speaker: NA
Text: chemicals are also subject to cost recovery

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangements.

Speaker: NA
Text: Before commenting on this particular Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: I will say a little about the ASO and its

Speaker: NA
Text: activities. Established by the Nuclear Non-

Speaker: NA
Text: Proliferation (Safeguards) Act 1987, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Director of Safeguards and the ASO manage

Speaker: NA
Text: domestic and international nuclear safeguards

Speaker: NA
Text: and physical protection programs in accord-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance with our stringent nuclear safeguards

Speaker: NA
Text: policies and requirements.

Speaker: NA
Text: ASO has a key role in ensuring that urani-

Speaker: NA
Text: um produced in and exported from Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: is used only for peaceful purposes and is not

Speaker: NA
Text: diverted into non-peaceful programs. In short,

Speaker: NA
Text: a significant proportion of ASO's program

Speaker: NA
Text: exists, and the associated costs are incurred,

Speaker: NA
Text: because of the need to safeguard our uranium

Speaker: NA
Text: industry. These are the costs the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: has decided to recover. I shall return to

Speaker: NA
Text: point when commenting on the associated

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: This first Bill provides in its substantive

Speaker: NA
Text: clause-clause 3-for a charge to be imposed

Speaker: NA
Text: on the companies which produce and export

Speaker: NA
Text: uranium in commercial quantities. Both Bills

Speaker: NA
Text: commence on 1 November 1993. III recogni-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion that it is reasonable for a producer to

Speaker: NA
Text: have generated a cash flow before being liable adjourned.

Speaker: NA
Text: for the charge, we have provided that no

Speaker: NA
Text: charge is payable until some uranium has

Speaker: NA
Text: been exported from the relevant processing

Speaker: NA
Text: facility.

Speaker: NA
Text: The uranium industry has been going

Speaker: NA
Text: through a difficult period in recent years.

Speaker: NA
Text: Prices have been low and, at the Ranger plant

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Northern Territory, production has

Speaker: NA
Text: fallen and some workers have been retrench-

Speaker: NA
Text: ed. Happily, prices have increased quite

Speaker: NA
Text: significantly in the last few months. Although

Speaker: NA
Text: the industry is by no means fully recovered at

Speaker: NA
Text: this stage, I am pleased to note recent com-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments by senior officials of Ranger's parent

Speaker: NA
Text: company, Energy Resources of Australia, that

Speaker: NA
Text: the market has strengthened recently, utilities

Speaker: NA
Text: are showing an interest in talking about future

Speaker: NA
Text: demand, and ERA has a number of new

Speaker: NA
Text: contracts under negotiation.

Speaker: NA
Text: I also note that Western Mining Corporation

Speaker: NA
Text: intends to increase uranium production from

Speaker: NA
Text: its Olympic Dam mine at Roxby Downs in

Speaker: NA
Text: South Australia as part of a mine production

Speaker: NA
Text: expansion program in the near future. Our

Speaker: NA
Text: decision to charge the companies for nuclear

Speaker: NA
Text: safeguards has not been made without regard

Speaker: NA
Text: to industry conditions. We estimate that the

Speaker: NA
Text: two current uranium producers, both of which

Speaker: NA
Text: have remained profitable despite the industry

Speaker: NA
Text: problems, will each pay only about $340,000

Speaker: NA
Text: annually at the present level of ASO activity,

Speaker: NA
Text: representing about 20c per kilogram of urani-

Speaker: NA
Text: um produced. This is less than one half of

Speaker: NA
Text: one per cent of the present value of uranium

Speaker: NA
Text: production.

Speaker: NA
Text: All in all, the Government believes these

Speaker: NA
Text: cost recovery measures-fully justifiable in

Speaker: NA
Text: terms of the principles I have outlined-are

Speaker: NA
Text: not unreasonable as regards the impact on the

Speaker: NA
Text: uranium industry. Furthennore, the arrange-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments for detennining the .annual charge

Speaker: NA
Text: this payable by the companies, which I shall

Speaker: NA
Text: describe shortly in discussing the associated

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill, will give them a genuine opportunity to

Speaker: NA
Text: influence through consultation the actual

Speaker: NA
Text: amount they would pay each y-. I commend

Speaker: NA
Text: the Bill to honourable members and present

Speaker: NA
Text: the explanatory memorandum for it and the

Speaker: NA
Text: associated Bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate (on motion by Mr MCGauran)

Speaker: NA
Text: AUSTRALIAN BROADCASTING COR-

Speaker: NA
Text: PORATION AMENDMENT BILL 1993

Speaker: NA
Text: First Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill received from the Senate, and read a

Speaker: NA
Text: first time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ordered that the second reading be made an

Speaker: NA
Text: order of the day for the next sitting.

Speaker: NA
Text: COMMITTEES

Speaker: NA
Text: Public Works Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: Reports

Speaker: Mr HOLLIS
Text: Throsby)-On behalf of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public

Speaker: NA
Text: Works, I present the first, second and third

Speaker: NA
Text: reports of the committee for 1993 relating to

Speaker: NA
Text: a housing development at Palmerston in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Northern Territory, a housing development at

Speaker: NA
Text: Flinders View near Ipswich, Queensland and

Speaker: NA
Text: HMAS Waterhen facilities modernisation,

Speaker: NA
Text: Waverton, New South Wales.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ordered that the reports be printed.

Speaker: Mr HOLLIS
Text: by leave-The first report

Speaker: NA
Text: which I have tabled deals with the constructhe

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of 210 dwellings at Palmerston in Darincrease

Speaker: NA
Text: win-70 of which will be for service persondemand

Speaker: NA
Text: nel and their families and the balance of

Speaker: NA
Text: houses will be offered for sale to private

Speaker: NA
Text: purchasers. The project will be undertaken in

Speaker: NA
Text: three stages at a net cost of $14.2 million.

Speaker: NA
Text: The committee has recommended that the

Speaker: NA
Text: project proceed as planned. The committee

Speaker: NA
Text: concluded that there is a need for the Defence

Speaker: NA
Text: Housing Authority to provide appropriate

Speaker: NA
Text: housing to cater for the increased Army

Speaker: NA
Text: presence in the north. The. site at Palmerston

Speaker: NA
Text: is ideally located for Army personnel working

Speaker: NA
Text: at Waler Barracks. The proposed construction

Speaker: NA
Text: of facilities, comprising Waler Barracks, for the public.

Speaker: NA
Text: the 2nd Cavalry Regiment, was the subject of

Speaker: NA
Text: an inquiry and report by the committee during

Speaker: NA
Text: 1992. This proposal is therefore directly

Speaker: NA
Text: related to that development.

Speaker: NA
Text: PaImerston, which was established in 1980,

Speaker: NA
Text: is located 22 kilometres east of Darwin and

Speaker: NA
Text: currently has a population of 8,000 residents.

Speaker: NA
Text: The houses will be located in the suburb

Speaker: NA
Text: Driver and will be built on 114 lots. The

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed development has been designed to

Speaker: NA
Text: comply with local planning guidelines. ConAmberley

Speaker: NA
Text: siderable regard has therefore been given

Speaker: NA
Text: road patterns and the provision of open ·space

Speaker: NA
Text: which are reflected in the civic design

Speaker: NA
Text: cept and the landscape master plan.

Speaker: NA
Text: The houses themselves will comprise 91 facilities.

Speaker: NA
Text: detached dwellings, 58 attached courtyard

Speaker: NA
Text: dwellings and 61 medium density dwellings.

Speaker: NA
Text: Features of the designs include: elevated

Speaker: NA
Text: floors; orientation to capture maximum

Speaker: NA
Text: ventilation and louvre windows for cross-flow

Speaker: NA
Text: ventilation; cyclone proof construction; metal

Speaker: NA
Text: wall and roof cladding; solar hot water; and

Speaker: NA
Text: ceiling fans and airconditioning of the living

Speaker: NA
Text: room and main sleeping area.

Speaker: NA
Text: House sizes and the numbers of bedrooms

Speaker: NA
Text: in each will be provided to meet service

Speaker: NA
Text: requirements. The designs will provide for a

Speaker: NA
Text: range of floor areas ranging from 115 square

Speaker: NA
Text: metres to 145 square metres. As I mentioned

Speaker: NA
Text: earlier, the Defence Housing Authority pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: poses to provide 70 dwellings for service

Speaker: NA
Text: families with the balance of 140 being offered

Speaker: NA
Text: for sale to private purchasers.

Speaker: NA
Text: At the public hearing the authority advised

Speaker: NA
Text: committee that it may be desirable to

Speaker: NA
Text: this holding to 50 per cent should

Speaker: NA
Text: from the private sector be low. The

Speaker: NA
Text: 140 committee was assured by the authority that

Speaker: NA
Text: it does not intend to establish an estate solely

Speaker: NA
Text: for service personnel, but wishes to integrate

Speaker: NA
Text: service families into the general community.

Speaker: NA
Text: The second report which I have just tabled

Speaker: NA
Text: involves the development of a 53.8-hectare

Speaker: NA
Text: site at Flinders View near Ipswich to improve

Speaker: NA
Text: the standard of housing for defence personnel

Speaker: NA
Text: at the nearby RAAF base Amberley. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Defence Housing Authority proposes to

Speaker: NA
Text: construct 180 dwellings and the balance of

Speaker: NA
Text: 370 dwelling sites will be offered for sale to

Speaker: NA
Text: Service and private sector housing will

Speaker: NA
Text: therefore be integrated within the proposed

Speaker: NA
Text: development. The estimated cost of the

Speaker: NA
Text: proposal is $31 million of which $18 million

Speaker: NA
Text: will be received from the sale of building lots.

Speaker: NA
Text: The committee has concluded that there is

Speaker: NA
Text: a need to provide suitable dwellings for those

Speaker: NA
Text: of service personnel from RAAF base Amberley

Speaker: NA
Text: occupying substandard houses and temporary

Speaker: NA
Text: rental accommodation in the Leichhardt and

Speaker: NA
Text: areas. The site at Flinders View is

Speaker: NA
Text: to well located for a housing development for

Speaker: NA
Text: service families due to its proximity to RAAF

Speaker: NA
Text: conbase Amberley and existing and proposed

Speaker: NA
Text: local schools, shopping and recreational

Speaker: NA
Text: An urban planning concept was developed

Speaker: NA
Text: for the proposal. This aims to achieve a

Speaker: NA
Text: mixed density neighbourhood based on

Speaker: NA
Text: integrated allotment, housing and road plan-

Speaker: NA
Text: ning design principles. Local housing pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: cincts have been designed to have the focus

Speaker: NA
Text: of a small village reserve or landscape fea-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture. Whilst the committee is generally satis-

Speaker: NA
Text: fied with the planning and design of the

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed development, its report makes a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of recommendations in relation to the

Speaker: NA
Text: provision of specific features in the houses.

Speaker: NA
Text: First, the committee has recommended that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Defence Housing Authority provide all

Speaker: NA
Text: dwellings with solar hot-water systems.

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendation is consistent with the stand

Speaker: NA
Text: taken by the committee on previous occaadvantages

Speaker: NA
Text: sions. Solar hot-water systems are a com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity norm and the authority should demonshore

Speaker: NA
Text: strate its commitment to energy conservation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Secondly, the committee has recommended

Speaker: NA
Text: that smoke detectors and earth leakage circuit

Speaker: NA
Text: breakers should also be installed in the

Speaker: NA
Text: es. Again, the committee believes the proviwill

Speaker: NA
Text: sion of these features is consistent with

Speaker: NA
Text: community expectations.

Speaker: NA
Text: The report also makes a wide-ranging

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendation which involves the authority

Speaker: NA
Text: reviewing its design criteria to ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: service housing is as energy efficient

Speaker: NA
Text: possible. However, the committee continues

Speaker: NA
Text: to be impressed by the progress made by

Speaker: NA
Text: Defence Housing Authority in improving the

Speaker: NA
Text: standard of housing provided to defence

Speaker: NA
Text: personnel.

Speaker: NA
Text: The third report which I have just tabledture

Speaker: NA
Text: we have been a very busy committee already,

Speaker: NA
Text: as you will see, Mr Deputy Speakerproposed

Speaker: NA
Text: concerns the proposed facilities modernisation

Speaker: NA
Text: at HMAS Waterhen at Waverton, a harbourmaritime

Speaker: NA
Text: side electorate of North Sydney.

Speaker: NA
Text: Waterhen is the Navy's national mine warfare

Speaker: NA
Text: base. The committee has recommended that

Speaker: NA
Text: the facilities modernisation, estimated to cost

Speaker: NA
Text: $73 million at December 1992 prices, should

Speaker: NA
Text: proceed as planned.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr MCGauran-What did Ted say?

Speaker: Mr HOLLIS
Text: Ted might speak after me,

Speaker: NA
Text: so we will wait until after he speaks. In

Speaker: NA
Text: arriving at this recommendation the committives

Speaker: NA
Text: tee gave careful attention to a number of

Speaker: NA
Text: matters such as the need for a modernised

Speaker: NA
Text: mine warfare base, the best location for it and

Speaker: NA
Text: the existing facilities at HMAS Waterhen.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is no doubt that the Navy needs

Speaker: NA
Text: proved facilities from which to operate its

Speaker: NA
Text: new mine warfare vessels which are planned

Speaker: NA
Text: for introduction in December 1997. The II.

Speaker: NA
Text: existing facilities at HMAS Waterhen would

Speaker: NA
Text: be inadequate to support the new minehunter

Speaker: NA
Text: coastal ships.

Speaker: NA
Text: Defence examined a number of possible

Speaker: NA
Text: alternative locations and the committee has

Speaker: NA
Text: concluded that the location of new purpose

Speaker: NA
Text: This built facilities in Sydney and at HMAS

Speaker: NA
Text: Waterhen offers cost, support and operational

Speaker: NA
Text: over other options examined.

Speaker: NA
Text: The number of personnel to be employed in

Speaker: NA
Text: facilities and attached vessels is expect-

Speaker: NA
Text: ed to be 766. The proposed capacity of the

Speaker: NA
Text: shore element is to accommodate 377 person-

Speaker: NA
Text: nel· at peak levels of operation during a

Speaker: NA
Text: housworking week. The balance of 389 personnel

Speaker: NA
Text: be employed in attached vessels which

Speaker: NA
Text: will deploy and return to the base on a con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinuing basis throughout the year.

Speaker: NA
Text: The main elements of the proposed work

Speaker: NA
Text: include a new operations and administrative

Speaker: NA
Text: that building, a supply and clearance diving

Speaker: NA
Text: as building, a technical workshops building,

Speaker: NA
Text: waterfront and external works, a car park

Speaker: NA
Text: the building and relocation works. The com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee's report concludes that the scope of the

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed development can be justified on the

Speaker: NA
Text: basis of the functions of HMAS Waterhen and

Speaker: NA
Text: the number of vessels and support infrastruc-

Speaker: NA
Text: it will be required to support. Further-

Speaker: NA
Text: more, the report concludes that, generally, the

Speaker: NA
Text: design and siting of facilities and

Speaker: NA
Text: other structures would not detract from the

Speaker: NA
Text: character of other facilities and

Speaker: NA
Text: HMAS structures in the area.

Speaker: NA
Text: The report does recommend, however, that

Speaker: NA
Text: the final design of the proposed car park will

Speaker: NA
Text: need to reflect its environmentally sensitive

Speaker: NA
Text: location and that defence· should ensure that

Speaker: NA
Text: personnel to be employed on the redevelop-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment base use public transport to the maxi-

Speaker: NA
Text: mum extent possible. The latter recommenda-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion takes account of the views of representa-

Speaker: NA
Text: of local residents who appeared before

Speaker: NA
Text: the committee at the public hearing. I com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mend the reports to the House.

Speaker: Mr MACK
Text: North Sydney)-by leave-I

Speaker: NA
Text: would like to support the recommendations of

Speaker: NA
Text: imthe Joint Committee on Public Works in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to HMAS Waterhen because this base

Speaker: NA
Text: has had nothing done on it since World War

Speaker: NA
Text: It was in fact in danger of being listed by

Speaker: NA
Text: the National Trust. Unlike most honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: members, I have spent a political career

Speaker: NA
Text: opposing government expenditure in my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate on things like roads, schools and

Speaker: NA
Text: technical colleges-which I know is unusual.

Speaker: NA
Text: The reason I have done that is the effects of

Speaker: NA
Text: those sorts of facilities on the very high

Speaker: NA
Text: density community of North Sydney.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the case of HMAS Waterhen; however,

Speaker: NA
Text: I would like to compliment the Navy on the

Speaker: NA
Text: way it has gone about this project in elaborate

Speaker: NA
Text: consultations with local residents and the

Speaker: NA
Text: local council. The only quibble I would have

Speaker: NA
Text: with the project is the extent of car parking

Speaker: NA
Text: on the base, on two basic grounds: first, the

Speaker: NA
Text: cost to the taxpayers because a couple of

Speaker: NA
Text: million dollars is proposed to be spent on car

Speaker: NA
Text: parking for this base; and, secondly, the wider

Speaker: NA
Text: problem of subsidising and creating

Speaker: NA
Text: overdependence on car usage, particularly in

Speaker: NA
Text: urban areas.

Speaker: NA
Text: This particular base does have a history of

Speaker: NA
Text: some trouble with access by motor vehicle to

Speaker: NA
Text: and from the site. I think the Government has

Speaker: NA
Text: to really look at all of its projects to try

Speaker: NA
Text: reduce the overdependence on car usage,

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly in urban areas, because we just

Speaker: NA
Text: simply cannot afford the costs in urban

Speaker: NA
Text: sprawl, pollution, hospital costs and fuel

Speaker: NA
Text: imports. It makes a mockery of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's statement earlier today about

Speaker: NA
Text: reducing greenhouse emissions when one puts

Speaker: NA
Text: 200 cars on a base such as this which is right

Speaker: NA
Text: in the heart of Australia's largest urban area.

Speaker: NA
Text: DELEGATION REPORTS

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliamentary Delegation to the

Speaker: NA
Text: European Institutions and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Netherlands

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: leave-I present the report entitled The

Speaker: NA
Text: European Institutions and the Netherlands. I

Speaker: NA
Text: was honoured to lead the Australian parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: mentary delegation to the European parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: mentary institutions and the Netherlands in

Speaker: NA
Text: September and October of last year. I was

Speaker: NA
Text: fortunate to have with me such a fine group

Speaker: NA
Text: of parliamentary colleagues and to have the

Speaker: NA
Text: support and cooperation that they gave as

Speaker: NA
Text: representatives of this Parliament. I am proud

Speaker: NA
Text: of the contribution that they made, the exper-

Speaker: NA
Text: tise that they brought and the competence and

Speaker: NA
Text: skills that they evinced through the discus-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions that we had. I think the overall impact

Speaker: NA
Text: of that delegation and its contribution was to

Speaker: NA
Text: strengthen Australia's relationships with the

Speaker: NA
Text: European parliamentary institutions and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Netherlands.

Speaker: NA
Text: The members of the delegation were: my

Speaker: NA
Text: special colleague, in terms of cooperation,

Speaker: NA
Text: support and assistance, the honourable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Bendigo ( Mr Reid), the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Gippsland ( Mr MCGauran),

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member for Fraser ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Langmore) and Senator John Herron. We

Speaker: NA
Text: were ably assisted, in terms of secretarial

Speaker: NA
Text: backup, patience, understanding, attention in

Speaker: NA
Text: a meticulous way to detail, by none other than

Speaker: NA
Text: the Deputy Sergeant-at-Arms of this chamber.

Speaker: NA
Text: In this respect we were exceedingly fortunate.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Dalma Dixon is not only a woman of

Speaker: NA
Text: remarkable patience but also a woman of

Speaker: NA
Text: remarkable competence and attention to detail,

Speaker: NA
Text: which at some times we thought may not

Speaker: NA
Text: to have been justified but the delegation was the

Speaker: NA
Text: better for it. We were very happy to have her

Speaker: NA
Text: with us and we say collectively, 'Thank you

Speaker: NA
Text: very much, Deputy Sergeant-at-Arms, for the

Speaker: NA
Text: service you gave to our delegation and to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Parliament'.

Speaker: NA
Text: On behalf of the delegation, I express our

Speaker: NA
Text: appreciation to the following staff of .the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian missions abroad who assisted us

Speaker: NA
Text: during the visit: the Australian Ambassador to

Speaker: NA
Text: Belgium and the European Communities,

Speaker: NA
Text: Ambassador Ted Pocock; the First Secretary,

Speaker: NA
Text: Hugh Borrowman; the Australian Ambassador

Speaker: NA
Text: to The Hague, Mr Warwick Weemaes; Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: John Monfries, counsellor; Ms Cate Steains,

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Secretary; and Mr Leo Cruise, coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: sellor, Australian Mission to the OECD. In

Speaker: NA
Text: their respective areas of responsibility, all

Speaker: NA
Text: were of great help to the delegation. They all

Speaker: NA
Text: helped to ensure that we were able to repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sent Australia at as good a level as possible.

Speaker: NA
Text: I also express our appreciation to the

Speaker: NA
Text: following two ladies: Ms Jan Furman and Ms

Speaker: NA
Text: Cheryl Harris from the gifts section of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Department of the Prime Minister and Cabi-

Speaker: NA
Text: net. I was a little puzzled at some of the

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendations that they made on appropri-

Speaker: NA
Text: ate gifts that we should make to the various

Speaker: NA
Text: parliaments and people whom we had to see

Speaker: NA
Text: abroad. I understood, after I reached those

Speaker: NA
Text: places and we made those presentations, that

Speaker: NA
Text: they had a level of knowledge and wisdom

Speaker: NA
Text: that we very much needed. Their choices

Speaker: NA
Text: were excellent and their contribution also

Speaker: NA
Text: needs to be recognised by this Parliament.

Speaker: NA
Text: I said at the outset that we had a fine group

Speaker: NA
Text: of parliamentarians. I think I would be fortu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nate amongst leaders of delegations to have

Speaker: NA
Text: had colleagues of the calibre that I had and to

Speaker: NA
Text: have had the level of cooperation that I had.

Speaker: NA
Text: There was unanimity, a free-flowing expres-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion of views but most important of all a

Speaker: NA
Text: strong allegiance to Australia in putting the

Speaker: NA
Text: best view forward for Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Supporting my colleagues-a number of

Speaker: NA
Text: them were mentioned in the report-were

Speaker: NA
Text: their respective spouses, partners and some

Speaker: NA
Text: members of families. I think they helped to

Speaker: NA
Text: add to the composition of the delegation and

Speaker: NA
Text: to the effect that we brought to our represen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tation to the European parliamentary institu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions.

Speaker: NA
Text: Several issues were raised in the course of

Speaker: NA
Text: discussions, among them the Maastricht

Speaker: NA
Text: Treaty. We were fortunate enough to be in

Speaker: NA
Text: Europe when the French referendum on the

Speaker: NA
Text: treaty was held on 20 September. The yes

Speaker: NA
Text: case was carried by the barest of margins-

Speaker: NA
Text: 51.05 per cent-and it was clear that the

Speaker: NA
Text: issues involved related more to the domestic

Speaker: NA
Text: politics of France than to the merits of the

Speaker: NA
Text: treaty and what it meant to Europe as a

Speaker: NA
Text: whole. It was extremely interesting to see the

Speaker: NA
Text: interplay between the European nations: the

Speaker: NA
Text: tensions; the difficulties of regionalism, or

Speaker: NA
Text: lack of regionalism in some cases; the princi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ple of subsidiarity; the feeling in some areas

Speaker: NA
Text: that they were not being properly represented

Speaker: NA
Text: by their nations in the debate about a single

Speaker: NA
Text: Europe.

Speaker: NA
Text: There was the issue of Yugoslavia. On page

Speaker: NA
Text: 37 of the report, it is stated in conclusion that

Speaker: NA
Text: the delegation was not fully persuaded that

Speaker: NA
Text: there was no possibility of an escalation of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Yugoslav conflict. Remembering that the

Speaker: NA
Text: report was put together soon after our return

Speaker: NA
Text: in October last year, it is tragic that we have

Speaker: NA
Text: subsequently witnessed the bloodshed and

Speaker: NA
Text: mayhem of which we were afraid when we

Speaker: NA
Text: discussed these issues with our European

Speaker: NA
Text: colleagues.

Speaker: NA
Text: As far as agricultural issues are concerned,

Speaker: NA
Text: those who had discussions with us came away

Speaker: NA
Text: with a better understanding of Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: viewpoint and of the impact of foreign poli-

Speaker: NA
Text: cies on our farmers, our livelihoods and

Speaker: NA
Text: agricultural economy than they had prior to

Speaker: NA
Text: the discussions. Whilst we could understand

Speaker: NA
Text: their views to some extent, it was important

Speaker: NA
Text: for them to understand that we could provide

Speaker: NA
Text: foodstuffs to Europe much more efficiently

Speaker: NA
Text: and at much lower prices than they could with

Speaker: NA
Text: their heavy subsidisation policy. It was also

Speaker: NA
Text: important for them to understand what effects

Speaker: NA
Text: the American enhanced agricultural program,

Speaker: NA
Text: EAP, and the subsidisation of exports had on

Speaker: NA
Text: other producers.

Speaker: NA
Text: The desire to unify Europe into a single

Speaker: NA
Text: market with monetary union and associated

Speaker: NA
Text: common security policies is strong but, as we

Speaker: NA
Text: said at the time, the original timetable is

Speaker: NA
Text: ambitious. Looking back-the deputy leader

Speaker: NA
Text: of the delegation, the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Bendigo will follow up this point-the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: clusions we drew at that time were accurate:

Speaker: NA
Text: the process is taking considerably longer than

Speaker: NA
Text: was anticipated.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think ours was a unique delegation in

Speaker: NA
Text: terms of the level of cooperation and consen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sus achieved, but a recurring theme in our

Speaker: NA
Text: discussions was that the Europeans wanted

Speaker: NA
Text: some continuity between delegations. I am not

Speaker: NA
Text: putting in a plug to be the leader of the next

Speaker: NA
Text: delegation-although it would be wonderful,

Speaker: NA
Text: it would be great-

Speaker: Mr GEAR
Text: Totally modest.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: to be so immodest, but that was the recurring

Speaker: NA
Text: theme. The Europeans found it difficult to

Speaker: NA
Text: accept that, after establishing a rapport, an

Speaker: NA
Text: understanding and a feeling for issues with

Speaker: NA
Text: one delegation, the next year there would be

Speaker: NA
Text: a fresh cast of players .. If even one member,

Speaker: NA
Text: the leader, or deputy leader were to remain

Speaker: NA
Text: the same between delegations, there would be

Speaker: NA
Text: a sense of continuity. We have made recom-

Speaker: NA
Text: mendations on how that could be achieved.

Speaker: NA
Text: The final· matter is our address to the

Speaker: NA
Text: inaugural Enlarged Parliamentary Assembly

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Council of Europe on 2 October 1992.

Speaker: NA
Text: We were the first delegation to speak by right

Speaker: NA
Text: to the assembly, and to address it as Austral-

Speaker: NA
Text: ians. I think that our contribution had an

Speaker: NA
Text: impact. We participated quite actively in the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee stage of the council, we had an

Speaker: NA
Text: impact upon the decisions that were reached,

Speaker: NA
Text: and we were also able to alter or fend off

Speaker: NA
Text: certain decisions.

Speaker: NA
Text: Overall, it was a very successful delegation.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am proud to have had the honour to have

Speaker: NA
Text: led it. I thank each of my colleagues, Ms

Speaker: NA
Text: . Dalma Dixon, our Deputy Serjeant-at-Arms,

Speaker: NA
Text: and all the others who helped us for their

Speaker: NA
Text: cooperation and support. I wish them well. I

Speaker: NA
Text: hope that we get the chance to speak with

Speaker: NA
Text: future delegations so that they will have a

Speaker: NA
Text: better understanding of what is involved. I

Speaker: NA
Text: conclude by expressing my special thanks to

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Relations Office who did a tremendous

Speaker: NA
Text: amount of preparatory work behind the scenes

Speaker: NA
Text: which made our task much easier.

Speaker: Mr REID
Text: Bendigo)-by leave-I support

Speaker: NA
Text: the remarks of the leader of the parliamentary

Speaker: NA
Text: delegation to the European institutions and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Netherlands, the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: fine leader and welded together an excellent

Speaker: NA
Text: delegation which worked very closely to-

Speaker: NA
Text: gether in regard to the issues that were raised

Speaker: NA
Text: during that visit. We had some very good

Speaker: NA
Text: colleagues who brought a wealth of know-

Speaker: NA
Text: ledge and information about the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: scene and the Australian economy and who

Speaker: NA
Text: participated ably in the whole process.

Speaker: NA
Text: It was certainly an exciting time to be there.

Speaker: NA
Text: The fortieth anniversary of the European

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament occurred whilst we were there, as

Speaker: NA
Text: did the French referendum on the Maastricht

Speaker: NA
Text: Treaty. We were able to gain a closer know-

Speaker: NA
Text: ledge of the current conflicts in the former

Speaker: NA
Text: Yugoslavian states. We have always main-

Speaker: NA
Text: tained strong links with the Netherlands and

Speaker: NA
Text: I am sure that the delegation's visit there

Speaker: NA
Text: strengthened those links. They will be further

Speaker: NA
Text: strengthened when we receive a visit from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Netherlands parliamentarians later this year.

Speaker: NA
Text: Participating in debate, particularly on

Speaker: NA
Text: agricultural matters, with my colleague the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Gippsland ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: MCGauran) in the Council of Europe in

Speaker: NA
Text: response to the OECD report was one of the

Speaker: NA
Text: highlights of the visit for me because it gave

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member for Gippsland, me

Speaker: NA
Text: and the whole delegation the opportunity to

Speaker: NA
Text: participate in an issue which was very import-

Speaker: NA
Text: ant to the Australian economy, the issue of

Speaker: NA
Text: subsidised food coming out of the European

Speaker: NA
Text: Community and the competition that Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: faced as a result.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think we made an impression in this area.

Speaker: NA
Text: When one participates in a debate like that

Speaker: NA
Text: and one can get the French delegates very

Speaker: NA
Text: angry and excited, one has had some success.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable member for Gippsland and I

Speaker: NA
Text: put a few burrs under the French delegates'

Speaker: NA
Text: saddles. They became quite agitated.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another important aspect of the delegation

Speaker: NA
Text: was our visit to the Australian war graves in

Speaker: NA
Text: Flanders and Ypres. We also attended a very

Speaker: NA
Text: impressive ceremony at Menin Gate. No-one

Speaker: NA
Text: left that ceremony without a lump in his

Speaker: NA
Text: throat. It was one of the most touching cere-

Speaker: NA
Text: monies that I have ever experienced in my

Speaker: NA
Text: life. I am sure that all of the delegation left

Speaker: NA
Text: with a greater respect for and understanding

Speaker: NA
Text: of the conflict that our own Australian service

Speaker: NA
Text: people were engaged in during that time.

Speaker: NA
Text: I join the honourable member for Shortland,

Speaker: NA
Text: the leader of the delegation, in thanking a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of people. I thank the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: missions and their support staff, who did an

Speaker: NA
Text: excellent job in supporting us and providing

Speaker: NA
Text: us with first-hand knowledge of what was

Speaker: NA
Text: occurring in each of the countries that we

Speaker: NA
Text: visited. I pay tribute to all of the people who

Speaker: NA
Text: have been mentioned by the leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: delegation.

Speaker: NA
Text: I also want to express my thanks to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Deputy Serjeant-at-Arms, Dalma Dixon, for

Speaker: NA
Text: her excellent guidance and assistance during

Speaker: NA
Text: that visit. We were under quite an amount of

Speaker: NA
Text: pressure from time to time because of tight

Speaker: NA
Text: timetabling, none of which we regret now of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, but it was pretty hectic at the time.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, Delma was able to pull all of the

Speaker: NA
Text: movements together. I thank her for her

Speaker: NA
Text: cooperation and assistance. All in all, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian delegation perfornied very credit-

Speaker: NA
Text: ably. I was pleased to be associated with a

Speaker: NA
Text: fine leader, the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Shortland, on that delegation.

Speaker: Mr MCGAURAN
Text: Gippsland)-by leave-

Speaker: NA
Text: I rise to endorse the remarks of my colleagues

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member for Shortland ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Peter Morris) and the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Bendigo ( Mr Reid). It was an unusually

Speaker: NA
Text: harmonious and united team. It was a remark-

Speaker: NA
Text: able experience and a tremendous privilege to

Speaker: NA
Text: be able to represent Australia in the visit to

Speaker: NA
Text: the European institutions and the Netherlands.

Speaker: NA
Text: I also wish to be associated with the thanks

Speaker: NA
Text: expressed by the leader of the delegation, the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Shortland, particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: to Ms Dalma Dixon for her work as our

Speaker: NA
Text: secretary. The honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Shortland's leadership had a great deal to do

Speaker: NA
Text: with the very strong and enthusiastic mood

Speaker: NA
Text: that permeated the team from beginning to

Speaker: NA
Text: end.

Speaker: NA
Text: It was one of those delegations where we

Speaker: NA
Text: never tired and never wanted to miss any sort

Speaker: NA
Text: of meeting or discussion for fear of missing

Speaker: NA
Text: something substantial. It was termed a visit to

Speaker: NA
Text: the European institutions, and it certainly was

Speaker: NA
Text: that. In fact, we came away from Europe

Speaker: NA
Text: marvelling at the different number of institu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions involved in the decision making which

Speaker: NA
Text: affects Europe as a whole. There was the

Speaker: NA
Text: European Parliament, the Council of Europe,

Speaker: NA
Text: the European Commission Council of

Speaker: NA
Text: Ministers, the European Commission, NATO,

Speaker: NA
Text: the North Atlantic Assembly, the OECD, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Strasbourg Conference on Democracy and, of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, the different national parliaments that

Speaker: NA
Text: we visited.

Speaker: NA
Text: It was generally agreed by the delegation

Speaker: NA
Text: that this institutional structure is not one

Speaker: NA
Text: can continue indefinitely in Europe, and there

Speaker: NA
Text: will have to be some sort of-dare I say-

Speaker: NA
Text: rationalisation; not that it is for me to preach

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Europeans as to what sort of institution-

Speaker: NA
Text: al structure they would wish to endorse into

Speaker: NA
Text: the future. But there is no doubt that even

Speaker: NA
Text: amongst themselves there are frank admis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions that there is tremendous overlap and

Speaker: NA
Text: duplication.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable member for Shortland

Speaker: NA
Text: raised our discussions regarding the deteriora-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion-remembering this was last October-in

Speaker: NA
Text: the former Yugoslav republic. It was obvious

Speaker: NA
Text: that the suffering and the bloodshed to that

Speaker: NA
Text: date would be accentuated into the future.

Speaker: NA
Text: Wherever we raised it-and with whomever-

Speaker: NA
Text: the reply was the same, 'There is nothing we

Speaker: NA
Text: can do. We are powerless to act or to

Speaker: NA
Text: intervene'. The truth is that very few, if any,

Speaker: NA
Text: countries in Europe are going to shed the life

Speaker: NA
Text: of one young soldier for the Balkans. There

Speaker: NA
Text: was a complete paralyses then-as there is

Speaker: NA
Text: now-in how to respond to the butchery and

Speaker: NA
Text: disast-i' that is now engulfing Bosnia, Serbia,

Speaker: NA
Text: Croatia and, of course, does threaten

Speaker: NA
Text: Macedonia and one or two of the other former

Speaker: NA
Text: republics of the federal republic of Yugosla-

Speaker: NA
Text: via.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is a disaster. It was frustrating for the

Speaker: NA
Text: people involved. Do not think for a moment

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Europeans were not horrified at their

Speaker: NA
Text: inability to act-they were. They know that

Speaker: NA
Text: night after night the whole world is watching

Speaker: NA
Text: the slaughter unfold. It is on their doorstep.

Speaker: NA
Text: They have had a European community-at

Speaker: NA
Text: least in name-for three or four decades, and

Speaker: NA
Text: now, faced with this enormous problem, they

Speaker: NA
Text: are unable to even remotely solve it.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable member for Bendigo raised

Speaker: NA
Text: our discussions with various parliamentarians

Speaker: NA
Text: in the European Commission regarding

Speaker: NA
Text: agricultural subsidies. I think it is true to say

Speaker: NA
Text: that we gave as good as what we got, if not

Speaker: NA
Text: more, and we very forcefully put the point of

Speaker: NA
Text: view that European consumers were the losers

Speaker: NA
Text: in the high protection regime that encircles

Speaker: NA
Text: Europe. We made that point time and again-

Speaker: NA
Text: even to the extent where we were unofficially

Speaker: NA
Text: told that we may have been overplaying our

Speaker: NA
Text: that hand. I think that is largely explained by

Speaker: NA
Text: certain parliamentarians from well-known

Speaker: NA
Text: countries who were tired of debate and argu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment with us.

Speaker: NA
Text: It was a tremendous privilege and a fasci-

Speaker: NA
Text: nating and enormously rewarding visit for the

Speaker: NA
Text: delegation personally and, as a whole, I

Speaker: NA
Text: believe for the Parliament of Australia.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Hollis)-I

Speaker: NA
Text: was pleased that the delegation was so harmo-

Speaker: NA
Text: nious. The European air must be different

Speaker: NA
Text: from the African air.

Speaker: NA
Text: HEALTH INSURANCE COMMISSION

Speaker: NA
Text: AMENDMENT BILL 1993

Speaker: NA
Text: First Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill received from the Senate, and 'read a

Speaker: NA
Text: first time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: Dr THEOPHANOUS
Text: Cal well-

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Health) (9.55 p.m.)-I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: This Bill amends the Health Insurance Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mission Act 1973 to allow the Health Insur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance Commission to plan, establish and

Speaker: NA
Text: administer the child-care cash rebate scheme

Speaker: NA
Text: for expenses incurred for work-related child

Speaker: NA
Text: care as announced by the Prime Minister ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Keating) on 9 February 1993.

Speaker: NA
Text: Under current Health Insurance Commission

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation, the Health Insurance Commission

Speaker: NA
Text: is restricted to undertake preparatory work in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to health insurance or other health

Speaker: NA
Text: related matters only. This amendment to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Health Insurance Commission Act 1973

Speaker: NA
Text: provides for additional functions for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Health Insurance Commission in respect of re-

Speaker: NA
Text: bates for child-care costs.

Speaker: NA
Text: Under the new arrangements, the Health

Speaker: NA
Text: Insurance Commission can plan and establish

Speaker: NA
Text: a scheme which will allow the payment of

Speaker: NA
Text: rebates for child-care costs to parents who are

Speaker: NA
Text: working, studying, training or seeking work.

Speaker: NA
Text: Such an amendment to the Act is required to

Speaker: NA
Text: enable the Health Insurance Commission to

Speaker: NA
Text: devote resources to develop and establish

Speaker: NA
Text: systems and procedures to register carers,

Speaker: NA
Text: register eligible families and make payments

Speaker: NA
Text: under the scheme from 1 July 1994. The new

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangements will also enable the Health

Speaker: NA
Text: Insurance Commission to administer a child-

Speaker: NA
Text: care cash rebate as specified by an Act. Such

Speaker: NA
Text: a scheme will be specified in amendments to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Child Care Act 1972, which is scheduled

Speaker: NA
Text: for amendment in Autumn 1994.

Speaker: NA
Text: The child-care cash rebate is part of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Government's comprehensive child-care

Speaker: NA
Text: policy which recognises that most parents

Speaker: NA
Text: need quality child care at some stage of their

Speaker: NA
Text: working lives and that they need help with

Speaker: NA
Text: the cost of child care. The child-care cash

Speaker: NA
Text: rebate recognises that the cost of child care is

Speaker: NA
Text: a legitimate expense for parents in earning an

Speaker: NA
Text: income. The rebates will significantly improve

Speaker: NA
Text: the affordability of child care for working

Speaker: NA
Text: parents.

Speaker: NA
Text: From 1 July 1994, parents using child care

Speaker: NA
Text: while in employment, training, studying or

Speaker: NA
Text: looking for work will be able to claim a

Speaker: NA
Text: rebate for part of their child-care expenses.

Speaker: NA
Text: An estimated 230,000 families, with 358,000

Speaker: NA
Text: children, will benefit from the scheme. After

Speaker: NA
Text: the first $16 of weekly child-care expenses,

Speaker: NA
Text: eligible families will be able to claim 30 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent of their child-care costs up to a ceiling

Speaker: NA
Text: of $110 per week for one child in care and

Speaker: NA
Text: .$220 per week for two or more children. The

Speaker: NA
Text: maximum child-care cash rebate will be

Speaker: NA
Text: $28.20 per week, or $1,466 per year, for one

Speaker: NA
Text: child and $61.20 per week, or $3,182 per

Speaker: NA
Text: year, for two or more children.

Speaker: NA
Text: The child-care cash rebate will be paid for

Speaker: NA
Text: any work related child-care expense for

Speaker: NA
Text: children aged up to 12 years. Child-care

Speaker: NA
Text: expenses incurred in formal child care-for

Speaker: NA
Text: example, long day care centres, family day

Speaker: NA
Text: care and outside school hours care-and in

Speaker: NA
Text: informal care arrangements-for example,

Speaker: NA
Text: with relatives and nannies-will be eligible

Speaker: NA
Text: for the rebate. Child-care expenses incurred in

Speaker: NA
Text: informal care have been included in recogni-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of the fact that almost two-thirds of

Speaker: NA
Text: working families use informal care, either by

Speaker: NA
Text: choice or because formal care is not available.

Speaker: NA
Text: Families will be able to claim the rebate by

Speaker: NA
Text: mail or in person at one of 240 Medicare

Speaker: NA
Text: offices around Australia. I commend this

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill to the House. I present the explanatory

Speaker: NA
Text: memorandum to this Bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: Leave granted for debate to continue forth-

Speaker: NA
Text: with.

Speaker: Mrs SULLIVAN
Text: Moncrieff) (10.00
