Speaker: NA
Text: p.m.)-I rise to state the position of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition on the Health Insurance Commis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion Amendment Bill. I think at the outset it

Speaker: NA
Text: should be made clear that this is nota debate

Speaker: NA
Text: about the Government's child-care policy; this

Speaker: NA
Text: is a debate about how the Government is to

Speaker: NA
Text: implement its child-care policy. The second

Speaker: NA
Text: reading speech of the Parliamentary Secretary

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Minister for Health (Dr Theophanous)

Speaker: NA
Text: made that clear. In the Senate, when this

Speaker: NA
Text: matter was being debated, the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Family Services (Senator Crowley) said very

Speaker: NA
Text: clearly that this is not the child-care policy.

Speaker: NA
Text: She said:

Speaker: NA
Text: Nothing can be done in the area of implementing

Speaker: NA
Text: of cash rebates until the Child Care Act is amended

Speaker: NA
Text: later on.

Speaker: NA
Text: She went on to say that we shall not see that

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill until some time in the Budget session. So

Speaker: NA
Text: we are not tonight debating child-care policy.

Speaker: NA
Text: I say that because the Minister in the Senate

Speaker: NA
Text: to a large extent misrepresented the concerns

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Opposition had about this Bill. I

Speaker: NA
Text: would not like to see that repeated in here

Speaker: NA
Text: tonight. So, armed with the foreknowledge of

Speaker: NA
Text: the sort of misrepresentation of the.

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition's position that took place,in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate, I lay that out very clearly here.

Speaker: NA
Text: This Bill gives powers to the Health Insur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance Commission to do something it does not

Speaker: NA
Text: have power to do at the moment. At present,

Speaker: NA
Text: its legislation restricts it to undertaking

Speaker: NA
Text: preparatory work in relation to health insur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance or other health related matters. This Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: will enable it to undertake preparatory work

Speaker: NA
Text: in relation to the Government's child-care

Speaker: NA
Text: policy, not the implementation of the policy.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, the Bill does rather more than

Speaker: NA
Text: just allow the Health Insurance Commission

Speaker: NA
Text: to undertake some preparatory work. During

Speaker: NA
Text: the debate in the Senate the coalition and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Democrats expressed considerable

Speaker: NA
Text: alarm. The Bill breaks new ground in the use

Speaker: NA
Text: of tax file numbers, to which the coalition has

Speaker: NA
Text: said it will not agree. We are agreeing to this

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill because we do not raise an objection to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Health Insurance Commission having the

Speaker: NA
Text: power to look at how something might be

Speaker: NA
Text: implemented. What we are objecting to is that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Health Insurance Commission has clearly

Speaker: NA
Text: no discretion in how this matter is to be

Speaker: NA
Text: implemented. I will refer in due course to

Speaker: NA
Text: some statements that were made during the

Speaker: NA
Text: election campaign, in Senate estimates com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittees on this matter just very recently, and

Speaker: NA
Text: in the debate on this Bill in the Senate, to

Speaker: NA
Text: illustrate those concerns.

Speaker: NA
Text: We will not raise any opposition to the

Speaker: NA
Text: passage of the Bill, as I have said. We agree

Speaker: NA
Text: that the charter of the Health Insurance

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission should be broadened sufficiently

Speaker: NA
Text: so that it can examine implementation of the

Speaker: NA
Text: child-care rebate system. Our concern is that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Health Insurance Commission will clearly

Speaker: NA
Text: have no discretion in a vital part of the

Speaker: NA
Text: mechanism. It does not have the power to

Speaker: NA
Text: fully report on methods of implementation; it

Speaker: NA
Text: has been told the system has to be implement-

Speaker: NA
Text: ed in only one way. That instruction on

Speaker: NA
Text: implementation is a direct breaking of an

Speaker: NA
Text: election campaign undertaking by the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment on the subject of privacy. I will come to

Speaker: NA
Text: that in a minute. In the second reading speech

Speaker: NA
Text: we have just heard, the Parliamentary Secre-

Speaker: NA
Text: tary said:

Speaker: NA
Text: The child-care cash rebate recognises that the cost

Speaker: NA
Text: of child care is a legitimate expense for parents in

Speaker: NA
Text: earning an income. The rebates will significantly

Speaker: NA
Text: improve the affordability of child care for working

Speaker: NA
Text: parents.

Speaker: NA
Text: Three cheers for the ultimate triumph of

Speaker: NA
Text: sanity and reason. I do not know for how

Speaker: NA
Text: many decades women have been saying that

Speaker: NA
Text: child care should be recognised as a legiti-

Speaker: NA
Text: mate expense of working where they are

Speaker: NA
Text: dependent children and they are their depend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ent children. For years the tax commissioner

Speaker: NA
Text: has been saying that this would require

Speaker: NA
Text: certain amendments to the legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: For the last 10 years this Government has

Speaker: NA
Text: been under pressure on that subject. It has

Speaker: NA
Text: long since been an undertaking o( the Liberal

Speaker: NA
Text: Party and the National Party, in a series of

Speaker: NA
Text: election campaigns, that, if elected to govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, we would move to recognise the very

Speaker: NA
Text: basic principle that a parent who has the

Speaker: NA
Text: prime responsibility for the care of children,

Speaker: NA
Text: and who needs to take on child care in order

Speaker: NA
Text: to earn an income, has incurred that expense

Speaker: NA
Text: of child care as a necessary part of earning

Speaker: NA
Text: that income. Overwhelmingly this relates to

Speaker: NA
Text: women.

Speaker: NA
Text: For a very long time in this Parliament we

Speaker: NA
Text: have been told by the Labor Party that that

Speaker: NA
Text: was not the way to achieve the objective of

Speaker: NA
Text: fairness for women in relation to child care.

Speaker: NA
Text: We were told that the way to do it was to

Speaker: NA
Text: subsidise the cost of child care. Finally,

Speaker: NA
Text: obviously, the pressure has become too much

Speaker: NA
Text: for the Government and now there is a recog-

Speaker: NA
Text: nition that, as the Parliamentary Secretary said

Speaker: NA
Text: in his second reading speech '. . . the cost of

Speaker: NA
Text: child care is a legitimate expense for parents

Speaker: NA
Text: in earning an income' and that:

Speaker: NA
Text: The rebates will significantly improve the

Speaker: NA
Text: affordability of child care for working parents.

Speaker: NA
Text: The coalition welcomes the fact that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Party has finally got aboard on this

Speaker: NA
Text: issue.

Speaker: NA
Text: I will very briefly make one point that has

Speaker: NA
Text: not been widely raised in the debate but is a

Speaker: NA
Text: matter that the Government must address. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliamentary Secretary said:

Speaker: NA
Text: Families will be able to claim the rebate by mail

Speaker: NA
Text: or in person at one of 240 Medicare offices around

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: If this is the way that this matter goes ahead,

Speaker: NA
Text: a matter of very basic equity has to be con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sidered. The figure of 240 MediCare offices

Speaker: NA
Text: around Australia sounds like a lot of offices,

Speaker: NA
Text: but it is not when one is talking about a

Speaker: NA
Text: population like that of A,Ustralia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Until very recently my electorate included

Speaker: NA
Text: rural areas, including the very significant rural

Speaker: NA
Text: area of Beaudesert, and it still includes a very

Speaker: NA
Text: long strip of the Gold Coast, which is a strip

Speaker: NA
Text: of provincial city population some 40 kilo-

Speaker: NA
Text: metres long. A very high proportion of my

Speaker: NA
Text: constituents are pensioners. Many people are

Speaker: NA
Text: in the position of having only one Medicare

Speaker: NA
Text: office to go to. Many of my elderly constitu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ents do not own motor vehicles and do not

Speaker: NA
Text: drive cars and it is a hardship for them to

Speaker: NA
Text: travel to this one office. Many times I have

Speaker: NA
Text: made representations for extra .Medicare

Speaker: NA
Text: offices and they have been rejected. I know

Speaker: NA
Text: that many honourable members have been in

Speaker: NA
Text: that position. There has been a view around-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mrs Crosio-Don't the doctors bulk-bill?

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Hollis)-

Speaker: NA
Text: Please continue to discuss the Bill and we

Speaker: NA
Text: will save the debates until later.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mrs SULLIVANI do not believe that

Speaker: NA
Text: that is a legitimate comment. If the non-

Speaker: NA
Text: provision of Medicare offices in areas of need

Speaker: NA
Text: is used as a stick to hold over doctors for

Speaker: NA
Text: bulk-billing, then maybe we have yet another

Speaker: NA
Text: reason for there being so few Medicare

Speaker: NA
Text: offices. I must admit it is not one that I had

Speaker: NA
Text: thought of before. Innocent little me!

Speaker: NA
Text: I thought it was because the Health insur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance Commission some years ago took on a

Speaker: NA
Text: huge computer with a capacity far outside its

Speaker: NA
Text: needs, obviously with the ID card as part of

Speaker: NA
Text: its planning, and it had to find a way to fill

Speaker: NA
Text: that capacity. A number of people who

Speaker: NA
Text: previously could make medical rebates were

Speaker: NA
Text: suddenly told that they could no longer.

Speaker: NA
Text: People had to do it by mail and the computer

Speaker: NA
Text: could print out the cheques, but there is

Speaker: NA
Text: apparently another reason.

Speaker: NA
Text: I return to the Opposition's initial concern

Speaker: NA
Text: about the issue. A few minutes ago I referred

Speaker: NA
Text: to the breaking of an election undertaking and

Speaker: NA
Text: I would like to outline to the House precisely

Speaker: NA
Text: what that was. During the election campaign

Speaker: NA
Text: a concern was raised through newspaper

Speaker: NA
Text: reports that the Government was going to

Speaker: NA
Text: require child carers to provide tax file number

Speaker: NA
Text: information to Medicare, administered by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Health Insurance Commission as a method of

Speaker: NA
Text: implementation. This raised concern.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Australian Privacy Foundation con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tacted the office of the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Jagajaga ( Mr Staples), then Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Aged, Family and Health Services, about it.

Speaker: NA
Text: An assurance was given by Minister Staples's

Speaker: NA
Text: private staff that a tax file number would not

Speaker: NA
Text: have to be provided to the Health Insurance

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission. In other words, during the

Speaker: NA
Text: campaign a concern was raised in relation to

Speaker: NA
Text: the tax file number because a newspaper got

Speaker: NA
Text: a whiff of the Government's intentions re-

Speaker: NA
Text: garding this issue. When the concern was

Speaker: NA
Text: taken up and pursued by the privacy founda-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, Minister Staples's office hit it on the

Speaker: NA
Text: head. The spokesman from Minister Staples's

Speaker: NA
Text: office did not tell the truth, because this Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: will enable the Government to implement

Speaker: NA
Text: exactly that policy.

Speaker: NA
Text: There was much waffling on the subject by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government in the Senate. The Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: was accused· of saying that the Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: policy was that child-care users would have

Speaker: NA
Text: to provide tax file numbers. I have read and

Speaker: NA
Text: reread that Senate debate. At no time did the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition say that. The Opposition just took

Speaker: NA
Text: the case as the Government put it and showed

Speaker: NA
Text: the dangers of that procedure. The public-

Speaker: NA
Text: people who care about the extended use of

Speaker: NA
Text: the tax file number, which would be improp-

Speaker: NA
Text: er-were lied to during the election campaign.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is no doubt about that.

Speaker: NA
Text: The people who were making the inquiry

Speaker: NA
Text: did so very carefully and specifically. What

Speaker: NA
Text: was said was recorded. The person who was

Speaker: NA
Text: saying that this was not going to happen was

Speaker: NA
Text: told that it was being written down. The

Speaker: NA
Text: words that Minister Staples's staffer had

Speaker: NA
Text: as written down by the representative of the

Speaker: NA
Text: privacy foundation, were read back to him

Speaker: NA
Text: over the telephone and it was confirmed that

Speaker: NA
Text: those words were the Government's policy,

Speaker: NA
Text: including the denial that a tax file number

Speaker: NA
Text: would have to be given by child-care provid-

Speaker: NA
Text: ers as part of the implementation. What was

Speaker: NA
Text: denied, absolutely and specifically, during

Speaker: NA
Text: election campaign is exactly what this Bill is

Speaker: NA
Text: about. At no time since has the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: responded to that. To the Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: credit, it has not dumped the staff member,

Speaker: NA
Text: because the staff member was doing what he

Speaker: NA
Text: was told to do.

Speaker: NA
Text: The tax file number is unnecessary; never-

Speaker: NA
Text: theless, the Government is determined to go

Speaker: NA
Text: ahead with it. The Government's policy could

Speaker: NA
Text: be implemented in a range of ways. As I have

Speaker: NA
Text: said, tonight's debate is not about the policy;

Speaker: NA
Text: it is about the implementation. The Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment could give these rebates in an utterly

Speaker: NA
Text: non-offensive way-in fact, several non-

Speaker: NA
Text: offensive ways-but it has indicated its

Speaker: NA
Text: determination to pursue the tax file number

Speaker: NA
Text: course.

Speaker: NA
Text: During Senate estimates committee hearings

Speaker: NA
Text: a hapless public servant tried to obfuscate

Speaker: NA
Text: indicate that maybe it was not all set in stone

Speaker: NA
Text: yet, but a few minutes later the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: dumped that public servant and said that the

Speaker: NA
Text: decision had been taken and that this was the

Speaker: NA
Text: way it was to proceed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Estimates committee evidence also revealed

Speaker: NA
Text: that the commission had looked at a range of

Speaker: NA
Text: ways that the Government's policy could be

Speaker: NA
Text: implemented still using the Medicare office

Speaker: NA
Text: device, but that the Government had instruct-

Speaker: NA
Text: ed the commission not to proceed with the

Speaker: NA
Text: alternatives, that the tax file number device

Speaker: NA
Text: was the one that had to be proceeded with.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have to ask why, in all the debate about

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australia card and its ultimate dumping

Speaker: NA
Text: and in all the subsequent debate about up-

Speaker: NA
Text: grading tax file numbers for the tax lurk

Speaker: NA
Text: purpose that the Australia card was supposed

Speaker: NA
Text: to meet, the Government went to some pains

Speaker: NA
Text: to say, 'The tax file number will not be used

Speaker: NA
Text: as a de facto ID card'. At least front bench

Speaker: NA
Text: government members did.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: used, for Social Security has a couple of words

Speaker: NA
Text: bubbling up, I can just tell. Maybe he did not

Speaker: NA
Text: think that. I want to make this very clear

Speaker: NA
Text: point: the then Treasurer, the present Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister ( Mr Keating), very specifically

Speaker: NA
Text: undertook that use of the tax file number

Speaker: NA
Text: would not be extended in a way that would

Speaker: NA
Text: intrude into non-relevant areas. There were,

Speaker: NA
Text: the I admit, some government backbenchers who

Speaker: NA
Text: put forward a different point of view, includ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the present Minister for Family Services.

Speaker: NA
Text: She put the view that if a tax file number

Speaker: NA
Text: were put in place it could be a de facto ID

Speaker: NA
Text: card. '

Speaker: NA
Text: Very significantly I believe-as does the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition-that there is a danger. If the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government is fair dinkum about not extend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing use of the, tax file number in a way that

Speaker: NA
Text: is bound to cause harm and intrusion, it has

Speaker: NA
Text: a range of alternatives. It could, of course, do

Speaker: NA
Text: what the Opposition said it was going to do,

Speaker: NA
Text: and I would like to refresh the memory of

Speaker: NA
Text: government members on the Opposition's

Speaker: NA
Text: policy on this matter. Our child-care policy

Speaker: NA
Text: statement reveals that we would have admin-

Speaker: NA
Text: istered our child-care rebate scheme as fol-

Speaker: NA
Text: lows:

Speaker: NA
Text: and Individuals who provide child care on which a

Speaker: NA
Text: rebate is to be claimed will be required to register

Speaker: NA
Text: with the Tax Office. Each registered carer will then

Speaker: NA
Text: be provided with a Registered Carer's Number

Speaker: NA
Text: which must be quoted on all rebate claim forms.

Speaker: NA
Text: Parents will have the option of claiming the rebate

Speaker: NA
Text: either fortnightly, in which case payment will be

Speaker: NA
Text: made in cash and available through Medicare

Speaker: NA
Text: offices, or annually in which case the rebate will

Speaker: NA
Text: be calculated as part of the parents' tax return.

Speaker: NA
Text: The administration of this scheme by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government and by the Opposition would not

Speaker: NA
Text: be very different, with one critical exception.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government will require the carer, the

Speaker: NA
Text: provider of child care, to give to the Health

Speaker: NA
Text: Insurance Commission a tax file number. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition was going to say to the carer,

Speaker: NA
Text: 'Here is a registered carer's number'. That

Speaker: NA
Text: number would be given again by the Tax

Speaker: NA
Text: Office, but there would be no revealing of

Speaker: NA
Text: that tax file number which can link into so

Speaker: NA
Text: many other things. It would be a special

Speaker: NA
Text: number issued by the Tax Office which would

Speaker: NA
Text: then be passed on to the person claiming

Speaker: NA
Text: child care to quote when obtaining a rebate.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is a very simple alternative system.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another alternative which was raised by

Speaker: NA
Text: Senator Harradine in debate and which was

Speaker: NA
Text: not, I believe, properly answered-and I hope

Speaker: NA
Text: it might be better answered when we debate

Speaker: NA
Text: the actual system in the Budget session-was

Speaker: NA
Text: the possibility of looking at the plain tax

Speaker: NA
Text: rebate system. That is a possibility. The

Speaker: NA
Text: objection that the Minister raised was that a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of people-and she made it sound

Speaker: NA
Text: like a huge number of peoplewho would

Speaker: NA
Text: be benefiting from this provision are not

Speaker: NA
Text: taxpayers. A number of them are not, that is

Speaker: NA
Text: true. A number of them are students or people

Speaker: NA
Text: who are undertaking further training before

Speaker: NA
Text: re-entering the work force or something like

Speaker: NA
Text: that. However, when pressed on the issue, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister could give no break-down of the

Speaker: NA
Text: figures at all.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think that it should be possible to give

Speaker: NA
Text: some close notional figure. If one knew what

Speaker: NA
Text: the break-down was between tax paying

Speaker: NA
Text: people who are going to be looking for this

Speaker: NA
Text: child-care rebate versus non-tax paying

Speaker: NA
Text: people, and then a break-down of the non-tax

Speaker: NA
Text: paying categories-at least a notional one-

Speaker: NA
Text: then it would be possible to construct some-

Speaker: NA
Text: thing that would fit the situation. But, after

Speaker: NA
Text: saying, 'No, we could not possibly do that

Speaker: NA
Text: because so many of them do not pay tax', the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister then could not give any clue at all

Speaker: NA
Text: about how many that was. To me, it was just

Speaker: NA
Text: a way of dismissing the argument without

Speaker: NA
Text: looking at the merits. Frankly, I am sorry to

Speaker: NA
Text: say that because I have a personal regard for

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister. But in my opinion she ended up

Speaker: NA
Text: looking very foolish on that particular subject.

Speaker: NA
Text: For the first time, service providers as

Speaker: NA
Text: against benefit recipients will have to provide

Speaker: NA
Text: a tax file number. That is breaking new and

Speaker: NA
Text: quite dangerous ground. There was a sugges-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion some time ago, which the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: hastily dropped-and we might come to it in

Speaker: NA
Text: debate on the next health Bill-that pharma-

Speaker: NA
Text: cists should be linked into the Health Insur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance Commission system. This was to be

Speaker: NA
Text: done for the sake of checking on the eligibili-

Speaker: NA
Text: ty for benefit of particular types of beneficiar-

Speaker: NA
Text: ies who presented with prescriptions. There

Speaker: NA
Text: was such an outcry about it that the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment had to drop the proposal that a service

Speaker: NA
Text: provider be linked into the system by com-

Speaker: NA
Text: puter.

Speaker: NA
Text: But now we come to what appears to be a

Speaker: NA
Text: very much more acceptable area of debate:

Speaker: NA
Text: that of child care. I am sorry to say that again

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister doubled back and contradicted

Speaker: NA
Text: herself several times in the course of the

Speaker: NA
Text: debate. She got really very confused indeed

Speaker: NA
Text: about whether what was in this Bill was a

Speaker: NA
Text: proposal. After it was made very clear at an

Speaker: NA
Text: estimates committee hearing that the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment had decided this was the way to go, she

Speaker: NA
Text: then tried to get out from under by saying

Speaker: NA
Text: that this was 'quite innocent legislation'. She

Speaker: NA
Text: then said:

Speaker: NA
Text: Nothing can be done in the area of implementing

Speaker: NA
Text: the cash rebates until the Child Care Act is amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ed later on.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have already referred to that. She said that

Speaker: NA
Text: it was 'just a proposal' which the Health

Speaker: NA
Text: Insurance Commission was looking at. Saying

Speaker: NA
Text: 'just a proposal' is like saying 'This is just an

Speaker: NA
Text: idea and here you are, Health Insurance

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission, kick this one around a bit; if

Speaker: NA
Text: you can think of a better proposal than this

Speaker: NA
Text: "just a proposal", then please make it'.

Speaker: NA
Text: The coalition made a proposal which was

Speaker: NA
Text: ignored. But, more importantly, the Health

Speaker: NA
Text: Insurance Commission has made, or embarked

Speaker: NA
Text: upon making, proposals-that comes out in

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate estimates reports-but it was told to

Speaker: NA
Text: stop and get on with the tax file number. So

Speaker: NA
Text: when the Minister was saying that this was

Speaker: NA
Text: 'just a proposal', she was being too coy and

Speaker: NA
Text: too ingenuous by half. It is far more than just

Speaker: NA
Text: a proposal. The Government has taken a

Speaker: NA
Text: decision which the coalition urges it to move

Speaker: NA
Text: away from.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of course, being so ingenuous and saying,

Speaker: NA
Text: 'You don't have to worry about this. You can

Speaker: NA
Text: happily support it, and when the proposal

Speaker: NA
Text: comes along then you can debate it', means

Speaker: NA
Text: that we will have a re-run of what the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister said, quite falsely, in Question Time

Speaker: NA
Text: about opposition policy in relation to social

Speaker: NA
Text: security and veterans affairs. We agree in

Speaker: NA
Text: principle with the child-care policy, but we

Speaker: NA
Text: object to the detail.

Speaker: NA
Text: When this legislation proceeds and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government goes ahead with the tax file

Speaker: NA
Text: number proposal, we will vote against it in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Senate and the Australian Democrats will

Speaker: NA
Text: vote against it in the Senate. They have put

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister on notice that they will not agree

Speaker: NA
Text: to the extension of the tax file number in this

Speaker: NA
Text: way. They were talking about care providers,

Speaker: NA
Text: not recipients as the Minister tried to say in

Speaker: NA
Text: her reply during the second reading debate.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is very clear that both the coalition and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Democrats-and the Minister wanted to

Speaker: NA
Text: talk about something else-will not support

Speaker: NA
Text: this legislation. If that happens, it will not

Speaker: NA
Text: through the Senate. Then of course the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister will say, 'But they voted for this Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: back in May. They let all this go ahead, and

Speaker: NA
Text: here· they are trying to stop the child care.

Speaker: NA
Text: They are against child care; they are against

Speaker: NA
Text: women; they are against all these other

Speaker: NA
Text: things'. And that would not be true. But we

Speaker: NA
Text: have seen it enough times in this Parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: to know that that method of deceitful

Speaker: NA
Text: misrepresentation of debate is the standard

Speaker: NA
Text: way in which the Government handles its

Speaker: NA
Text: problems.

Speaker: NA
Text: I tell the Government now that throughout

Speaker: NA
Text: the recess the coalition will be making crystal

Speaker: NA
Text: clear what this Government is doing and how

Speaker: NA
Text: it has changed direction in relation to tax file

Speaker: NA
Text: numbers. We will be reminding the public

Speaker: NA
Text: why that system of identity cards was

Speaker: NA
Text: dropped. We will be reminding them of the

Speaker: NA
Text: outrage that built in this community at the

Speaker: NA
Text: linking together of certain types of very

Speaker: NA
Text: sensitive information. We will be reminding

Speaker: NA
Text: them that there was a fear when the tax file

Speaker: NA
Text: number was upgraded that this might be the

Speaker: NA
Text: ID card in another form. We will be remind-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing them in words of one syllable that the

Speaker: NA
Text: present PrirneMinister, when Treasurer, intro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ducedthe tax file number and said, 'This will

Speaker: NA
Text: not happen'. We will also be making crystal

Speaker: NA
Text: clear that we support rebates for child care

Speaker: NA
Text: and have been doing so for years. If we had

Speaker: NA
Text: been in government, it would have been

Speaker: NA
Text: implemented by now. It is the Labor Party's

Speaker: NA
Text: views that have stopped those rebates being

Speaker: NA
Text: implemented before now.

Speaker: NA
Text: In conclusion, as I said at the beginning of

Speaker: NA
Text: my speech, this is not a debate about child-

Speaker: NA
Text: care rebates. That debate will come in the

Speaker: NA
Text: form of amendments to the Child Care Act,

Speaker: NA
Text: as the Minister said. We are amending the

Speaker: NA
Text: Health Insurance Commission Act here

Speaker: NA
Text: tonight. We will then consider all of these

Speaker: NA
Text: things fully, look at who is affected and

Speaker: NA
Text: consider the alternatives should the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment decide to go ahead with the implementa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of the tax file number. I urge the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment to make a decision; that it gives the

Speaker: NA
Text: Health Insurance Commission genuine free-

Speaker: NA
Text: dom to look at proposals for implementing its

Speaker: NA
Text: child-care policy and that it puts those propo-

Speaker: NA
Text: get sals forward, as this Bill gives the Health

Speaker: NA
Text: Insurance Commission the power to do. The

Speaker: NA
Text: only thing that will not empower the Health

Speaker: NA
Text: Insurance Commission to do that will be if

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government, through private directive-

Speaker: NA
Text: not through legislation-tells the Health

Speaker: NA
Text: Insurance Commission that it may not look at

Speaker: NA
Text: the alternatives but must instead stick with

Speaker: NA
Text: this so far unexplained but entirely obnoxious

Speaker: NA
Text: proposal of implementation of the tax file

Speaker: NA
Text: number for a purpose which we had been

Speaker: NA
Text: assured in this Parliament would never be put.

Speaker: Ms HENZELL
Text: Capricornia) (10.27

Speaker: NA
Text: p.m.)-I find myself feeling the need to

Speaker: NA
Text: remind my colleague the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Moncrieff ( Mrs Sullivan) that I hope that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition will not be, as the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister ( Mr Keating) said in Question Time

Speaker: NA
Text: today, revengeful and vengeful, that it will

Speaker: NA
Text: not go out in the recess and nitpick and have

Speaker: NA
Text: an absolute beat-up on the issue raised by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Health Insurance Commission Amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill. It is quite clear from the second reading

Speaker: NA
Text: speech on the Bill that it is an enabling piece

Speaker: NA
Text: of legislation and that all bets will be up and

Speaker: NA
Text: available for people to fully debate the child-

Speaker: NA
Text: care legislation. With this Bill, we will have

Speaker: NA
Text: to make sure that we have accountability. Of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, whatever is finally decided, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendations that come back, it will be

Speaker: NA
Text: public money and we have to make sure that

Speaker: NA
Text: we are efficient and accountable as a govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. I am sure the Opposition would want

Speaker: NA
Text: that.

Speaker: NA
Text: I return to the Bill. I think there are con-

Speaker: NA
Text: siderable areas of agreement between the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government and the Opposition on this

Speaker: NA
Text: matter. This enabling legislation will allow

Speaker: NA
Text: the Health Insurance Commission to provide

Speaker: NA
Text: the Parliament during the recess with some

Speaker: NA
Text: plans to establish and administer this scheme.

Speaker: NA
Text: We all agree that it is necessary to provide

Speaker: NA
Text: working parents with the ability to get some

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance-which is very essential-to enable

Speaker: NA
Text: them to look after their families and be

Speaker: NA
Text: productive in our economy. We are not trying

Speaker: NA
Text: to do anything by stealth. This very useful

Speaker: NA
Text: initiative that I believe really caught' the

Speaker: NA
Text: imagination of the electorate is to enable

Speaker: NA
Text: families to use the Medicare system to pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vide this kind of facility for parents.

Speaker: NA
Text: The legislation that will come in in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget sitting will provide all the answers

Speaker: NA
Text: and the reassurance, not only to the Opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion but also to the community, about how

Speaker: NA
Text: effective this scheme will be. The Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has been criticised for delaying the

Speaker: NA
Text: implementation of election promises. How-

Speaker: NA
Text: ever, as both sides of the House would know,

Speaker: NA
Text: such new initiatives are administratively

Speaker: NA
Text: complex and must be set in place with due

Speaker: NA
Text: process, hence this enabling legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are asking the Health Insurance Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mission to allocate resources, establish sys-

Speaker: NA
Text: tems and procedures, register carers, register

Speaker: NA
Text: eligible families, and make payments to

Speaker: NA
Text: families. Effectively, this legislation allows

Speaker: NA
Text: the Health Insurance Commission to plan and

Speaker: NA
Text: administer the scheme. I agree that there are

Speaker: NA
Text: 250 Medicare offices across the country and

Speaker: NA
Text: the cost of implementing this scheme is $2.25

Speaker: NA
Text: million. Program and running costs will be

Speaker: NA
Text: outlined when the amendments to the Child

Speaker: NA
Text: Care Act are introduced in 1994.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the very positive aspects of these

Speaker: NA
Text: proposals is the efficient use of existing

Speaker: NA
Text: government services to provide a further

Speaker: NA
Text: family support initiative rather than develop

Speaker: NA
Text: a new bureaucracy. The honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Moncrieff is splitting straws at the idea

Speaker: NA
Text: the Taxation Office putting forward a new tax

Speaker: NA
Text: number, some other way of identifying the

Speaker: NA
Text: child-care providers. It would seem to be

Speaker: NA
Text: nitpicking to me. Of course, we will have to

Speaker: NA
Text: find some way of making sure that the trans-

Speaker: NA
Text: actions are codified but that will be presented

Speaker: NA
Text: as a range of proposals. I am sure there will

Speaker: NA
Text: be much debate in both Houses when the

Speaker: NA
Text: proposals are introduced.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Medicare office and what it symbolises

Speaker: NA
Text: has become part of our national culture, and

Speaker: NA
Text: I firmly believe the threat to the viability of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Medicare system was one of the many

Speaker: NA
Text: aspects of coalition policy that led to the

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate rejecting the coalition at the recent

Speaker: NA
Text: election. At the same time, the very positive

Speaker: NA
Text: proposals and track record of the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: on child-care options was one of the big

Speaker: NA
Text: winners for the Labor Party in the recent

Speaker: NA
Text: election campaign.

Speaker: NA
Text: These initiatives will further improve the

Speaker: NA
Text: position of Medicare in the national psyche as

Speaker: NA
Text: an outreach service by government to the

Speaker: NA
Text: community. Hopefully-and here is my

Speaker: NA
Text: further point of agreement with the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Moncrieff-in cities such as

Speaker: NA
Text: Rockhampton and other regional centres, in

Speaker: NA
Text: Capricornia and elsewhere, there may well be

Speaker: NA
Text: the need for an extension of service delivery

Speaker: NA
Text: points which will enable easy access for both

Speaker: NA
Text: Medicare refunds and child-care rebates. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: certainly an issue of concern in regional areas.

Speaker: NA
Text: Accessibility, both physical and temporal,

Speaker: NA
Text: is an important aspect of the proposed

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme. Families will be able to claim the

Speaker: NA
Text: rebate by mail or in person each week as they

Speaker: NA
Text: incur the cost for work-related child care. In

Speaker: NA
Text: comparison, tax rebates, which the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Moncrieff suggested, tend to

Speaker: NA
Text: favour higher income earners and there is

Speaker: NA
Text: often a long waiting period. Taxation deduc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions also disadvantage low income earners,

Speaker: NA
Text: part-time workers and students, all of whom

Speaker: NA
Text: are much more effectively covered by these

Speaker: NA
Text: proposals. At the end of every week, at the

Speaker: NA
Text: point where the costs are being incurred,

Speaker: NA
Text: working parents will be able to recoup a

Speaker: NA
Text: portion of those costs.

Speaker: NA
Text: As the Parliamentary Secretary to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Health (Dr Theophanous) indicat-

Speaker: NA
Text: of ed, once the first $16 a week has been put

Speaker: NA
Text: forward, parents will be able to receive up to

Speaker: NA
Text: $28 a week for one child or $61.20 per week

Speaker: NA
Text: for two or more children. At the end of the

Speaker: NA
Text: week when hard-pressed families will be

Speaker: NA
Text: trying to balance their budgets, that will be

Speaker: NA
Text: very helpful. The cash rebate will not be

Speaker: NA
Text: income tested and will be available to parents

Speaker: NA
Text: working fullor part-time, studying or train-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing, or looking for work. These are truly very

Speaker: NA
Text: effective initiatives and were very positive

Speaker: NA
Text: parts of the proposal put forward in the

Speaker: NA
Text: campaign. As the Minister for Family Ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vices (Senator Crowley) noted in her second

Speaker: NA
Text: reading speech in the Senate:

Speaker: NA
Text: The child care cash rebate recognises that the cost

Speaker: NA
Text: of child care is a legitimate

Speaker: NA
Text: earning an income. The rebates will significantly

Speaker: NA
Text: improve the affordability of child care for working

Speaker: NA
Text: parents.

Speaker: NA
Text: As the Parliamentary Secretary indicated,

Speaker: NA
Text: some 358,000 children will benefit directly

Speaker: NA
Text: from this Labor Government initiative at a

Speaker: NA
Text: cost in the full year to government of $149

Speaker: NA
Text: million. Those families now receiving assist-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance through maximum fee relief will not be

Speaker: NA
Text: eligible for the cash rebate system.

Speaker: NA
Text: The child-care cash rebate scheme will be

Speaker: NA
Text: available for costs incurred where parents use

Speaker: NA
Text: both fonnal accredited child-care programs

Speaker: NA
Text: and infonnal arrangements such as family

Speaker: NA
Text: members, neighbours and nannies. As we

Speaker: NA
Text: know, two-thirds of parents use these types of

Speaker: NA
Text: infonnal systems, whether this is through

Speaker: NA
Text: personal choice or lack of availability of

Speaker: NA
Text: accredited child-care placements which, of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, the Government is committed to

Speaker: NA
Text: improve.

Speaker: NA
Text: The power of choice is very important at a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of levels. Firstly, it allows parents to

Speaker: NA
Text: seek the best quality child care for their

Speaker: NA
Text: children. At the second level it provides real

Speaker: NA
Text: encouragement for women to seek employ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, to retrain, to study or to move from

Speaker: NA
Text: part-time to full-time employment. There is

Speaker: NA
Text: no doubt that the cost of child care in the past

Speaker: NA
Text: has been a real disincentive for women to re-

Speaker: NA
Text: enter the paid employment sector.

Speaker: NA
Text: As the report of the House of Representa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tives Standing Committee on Legal and

Speaker: NA
Text: Constitutional Affairs Half way to equal

Speaker: NA
Text: noted, nearly 50 per cent of married women

Speaker: NA
Text: in the paid work force have children under the

Speaker: NA
Text: age of five. Seventy per cent have children

Speaker: NA
Text: between the ages of five and nine and all

Speaker: NA
Text: these children are requiring either full day

Speaker: NA
Text: care, after school care or care in relation to

Speaker: NA
Text: shift work. I think it is important to recall

Speaker: NA
Text: what the report had to say about this very

Speaker: NA
Text: important social justice issue for working

Speaker: NA
Text: parents and particularly women workers. It

Speaker: NA
Text: stated:

Speaker: NA
Text: The paramount issue identified by the vast majority

Speaker: NA
Text: of submissions which dealt with women and

Speaker: NA
Text: employment was that of child care. The submis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions almost universally argued that good quality,

Speaker: NA
Text: affordable child care was the basic necessity for

Speaker: NA
Text: women to have a realistic choice as to their life

Speaker: NA
Text: expense for parents in options.

Speaker: NA
Text: I will refer to one other section of the report

Speaker: NA
Text: which stated:

Speaker: NA
Text: The fact that inadequate child care impacts so

Speaker: NA
Text: greatly on women rather than men in terms of

Speaker: NA
Text: workforce opportunities is a stark reminder of how

Speaker: NA
Text: society and largely parents see mothers as the

Speaker: NA
Text: prime carers of children. Given this, there is a

Speaker: NA
Text: temptation to portray child care as a 'women's

Speaker: NA
Text: issue'. The evidence to the Committee strongly

Speaker: NA
Text: rejects this proposition and argues that child care

Speaker: NA
Text: is an economic and productivity issue as well as a

Speaker: NA
Text: basic test of the community's commitment to

Speaker: NA
Text: equity.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is no doubt that this debate has been

Speaker: NA
Text: going on for a long time and many political

Speaker: NA
Text: representatives, many women's groups, have

Speaker: NA
Text: been advocating this position for a consider-

Speaker: NA
Text: able time. It certainly has been responded to

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Government in the New National

Speaker: NA
Text: Agenda for Women, which made the point:

Speaker: NA
Text: Child care is an issue for families, for employers,

Speaker: NA
Text: for unions and for all levels of government. We

Speaker: NA
Text: need to work together to build a strong child care

Speaker: NA
Text: program and to make things work both at home and

Speaker: NA
Text: work.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, .it is important to see that over the

Speaker: NA
Text: last 10 years of Labor governments a great

Speaker: NA
Text: deal has been achieved. I disagree with the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Moncrieff in her

Speaker: NA
Text: interpretation of those events. Let us look at

Speaker: NA
Text: the facts. Commonwealth funded child-care

Speaker: NA
Text: places have increased from 46,000 to 193,000

Speaker: NA
Text: from 1983 to 1990, and the Government has

Speaker: NA
Text: announced a commitment to ensure 250,000

Speaker: NA
Text: places by 1995-96. The Government has

Speaker: NA
Text: increased spending on child care from $65

Speaker: NA
Text: million in 1983 to $440 million in 1992. In

Speaker: NA
Text: 1984 the Government made child-care fee

Speaker: NA
Text: relief available to low and middle income

Speaker: NA
Text: families, and in 1991 fee relief was extended

Speaker: NA
Text: to eligible families using private and employ-

Speaker: NA
Text: er sponsored child-care services. Over

Speaker: NA
Text: 130,000 families were assisted in 1991.

Speaker: NA
Text: Th- Government's track record on the

Speaker: NA
Text: expansion of child care has been very credit-

Speaker: NA
Text: able. The commitment we are providing for

Speaker: NA
Text: the future, as outlined in the new national

Speaker: NA
Text: agenda for women, gives this Government a

Speaker: NA
Text: great challenge. I believe that we will meet

Speaker: NA
Text: that challenge. We will work with the State,

Speaker: NA
Text: Territory and local governments, community

Speaker: NA
Text: groups and employers to increase child-care

Speaker: NA
Text: places, with a commitment of 250 child-care

Speaker: NA
Text: places by 1996.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government is also committed to

Speaker: NA
Text: improving the accreditation of child care so

Speaker: NA
Text: that we ptovide quality child care. It is very

Speaker: NA
Text: important not only that child care be afford-

Speaker: NA
Text: able but also that working parents know that,

Speaker: NA
Text: when their children are being cared for away

Speaker: NA
Text: from direct parental supervision, the quality

Speaker: NA
Text: of that care is excellent. The program outlined

Speaker: NA
Text: during the campaign was a real winner for

Speaker: NA
Text: this Government. I have absolute confidence

Speaker: NA
Text: that both sides can look forward to the new

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation with confidence.

Speaker: NA
Text: In summary, this enabling legislation is one

Speaker: NA
Text: more step in a proud record of achievement

Speaker: NA
Text: by Labor governments in this country to

Speaker: NA
Text: address the issues of quality and affordable

Speaker: NA
Text: 'child care. It is very important that we main-

Speaker: NA
Text: tain the important issues. The quality of the

Speaker: NA
Text: child care that we provide, the access and the

Speaker: NA
Text: social justice that is involved in providing

Speaker: NA
Text: are absolutely important to the future develop-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of our children and our country's future.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is very easy for me to commend this Bill to

Speaker: NA
Text: the House.

Speaker: Ms DEAHM
Text: Macquarie) (10.41 p.m.)-I

Speaker: NA
Text: will be brief and I will not repeat any of the

Speaker: NA
Text: comments that have already been made. I

Speaker: NA
Text: fully endorse the words of the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Capricomia (Ms Henzell). In

Speaker: NA
Text: supporting the Health Insurance Commission

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendment Bill, I wish to point out its wider

Speaker: NA
Text: implications and also its historical signifi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cance.

Speaker: NA
Text: When I first entered the work force at the

Speaker: NA
Text: age of I5-that was. in 1955; if honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: members have their calculators at hand, they

Speaker: NA
Text: can work out how old I am-it was accepted

Speaker: NA
Text: that girls worked until they got married. They

Speaker: NA
Text: left work when they got married to become

Speaker: NA
Text: full-time homemakers, child-bearers and child

Speaker: NA
Text: carers. The only women who worked were

Speaker: NA
Text: highly professional women-they were in the

Speaker: NA
Text: minority, as they still are in many places-or

Speaker: NA
Text: extremely poor women who had to work in

Speaker: NA
Text: order to keep the family. This was certainly

Speaker: NA
Text: looked down on at that time. I certainly did

Speaker: NA
Text: not live in a very well-off area. The question

Speaker: NA
Text: of child care did not really arise at that time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Further on in my life, like a lot of older

Speaker: NA
Text: women, I undertook a tertiary degree. I did

Speaker: NA
Text: this by external study. I met a lot of women

Speaker: NA
Text: who had gone through those stages of

Speaker: NA
Text: homemaking, child-bearing and now, in their

Speaker: NA
Text: middle age, wished to join the work force. By

Speaker: NA
Text: that time it was accepted that it was all right

Speaker: NA
Text: for women to work in their own careers, not

Speaker: NA
Text: just for economic reasons. This has been one

Speaker: NA
Text: of the biggest breakthroughs for women and

Speaker: NA
Text: for families as a whole. It is accepted that

Speaker: NA
Text: women do have careers and can have a life of

Speaker: NA
Text: their own in the work force and not just be

Speaker: NA
Text: dependent.

Speaker: NA
Text: I met a lot of very interesting women at

Speaker: NA
Text: university who were studying by that particu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lar method because they could not leave their

Speaker: NA
Text: children. Many went through difficult times

Speaker: NA
Text: with their marriages and their families be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause they wanted a career of their own and

Speaker: NA
Text: they wanted to study. I saw marriages break

Speaker: NA
Text: up and I saw others consolidate. Child care

Speaker: NA
Text: this was a very integral part of this. It is now

Speaker: NA
Text: generally accepted, as I have said, that women

Speaker: NA
Text: can have careers of their own. Child care is

Speaker: NA
Text: being more and more accepted in the work-

Speaker: NA
Text: place and in the community.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is significant that several new members

Speaker: NA
Text: of this House have advocated the provision of

Speaker: NA
Text: child care in this place. Mr Speaker is looking

Speaker: NA
Text: at the facilities that can be provided. Women

Speaker: NA
Text: were discouraged from entering parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: until they reached a matur- age, like me,

Speaker: NA
Text: because of that problem. The honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Lowe ( Mrs Easson) is a good

Speaker: NA
Text: example of a woman who has taken on this

Speaker: NA
Text: role while she has two young children. In the

Speaker: NA
Text: New South Wales Parliament at the moment

Speaker: NA
Text: a new member of the Ministry has borne a

Speaker: NA
Text: child during her time as a member of parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. When asked how she was going to

Speaker: NA
Text: handle a ministerial position, she said that

Speaker: NA
Text: one-year-old child was cared for in the Parlia- work force.

Speaker: NA
Text: ment House child-care centre. Obviously,

Speaker: NA
Text: New South Wales has done something about

Speaker: NA
Text: this.

Speaker: NA
Text: The more facilities that we have provided

Speaker: NA
Text: in the workplace and in the community, the

Speaker: NA
Text: more scope women will have for furthering

Speaker: NA
Text: their careers. However, in saying that, we are

Speaker: NA
Text: not discouraging women who wish to stay at

Speaker: NA
Text: home· to look after their children. Another

Speaker: NA
Text: election promise which will be honoured is to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide extra assistance for women who

Speaker: NA
Text: choose to stay at home to look after their

Speaker: NA
Text: children. In my electorate, which is not quite

Speaker: NA
Text: the same size as that of the honourable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Capricornia-although we do have

Speaker: NA
Text: quite a lot of isolated places-there are

Speaker: NA
Text: insufficient child-care places. With this

Speaker: NA
Text: provision I think we will see the development

Speaker: NA
Text: of more of those places. It is certainly some-

Speaker: NA
Text: thing I will be working for over the next three

Speaker: NA
Text: years and, hopefully, beyond.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable member for Capricornia

Speaker: NA
Text: also alluded to the fact that child care is now

Speaker: NA
Text: accepted as an economic issue, and I com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mend the Prime Minister ( Mr Keating) for

Speaker: NA
Text: announcing these child-care measures as part

Speaker: NA
Text: of his economic statement. Child care is no

Speaker: NA
Text: longer just a welfare issue or a women's

Speaker: NA
Text: issue-indeed, it is not just a women's issue.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have already found in my short term as a

Speaker: NA
Text: member of Parliament that there are men who

Speaker: NA
Text: are child carers and who find themselves in

Speaker: NA
Text: an extremely difficult position when they

Speaker: NA
Text: become sole parents. So those child-care

Speaker: NA
Text: places and child-care rebates will also be of

Speaker: NA
Text: great advantage to men.

Speaker: NA
Text: I will not say any more than that. I wanted

Speaker: NA
Text: the House to realise that this is an historic

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill. It will be more fully debated, as has

Speaker: NA
Text: been said, under the child-care legislation in

Speaker: NA
Text: the next sessiof,l. It must not pass without

Speaker: NA
Text: acknowledging that we have come a long

Speaker: NA
Text: way, even though it has been slow. The

Speaker: NA
Text: development of opportunities for women, of

Speaker: NA
Text: which child care has been a great part, has

Speaker: NA
Text: been slow, but the opportunities are increas-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing. There are more women in this place now,

Speaker: NA
Text: and there will be more in the future. Child

Speaker: NA
Text: care is an integral part of enabling those

Speaker: NA
Text: her people to become productive members of the

Speaker: Dr THEOPHANOUS
Text: Calwell-Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: mentary Secretary to the Minister for Hous-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing, Local Government and Community

Speaker: NA
Text: Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Health) (10.47 p.m.)-in reply-I

Speaker: NA
Text: commend the speeches of the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Capricornia (Ms Henzell) and the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Macquarie (Ms

Speaker: NA
Text: Deahm) on the Health Insurance Commission

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendment Bill. I concur with the comment

Speaker: NA
Text: of the honourable member for Macquarie that

Speaker: NA
Text: this is an historic piece of legislation, espe-

Speaker: NA
Text: cially in the area of women's rights. Although

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member for Moncrieff ( Mrs

Speaker: NA
Text: Sullivan) tried to represent it as only a small

Speaker: NA
Text: step, in fact, it is one of the most important

Speaker: NA
Text: and significant steps because it commits the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government to a timetable to implement the

Speaker: NA
Text: changes and to develop the full system to

Speaker: NA
Text: bring before this Parliament.

Speaker: NA
Text: One could not imagine anything more

Speaker: NA
Text: democratic than that. Firstly, the commitment

Speaker: NA
Text: was made in the election. Secondly, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government brought in the enabling legisla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to study ways and means of bringing in

Speaker: NA
Text: the whole process and to allow the planning

Speaker: NA
Text: towards implementation to take place. Third-

Speaker: NA
Text: ly, the legislation allows for a situation where

Speaker: NA
Text: there is discussion in the public arena. .

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable member for Moncrieff

Speaker: NA
Text: chose not to compliment the Government for

Speaker: NA
Text: the speedy implementation of an election

Speaker: NA
Text: promise. We have heard a lot of nonsense

Speaker: NA
Text: from the Opposition and some of the media

Speaker: NA
Text: about the Government not meeting election

Speaker: NA
Text: promises, but here is an historic piece of

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation that will meet a very important

Speaker: NA
Text: election promise, especially with respect to

Speaker: NA
Text: the rights of women. The honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Moncrieff hardly emphasised that. Instead,

Speaker: NA
Text: our she ranged widely in her discussion. She even

Speaker: NA
Text: referred to the comments earlier today of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister ( Mr Keating) when she said,

Speaker: NA
Text: 'Look, if we block this legislation because of

Speaker: NA
Text: the so-called concern which is raised about

Speaker: NA
Text: the tax file number' -and I will return to th-t

Speaker: NA
Text: in a minute-' and if we block this legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: with the Democrats, the child-care rebates

Speaker: NA
Text: will not come through for all the people who

Speaker: NA
Text: are to benefit, but don't blame us because,

Speaker: NA
Text: after all, it is your fault'.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable member for Moncrieff used

Speaker: NA
Text: the example of what was done in the Senate

Speaker: NA
Text: this day with respect to the social security

Speaker: NA
Text: veterans legislation. She tried to say that that

Speaker: NA
Text: was a very good example. It was a good

Speaker: NA
Text: example of the Opposition trying to block the

Speaker: NA
Text: social justice agenda of this··Government,

Speaker: NA
Text: which has brought in very important measures

Speaker: NA
Text: to aid social security and veterans beneficiar- sions.

Speaker: NA
Text: ies. What happened? The Opposition brought

Speaker: NA
Text: in something that was the reverse of some-

Speaker: NA
Text: thing that had already been passed by this

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament and tried to add it to the Bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mrs Sullivan- Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise

Speaker: NA
Text: a point of order. I have listened very carefully

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Health, who I assume will take his seat

Speaker: NA
Text: now that I have the call. I will not take

Speaker: NA
Text: exception to the earlier stages of his remarks,

Speaker: NA
Text: but I draw your attention to the standing order

Speaker: NA
Text: which says that, a question having been

Speaker: NA
Text: disposed of, it cannot be raised again. I did

Speaker: NA
Text: not canvass the ins and outs of the amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments. I did not mention the content of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill that I referred to or the amendment. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliamentary Secretary is now making

Speaker: NA
Text: statements about the Government's program

Speaker: NA
Text: of social justice and so on. He is starting to

Speaker: NA
Text: go into detail on a matter that has been

Speaker: NA
Text: dispatched by this House, and that is out of

Speaker: NA
Text: order. We cannot re-canvass a debate which

Speaker: NA
Text: has taken place today and which has been

Speaker: NA
Text: finalised.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Newell)-

Speaker: NA
Text: There is no point of order. However, I remind

Speaker: NA
Text: the Parliamentary Secretary to confine his

Speaker: NA
Text: remarks to what has been said in the debate

Speaker: NA
Text: so far.

Speaker: Dr THEOPHANOUS
Text: The honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Moncrieff raised this issue in her

Speaker: NA
Text: comments.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mrs Sullivan-Not in the way you are.

Speaker: Dr THEOPHANOUS
Text: She raised the

Speaker: NA
Text: issue, but she does not think I am entitled to

Speaker: NA
Text: reply to her. That is the whole point of a

Speaker: NA
Text: reply to a speech in the second reading

Speaker: NA
Text: debate. I think I have made my point on that

Speaker: NA
Text: matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: I will now turn to the other matter, which

Speaker: NA
Text: concerns the possibility that some excuse may

Speaker: NA
Text: be found by the Opposition and, as the hon-

Speaker: NA
Text: ourable member for Moncrieff hopes, the

Speaker: NA
Text: and Democrats, to block this very important and

Speaker: NA
Text: historic legislation. What was the excuse that

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member for Moncrieff raised?

Speaker: NA
Text: She raised a concern about the tax file num-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber and the question of whether this legisla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion is in breach of various privacy provi-

Speaker: NA
Text: Notwithstanding the various guarantees by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for Family Services (Senator

Speaker: NA
Text: Crowley) that the Privacy Commissioner has

Speaker: NA
Text: been and will be involved in the development

Speaker: NA
Text: and consideration of the system, what do we

Speaker: NA
Text: have? We have the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Moncrieff telling us that the Government is

Speaker: NA
Text: finnly committed to one particular interpreta-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of the involvement of the tax file num-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber-her interpretation and the Liberal Party's

Speaker: NA
Text: interpretation-and that, therefore, the legisla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion may be blocked because of this. She said

Speaker: NA
Text: this without even accepting the offer of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister that this matter be discussed with the

Speaker: NA
Text: Privacy Commissioner and that all privacy

Speaker: NA
Text: concerns be addressed in this process.

Speaker: NA
Text: What did the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Moncrieff then do? She came up with some

Speaker: NA
Text: half-baked idea that there is some very simple

Speaker: NA
Text: way out of this which the Govenunent could

Speaker: NA
Text: have adopted to overcome any question of the

Speaker: NA
Text: tax file number. But she has not thought

Speaker: NA
Text: through the ramifications of the proposal that

Speaker: NA
Text: she put forward. She simply put it forward as

Speaker: NA
Text: though it were some gospel to which we

Speaker: NA
Text: would readily agree.

Speaker: NA
Text: If the honourable member for Moncrieff or

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition has a serious proposal to put

Speaker: NA
Text: forward, let them put it forward in detail and

Speaker: NA
Text: I am sure that the Government will look at it,

Speaker: NA
Text: as will the Privacy Commissioner. The reality

Speaker: NA
Text: is that the Opposition is again flagging the

Speaker: NA
Text: fact that it will try to undermine the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's social justice policies as it did

Speaker: NA
Text: today in respect of the social security and

Speaker: NA
Text: veterans legislation. It will try to find any

Speaker: NA
Text: excuse in order to block important social

Speaker: NA
Text: justice measures.

Speaker: NA
Text: We will not be deflected by these sorts of

Speaker: NA
Text: comments. If the Opposition has concerns

Speaker: NA
Text: about the tax file number and the Privacy

Speaker: NA
Text: Commissioner is prepared to take them up,

Speaker: NA
Text: we will consider them, look at them in great

Speaker: NA
Text: detail and come to an accommodation of

Speaker: NA
Text: those concerns. But let us not use these sorts

Speaker: NA
Text: of concerns as some kind of red herring or an

Speaker: NA
Text: excuse to block an important piece of legisla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion benefiting millions of Australians.

Speaker: NA
Text: , Question resolved in the affirmative.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Third Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Leave granted for third reading to be moved

Speaker: NA
Text: forthwith.

Speaker: NA
Text: Motion (by Dr Theophanous) proposed:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the Bill be now read a third time.

Speaker: Mrs SULLIVAN
Text: Moncrieff) (10.56

Speaker: NA
Text: p.m.)-I rise reluctantly because I do not

Speaker: NA
Text: want to draw out the proceedings of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House until an unearthly hour tonight. But I

Speaker: NA
Text: want to set right the record on some of the

Speaker: NA
Text: matters raised by the Parliamentary Secretary

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Minister for Health (Dr Theophanous)

Speaker: NA
Text: in his reply on the second reading and specifi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cally some of the things he claimed that I said

Speaker: NA
Text: and some of the things that he claimed the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Family Services (Senator

Speaker: NA
Text: Crowley) said.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister said that I said that this was

Speaker: NA
Text: only a small step. I do not recall saying

Speaker: NA
Text: anything of the sort. I said it was of only

Speaker: NA
Text: limited significance in the child-care debate

Speaker: NA
Text: because the Child Care Act will be amended

Speaker: NA
Text: in due course when we will have a full debate

Speaker: NA
Text: on that, and I will enjoy joining in and saying

Speaker: NA
Text: how good it is. I said a little bit in relation

Speaker: NA
Text: that earlier when I said it was about time the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government moved along this track; but there

Speaker: NA
Text: is no debate about that at the moment. I said

Speaker: NA
Text: it is not a significant part of the debate.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister was absolutely wrong when he

Speaker: NA
Text: went on to say that it is very significant

Speaker: NA
Text: because it will provide for discussion in the

Speaker: NA
Text: public arena of the proposal and some sort of

Speaker: NA
Text: public input to the proposal's implementation.

Speaker: NA
Text: There has been no policy announcement or

Speaker: NA
Text: intention of the Government to involve the

Speaker: NA
Text: public in this at all. The Health Insurance

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission Amendment Bill simply gives

Speaker: NA
Text: the Health Insurance Commission $2 112

Speaker: NA
Text: million, which is the money it needs to go

Speaker: NA
Text: into the details of the proposal and put it

Speaker: NA
Text: forward so that when the Child Care Act is

Speaker: NA
Text: amended an administrative structure will be

Speaker: NA
Text: in place. But there is no proposal for public

Speaker: NA
Text: consultation or discussion on that.

Speaker: NA
Text: I reiterate, contrary to what the Parliamen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tary Secretary said in his speech, that this is

Speaker: NA
Text: both the keeping of a promise and the break-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing of a promise. It is the keeping of a prom-

Speaker: NA
Text: ise in relation to child care-moving towards

Speaker: NA
Text: that-and it is the breaking of a promise in

Speaker: NA
Text: regard to the use of the tax file number. That

Speaker: NA
Text: was quite specific during the election cam-

Speaker: NA
Text: paign:

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister then went on to say that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition would find some excuse to oppose

Speaker: NA
Text: this historic measure. We do not oppose the

Speaker: NA
Text: child-care rebate at all; it was our policy too

Speaker: NA
Text: during the election campaign. Our method of

Speaker: NA
Text: implementation was different, but I have said

Speaker: NA
Text: we will oppose the extension of the tax file

Speaker: NA
Text: number and we have said that in the Senate.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is very clear that the Parliamentary Secre-

Speaker: NA
Text: tary had not looked at the Hansard of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate debate because he invented statements

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Minister in the Senate debate and so

Speaker: NA
Text: on that simply are not there. I said at one

Speaker: NA
Text: stage of the debate, 'What page of the Hans-

Speaker: NA
Text: ard is that?'. He was making it up as he went

Speaker: NA
Text: along. I reiterate it because I will not have

Speaker: NA
Text: myself or the Opposition misrepresented on

Speaker: NA
Text: this.

Speaker: NA
Text: I said the Opposition has said it will oppose

Speaker: NA
Text: the extension of the tax file number. I also

Speaker: NA
Text: relayed to the House something the Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: to mentary Secretary should have known-that

Speaker: NA
Text: Senator Lees, speaking for the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Democrats in this debate, also said, in words

Speaker: NA
Text: of one syllable, that the Democrats will not

Speaker: NA
Text: support the extension of the use of the tax file

Speaker: NA
Text: number in this way.

Speaker: NA
Text: Senator Lees spoke very strongly for the

Speaker: NA
Text: proposal of child-care rebates, as did Senator

Speaker: NA
Text: Newman, and as would I if that was what the

Speaker: NA
Text: debate was about tonight, but it is not. So

Speaker: NA
Text: there is no contest on child-care rebates. The

Speaker: NA
Text: contest is on the Government attempting to

Speaker: NA
Text: use an issue which has total support as a

Speaker: NA
Text: device to do something that clearly the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity a long time ago said it did not want

Speaker: NA
Text: and that the Prime Minister ( Mr Keating) five

Speaker: NA
Text: years ago said in this place would not happen.

Speaker: NA
Text: Keeping the Government honest is what the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition was on about. I am sorry, but the

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliamentary Secretary's representation was

Speaker: NA
Text: exactly what I said would happen-dishonest

Speaker: NA
Text: representation of the Opposition's point of

Speaker: NA
Text: view on child care. It had nothing to do with

Speaker: NA
Text: child care.

Speaker: NA
Text: As far as the Opposition putting forward its

Speaker: NA
Text: alternatives is concerned, it has. It put forward

Speaker: NA
Text: an alternative method of implementation

Speaker: NA
Text: during the election campaign and also in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate. What we are objecting to is the words

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Minister, Senator Crowley, in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate-it is all in the Hansard from page

Speaker: NA
Text: 688 onwards for those who want to read it-

Speaker: NA
Text: that this is a simple little Bill that really

Speaker: NA
Text: not do anything. At one stage, Senator

Speaker: NA
Text: Crowley said that we really ought to be

Speaker: NA
Text: talking about this Bill when we come back

Speaker: NA
Text: with the amendments to the Child Care Act.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of course, what she is trying to do is channel

Speaker: NA
Text: the opposition to the extension of the tax file

Speaker: NA
Text: number into phoney opposition to child care.

Speaker: NA
Text: I take advantage of my right to speak on the

Speaker: NA
Text: third reading to set right something that was

Speaker: NA
Text: misrepresented in the second reading debate.

Speaker: Dr THEOPHANOUS
Text: Calwell-Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: mentary Secretary to the Minister for Health)

Speaker: NA
Text: (11.02 p.m.)-in reply-This is a further

Speaker: NA
Text: attempt by the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Moncrieff ( Mrs Sullivan) to make a whole

Speaker: NA
Text: range of gratuitous comments. Let me reaf-

Speaker: NA
Text: firm what I said, and that is that the Privacy

Speaker: NA
Text: Commissioner wi11100k at these concerns in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to the tax file number. If the Opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion has concerns it can put them to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Privacy Commissioner or put them to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government and we will certainly look at

Speaker: NA
Text: them.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable member for Moncrieff tried

Speaker: NA
Text: to go back on some of the comments she

Speaker: NA
Text: made earlier, and I ask people to read the

Speaker: NA
Text: Hansard and look at what she said at the

Speaker: NA
Text: beginning of the debate. I do not want to hold

Speaker: NA
Text: up the House in relation to this matter, but I

Speaker: NA
Text: reinforce the fact that this is very important

Speaker: NA
Text: enabling legislation to implement the child-

Speaker: NA
Text: care rebates which are very important to

Speaker: NA
Text: millions of Australians.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question resolved in the affirmative.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill read a third time.

Speaker: NA
Text: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT

Speaker: NA
Text: ISLANDER COMMISSION

Speaker: NA
Text: AMENDMENT LEGISLATION

Speaker: Mr OKEEFE
Text: Burke-Parliamentary

Speaker: NA
Text: Secretary to the Minister for Transport and

Speaker: NA
Text: Communications)-by leave-I thank the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition for its indulgence in granting me

Speaker: NA
Text: leave. This is a statement which I intended to

Speaker: NA
Text: make at the time the legislation was passed

Speaker: NA
Text: earlier this evening, but I got caught up in the

Speaker: NA
Text: proceedings-a trap for young players, I

Speaker: NA
Text: suppose you could say.

Speaker: NA
Text: What I was intending to do on behalf of the

Speaker: NA
Text: does Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait

Speaker: NA
Text: Islander Affairs ( Mr Tickner) was point out

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Government has reluctantly accepted

Speaker: NA
Text: the amendments to the legislation which were

Speaker: NA
Text: moved by the Opposition and the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Democrats in the Senate. The reason for this

Speaker: NA
Text: is that, in view of the scheduled timetable for

Speaker: NA
Text: the ATSIC elections, the Government has no

Speaker: NA
Text: practical option but to accept the amendments

Speaker: NA
Text: to allow other necessary changes to the

Speaker: NA
Text: ATSIC Act to proceed in time for the ATSIC

Speaker: NA
Text: elections later this year.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister has asked me also to convey

Speaker: NA
Text: his apologies to the House for his inability to

Speaker: NA
Text: be here tonight as he is undertaking a visit to

Speaker: NA
Text: Torres Strait in the company of the shadow

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait

Speaker: NA
Text: Islander Affairs.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister has asked me to place on

Speaker: NA
Text: record his profound and deep regret that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition and Australian Democrats have

Speaker: NA
Text: combined together to propose amendments

Speaker: NA
Text: which will deny Aboriginal and Torres Strait

Speaker: NA
Text: Islander people the right to have a totally

Speaker: NA
Text: elected ATSIC board and the right to elect the

Speaker: NA
Text: chairperson of ATSIC. It was a source of

Speaker: NA
Text: great pride to the Government that, had these

Speaker: NA
Text: proposals gone forth without amendment,

Speaker: NA
Text: indigenous people in this country would have

Speaker: NA
Text: been able to achieve the social justice

Speaker: NA
Text: milestone of having their affairs conducted by

Speaker: NA
Text: a totally elected body, in this, the United

Speaker: NA
Text: Nations International Year of the World's

Speaker: NA
Text: Indigenous People.

Speaker: NA
Text: The changes proposed by the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: to ATSIC were directly in line with the

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendations of the Royal Commission

Speaker: NA
Text: into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. I would

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly direct the attention of the House

Speaker: NA
Text: to the royal commission's overview and

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendations, including the following key

Speaker: NA
Text: points. Paragraph 1.7.22 states:

Speaker: NA
Text: The perception of many Aboriginal people . . . is

Speaker: NA
Text: that too often policies are propounded, programs

Speaker: NA
Text: put forward . . . in a form which has been largely

Speaker: NA
Text: determined in the bureaucracies ... not by Abo-

Speaker: NA
Text: riginal people. The agenda is being fixed by non-

Speaker: NA
Text: Aboriginal people.

Speaker: NA
Text: Paragraph 1.7.23 states:

Speaker: NA
Text: In the ultimate, self-determination is basically about

Speaker: NA
Text: people having the right to make decisions concern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing their own lives, their own communities, the

Speaker: NA
Text: right to retain their culture and to develop it.

Speaker: NA
Text: Paragraph 1.7.34 states:

Speaker: NA
Text: . . . the whole thrust of this report is directed

Speaker: NA
Text: towards the empowerment of Aboriginal society on

Speaker: NA
Text: the basis of their deeply held desire, their demon-

Speaker: NA
Text: strated capacity, their demonstrated right to exer-

Speaker: NA
Text: cise, according to circumstances, maximum control

Speaker: NA
Text: over their own lives and that of their own commu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nities; that such an empowerment requires that the

Speaker: NA
Text: broader society . . . approaches the relationships

Speaker: NA
Text: with the Aboriginal society on the basis of the

Speaker: NA
Text: principle of self-determination.

Speaker: NA
Text: It should be noted for the record that the

Speaker: NA
Text: totality of the Government's proposals were

Speaker: NA
Text: not in response to proposals put forward by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition, but were directly in line with

Speaker: NA
Text: the ideas put forward by indigenous people,

Speaker: NA
Text: through the section 26 review process, carried

Speaker: NA
Text: out as an essential step in the refonn of the

Speaker: NA
Text: ATSIC Act. The ATSIC' commissioners

Speaker: NA
Text: debated all the issues and, after careful con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sideration, recommended a fully elected

Speaker: NA
Text: ATSIC. The Government supported their

Speaker: NA
Text: position and, regrettably, the Opposition has

Speaker: NA
Text: undermined it.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government is disappointed that the

Speaker: NA
Text: idea of a totally elected commission and

Speaker: NA
Text: chairperson has been so decisively rebuffed

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Opposition. The Minister has asked me

Speaker: NA
Text: to record the fact that, while he retains his

Speaker: NA
Text: personal respect for the shadow Minister and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Leader of the Australian Democrats,

Speaker: NA
Text: Senator Kernot, and looks forward to continu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing to strive for cross-party cooperation with

Speaker: NA
Text: them, he does reject the arguments put for-

Speaker: NA
Text: ward by the Democrats and the Opposition in

Speaker: NA
Text: support of their proposals.

Speaker: NA
Text: The views expressed by the Opposition and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Democrats are in defiance of the central

Speaker: NA
Text: theme underpinning the recommendations of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths

Speaker: NA
Text: in Custody, namely, empowerment and self-

Speaker: NA
Text: determination. The Minister has already begun

Speaker: NA
Text: to receive letters of outrage in opposition to

Speaker: NA
Text: the attitude being taken in relation to this

Speaker: NA
Text: matter. To give an idea of the vehemence of

Speaker: NA
Text: this criticism, he has asked me to refer to the

Speaker: NA
Text: letter forwarded to all members and senators

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Sydney Regional Council of ATSIC

Speaker: NA
Text: which highlighted that, while the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Democrats have been very ready to

Speaker: NA
Text: support the non-election and consequent

Speaker: NA
Text: appointment of two ATSIC commissioners

Speaker: NA
Text: and the chairperson, 'this provision is con-

Speaker: NA
Text: spicuously absent from our non-Aboriginal

Speaker: NA
Text: elected rcounterpart in Canberra, the Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of Australia, and reflects the paternalism

Speaker: NA
Text: which our non-Aboriginal minders continue

Speaker: NA
Text: to perpetrate upon our people' .

Speaker: NA
