Text: The Minister, in preparing these remarks for

Speaker: NA
Text: me to deliver, has deliberately chosen not to

Speaker: NA
Text: use inflammatory and critical language of any

Speaker: NA
Text: kind in expressing his own opposition to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition's amendments, but believes their

Speaker: NA
Text: advocacy is an extremely sad day for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Parliament, and believes that

Speaker: NA
Text: history will judge the Democrats and coalition

Speaker: NA
Text: harshly for the stand they have taken on this

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment.

Speaker: NA
Text: It should be noted that the ATSIC legisla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion confers very little, if any, substantive

Speaker: NA
Text: powers on the chairperson. The ATSIC genie

Speaker: NA
Text: remains well and truly out of the parliamen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tary bottle, and nothing constructive whatso-

Speaker: NA
Text: ever is gained for the Parliament in forcing

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister to continue to appoint commis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sioners and the chairperson. The Minister is

Speaker: NA
Text: convinced, however, that ATSIC will continue

Speaker: NA
Text: to develop and prosper with cross-party

Speaker: NA
Text: cooperation as a genuine vehicle for self-

Speaker: NA
Text: detennination for indigenous people in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country and that, within the not too distant

Speaker: NA
Text: future, both the Opposition and the Democrats

Speaker: NA
Text: will be convinced of the desirability of sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: porting the changes that the Minister proposed

Speaker: NA
Text: in the original draft Bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: Given the text of the remarks that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister wanted recorded, it is obvious that

Speaker: NA
Text: he has a considered and deeply-felt position.

Speaker: NA
Text: I appreciate the Opposition granting me leave

Speaker: NA
Text: to read these remarks into the Hansard.

Speaker: NA
Text: NATIONAL HEALTH AMENDMENT

Speaker: NA
Text: BILL 1993

Speaker: NA
Text: First Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill received from the Senate, and read a

Speaker: NA
Text: first time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: Dr THEOPHANOUS
Text: Calwell-

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Health) (11.10 p.m.)-I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: The purpose of the National Health Ame-d­

Speaker: NA
Text: ment Bill 1993 is to clarify doubts concemmg

Speaker: NA
Text: the interpretation of section 135AA of the

Speaker: NA
Text: National Health Act 1953, requiring the issue

Speaker: NA
Text: of guidelines by the Privacy· Commissioner

Speaker: NA
Text: relat:'lg to information obtained under the

Speaker: NA
Text: Medicare benefits program and the pharma-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceutical benefits program. Under these two

Speaker: NA
Text: programs the Government rece-v- annu-lly

Speaker: NA
Text: claims for approximately 157 wIlton medlcal

Speaker: NA
Text: services and 94 million pharmaceutical pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: scriptions. Over $6 billion annually is spent

Speaker: NA
Text: on these services by the Government. Effi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cient and accurate processing of this huge

Speaker: NA
Text: quantity of information requires the use of

Speaker: NA
Text: large computerised databases.

Speaker: NA
Text: Legislation provides for the privacy. -f all

Speaker: NA
Text: information gathered as part of the administra-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of these very large and complex pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: grams. Section 135A of the National Health

Speaker: NA
Text: Act 1953 and section 130 of the Health

Speaker: NA
Text: Insurance Act 1973 require officers to observe

Speaker: NA
Text: secrecy in respect of all information obtained

Speaker: NA
Text: in the course of their duties. The Privacy Act

Speaker: NA
Text: 1988 also applies to the collection, storage,

Speaker: NA
Text: use and disclosure of personal information

Speaker: NA
Text: which is obtained in the administration of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Medicare benefits program and the pharma-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceutical benefits program. In addition, the

Speaker: NA
Text: agencies responsible for administering these

Speaker: NA
Text: programs have agreed to be bound by. the

Speaker: NA
Text: Privacy Commissioner's data matching gmde-

Speaker: NA
Text: lines.

Speaker: NA
Text: Section 135AA of the National Health Act

Speaker: NA
Text: 1953 complements this general framework by

Speaker: NA
Text: expressly providing that the Privacy Commis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sioner shall develop, in consultation with

Speaker: NA
Text: affected organisations, privacy guidelines

Speaker: NA
Text: relating to information obtained under the

Speaker: NA
Text: programs. This section was enacted in 1991

Speaker: NA
Text: following an amendment moved by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition in the Senate which was accepted

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Privacy Commissioner's subsequent

Speaker: NA
Text: consultations on the guidelines, and advice

Speaker: NA
Text: from the Office of General Counsel in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Attorney-General's Department which was

Speaker: NA
Text: provided to the then Department of Health,

Speaker: NA
Text: Housing and Community Services, revealed

Speaker: NA
Text: a number of problems relating to the wording

Speaker: NA
Text: of that section. For example, on one reading

Speaker: NA
Text: of the current provision, personal identifica-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion information held in the eligibility emol-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment databases-that is, name, address,

Speaker: NA
Text: Medicare card number and pharmaceutical

Speaker: NA
Text: entitlements number-would need to be

Speaker: NA
Text: deleted and reconstructed each five years

Speaker: NA
Text: thereby necessitating the issue of new eligi-

Speaker: NA
Text: bility cards at considerable public expense for

Speaker: NA
Text: no net benefit. Similar problems may relate to

Speaker: NA
Text: databases containing the names, addresses and

Speaker: NA
Text: qualifications of all approv- providers of

Speaker: NA
Text: services and goods. A further difficulty rel-tes

Speaker: NA
Text: to uncertainty as to whether the sechon

Speaker: NA
Text: applies only to information received after the

Speaker: NA
Text: commencement date of the Health Legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: (pharmaceutical Benefits) Amendment Act

Speaker: NA
Text: 1991; that is, 27 June 1991.

Speaker: NA
Text: The various difficulties were identified by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Privacy Commissioner in his rep-rt to

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament of 28 May 1992. The Pnvacy

Speaker: NA
Text: Commissioner has deferred issuing privacy

Speaker: NA
Text: guidelines under the existing section pending

Speaker: NA
Text: the proposed legislative amendments con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tained in this Bill. The provisions in this

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill have been developed in consultation with

Speaker: NA
Text: the Privacy Commissioner. Officials have also

Speaker: NA
Text: discussed these issues with members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition and the Australian Democrats.

Speaker: NA
Text: The purpose of this Bill is to clarify section

Speaker: NA
Text: 135AA to overcome the problems identified

Speaker: NA
Text: during the consideration of the draft guide-

Speaker: NA
Text: lines. It repeals the existing section -d

Speaker: NA
Text: substitutes a new section 135AA with, subject

Speaker: NA
Text: to the differences identified below, the same

Speaker: NA
Text: general structure. The Privacy Commissioner

Speaker: NA
Text: will still be required to issue privacy guide-

Speaker: NA
Text: lines for the management of information

Speaker: NA
Text: stored in computer databases and to conduct

Speaker: NA
Text: consultations with affected organisations. The

Speaker: NA
Text: guidelines will also have to be tabled in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament as a disallowable instrument.

Speaker: NA
Text: To avoid the need to delete and reconstruct

Speaker: NA
Text: eligibility enrolment databases every five

Speaker: NA
Text: years, the new section 135AA makes it clear

Speaker: NA
Text: that the guidelines to be formulated by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Privacy Commissioner do not extend to

Speaker: NA
Text: information contained in databases maintained

Speaker: NA
Text: for the purpose of identifying persons eligible

Speaker: NA
Text: to receive benefits. For similar reasons infor-

Speaker: NA
Text: mation simply identifying the practitioners

Speaker: NA
Text: and pharmacists who provide goods and

Speaker: NA
Text: services or issue referrals in connection with

Speaker: NA
Text: claims are also excluded.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Bill restricts the scope of the proposed

Speaker: NA
Text: guidelines to databases as it is not practicable

Speaker: NA
Text: to cover information held on paper files-that

Speaker: NA
Text: is, otherwise the guidelines would require the

Speaker: NA
Text: removal of patient names from general files

Speaker: NA
Text: containing ministerial correspondence. How-

Speaker: NA
Text: ever, the Bill does require the guidelines

Speaker: NA
Text: issued by the Privacy Commissioner to speci-

Speaker: NA
Text: fy the circumstances in which creating paper

Speaker: NA
Text: copies of information in computer databases

Speaker: NA
Text: is prohibited.

Speaker: NA
Text: Notwithstanding those exemptions, the

Speaker: NA
Text: disclosure of such information will continue

Speaker: NA
Text: to be regulated by the general secrecy provi-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions under the National Health Act 1953, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Health Insurance Act 1973 and the Privacy

Speaker: NA
Text: Act 1988. The new section 135AA also

Speaker: NA
Text: specifies that the guidelines will cover infor-

Speaker: NA
Text: mation held by an agency whether or not it

Speaker: NA
Text: was obtained after the commencement of the

Speaker: NA
Text: new section.

Speaker: NA
Text: The new section also specifies the content

Speaker: NA
Text: of the guidelines. In particular, it requires

Speaker: NA
Text: guidelines to cover the ways in which infor-

Speaker: NA
Text: mation may be stored; the circumstances

Speaker: NA
Text: under which the making of paper copies of

Speaker: NA
Text: the information in the databases is prohibited;

Speaker: NA
Text: the uses to which agencies may put the

Speaker: NA
Text: information, for example, to process claims,

Speaker: NA
Text: to investigate fraud; and the circumstances in

Speaker: NA
Text: which agencies may disclose information. It

Speaker: NA
Text: also requires that information obtained from

Speaker: NA
Text: claims for medical benefits must be stored in

Speaker: NA
Text: a separate database from information obtained

Speaker: NA
Text: from claims for pharmaceutical benefits, and

Speaker: NA
Text: prohibits linkage of such information except

Speaker: NA
Text: in the way specified in the guidelines. It also

Speaker: NA
Text: requires the guidelines to make special provi-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions in relation to the storage and retrieval of

Speaker: NA
Text: information that is more than five years old.

Speaker: NA
Text: Any complaint about breach of the guide-

Speaker: NA
Text: lines will be regarded as a complaint under

Speaker: NA
Text: the Privacy Act 1988, enabling the Privacy

Speaker: NA
Text: Commissioner to exercise the powers avail-

Speaker: NA
Text: able under that Act. As a transitional measure,

Speaker: NA
Text: consultations on guidelines already conducted

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Privacy Commissioner in 1991-92 will

Speaker: NA
Text: remain effective under the new section to

Speaker: NA
Text: avoid unnecessary duplication of effort.The

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill also provides for a number of consequen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tial amendments to the National Health Act

Speaker: NA
Text: 1953 and to the Privacy Act 1988.

Speaker: NA
Text: I commend this Bill to the House and I

Speaker: NA
Text: present the explanatory memorandum to this

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: Leave granted for debate to continue forth-

Speaker: NA
Text: with.

Speaker: Mrs SULLIVAN
Text: Moncrieff) (11.18

Speaker: NA
Text: p.m.)-I will be very brief. The National

Speaker: NA
Text: Health Amendment Bill has interesting ori-

Speaker: NA
Text: gins. It is an interesting example of the fact

Speaker: NA
Text: that at times parliament can, through its

Speaker: NA
Text: activities, actually affect what happens in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country. In 1989 Senator Patterson, a Liberal

Speaker: NA
Text: senator from Victoria, happened to ask some

Speaker: NA
Text: questions in an estimates committee hearing

Speaker: NA
Text: relating to the retention of certain information

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Health Insurance Commission. She

Speaker: NA
Text: found that there was no policy in relation to

Speaker: NA
Text: the privacy or security of records. I just

Speaker: NA
Text: reiterate a couple of the figures that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: the Health (Dr Theophanous) just gave to this

Speaker: NA
Text: House in the second reading speech. He said:

Speaker: NA
Text: Under these two programs the Government receives

Speaker: NA
Text: annually claims for approximately 157 million

Speaker: NA
Text: medical services and 94 million pharmaceutical

Speaker: NA
Text: prescriptions. Over $6 billion annually is spent on

Speaker: NA
Text: these services by the Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: He went on to say:

Speaker: NA
Text: Efficient and accurate processing of this huge

Speaker: NA
Text: quantity of information requires the use of

Speaker: NA
Text: computerised databases.

Speaker: NA
Text: The number of services involved gives an

Speaker: NA
Text: indication of the huge amount of personal

Speaker: NA
Text: information that is held in the Health Insur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance Commission database, and that is an

Speaker: NA
Text: annual occurrence. It has been established,

Speaker: NA
Text: certainly through estimates committees with

Speaker: NA
Text: Health Insurance Commission witnesses, that

Speaker: NA
Text: where there are patterns of types of medical

Speaker: NA
Text: services-for example, pathology tests-

Speaker: NA
Text: combined with the types of medication pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: scribed, one can actually identify an

Speaker: NA
Text: individual's medical condition, whatever it

Speaker: NA
Text: may be. The condition does not need to be

Speaker: NA
Text: specified; it can be put together from the

Speaker: NA
Text: information. As a result, the .information

Speaker: NA
Text: becomes very personal and is clearly very

Speaker: NA
Text: extensive. We would all have some amount

Speaker: NA
Text: of personal information on that database-

Speaker: NA
Text: information which is not protected by any

Speaker: NA
Text: particular privacy provisions.

Speaker: NA
Text: Since 1989 Senator Patterson has pursued

Speaker: NA
Text: this matter in the Senate and through esti-

Speaker: NA
Text: mates committees with a view to pushing the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government into doing something about

Speaker: NA
Text: protecting the privacy of information on the

Speaker: NA
Text: database. In June 1991 the Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments to the Nationat' Health Act

Speaker: NA
Text: sought to establish a computer link between

Speaker: NA
Text: pharmacists and the Health Insurance Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mission for the purpose of checking an

Speaker: NA
Text: individual's eligibility for benefits under the

Speaker: NA
Text: pharmaceutical benefits scheme. It was a huge

Speaker: NA
Text: step at the time-pharmacists being forced to

Speaker: NA
Text: link with the Health Insurance Commission by

Speaker: NA
Text: computer so that certain personal matters

Speaker: NA
Text: could be pursued-when there were other

Speaker: NA
Text: ways of doing it. As a result, matters other

Speaker: NA
Text: than individual benefits could be checked

Speaker: NA
Text: through the system.

Speaker: NA
Text: The amendments required the issuing of

Speaker: NA
Text: guidelines by the Privacy Commissioner for

Speaker: NA
Text: the management of data generated by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Medicare and pharmaceutical benefits pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: gram. The guidelines were designed to ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: dress the issue of privacy which had been

Speaker: NA
Text: raised earlier. A report to the Parliament in

Speaker: NA
Text: December 1991 by the Auditor-General and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Department of Finance found that the

Speaker: NA
Text: expected savings from the computer checking

Speaker: NA
Text: system were significantly overstated. As a

Speaker: NA
Text: large consequence, the Government decided not to

Speaker: NA
Text: proceed with the system. However, the re-

Speaker: NA
Text: quirement from the Privacy Commissioner to

Speaker: NA
Text: issue guidelines on Medicare and pharmaceu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tical benefits programs remained.

Speaker: NA
Text: By way of an aside, we ought to keep that

Speaker: NA
Text: example in front of us. I repeat that the report

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Auditor-General and the Department of

Speaker: NA
Text: Finance found that the expected savings from

Speaker: NA
Text: the computer checking system were signifi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cantly overstated. A proposal which made

Speaker: NA
Text: significant advances in the area of linking

Speaker: NA
Text: personal information, computer databaSes and

Speaker: NA
Text: service providers with the Health Insurance

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission was a very major administrative

Speaker: NA
Text: step with many implications. Whatever one

Speaker: NA
Text: thinks about it, and however the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: felt about it at the time, it had been suggested

Speaker: NA
Text: that there were significant savings to be made

Speaker: NA
Text: and that was the justification for implement-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the system.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Department of Health did not admit

Speaker: NA
Text: that it was wrong. It took the Auditor-General

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Department of Finance to identify that

Speaker: NA
Text: the department was wrong about the savings

Speaker: NA
Text: to be made. If the report had not been written

Speaker: NA
Text: and the inquiry not undertaken, and if the

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament had agreed to the proposal, then I

Speaker: NA
Text: presume that we would have had this forced

Speaker: NA
Text: linking when the savings simply were not

Speaker: NA
Text: there. We should bear in mind that these

Speaker: NA
Text: claims are made from time to time and that a

Speaker: NA
Text: government acting on them will be taken in

Speaker: NA
Text: a significant direction-a direction, with all

Speaker: NA
Text: its implications, in which it might not want to

Speaker: NA
Text: go-having been persuaded by costings based

Speaker: NA
Text: on incorrect information. Very often we are

Speaker: NA
Text: told just that; very often there is a dispute in

Speaker: NA
Text: this place about cost savings and so on. We

Speaker: NA
Text: should always take care when taking such a

Speaker: NA
Text: big step if we are told to do it for money

Speaker: NA
Text: reasons.

Speaker: NA
Text: As the Parliamentary Secretary said on

Speaker: NA
Text: behalf of the Minister for Health (Senator

Speaker: NA
Text: Richardson), a procedure was adopted under

Speaker: NA
Text: which certain guidelines were issued, and

Speaker: NA
Text: certain difficulties were encountered with it.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Bill attempts to address those difficulties.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I understand it, the Privacy Commissioner

Speaker: NA
Text: has foreseen no serious problems with the

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill, but he has identified two areas that he

Speaker: NA
Text: will be monitoring. The first is in relation

Speaker: NA
Text: the guidelines, which he recommends should

Speaker: NA
Text: not apply to paper files for the present. He

Speaker: NA
Text: will report to the Parliament if he sees any

Speaker: NA
Text: future difficulty with that provision. The

Speaker: NA
Text: second matter relates to the definition of the

Speaker: NA
Text: word 'database', and he will also keep an eye

Speaker: NA
Text: on that.

Speaker: NA
Text: In conclusion, in the past the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: has held personal health information indefi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nitely in a readily identifiable form. Prior

Speaker: NA
Text: the development of the guidelines by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Privacy Commissioner, the Government' had

Speaker: NA
Text: no policy on the retention, retrieval and

Speaker: NA
Text: destruction of personalised health information.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is pressure from the coalition which has

Speaker: NA
Text: forced it to address this issue and to take

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary step through this Bill, which we

Speaker: NA
Text: support.

Speaker: Mr HAVILAND
Text: Macarthur) (11.25

Speaker: NA
Text: p.m.}-I have pleasure in supporting the

Speaker: NA
Text: National Health Amendment Bill 1993. This

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill seeks to clarify doub- concerning the

Speaker: NA
Text: interpretation of the existing provisions which

Speaker: NA
Text: were identified by the Privacy Commissioner

Speaker: NA
Text: in May 1992. Medicare is the fairest and most

Speaker: NA
Text: equitable health insurance system Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: has ever had. It compares favourably with

Speaker: NA
Text: other health systems throughout the world and

Speaker: NA
Text: is a significant achievement of this Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Government. The Australian people's confi-

Speaker: NA
Text: dence in Medicare and their concern for its

Speaker: NA
Text: retention were amongst the principal reasons

Speaker: NA
Text: for the Government's success at the recent

Speaker: NA
Text: Federal election.

Speaker: NA
Text: Similarly, the pharmaceutical benefits

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme has played a significant role in pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: viding Australians with prescribed drugs at

Speaker: NA
Text: reasonable cost, particularly in relation to

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioners and lower income earners. Like

Speaker: NA
Text: Medicare, the pharmaceutical benefits scheme

Speaker: NA
Text: is an important component in the provision of

Speaker: NA
Text: a health care scheme based on the principles

Speaker: NA
Text: of access, equity and social justice. However,

Speaker: NA
Text: both the Medicare benefits scheme and the

Speaker: NA
Text: pharmaceutical benefits scheme by necessity

Speaker: NA
Text: account for a significant amount of Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth budgetary outlays. In the 1991-92

Speaker: NA
Text: financial year, Medicare benefit payments

Speaker: NA
Text: totalled over $4.5 billion and pharmaceutical

Speaker: NA
Text: to benefits totalled nearly $1.2 billion.

Speaker: NA
Text: Many of those opposite have very different

Speaker: NA
Text: philosophical views to the Government on

Speaker: NA
Text: questions such as Medicare and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's role in funding our health

Speaker: NA
Text: system. The Labor Party believes that govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments have a legitimate and, indeed, essential

Speaker: NA
Text: role in providing access to essential services

Speaker: NA
Text: such as health care through Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure. However, one principle on which

Speaker: NA
Text: to there should be agreement on both sides of

Speaker: NA
Text: the House is that when there is an improved

Speaker: NA
Text: government program which is provided at

Speaker: NA
Text: significant cost to taxpayers, such as Medicare

Speaker: NA
Text: or the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, it is

Speaker: NA
Text: essential that the money is spent in the most

Speaker: NA
Text: the equitable and cost-effective manner possible

Speaker: NA
Text: and that abuse of Commonwealth money is

Speaker: NA
Text: kept to an absolute minimum.

Speaker: NA
Text: The need for privacy legislation is well

Speaker: NA
Text: documented. The intention of the Privacy Act

Speaker: NA
Text: and similar legislation is to protect private

Speaker: NA
Text: individuals against public disclosure of infor-

Speaker: NA
Text: mation relating to them which is of a personal

Speaker: NA
Text: or sensitive nature but which is held on file

Speaker: NA
Text: by a government agency. Indeed, individual

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians have a right to expect that person-

Speaker: NA
Text: al information in the hands of such authorities

Speaker: NA
Text: should be subject to confidentiality. However,

Speaker: NA
Text: there is a need to ensure that legitimate

Speaker: NA
Text: privacy principles are balanced against the

Speaker: NA
Text: public interest, particularly in relation to the

Speaker: NA
Text: possible misuse of public money. This is the

Speaker: NA
Text: essential aim of this amendment-to clarify

Speaker: NA
Text: privacy provisions to ensure that legitimate

Speaker: NA
Text: privacy concerns of individuals are protected

Speaker: NA
Text: while enabling government agencies, in this

Speaker: NA
Text: case the Health Insurance Commission, to

Speaker: NA
Text: adequately safeguard against fraud and misuse

Speaker: NA
Text: of taxpayers' money.

Speaker: NA
Text: Measures which rightly protect the individ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ual privacy of innocent citizens must not be

Speaker: NA
Text: allowed to become a vehicle whereby corpo-

Speaker: NA
Text: rate criminals can defraud the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth. In my first speech, on 6 May, I

Speaker: NA
Text: referred briefly to the issue of medical fraud

Speaker: NA
Text: and overservicing by medical practitioners, an

Speaker: NA
Text: area in which I have a background of experi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ence. In 1982, the then Labor Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: drew attention to reports that a Department of

Speaker: NA
Text: Health estimate supported by the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Medical Association showed the level of

Speaker: NA
Text: abuse of Commonwealth medical benefits

Speaker: NA
Text: through fraud or excessive servicing to be

Speaker: NA
Text: around $100 million a year. This represented

Speaker: NA
Text: approximately seven per cent of total

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth medical benefit payments,

Speaker: NA
Text: this of course being prior to the introduction

Speaker: NA
Text: of Medicare.

Speaker: NA
Text: This led to a Public Accounts Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: inquiry into medical fraud and overservicing

Speaker: NA
Text: which produced an interim report in Decem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber 1982. The report was extremely critical of

Speaker: NA
Text: the then Department of Health's administra-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of the relevant program and made a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of recommendations. This led to a

Speaker: NA
Text: hurried shake-up of senior administration in

Speaker: NA
Text: the department, the allocation of additional

Speaker: NA
Text: resources, and the creation of a new surveil-

Speaker: NA
Text: lance and investigation division. This all

Speaker: NA
Text: commenced in the dying days of the Fraser

Speaker: NA
Text: Government and was completed by the in-

Speaker: NA
Text: coming Labor Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: A number of highly trained and skilled staff

Speaker: NA
Text: were employed to utilise a highly sophisticat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ed computer system. However, the best efforts

Speaker: NA
Text: of these staff were undermined by elements

Speaker: NA
Text: of the medical establishment, both inside and

Speaker: NA
Text: outside the bureaucracy. This situation intensiinvestigation

Speaker: NA
Text: fied as an increasing number of cases of

Speaker: NA
Text: abuse were being identified by analysis of

Speaker: NA
Text: computer data.

Speaker: NA
Text: The threat of increasing exposure of cases

Speaker: NA
Text: of fraud and overservicing caused resentment

Speaker: NA
Text: and hostility amongst sections of the medical

Speaker: NA
Text: profession, although it was never suggested

Speaker: NA
Text: by anyone that anything other than a minority

Speaker: NA
Text: of medical practitioners was involved in cases

Speaker: NA
Text: of abuse. The controversy surrounding this

Speaker: NA
Text: issue coincided with the Medicare doctors

Speaker: NA
Text: dispute in New South Wales in 1984 and

Speaker: NA
Text: 1985. In 1985 the Government decided to

Speaker: NA
Text: abolish the Department of Health surveillance

Speaker: NA
Text: and investigation program and transferred

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility for control of medifraud and

Speaker: NA
Text: excessive servicing to the Health Insurance

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission.

Speaker: NA
Text: This was an understandable decision by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government in light of the department's

Speaker: NA
Text: ultimate failure to come to grips with the

Speaker: NA
Text: problem and to reduce the level of abuse

Speaker: NA
Text: which was still estimated at the time to be

Speaker: NA
Text: around about seven per cent of Medicare

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits. However, it must be said that the

Speaker: NA
Text: consultant's report which recommended the

Speaker: NA
Text: transfer of the function to the commission was

Speaker: NA
Text: poorly researched, factually incorrect and

Speaker: NA
Text: extremely unfair in its criticism of some

Speaker: NA
Text: aspects of the program, and gave a totally

Speaker: NA
Text: misleading impression of the reasons for the

Speaker: NA
Text: failure of the program. Nevertheless, the

Speaker: NA
Text: transfer of responsibility to the commission

Speaker: NA
Text: was seen as a fresh start by the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: and by the medical profession.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Auditor-General's report No. 17 of

Speaker: NA
Text: 1992-93, which was tabled in December last

Speaker: NA
Text: year, deals with the Insurance Commission's

Speaker: NA
Text: perfonnance in dealing with medifraud and

Speaker: NA
Text: excessive servicing since 1985. Some of the

Speaker: NA
Text: findings and recommendations of this report

Speaker: NA
Text: give cause for concern. Among its key find-

Speaker: NA
Text: ings the report says:

Speaker: NA
Text: The perfonnance of the Commission, with the

Speaker: NA
Text: exception of the last 12 months, shows little

Speaker: NA
Text: improvement over that of the then Department of

Speaker: NA
Text: Health in the early 1980s.

Speaker: NA
Text: The report also says that the commission's

Speaker: NA
Text: legislative powers to combat fraud and exces-

Speaker: NA
Text: sive servicing are deficient in regard to the

Speaker: NA
Text: and prosecution of unethical

Speaker: NA
Text: medical providers, and that the Medical

Speaker: NA
Text: Services Committee of Inquiry, the bodies

Speaker: NA
Text: that deal with cases of excessive servicing,

Speaker: NA
Text: were not operating successfully and should be

Speaker: NA
Text: replaced by tribunals.

Speaker: NA
Text: These are just two of a number of examples

Speaker: NA
Text: which were covered by recommendations of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Public Accounts Committee in 1982, but

Speaker: NA
Text: which, as the Auditor-General's report points

Speaker: NA
Text: out, have not been implemented. Another key

Speaker: NA
Text: finding of the Auditor-General's report is of

Speaker: NA
Text: particular relevance to the Bill before us

Speaker: NA
Text: tonight. The Auditor-General found:

Speaker: NA
Text: The ability to release infonnation for investigation

Speaker: NA
Text: is important in preventing Medifraud, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission has been reluctant to fully utilise its

Speaker: NA
Text: powers under the Health Insurance Act because of

Speaker: NA
Text: uncertainty about the effect of privacy legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: A comprehensive policy is needed.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a clear example of the importance of

Speaker: NA
Text: clarifying the distinction between privacy

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions in legislation and the need for

Speaker: NA
Text: access to infonnation in the public interest in

Speaker: NA
Text: order to prevent or detect fraud or misuse of

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth funds. Even though the report

Speaker: NA
Text: in question refers to the Health Insurance Act,

Speaker: NA
Text: the same principle applies to the National

Speaker: NA
Text: Health Act which this Bill seeks to amend.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would like to take this argument a bit

Speaker: NA
Text: further in relation to the provision of informa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion between government agencies. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: aware of at least one case in recent years

Speaker: NA
Text: where the Australian Taxation Office was

Speaker: NA
Text: seeking to prosecute a medical practitioner for

Speaker: NA
Text: failure to declare taxable income. The Tax

Speaker: NA
Text: Office sought information from the Health

Speaker: NA
Text: Insurance Commission in relation to the

Speaker: NA
Text: doctor's earnings from Medicare benefits.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, I understand that the commission

Speaker: NA
Text: refused to supply the information because of

Speaker: NA
Text: concerns over breaches of the secrecy provi-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion of the Health Insurance Act.

Speaker: NA
Text: The point is that the intent of any privacy

Speaker: NA
Text: based provision-whether in a privacy Act or

Speaker: NA
Text: in any other legislation-is surely to protect

Speaker: NA
Text: the privacy of individuals against public

Speaker: NA
Text: disclosure of personal information. I stress

Speaker: NA
Text: words 'public disclosure'. In this case we

Speaker: NA
Text: could reasonably assume that this would mean

Speaker: NA
Text: that names of individual patients of the doctor

Speaker: NA
Text: in question, and details of their medical

Speaker: NA
Text: conditions or medical procedures undertaken,

Speaker: NA
Text: would quite properly remain confidential.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, in this case the only information

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Tax Office had been seeking from the

Speaker: NA
Text: commission was the total Medicare benefits

Speaker: NA
Text: paid to the doctor in question in a given

Speaker: NA
Text: period. No patient details were sought; nor

Speaker: NA
Text: were they required, yet the information

Speaker: NA
Text: requested could not be supplied by the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mission because of the secrecy provisions.

Speaker: NA
Text: This further emphasises the need for compre-

Speaker: NA
Text: hensive guidelines that strike the appropriate

Speaker: NA
Text: balance between the need for individual

Speaker: NA
Text: privacy and the need for government agencies

Speaker: NA
Text: to have access to necessary evidence in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to the prevention or detection of

Speaker: NA
Text: abuse of government funds, or recovery of

Speaker: NA
Text: such funds, which is clearly in the public

Speaker: NA
Text: interest. This Bill is an appropriate and timely

Speaker: NA
Text: step in this direction.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Auditor-General's report made a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of other observations in relation to

Speaker: NA
Text: medifraud and excessive servicing which I

Speaker: NA
Text: would like to mention briefly. It points out

Speaker: NA
Text: that many of the problems which existed

Speaker: NA
Text: within the Department of Health's program in

Speaker: NA
Text: the early 1980s and which were referred to in

Speaker: NA
Text: various reports of the Public Accounts Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee still appeared to exist and were only

Speaker: NA
Text: just beginning to be addressed by the Health

Speaker: NA
Text: Insurance Commission.

Speaker: NA
Text: Further, the report suggests that the previ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ous estimate of seven per cent of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Medicare benefit as the level of abuse could

Speaker: NA
Text: still be appropriate today. Given the current

Speaker: NA
Text: annual Medicare benefit payout of $4.5

Speaker: NA
Text: billion, this means that the amount of money

Speaker: NA
Text: lost on abuse of Medicare could be in excess

Speaker: NA
Text: of $300 million a year. In this respect, I am

Speaker: NA
Text: encouraged by the recent announcement by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for Health (Senator Richardson)

Speaker: NA
Text: that he will seek the cooperation of the AMA

Speaker: NA
Text: in attempting to crack down on fraud and

Speaker: NA
Text: excessive servicing.·

Speaker: NA
Text: It is acknowledged that only a minority of

Speaker: NA
Text: medical practitioners abuse the system. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: the .clearly in the interests of the responsible

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the profession to work with the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government to reduce the level of abuse,

Speaker: NA
Text: thereby enabling Medicare funds to be spent

Speaker: NA
Text: more appropriately on improving our health

Speaker: NA
Text: system.

Speaker: NA
Text: As the Auditor-General's report says, the

Speaker: NA
Text: pressures on the Medicare budget are con-

Speaker: NA
Text: siderable, with the advent of new medical

Speaker: NA
Text: procedures and the growth of entrepreneurial

Speaker: NA
Text: medicine. The emergence of organised fraud

Speaker: NA
Text: and excessive servicing, protected by corpo-

Speaker: NA
Text: rate veils and the best advice money can buy,

Speaker: NA
Text: as the report says, represents a real challenge

Speaker: NA
Text: to the efficient and effective use of the health

Speaker: NA
Text: budget. Clearly, there will be a great responsi-

Speaker: NA
Text: bility on the commission and the medical

Speaker: NA
Text: profession to meet this challenge. The Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: before us represents a small but significant

Speaker: NA
Text: measure in this context. I commend the Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: to the House.

Speaker: Mr REID
Text: Bendigo) (11.36 p.m.)-I rise to

Speaker: NA
Text: support the remarks made by my colleague

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member for Moncrieff ( Mrs

Speaker: NA
Text: Sullivan) on the National Health Amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill. It is principally through the efforts of the

Speaker: NA
Text: coalition since 1989 that this Bill is currently

Speaker: NA
Text: before the House. I refer to the efforts of a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of senators in another place-Senators

Speaker: NA
Text: Walters, Patterson and Watson-who have

Speaker: NA
Text: been pursuing this issue for some four years.

Speaker: NA
Text: I also pay tribute to a former member of this

Speaker: NA
Text: House, Dr Bob Woods, the former member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Lowe, who was also very active with

Speaker: NA
Text: regard to this issue.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Bruce Scott-A great shadow Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: too.

Speaker: NA
Text: i

Speaker: Mr REID
Text: That is quite right. He was a

Speaker: NA
Text: very fine shadow Minister. He was a great

Speaker: NA
Text: loss to this House and the public of Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Since 1989 the coalition has been pursuing

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government on the issue of retention

Speaker: NA
Text: retrieval and destruction of personalised

Speaker: NA
Text: information held by the then Department of

Speaker: NA
Text: Health, Housing and Community Services and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Health Insurance Commission.

Speaker: NA
Text: In June 1991, the government amendments

Speaker: NA
Text: to the National Health Act sought to establish

Speaker: NA
Text: a computer link between pharmacists and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Health Insurance Commission, and that

Speaker: NA
Text: certainly caused quite a lot of consternation

Speaker: NA
Text: amongst the pharmacists in my electorate. The

Speaker: NA
Text: purpose of that computer link was to check an

Speaker: NA
Text: individual's' eligibility for benefits under

Speaker: NA
Text: pharmaceutical benefits scheme. The amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments also required the issuing of guidelines

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Privacy Commissioner for the manage-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of data generated by the Medicare and

Speaker: NA
Text: pharmaceutical benefits programs. These

Speaker: NA
Text: guidelines were to address the issues of

Speaker: NA
Text: privacy which had been raised by Senators

Speaker: NA
Text: Walters, Patterson and Watson.

Speaker: NA
Text: A report to the Parliament in December

Speaker: NA
Text: 1991 by the Auditor-General and the Depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: me-t of Finance found that the expected

Speaker: NA
Text: savmgs from the computer checking system

Speaker: NA
Text: were significantly overstated. As a conse-

Speaker: NA
Text: quence, the Government' decided not to

Speaker: NA
Text: pr-ceed with the system. However, the re-

Speaker: NA
Text: qurrement for the Privacy Commissioner to

Speaker: NA
Text: issue guidelines on the Medicare and pharma-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceutical benefits programs remained. Draft

Speaker: NA
Text: guidelines were prepared by the Privacy

Speaker: NA
Text: Commissioner for tabling by April 1992.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, after advice from the office of

Speaker: NA
Text: general council, he instead made a report to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Parliament in May 1992, indicating that

Speaker: NA
Text: he could not table the guidelines since they

Speaker: NA
Text: appeared to be inconsistent with certain

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions of the National Health Act. This

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill now addresses those provisions.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to refer to the efforts of Senator

Speaker: NA
Text: Patterson in pursuing this issue through

Speaker: NA
Text: Estimates Committee C where Senator Patter-

Speaker: NA
Text: son expressed her concern by asking the

Speaker: NA
Text: officers of the department whether it would be

Speaker: NA
Text: feasible to identify families with genetic

Speaker: NA
Text: disorders such as fibrocystic disease from,

Speaker: NA
Text: firstly, the type of doctor they visit, secondly,

Speaker: NA
Text: th- type of treatment that they receive and,

Speaker: NA
Text: thirdly, the types of drugs they are prescribed.

Speaker: NA
Text: The answer Senator Patterson was given at

Speaker: NA
Text: Estimates Committee C was that it would be

Speaker: NA
Text: possible in fact to identify these people. That

Speaker: NA
Text: is something about which the community

Speaker: NA
Text: ought to be very concerned. That led Senator

Speaker: NA
Text: Patterson to push for a period of four years

Speaker: NA
Text: for the department to develop a much better

Speaker: NA
Text: privacy policy in relation to Medicare data.

Speaker: NA
Text: This legislation goes only part of the way

Speaker: NA
Text: to allaying the fears expressed by Senator

Speaker: NA
Text: Patterson, Senator Walters and Senator Wat-

Speaker: NA
Text: son. They believe that that legislation should

Speaker: NA
Text: go further than it does, but at least it is

Speaker: NA
Text: the placing something into position where it can

Speaker: NA
Text: be watched and developed. I know that the

Speaker: NA
Text: senators on the coalition side who have been

Speaker: NA
Text: active in the implementation of this legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: take great credit, which is due to them for the

Speaker: NA
Text: very Important role that they played in ' mak-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing sure that the Government in fact ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: dressed these questions which were raised in

Speaker: NA
Text: another place.

Speaker: NA
Text: I believe that the legislation currently before

Speaker: NA
Text: us goes part of the way but I am sure that it

Speaker: NA
Text: will be watched very closely by the coalition.

Speaker: NA
Text: Most of the credit should go to the coalition

Speaker: NA
Text: parties for bringing the Government to the

Speaker: NA
Text: implementation of this legislation. I can

Speaker: NA
Text: assure honourable members that the coalition

Speaker: NA
Text: will be watching the progress and the imple-

Speaker: NA
Text: mentation of this legislation to ensure that its

Speaker: NA
Text: fears and concerns in respect of it are fully

Speaker: NA
Text: and properly met by the Government.

Speaker: Dr THEOPHANOUS
Text: CalweU-

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Health) (11.43 p.m.)-in reply-:-I want to

Speaker: NA
Text: thank the honourable member for Macarthur

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Haviland) for his very thoughtful contri-

Speaker: NA
Text: bution-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mrs Sullivan-Go on, be generous. Thank

Speaker: NA
Text: us too.

Speaker: Dr THEOPHANOUS
Text: And also the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition, especially the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Moncrieff who keeps interrupting me. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Government appreciates the Opposition's

Speaker: NA
Text: support for this legislation. I want to point out

Speaker: NA
Text: to the honourable member for Macarthur, on

Speaker: NA
Text: the question about the importance of there

Speaker: NA
Text: being some provisions which allow for the

Speaker: NA
Text: checking of medical fraud and certain issues

Speaker: NA
Text: of overservicing, that in fact the Privacy

Speaker: NA
Text: Commissioner accepted this as one of the

Speaker: NA
Text: legitimate concerns of the department in his

Speaker: NA
Text: report. In his report he refers to certain

Speaker: NA
Text: aspects of the operations· of the department

Speaker: NA
Text: and cited examples of where the department

Speaker: NA
Text: was required to re-identify patient data. These

Speaker: NA
Text: included:

Speaker: NA
Text: to support the work of a Royal Commission

Speaker: NA
Text: to support the work of a Parliamentary inquiry

Speaker: NA
Text: to assist in a murder trial or coronial inquiry

Speaker: NA
Text: to assist in medical board and medical complaint

Speaker: NA
Text: tribunal hearings

Speaker: NA
Text: to respond to requests by a patient

Speaker: NA
Text: if a matter previously under the control of the

Speaker: NA
Text: HlC were to be the subject of further inquiry by

Speaker: NA
Text: the HIC (fraud investigation)

Speaker: NA
Text: to support epidemiological studies where it

Speaker: NA
Text: possible to trace service utilisation over time

Speaker: NA
Text: involving the same patient using an identification

Speaker: NA
Text: number (because of different identification

Speaker: NA
Text: numbering schemes in different health schemes)

Speaker: NA
Text: to enable epidemiological studies where the

Speaker: NA
Text: studies involve medical service utilisation and

Speaker: NA
Text: drug service utilisation and a common identifier

Speaker: NA
Text: is not present in both systems.

Speaker: NA
Text: to enable tracking of individuals who may have

Speaker: NA
Text: taken a drug for which a new, lon:g term, serious

Speaker: NA
Text: side effect emerges.

Speaker: NA
Text: (Some of the above uses of identified data only

Speaker: NA
Text: require temporary re-identification of data to enable area.

Speaker: NA
Text: a link to be made between two schemes or data

Speaker: NA
Text: bases and names were not stored permanently.)

Speaker: NA
Text: All that information is important in addressing

Speaker: NA
Text: the concerns mentioned by the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Macarthur. I thank aU honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: members who contributed to the debate. I

Speaker: NA
Text: commend the legislation to the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question resolved in the affirmative ..

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Third Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Leave granted for third reading to be moved

Speaker: NA
Text: forthwith.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill (on motion by Dr Theophanous) read

Speaker: NA
Text: a third time.

Speaker: NA
Text: ADJOURNMENT

Speaker: NA
Text: Motion (by Dr Theophanous) proposed:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the House do now adjourn.

Speaker: NA
Text: Education Scholarships

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Text: O'Connor) (11.47 p.m.)-

Speaker: NA
Text: As most honourable members know, I have

Speaker: NA
Text: for many years brought students from senior

Speaker: NA
Text: high schools within my electorate to the

Speaker: NA
Text: national capital on education scholarships.

Speaker: NA
Text: Tonight in the Speaker's gallery I have two

Speaker: NA
Text: young men who are the 33rd and 34th stu-

Speaker: NA
Text: dents to participate in this scholarship. They

Speaker: NA
Text: are Bradley Cox, aged 17 years; a year 12

Speaker: NA
Text: student from Merredin Senior High School,

Speaker: NA
Text: who lives 60 kilometres away in the farming

Speaker: NA
Text: community of Doodlakine-the home of

Speaker: NA
Text: Senator Walsh-and travels to school each

Speaker: NA
Text: day. He hopes to continue studying science at

Speaker: NA
Text: university next year. Also present is Regan

Speaker: NA
Text: Opalinski, aged 15 years, a year 10 student

Speaker: NA
Text: from Katanning Senior High School, who

Speaker: NA
Text: comes from the farming community of Tam-

Speaker: NA
Text: is not bellup but boards in Katanning. I take this

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity to -incerely thank Ansett Austral-

Speaker: NA
Text: ia for its assistance. As is the custom, I have

Speaker: NA
Text: invited both of the students to write a short

Speaker: NA
Text: speech which I now have the pleasure in

Speaker: NA
Text: reading. Bradley writes:

Speaker: NA
Text: Merriden is a relatively large country town-

Speaker: NA
Text: population 4,300-which is located 260 kilometres

Speaker: NA
Text: East of Perth, halfway between Perth and Kalgoor-

Speaker: NA
Text: lie along the Great Eastern Highway. It is the

Speaker: NA
Text: centre of the wheatbelt region of Western Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: and is focused on the surrounding wheat and sheep

Speaker: NA
Text: farms which are very important industries to the

Speaker: NA
Text: The district was first settled in the early 1800's by

Speaker: NA
Text: sandalwood cutters and later some of the land was

Speaker: NA
Text: taken up by pastoralists who used it for grazing.

Speaker: NA
Text: The area grew and eventually became a large

Speaker: NA
Text: agricultural area, as the development of the railway

Speaker: NA
Text: and discovery of gold at Coolgardie brought more

Speaker: NA
Text: people.

Speaker: NA
Text: Today the town is very important as the main tov.:n

Speaker: NA
Text: in the shire, and many people travel to Merredm

Speaker: NA
Text: for shopping, school and medical needs.

Speaker: NA
Text: It has many. facilities such as an agricultural

Speaker: NA
Text: research station, its own newspaper and many

Speaker: NA
Text: sporting and cultural clubs.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the most noticeable features of Merredin is

Speaker: NA
Text: its beautiful trees and rose bushes, which adorn the

Speaker: NA
Text: town in a fairly hot climate.

Speaker: NA
Text: The education facilities of the town are very good,

Speaker: NA
Text: including three primary schools and the senior high

Speaker: NA
Text: school which I attend.

Speaker: NA
Text: The senior high school has 367 students which

Speaker: NA
Text: come from the surrounding region.

Speaker: NA
Text: This small school has both advantages and disad-

Speaker: NA
Text: vantages. The small population allows a friendlier

Speaker: NA
Text: atmosphere but there are also less facilities for

Speaker: NA
Text: study.

Speaker: NA
Text: Similarly, the town of Merredin is a friendly,

Speaker: NA
Text: peaceful place but is isolated from the city.

Speaker: NA
Text: A major concern for all people in the country areas

Speaker: NA
Text: is the declining population which means that shops

Speaker: NA
Text: and facilities are slowly disappearing. This process

Speaker: NA
Text: leads to diminishing employment in country areas.

Speaker: NA
Text: Roads and transport costs are also important

Speaker: NA
Text: because of the distances involved. However, the

Speaker: NA
Text: pioneering spirit which enabled people to overcome

Speaker: NA
Text: the hardships of isolation and distance and to create

Speaker: NA
Text: the town, will ensure the survival of the area.

Speaker: NA
Text: The rural people love the space, peace and friendli-

Speaker: NA
Text: ness of the district, compared to the rush, noise,

Speaker: NA
Text: overcrowding, crime and pollution of the cities.

Speaker: NA
Text: Regan Opalinski writes:

Speaker: NA
Text: My home, which is on a sheep, wheat and pig

Speaker: NA
Text: farm, is situated 72 kilometres south of Katanning.

Speaker: NA
Text: The town of Katanning is 320 kilometres south of

Speaker: NA
Text: Perth and 180 kilometres north of Albany and is

Speaker: NA
Text: located in the Great Southern Region of Western

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. It is an important regional centre with a

Speaker: NA
Text: shire population of 4,616 and covers an area of

Speaker: NA
Text: 1,524 square kilometres. The Great Southern

Speaker: NA
Text: Region's population represents 2.9 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: WA's population and 10.3 per cent of the rural

Speaker: NA
Text: population. Between the last two censuses, Katan-

Speaker: NA
Text: ning was one of the few shires to increase in

Speaker: NA
Text: population, gaining 6.2 per cent higher than the

Speaker: NA
Text: average ..

Speaker: NA
Text: Katanning has a large exporting abattoir, creating

Speaker: NA
Text: job opportunities for around 340 people, which

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits the district. Katanning has the largest

Speaker: NA
Text: saleyards in WA outside Perth. Katanning also has

Speaker: NA
Text: very large grain storage bins. Local crops are

Speaker: NA
Text: wheat, barley, lupins and oats; and wool, sheep,

Speaker: NA
Text: cattle and pigs are the main animal products.

Speaker: NA
Text: Katanning's climate consists of warm dry summers

Speaker: NA
Text: and cool wet winters and is ideally suited to crop

Speaker: NA
Text: and livestock farming.

Speaker: NA
Text: Katanning has a senior high school, which I attend,

Speaker: NA
Text: providing secondary education for 550 students

Speaker: NA
Text: from all over the region. The high school is very

Speaker: NA
Text: competitive and has a reputation for excellence

Speaker: NA
Text: both academically and in sport, where it is very

Speaker: NA
Text: well known for its athletic performance. It com-

Speaker: NA
Text: petes in many sporting events such as the high

Speaker: NA
Text: schools country week carnival in Perth, summer

Speaker: NA
Text: cup in Albany and numerous other athletics and

Speaker: NA
Text: swimming carnivals.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is a residential hostel, St Andrews College,

Speaker: NA
Text: located close to the school, catering for those who

Speaker: NA
Text: live in the outlying regions. Katanning boasts a

Speaker: NA
Text: good range of sporting facilities, including golf

Speaker: NA
Text: courses, lawn bowls, tennis, swimming pools and

Speaker: NA
Text: sporting ovals and soon an indoor recreation centre.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is a community built on solid foundations and is

Speaker: NA
Text: going ahead despite the difficult times in rural

Speaker: NA
Text: areas.

Speaker: NA
Text: I thank the Speaker and the officers concerned

Speaker: NA
Text: for making it possible for a group of young

Speaker: NA
Text: people to attend the Governor-General's

Speaker: NA
Text: Address-in-Reply, particularly the Serjeant-at-

Speaker: NA
Text: Arms for giving them a good look at the

Speaker: NA
Text: mace and telling them its history. It was

Speaker: NA
Text: extremely interesting.

Speaker: NA
Text: l{outh lIomelessness

Speaker: Mr RONALDSON
Text: Ballarat) (11.52

Speaker: NA
Text: p.m.)-Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. May

Speaker: NA
Text: I take this opportunity-the first I have had-

Speaker: NA
Text: to officially congratulate you on your eleva-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to that role. Tonight I wish to speak

Speaker: NA
Text: about an issue that affects all Australians-

Speaker: NA
Text: that of youth homelessness. Although this

Speaker: NA
Text: issue has received prominence only in recent

Speaker: NA
Text: years, the many organisations throughout

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia which have been dealing specifically

Speaker: NA
Text: with this national tragedy will attest to the

Speaker: NA
Text: fact that it is not a new one.

Speaker: NA
Text: As far as the wider Australian community

Speaker: NA
Text: is concerned, however, it was the publication

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Burdekin report in early 1989 that

Speaker: NA
Text: raised public awareness of the extent and

Speaker: NA
Text: seriousness of youth homelessness because of

Speaker: NA
Text: the extensive media attention it received. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Burdekin report gave estimates of youth

Speaker: NA
Text: sheep homelessness which sent a shudder through

Speaker: NA
Text: the community. It claimed that between

Speaker: NA
Text: 20,000 and 25,000 Australians under the age

Speaker: NA
Text: of 18 were homeless. What was even more

Speaker: NA
Text: shocking was the likely estimate that between

Speaker: NA
Text: 50,000 and 70,000 young people were either

Speaker: NA
Text: homeless or at serious risk. I suspect that for

Speaker: NA
Text: want of a better description these young

Speaker: NA
Text: people were tagged with the name 'street

Speaker: NA
Text: kids'. The push to address their plight has

Speaker: NA
Text: helped raise awareness of other youth related

Speaker: NA
Text: issues such as drug abuse and youth suicide.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are now a large number of organisa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions throughout the country that are specifi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cally targeting assistance to street kids, and

Speaker: NA
Text: fortunately this is becoming more and more

Speaker: NA
Text: hands-on. There has been criticism in the past

Speaker: NA
Text: that philosophical debates about the cause of

Speaker: NA
Text: the problem were taking precedence over

Speaker: NA
Text: direct hands-on contact with affected street

Speaker: NA
Text: kids. The great challenge for governments,

Speaker: NA
Text: both State and Federal, is to ensure that both

Speaker: NA
Text: aspects are adequately funded and appropriate

Speaker: NA
Text: priorities accorded. Following the tabling of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Burdekin report, an extra $100 million

Speaker: NA
Text: was allocated by the Commonwealth Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment over a four-year period specifically to

Speaker: NA
Text: tackle youth homelessness. However, there is

Speaker: NA
Text: still an enormous amount to be done, and

Speaker: NA
Text: appropriate responses need to be both devel-

Speaker: NA
Text: oped and refined.

Speaker: NA
Text: While the methodology used by the Burde-

Speaker: NA
Text: kin inquiry has been questioned in some

Speaker: NA
Text: quarters, it is my belief that it does the debate

Speaker: NA
Text: no good whatsoever to debate numbers alone.

Speaker: NA
Text: The debate should be centred on appropriate

Speaker: NA
Text: responses at the street level to address the

Speaker: NA
Text: root causes of youth homelessness. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: generally agreed that the primary causes of

Speaker: NA
Text: youth homelessness are family instability and

Speaker: NA
Text: breakdown, poverty and unemployment. The

Speaker: NA
Text: increase in youth homelessness can be di-

Speaker: NA
Text: rectly equated with the deteriorating position

Speaker: NA
Text: of those three root causes.

Speaker: NA
Text: The serious issues of family instability and

Speaker: NA
Text: breakdown, poverty and unemployment that

Speaker: NA
Text: affect the wider community can therefore be

Speaker: NA
Text: seen to be exacerbating the problems facing

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's youth. The need to address the

Speaker: NA
Text: immediate requirements of street kids such as

Speaker: NA
Text: crisis accommodation and long-term housing

Speaker: NA
Text: is obvious, and so too is the need to address

Speaker: NA
Text: the issues of job creation, income support and

Speaker: NA
Text: social support.

Speaker: NA
Text: While considerable financial and human

Speaker: NA
Text: resources have been allocated in an endeavour

Speaker: NA
Text: to address the youth homelessness tragedy, it

Speaker: NA
Text: is glaringly obvious that there has been no

Speaker: NA
Text: improvement. Indeed, workers in the field are

Speaker: NA
Text: adamant that the situation is deteriorating

Speaker: NA
Text: even further. On that basis, it is a matter of

Speaker: NA
Text: great urgency for the community to address

Speaker: NA
Text: the bigger picture agenda, which should

Speaker: NA
Text: include a review of the availability of educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to young people and also the availability

Speaker: NA
Text: of health services and employment opportuni-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties and training.

Speaker: NA
Text: Probably the saddest aspect of youth home-

Speaker: NA
Text: lessness is that in the vast majority of cases

Speaker: NA
Text: homeless young people are in that position

Speaker: NA
Text: through no fault of their own. On that basis

Speaker: NA
Text: the questions of family instability and break-

Speaker: NA
Text: down, poverty and unemployment must be

Speaker: NA
Text: addressed in the context of being the main

Speaker: NA
Text: causes of, or at the very least major contribu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tors to, youth homelessness.

Speaker: NA
Text: Federal Airports Corporation:

Speaker: NA
Text: Residential Land Acquisition

Speaker: Mr ALDRED
Text: Deakin) (11.55 p.m.)- Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Deputy Speaker, I would like to join my

Speaker: NA
Text: colleague in congratulating you on your

Speaker: NA
Text: elevation to the office of Deputy Speaker.

Speaker: NA
Text: In this adjournment debate I wish to draw

Speaker: NA
Text: the attention of the House to the plight of a

Speaker: NA
Text: Victorian citizen and resident of Barbiston

Speaker: NA
Text: Road, Keilor, Mr Jesse Boyse, otherwise

Speaker: NA
Text: known as 'Snowy' Boyse. To put this matter

Speaker: NA
Text: into context, Snowy Boyse, who is 73 years

Speaker: NA
Text: of age, owns one of the properties on

Speaker: NA
Text: Barbiston Road which the Federal Airports

Speaker: NA
Text: Corporation, the FAC, is attempting to ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: quire in order to extend the runways of

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne Airport.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Boyse, in a letter to my colleague the

Speaker: NA
Text: shadow Minister for tourism and aviation, the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Fadden ( Mr Jull),

Speaker: NA
Text: dated 26 February 1993, explained that some

Speaker: NA
Text: residents of Barbiston Road have, under

Speaker: NA
Text: pressure, accepted FAC offers dealing with

Speaker: NA
Text: residents outside the Lands Acquisition Act

Speaker: NA
Text: 1989, the LAA, by agreement under section

Speaker: NA
Text: 36 of the Federal Airports Corporation Act

Speaker: NA
Text: 1986, the FACA.

Speaker: NA
Text: Snowy maintains that by offering these

Speaker: NA
Text: terms the FAC is precluding residents from

Speaker: NA
Text: the rights and privileges to which landowners

Speaker: NA
Text: are entitled under the LAA, including an

Speaker: NA
Text: equivalent dwelling, stamp duty on the new

Speaker: NA
Text: property, exemption from capital gains tax,

Speaker: NA
Text: removal expenses, and access to all legal

Speaker: NA
Text: expenses in the event of differences of opin-

Speaker: NA
Text: ion regarding the transaction. Residents have

Speaker: NA
Text: been asked to get valuations on their proper-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties but Snowy protests that there are no

Speaker: NA
Text: potential buyers because it is a well-known

Speaker: NA
Text: fact that the land is 'condemned' and 'has no

Speaker: NA
Text: sale value'; therefore potential buyers are

Speaker: NA
Text: existent.

Speaker: NA
Text: Snowy, together with a neighbour, Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Graham Tamworth, wrote to the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Transport and Communications (Senator

Speaker: NA
Text: Collins) to organise a time for a petition from

Speaker: NA
Text: residents to be given to him in Canberra but,

Speaker: NA
Text: through the honourable member for Calwell

Speaker: NA
Text: (Dr Theophanous), I understand, were in-

Speaker: NA
Text: formed that the Minister refused.

Speaker: NA
Text: According to Snowy, the FAC has been on

Speaker: NA
Text: his property without permission making bore

Speaker: NA
Text: tests for runways and doing a geological

Speaker: NA
Text: survey; yet the FAC has informed him by

Speaker: NA
Text: letter that it doeS not need his property.

Speaker: NA
Text: Recently Snowy sent a letter to the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: making a claim for compensation under

Speaker: NA
Text: section 98 of the LAA. The Minister referred

Speaker: NA
Text: him to the FAC and informed him that he did

Speaker: NA
Text: not respond to his claim. Snowy maintains

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Minister should have issued a claim

Speaker: NA
Text: form as required under. the LAA. Instead the

Speaker: NA
Text: FAC has been negotiating settlements by

Speaker: NA
Text: agreement under section 36 of the FACA.

Speaker: NA
Text: All this becomes rather complicated, but

Speaker: NA
Text: basically Snowy maintains that the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: has not done his job under sections 97 and 98

Speaker: NA
Text: of the LAA and he has refused to negotiate

Speaker: NA
Text: with the FAC. It appears that Snowy has right

Speaker: NA
Text: on his side. He has been pushed from pillar

Speaker: NA
Text: to post and has recently been informed by the

Speaker: NA
Text: FAC that unless he is prepared to negotiate

Speaker: NA
Text: with it under its terms and conditions it will

Speaker: NA
Text: let him wait there for up to 15 years before it

Speaker: NA
Text: finally uses the LAA to forcibly take his

Speaker: NA
Text: home and lane'. By that time Snowy will be

Speaker: NA
Text: 88 years old. Is it any wonder that Snowy

Speaker: NA
Text: regards the FAC as absolutely unscrupulous?

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: described as 'a public authority with a private

Speaker: NA
Text: enterprise philosophy'-in 1991-92 made a

Speaker: NA
Text: profit of $142 million which, after the pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of interest, et cetera, became a net profit

Speaker: NA
Text: of $35 million. Snowy Boyse describes that

Speaker: NA
Text: organisation as 'private individuals who have

Speaker: NA
Text: been given the jurisdiction over my proper-

Speaker: NA
Text: ty-for profit motives'. He goes on to give an

Speaker: NA
Text: account of the FAC's dealings with a Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Robert Shaw of Rosebank farm, Barbiston

Speaker: NA
Text: Road, Keilor, which are, to say the least, very

Speaker: NA
Text: suspect but tOb.lengthy to deal with here. Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: nonBoyse concludes his letter by saying that all

Speaker: NA
Text: residents should be dealt with on a 'level

Speaker: NA
Text: playing field' as laid down under the LAA.

Speaker: NA
Text: As the events of 13 March ensued, the

Speaker: NA
Text: shadow Minister was unable to come to

Speaker: NA
Text: Snowy's aid as he had hoped. I therefore wish

Speaker: NA
Text: to draw this matter to the attention of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House and the Minister involved in the hope

Speaker: NA
Text: that Snowy will now receive fairer treatment

Speaker: NA
Text: than he has so far from the FAC.It would

Speaker: NA
Text: appear that on this matter ministerial interven-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion is most definitely required.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question resolved in the affirmative.

Speaker: NA
Text: House adjourned at 11.59 p.m.

Speaker: NA
Text: NOTICES

Speaker: NA
Text: The following notices were given:

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Filing to move-

Speaker: NA
Text: That this House

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) notes the visit of Mr Vo Van Kiet, Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister of the Socialist Republic of Viet-

Speaker: NA
Text: nam to Australia, and deplores his

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's record of substantial human

Speaker: NA
Text: rights abuses; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) calls on the Government to:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) immediately and unconditionally release

Speaker: NA
Text: all political prisoners and prisoners of

Speaker: NA
Text: conscience, including the Venerable Thich

Speaker: NA
Text: Huyen Quang;

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) introduce basic human rights to Vietnam,

Speaker: NA
Text: including freedom of assembly, religious

Speaker: NA
Text: worship and speech, a free press and free

Speaker: NA
Text: and open elections;

Speaker: NA
Text: (c) provide for the creation of a pluralist free

Speaker: NA
Text: enterprise economy; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (d) demonstrate to the Parliament of Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: how and where aid monies provided to

Speaker: NA
Text: Vietnam by Australia are spent and how

Speaker: NA
Text: that aid encourages the cultivation of a

Speaker: NA
Text: more democratic and free society in Viet-

Speaker: NA
Text: nam.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Filing to move-

Speaker: NA
Text: That this House:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) deplores the Prime Minister's constant

Speaker: NA
Text: rewriting of Australian·history to suit his

Speaker: NA
Text: own political purposes;

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) particularly deplores the Prime Minister's

Speaker: NA
Text: denigration of the Menzies years,' a period

Speaker: NA
Text: of growth, employment and stability where

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia developed a strong national identiPublic

Speaker: NA
Text: ty that reflected its role as a positive and

Speaker: NA
Text: beneficial influence in its region; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) contrasts the Prime Minister's own legacy

Speaker: NA
Text: The following answers to questions were circulated:

Speaker: NA
Text: Social Security Compliance: Project

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No.3)

Speaker: Mr CONNOLLY
Text: the Minister for Social

Speaker: NA
Text: Security, upon notice, on 5 May 1993:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Did his predecessor infonn the House on 10

Speaker: NA
Text: September 1992 that his Department, in conjunction

Speaker: NA
Text: with the Australian National University, had

Speaker: NA
Text: engaged Professor Dick Weatherley of theUniver-

Speaker: NA
Text: sity of Washington to conduct a research project

Speaker: NA
Text: into social security compliance in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) Was the project conducted; if so, (a) what

Speaker: NA
Text: was examined, (b) what sum did his Department

Speaker: NA
Text: pay Professor Weatherley, (c) for how long was the

Speaker: NA
Text: Professor engaged by the Department and (d) did

Speaker: NA
Text: the Professor present a report on the project and

Speaker: NA
Text: will he make the report available. .

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Baldwin-The answer to the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) The fonner Minister for Social Security, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Hon. Neal Blewett MP, did infonn the House on

Speaker: NA
Text: 10 September 1992 about a research project being

Speaker: NA
Text: conducted by Professor R. A. Weatherley. The

Speaker: NA
Text: project was carried out under the Administration,

Speaker: NA
Text: Compliance and Govemability Program of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Research School of Social Services at the Austral-

Speaker: NA
Text: ian National University. The Department of Social

Speaker: NA
Text: Security provided a grant to the Australian National

Speaker: NA
Text: University to assist with the project.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) (a) The project has been completed. Professor

Speaker: NA
Text: Weathedey's research into factors contributing to

Speaker: NA
Text: compliance and non-compliance with Social

Speaker: NA
Text: Security rules and procedures was based on exten-

Speaker: NA
Text: sive field work, review of the documentary records

Speaker: NA
Text: and comparative examination of compliance in the

Speaker: NA
Text: United States, Denmark, Sweden and Finland.

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) The Department agreed to provide a grant of

Speaker: NA
Text: $167,000 towards the project. To date $150,000 of

Speaker: NA
Text: this has been paid.

Speaker: NA
Text: (c) Professor WeatherIey conducted his research

Speaker: NA
Text: from July 1990 to November 1992.

Speaker: NA
Text: (d) ·Professor Weatherley provided his report

Speaker: NA
Text: entitled 'Compliance Policies In Social Security'

Speaker: NA
Text: in February 1993. A copy of the report will be

Speaker: NA
Text: made available to the Member for Bradfield.
