Speaker: NA
Text: Shipping: Nuclear Armed or Nuclear

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 38)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Langmore asked the Minister repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: senting the Minister for Defence, upon notice,

Speaker: NA
Text: on 5 May 1993:

Speaker: NA
Text: What visits have been made by nuclear armed

Speaker: NA
Text: and/or nuclear powered vessels to Jervis Bay since

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Text: The Minister for Defence has

Speaker: NA
Text: provided the following answer to the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member's question:

Speaker: NA
Text: There has been only one visit by a nuclear

Speaker: NA
Text: powered vessel to Jervis Bay since 1983. The

Speaker: NA
Text: submarine USS Sea Dragon anchored for 36 hours

Speaker: NA
Text: during the period 12-14 February 1983.

Speaker: NA
Text: Additional Family Payment

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 47)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Filing asked the Minister for Social

Speaker: NA
Text: Security, upon notice, on 5 May 1993:

Speaker: NA
Text: Can a family with one child, (a) renting a house,

Speaker: NA
Text: earn up to $28 007 and (b) paying off a mortgage

Speaker: NA
Text: earn up to $24 169 before their Family Allowance

Speaker: NA
Text: Supplement ceases; if so, (i) why is there a

Speaker: NA
Text: ence and (ii) what steps will be taken to restore a

Speaker: NA
Text: balance.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Baldwin-The answer to the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) A family with one child under 13 years,

Speaker: NA
Text: renting a house, can earn up to $28 007 including

Speaker: NA
Text: rent assistance; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) A family with one child under 13 years, not

Speaker: NA
Text: renting privately, can earn up to $24 169 per year,

Speaker: NA
Text: before their Family Allowance Supplement (now

Speaker: NA
Text: Additional Family Payment) ceases.

Speaker: NA
Text: (i) There is a difference between the amount a

Speaker: NA
Text: private renter and the amount a homeowner can

Speaker: NA
Text: earn before their Additional Family Payment ceases

Speaker: NA
Text: as the amount earned by the renting family includes

Speaker: NA
Text: rent assistance. Rent assistance is paid to private

Speaker: NA
Text: renters in recognition of the costs involved in

Speaker: NA
Text: renting accommodation in the private rental market.

Speaker: NA
Text: Homeowners receive other benefits from the

Speaker: NA
Text: and taxation system; such as exemption from capital

Speaker: NA
Text: gains tax on the family home under certain condi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions and the exemption of the family home from

Speaker: NA
Text: Department of Social Security (DSS) assets testing

Speaker: NA
Text: rules.

Speaker: NA
Text: Low income home buyers may also receive

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance through home ownership programs

Speaker: NA
Text: operated by State Housing Authorities.

Speaker: NA
Text: (ii) There will be no change to the amounts

Speaker: NA
Text: earned by homebuyers or renters before Additional

Speaker: NA
Text: Powered Family Payment ceases, for the reasons outlined in

Speaker: NA
Text: (i) above.

Speaker: NA
Text: Republic

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 72)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Lieberman asked the Prime Minister,

Speaker: NA
Text: upon notice, on 10 May 1993:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) What will be the cost to the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: of the committee which is working on the republi-

Speaker: NA
Text: can issue.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) What costs will be incurred by the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth with respect to all other aspects of the

Speaker: NA
Text: republican issue over the period to (a) May 1994,

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) May 1995 and (c) May 1996.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) What was the cost to the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: since May 1990 of any measures taken with respect

Speaker: NA
Text: to the republican issue and what are the details of

Speaker: NA
Text: the expenditure.

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Text: The answer to the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) The cost of the Republic Advisory Commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: tee, including secretariat services, is expected to be

Speaker: NA
Text: of the order of $280,000.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) It is not possible to make accurate predictions

Speaker: NA
Text: differof the kind sought by the honourable member.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) My department has prepared advice on

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangements for setting up the Republic Advisory

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee and associated matters. Preparation of

Speaker: NA
Text: advice of this kind is not separately costed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Republic

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 84)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Slipper asked the Prime Minister, upon

Speaker: NA
Text: notice, on 11 May 1993:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Has he expressed both a preference for a

Speaker: NA
Text: minimalist position on republican change whereby

Speaker: NA
Text: a president would replace the Governor-General

Speaker: NA
Text: with existing vice-regal powers intact and opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to the reserve powers of the Governor-General;

Speaker: NA
Text: if so, how does he reconcile the two positions.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) Would the political disintegration of Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: follow if a referendum did not eStablish a majority

Speaker: NA
Text: in favour of republican change in all States.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) How could he deal with problems arising

Speaker: NA
Text: from State constitutional monarchies co-existing in

Speaker: NA
Text: a federation with republican States under a republi-

Speaker: NA
Text: can national structure.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) Will a referendum be conducted on Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: becoming a republic; if so, would he seek to

Speaker: NA
Text: override referendum results in States which chose

Speaker: NA
Text: to remain constitutional monarchies and what

Speaker: NA
Text: would be the effect on Australian democracy.

Speaker: NA
Text: (5) What authority does he propose the president

Speaker: NA
Text: would have over the presidents, governors or heads

Speaker: NA
Text: of state of the States.

Speaker: NA
Text: (6) Would the presidents, governors or heads of

Speaker: NA
Text: state of the States act as the national president's

Speaker: NA
Text: deputies in accordance with the latter's directions.

Speaker: NA
Text: (7) Would the national president's directions be

Speaker: NA
Text: framed by the Prime Minister; if so, what would be

Speaker: NA
Text: the effect on the federal system.

Speaker: NA
Text: (8) Does he propose to restrain the powers of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate; if so, how.

Speaker: NA
Text: (9) Does he intend to make the Senate more

Speaker: NA
Text: representative; if so, how.

Speaker: NA
Text: (to) Does he intend to abolish the States and

Speaker: NA
Text: replace them with regions.

Speaker: NA
Text: (11) How would he ensure the stability of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian political institutions and citizens'

Speaker: NA
Text: freedoms under a republic.

Speaker: NA
Text: (12) Does he propose to change the external

Speaker: NA
Text: affairs power in the Constitution to enable the

Speaker: NA
Text: States to exercise their responsibilities fully; if so,

Speaker: NA
Text: how.

Speaker: NA
Text: (13) Does he propose that Aboriginals be in-

Speaker: NA
Text: volved in altering the Constitution to promote

Speaker: NA
Text: reconciliation; if so, how.

Speaker: NA
Text: (14) Does he intend to change the Constitution

Speaker: NA
Text: to enable one person to hold simultaneously the

Speaker: NA
Text: positions of president and Prime Minister.

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Text: The answer to the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1)-(14) The honourable member's question

Speaker: NA
Text: appears to be based on a presumption that I have

Speaker: NA
Text: an agenda for change far wider than the one I have

Speaker: NA
Text: stated publicly. That is not so.

Speaker: NA
Text: Republic

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 128)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Slipper asked the Prime Minister, upon

Speaker: NA
Text: notice, on 13 May 1993:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Would any economic benefits flow to

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's one million jobless from the successful

Speaker: NA
Text: implementation of Australia as a republic; if so,

Speaker: NA
Text: what are they.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) How many jobs would be created by the

Speaker: NA
Text: declaration of a republic.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) How would Australia's foreign debt be

Speaker: NA
Text: reduced by the declaration of a republic.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) What prospect of employment would the

Speaker: NA
Text: declaration of a republic give to the long term

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployed.

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Text: The answer to the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1)-(4) I assume the honourable member would

Speaker: NA
Text: not be foolish enough to claim that retainirig the

Speaker: NA
Text: British monarch as Australia's head of state would

Speaker: NA
